Person Re-identification (ReID), the retrieval of the same person across multiple cameras, has garnered significant attention from both academia and industry [19, 30, 33, 35, 42, 43]. While Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) have greatly improved ReID accuracy, their black-box nature limits trust, especially in critical applications [44].  This paper addresses the crucial yet under-explored area of interpreting CNN-based person ReID models.

A typical CNN-based ReID system maps query and gallery images into a metric space, calculating pairwise distances to generate a ranked list of gallery images, as illustrated in Figure 1(a).  While existing methods like Ranking Activation Maps [37] can visualize related regions between individuals, they lack semantic explanations of similarity or dissimilarity.  Attributes, such as clothing color and type, offer human-understandable semantics and have been used as mid-level ReID features [18].  However, no existing method leverages attributes to explain ReID results.  This paper aims to develop an attribute-guided interpreter to answer two key questions: 1) which attributes differentiate two individuals, and 2) how much each attribute contributes to this difference, as visualized in Figure 1(b).  Such an interpreter can help users focus on key discrepancies and aid developers in improving ReID accuracy, as shown in Figure 1(c).

Interpreting ReID models with attributes presents unique challenges.  The distance-based output of ReID models complicates the use of class activation or gradients for visualization and semantic disentanglement, unlike classification tasks [24, 47].  The diverse and imbalanced nature of real-world attributes [7, 15, 18] can introduce biases, with prominent attributes like coats potentially overshadowing smaller yet discriminative attributes like hats.  Furthermore, the availability of only weakly-annotated image-level or ID-level attribute labels, without precise bounding boxes or masks [18], hinders accurate attribute localization and visualization.

To address these challenges, we propose Attribute-guided Metric Distillation, a post-hoc method for explainable person ReID.  We introduce a pluggable interpreter network that leverages knowledge from a target ReID model via metric distillation.  This interpreter, grafted onto the target model, inherits the initial CNN stages to utilize low-level and mid-level features.  The remaining layers incorporate an attribute decomposition head, enabling the generation of attribute-guided attention maps (AAMs) for input image pairs.  These AAMs visualize discriminative attributes and decompose visual features and distances into attribute-guided components, quantifying each attribute's contribution to the overall distance.

Depuis les années 1980, les pays du Maghreb subissent des invasions périodiques de criquets pèlerins, un phénomène inédit auparavant.  Si cela évoque les dix plaies d'Égypte, ces invasions ne sont en rien une malédiction : les criquets sont comestibles et appréciés des volailles.

Autrefois, en Algérie par exemple, les criquets pèlerins arrivaient en été.  Attirés la nuit par les lampadaires, ils s'y brûlaient les ailes ou se jetaient dans les feux nocturnes.  Au petit matin, les poulets se régalaient de ces insectes grillés.

Or, les nouvelles générations de criquets semblent moins sensibles à la lumière et au feu, témoignant peut-être d'une mutation ou d'une manipulation génétique en laboratoire occidental.

L'Algérie a notamment été envahie par des nuées de sauterelles porteuses de puces RFID pour le téléguidage, placées sur l'abdomen, près de la tête et sur les pattes. Certaines arboraient des étiquettes numérotées à 9 ou 13 chiffres, semblables à des codes-barres.  Si certains laboratoires occidentaux ont reconnu marquer des insectes pour étudier leurs déplacements,  le nombre d'individus marqués (près de 20 % de la population de criquets) interroge.  En 1991,  sous le gouvernement des généraux Nezzar et Toufik, pendant la période des massacres imputés aux GIA (Groupes Islamiques Armés),  le gouvernement algérien a combattu ces sauterelles avec des insecticides présentés comme inoffensifs pour la population.  Or, ces pulvérisations, qui ont duré des mois, ont rendu les criquets impropres à la consommation,  condamnant les élevages de volailles.  Une opération similaire s'est déroulée simultanément en Californie, suggérant une possible orchestration conjointe de la France, des États-Unis, d'Israël (via le Mossad), du Maroc et de généraux algériens.

Contrôler un essaim de criquets pèlerins est relativement simple : il suffit d'équiper quelques individus meneurs pour que la colonie, grégaire par nature, les suive.  Dès 2006, l'Agence américaine des programmes de recherches avancée de défense (DARPA) explore le contrôle électronique d'insectes.  Fin 2012, en collaboration avec l'université de Caroline du Nord, elle a présenté un cafard de Madagascar "piloté" par impulsions électroniques.

La chute de Kadhafi a eu des conséquences inattendues, au-delà de la prolifération des armes. L'afflux massif de criquets pèlerins dans les pays du Sahel en est une.  Dans un communiqué du 5 juin, la FAO (Organisation des Nations unies pour l'alimentation et l'agriculture) tire la sonnette d'alarme. Malgré les efforts de l'Algérie et de la Libye depuis mi-mai (des infestations acridiennes y ont été signalées en janvier), les criquets progressent vers le Mali et le Niger, menaçant les cultures.  Comme l'expliquait "Jeune Afrique" le 10 juin, le régime de Kadhafi possédait un système anti-acridien performant. La révolution l'a démantelé et la lutte contre les criquets n'est pas une priorité pour les nouvelles autorités.

La Commission de lutte contre le criquet pèlerin dans la région occidentale (CLCPRO, un comité interrégional de la FAO créé en 2002 regroupant 11 pays du Maghreb et du Sahel) redouble d'efforts.  Fin mai, des essaims ont été signalés au Niger (régions d'Arlit et d'Agadez).  Des équipes ont été déployées pour enrayer la reproduction des insectes, favorisée par des pluies précoces. 700 hectares ont été traités, mais les essaims se dirigent vers le sud,  mettant en péril 500 000 hectares de cultures.

[Photo d'un criquet pèlerin en Mauritanie en 2004, publiée sur Flickr par la Sopfcim (Société de protection des forêts contre les insectes et maladies).]

Ces efforts resteront vains si le Mali, membre de la CLCPRO, n'agit pas.  Or, la présence de groupes armés au nord du Mali, zone de reproduction des criquets, empêche l'accès des autorités et de la FAO.

La dernière invasion, entre 2003 et 2005, conjuguée à une sécheresse sévère, avait provoqué une famine dramatique au Niger en 2005, touchant 3 millions de personnes, dont 800 000 enfants.  Déjà confronté à une crise alimentaire (mauvaises récoltes de 2011), le Niger risque de subir des conséquences catastrophiques.

The increasing availability of electronic healthcare records, containing both patient state and clinician actions, has opened opportunities to use machine learning to model clinical decision-making policies. Consequently, off-policy reinforcement learning (RL) for optimal sequential clinical decisions has become a leading approach for AI-based interventions (Komorowski, 2018; Gottesman et al., 2019).  RL generally demonstrates promising performance, with the potential to surpass human experts when tested on retrospective or simulated data (Ernst et al., 2006; Bothe et al., 2013; Lowery & Faisal, 2013; Li et al., 2020; Liu et al., 2020).  Initial RL-derived systems, autonomously intervening on patients, have been successfully deployed in controlled rehabilitation settings (Wannawas et al., 2021). However, hospital-based RL-driven interventions at the bedside carry greater risks due to patient health status and the potential negative impact of interventions. Therefore, there is a growing need to prioritize the development of inherently risk- and safety-aware RL systems for healthcare. This requires RL algorithms to account for noise and uncertainty in their operation and to make these critical performance factors interrogatable, allowing developers, regulators, and users to specify safety and trust margins.

Sepsis treatment in critical care is one area where RL has shown significant potential.  Sepsis is responsible for nearly a third of patient deaths (Stevenson et al., 2014), yet optimal decision-making policies remain unclear. RL methods applied to retrospective data have yielded promising results, potentially identifying individualized and clinically effective treatment decisions that could significantly reduce mortality (Komorowski, 2018). In this context, the RL agent's actions (sometimes referred to as the "AI Clinician") are communicated as recommendations (through a clinical decision support system, or CDSS) to a human expert, such as a critical care clinician, who can then choose to implement or disregard them. This intensive care application has rapidly become a popular use case for RL in healthcare, partly due to the public availability of high-density, high-quality datasets and the immediate utility of RL compared to supervised learning. Consequently, clinical trials of RL systems are expanding, but limitations in interpretability, safety, and trust must be addressed before widespread deployment can be considered.

Two primary sources of uncertainty limit the capability of an RL agent's optimal policy. First, noise or randomness inherent in the dynamics of both the patient's condition and the agent's actions introduces uncertainty. This aleatoric uncertainty (from the Latin *alea* for "dice") can be measured by repeating the same action and observing trial-to-trial variability (Faisal et al., 2008). It captures the inherent randomness in the system, including physiological processes, treatment effects, and healing outcomes—factors the agent can mitigate but not directly control.  In healthcare, many interventions have probabilistic outcomes, and it's crucial for stakeholders to understand whether a proposed outcome's success is influenced by chance.

Second, epistemic uncertainty (from the Greek *episteme* for "knowledge") reflects how well the model has learned from finite data and how well it can fit the problem.  In healthcare, this could indicate limited data for specific state-space regions or state transitions, such as encountering a new disease or prescribing a drug infrequently used for a particular patient type. Epistemic uncertainty is crucial for recommender system safety, allowing stakeholders to weigh AI recommendations against human judgment or seek expert opinions.

Conventional RL models typically do not provide access to these two types of uncertainty.  Even advanced probabilistic RL models, such as Bayesian RL (Ghavamzadeh et al., 2016) and distributional reinforcement learning (Bellemare et al., 2017), often confound or conflate them.  However, decomposing these components would significantly benefit the interpretation of RL agent treatment recommendations. For example, high aleatoric but low epistemic uncertainty in a given state would suggest inherent stochasticity, warranting heightened clinician attention. Conversely, high epistemic uncertainty would indicate insufficient data or model convergence, signaling that the model's output should be treated with caution.

Venus: A Worthy Pursuit Despite the Dangers

Venus, often called the "Evening Star," is one of the brightest points of light in the night sky, easily spotted by even amateur stargazers.  This striking celestial body, frequently referred to as Earth's twin due to its similar size and density, and occasionally its proximity, deserves our attention and further exploration. While undertaking such a mission presents undeniable risks, the potential rewards of understanding our closest planetary neighbor are immense.

The question arises: why invest our time and resources in exploring Venus?  The answer lies in the tantalizing possibilities it holds.  Venus possesses features analogous to Earth, including a rocky surface with valleys, mountains, and craters. This similarity sparks curiosity about the planet's composition and history, including the potential for shared geological materials between Earth and Venus.  Furthermore, the very presence of these familiar features raises intriguing questions about the potential for other, yet undiscovered, similarities.

Before sending humans, however, a preliminary robotic mission is crucial.  A demo rover could assess unforeseen hazards and gather further data on the planet's surface and atmosphere.  This information would be invaluable in preparing a safe and effective human mission.

While Venus presents seemingly survivable conditions for humans in its upper atmosphere, with plentiful solar power and manageable radiation levels according to some studies, significant challenges remain.  The planet's incredibly dense atmosphere, composed almost entirely of carbon dioxide, and its extreme temperatures, hot enough to liquefy metal and crush deep-sea submarines, pose considerable obstacles.  These dangers necessitate careful planning and technological innovation to ensure the safety of any human explorers.

Despite these challenges, the potential benefits of a Venus mission are compelling.  Further study could unveil new information about planetary formation, the evolution of atmospheres, and perhaps even the potential for life beyond Earth.  The author's argument for Venus exploration as a "worthy pursuit despite the dangers" is supported by the planet's unique characteristics, the possibility of scientific breakthroughs, and the inherent human drive to explore and understand the universe around us.  By taking measured steps, beginning with robotic exploration and culminating in carefully planned human missions, the United States, through collaborative scientific efforts, could achieve a significant victory in space exploration and expand our understanding of our place in the cosmos.

## 《天能》影评：超越理解，感受时间流动

克里斯多夫·诺兰执导的《天能》（Tenet），在经历多次定档波折后终于上映，这部万众期待的大师级作品，以超越时空的哲理、颠覆传统的叙事、以及震撼的场面，为观众交织出一幕幕扣人心弦的篇章。本篇影评无雷，请放心阅读。

诺兰导演过去20年不断以颠覆性的作品刷新观众的想象，积累了无数“信徒”。他的叙事手法和概念令人深深着迷，即使脉络看似扑朔迷离，却引人反复咀嚼，回味无穷，这正是诺兰电影的最大魅力所在。

从《记忆拼图》对记忆的依赖与负罪感的诠释，到《黑暗骑士》系列对人性底层执迷的挖掘；从《全面启动》对梦境、现实和潜意识的刻画，到《星际效应》透过虫洞和太空旅程揭示的亲情；再到《敦克尔克大行动》对抗战精神的深化，诺兰的作品始终充满着极致的追求，令人赞叹。

而《天能》再次突破感官极限，以毫无冷场的节奏和完美的剧本架构，交织出无与伦比的感动，以及对自我坚持和信念的探讨。

**别尝试理解，去感受它**

诺兰对极致的追求，或许让部分观众难以完全理解电影的脉络。然而，这部电影的重点并非要求观众理解，而是透过观影体验，去感受那段时间、感悟那段光阴下的独特真义。诺兰再次掀起电影圈新浪潮，引发观众的反思和思辨。

电影讲述主角仅凭一个词“天能”，为全人类的存亡而战。他进入晦暗的国际谍报世界，执行一项超越现实时间限制的重大任务。影片由约翰·大卫·华盛顿、罗伯特·帕丁森、伊丽莎白·德比齐和肯尼斯·布莱纳主演。

**时间：仿佛有了生命力**

诺兰表示，《天能》以全新的方式诠释间谍片和动作片，他不仅希望以崭新的方式描述时间，更期待带给观众精彩刺激的元素。如同十年前以劫盗电影手法拍摄《全面启动》，这次则以间谍电影手法来拍摄《天能》。

《天能》最引人入胜之处，在于它赋予了“时间”这个抽象概念全新的生命力。时间是什么？它代表着成长和老化，但它能否被翻转和颠覆？电影中完备的科学架构和哲理思维，似乎让一切成为可能。时间如同记忆的钥匙，在回忆中寻找内心深处的密码，赋予思绪深沉的渲染力。

**颠覆传统的极致想象**

从《全面启动》的虚实交错，到《星际效应》的空间概念，再融合《记忆拼图》的记忆时间观，《天能》集诺兰作品之大成，以丰富的资讯量和一句句引人深思的台词，带来一场视听盛宴。

诺兰擅长以情感丰富的电影带来震撼，启发思考，突破传统思维。

Il y a quelques mois, la chancelière Angela Merkel était critiquée pour sa politique migratoire et jugée en fin de parcours politique.  Or, sa gestion de la crise sanitaire et sa préparation à la pandémie ont été saluées.  Sa popularité a atteint des sommets et son parti, la CDU/CSU, a gagné 10 points en deux mois dans les sondages, atteignant 38 % d’intentions de vote.

Depuis plusieurs jours, la chancelière dénonce l’impatience croissante de la population face aux mesures de restriction imposées depuis un mois et demi et à leurs conséquences économiques.  Cette stratégie de fermeté est de plus en plus contestée en Allemagne, malgré la réouverture de certains magasins dès le 20 avril.

Les stratégies et les rythmes de déconfinement divergent entre la France et l’Allemagne, tout comme les réactions et les critiques politiques.  Si Emmanuel Macron a incité le gouvernement à préparer un plan de déconfinement, Angela Merkel préconise une approche très progressive, rappelant que l’Allemagne et l’Europe ne sont encore « qu’au début de l’épidémie ».

Le climat politique évolue et la contestation s’amplifie, y compris au sein de son propre parti, la CDU.  Wolfgang Schäuble, président de la Chambre des députés et ancien ministre des Finances, personnalité influente en Allemagne et dans les milieux économiques, a mis en garde contre des restrictions prolongées des libertés fondamentales. « Quand j’entends que toute autre considération doit être subordonnée à la protection de la vie humaine, je considère que cet absolutisme n’est pas justifié », a-t-il déclaré ce week-end au quotidien *Tagesspiegel*.

Armin Laschet, président de la puissante région de Rhénanie-du-Nord-Westphalie et candidat à la succession d’Angela Merkel, s’oppose également à la chancelière depuis plusieurs jours, plaidant pour un déconfinement accéléré. « Bien sûr, il est question de vie ou de mort », a-t-il concédé dimanche soir sur la chaîne ARD, mais il faut également « prendre en compte » les conséquences du confinement, notamment pour les enfants « qui restent confinés chez eux depuis six semaines ».  Il a critiqué les pronostics des virologues – auxquels la chancelière, de formation scientifique, accorde une grande importance –, les jugeant trop pessimistes, et a souligné que dans sa région, « 40 % des lits de soins intensifs sont libres ».

Lundi, le quotidien *Bild*, le plus lu d’Allemagne, a relayé ces critiques et appelé la chancelière, dans un éditorial, à « mettre fin à son entêtement ».  L’opposition, jusque-là discrète, se fait plus critique. Christian Lindner, président du FDP, a décrété « la fin de la grande unité nationale » face au coronavirus.  Son parti s’inquiète des répercussions économiques sur les PME et dénonce les restrictions des libertés individuelles.

The two men, Jonathon Radcliffe and Valentine Spencer, stood in the middle of nowhere, a dusty road winding back towards the city.  A midday breeze whipped sand around them. There was no trace of any vehicle that might have brought them to this desolate spot.  Radcliffe, clad in a tough leather coat and high boots, cut a stark contrast to Spencer, whose attire consisted of sharply lined slim trousers and a finely tailored silk shirt, conspicuously lacking sleeves.  Despite their differing tastes, they were firm friends, the kind who often saved each other's lives – one rarely seen without the other.

"Why did you have to announce it?" Radcliffe questioned, his gaze fixed on Spencer. "Why didn't you just do it?"

Spencer, the smaller of the two, pushed his spectacles back up his nose with a delicate forefinger. "Because this way we're living life."

"As opposed to...?"

"I don't know. Being boring. The point is, Jon, it has been announced, and we are obligated."

"Obligations have placed us in danger quite a bit lately, Val," Radcliffe countered, his eyes scanning the road where occasional horse-drawn carriages and steam-carriages interrupted the monotony.

"Obligations are usually best avoided, I agree. But this time it's important. Trust me."

They had set their meeting spot; now they waited. Their contacts were due to arrive, though the wait promised to be lengthy. A half-hour passed before the first group of police appeared.  Their wagons pulled up at the side of the road, the officers immediately falling into a nervous discussion, clutching fliers in their hands.

"In a moment," Radcliffe murmured to Spencer, "they are going to walk up here and arrest us. Care to let me in on the plan?"

"It's really simple. They can't arrest us yet because we haven't done anything illegal."

"But we were planning on it."

"I know. That's why I put it on the poster," Spencer replied, a hint of mischief in his voice.

"The same posters that you put up all over town?"  Radcliffe’s incredulity was evident.

Spencer shrugged. "We had to let Leem know where to meet us somehow."

"Carrier pigeon would have been a lot less.... loud," Radcliffe grumbled.

"Ostentatious," Spencer corrected.

"That word is ostentatious…"

Their exchange was interrupted by a policewoman.  Jumping down from a wagon, she approached, identification held high in one hand, a rolled-up parchment gripped tightly in the other.  An uneasy smile played on her lips.

"Spencer and Radcliffe, I presume? The notorious sky pirates?"

"That's us," Spencer responded, tipping his hat. "Rather warm out here today isn't it, officer?"

"Is that why you cut the arms off your shirt?" she asked, suspicion lacing her tone.

"I lost them in a bet last night," Spencer explained smoothly. "Drunkards gamble for the strangest things, you know. Anyway, I presume you're here to arrest us?"

"I am."

"You can't," Radcliffe interjected. "We haven't done anything illegal yet."

The policewoman unfurled the parchment. Spencer grinned, indicating Radcliffe’s identical copy. "We have our own. Although I do appreciate you bringing it along.”

With a sigh, the policewoman began to read aloud, her voice clipped and official:  "I, Valentine Spencer, hereby arrange to meet with Leem and his gang on the Main Road at High Noon precisely eight miles outside of town. I will bring my business associate Jonathon Radcliffe and we will engage in illegal activities. I trust our reputation precedes us. Sincerely, Valentine Spencer and Jonathon Radcliffe. PS; That's Spencer and Radcliffe, the two sky pirates who have bounties on their heads in twelve counties. Captains of the Starchaser."

She looked up, her confusion evident. Spencer simply nodded.

"That's what I wrote. What questions do you have, Mira?"

"You know my name?"

"Of course. You've been chasing us for some time. Dockman warned us when we landed that you'd probably come gunning for us. I thought we would give you a fair chance."

Increasingly bewildered, Mira glanced at Radcliffe, who shrugged.  "Don't look at me. I'm as in the dark as you are."

"Mira," Spencer addressed the policewoman, "can I make a suggestion? As you can't arrest us until you see us do something illegal, I suggest you take a seat on your wagon over there or you are going to get awful tired. Either that or stay with us and we can play some games?"

"What kind of games?"

"The kind where I can win a pair of sleeves."

Thunder crossed Mira's face, quickly followed by a furious retreat to her wagon, barking orders at the other officers.  Radcliffe turned to Spencer, his voice low. "I don't appreciate being kept out of the loop on this one, Val. Just a warning will be good."

"Admit it, you're enjoying this. The adrenaline rush has got to be worth it," Spencer retorted with a grin.

"Yea, I am," Radcliffe conceded. "But if we end up in prison—"

"—again—" Spencer finished.

"—then I reserve the right to be angry at you."

"Right reserved, friend. Now just hush up, there's an entire wagon of police there waiting for us to say something incriminating."

Semantic textual similarity (STS) and information retrieval (IR) tasks have been principal measures for tracking the progress of dense representation models (Agirre et al., 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016; Cer et al., 2017; Thakur et al., 2021).  While STS remains a common evaluation metric in sentence representation research, it is known for its limited real-world applicability (Neelakantan et al., 2022; Muennighoff et al., 2023b), inherent ambiguity (Deshpande et al., 2023), and performance orthogonality with IR and other downstream tasks (Reimers et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2021; Xiao et al., 2023a).

In the era of large language models (LLMs), Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) (Lewis et al., 2020; Neelakantan et al., 2022; Xu et al., 2023; Gao et al., 2023) has become a favored alternative to standard end-to-end generative language models (OpenAI, 2023; Touvron et al., 2023). This shift is driven by LLMs' inherent weaknesses regarding factual errors stemming from hallucinations (Ji et al., 2023), outdated knowledge (Vu et al., 2023), limitations with long-tailed knowledge (Kandpal et al., 2023; Malaviya et al., 2023), and reasoning failures, such as in logical deduction (Berglund et al., 2023).

RAG is employed differently across various NLP tasks:

* **Knowledge-Intensive Tasks:** RAG retrieves up-to-date and reliable knowledge references (Vu et al., 2023; Malaviya et al., 2023), which serve as new prompts for LLMs to extract information and formulate responses. This mitigates hallucinations (Ji et al., 2023) and reduces the need for frequent LLM fine-tuning.
* **Reasoning-Dependent Tasks:** RAG fetches the most relevant chunks from extensive inputs to guide LLM focus, for example, in multi-hop question answering where reasoning across multiple documents is required.  Reasoning with such long contexts is challenging even for LLMs with extended context windows, and impossible for those with shorter ones (Xu et al., 2023).

Despite the promise of dense retrievers for knowledge-intensive tasks, they struggle to retrieve reliable and cite-worthy references (Malaviya et al., 2023) compared to state-of-the-art proprietary LLMs used independently (OpenAI, 2023). This highlights a weakness in retrievers' ability to assist LLMs.  This discrepancy is amplified in reasoning-intensive tasks, where RAG often shows inconsistent gains or even performance degradation compared to standalone LLMs (Bai et al., 2023; Xu et al., 2023).

Given the complex role of dense representation models in the LLM era, accurately assessing their advanced language understanding capabilities is crucial.

Identifying conserved quantities has significant practical applications, driving decades of research in applied mathematics.  This work presents a novel data-driven methodology for learning the symbolic forms of conservation laws, minimizing data requirements and automating parameter selection.

Traditional approaches for discovering conservation laws include analytical methods, such as solving linear systems derived from stoichiometric matrices [2, 3, 4] for linear relations and employing more sophisticated techniques for nonlinear ones [5]. Lie group theory has also been extensively used [6, 7, 8, 9, 10].  Computationally, algorithms like manifold learning [11] and AI-Poincaré 2.0 [12] learn conservation laws from dynamical system inputs.  The Sparse Invariant Detector (SID) [13] offers a non-black-box linear algebraic approach.

However, with the rise of data-driven modeling, the challenge lies in recovering conservation laws *without* a priori knowledge of system dynamics. Existing data-driven methods range from specialized approaches for Hamiltonian functions [14, 15] to more general neural network-based techniques like AI-Poincaré [16] and ConservNet [17].  Other approaches leverage deep neural nets with Noether's theorem [18], manifold learning with optimal transport [19], and machine learning to identify both conservation laws and dynamical system structure [20]. Koopman theory combined with data-driven regression provides symbolic representations [1].  These methods typically require between 100 [20] and over 1000 data points [12], with higher-order systems potentially needing more.  Robustness to noise remains a key challenge.

This paper adopts an SVD-based null space estimation method, offering robustness and lower data requirements.  Often, as few as 20 points suffice for accurate recovery, even with substantial noise.  Beyond minimizing data needs, the method learns the *functional form* of the conservation law(s), a feature shared with the sparse identification paradigm used in [1].  Challenges associated with this approach include choosing appropriate functional libraries and optimality thresholds.

To address these challenges, we develop a unified data-driven approach for automatically selecting the optimal learning library and polynomial degree.  This approach utilizes a sequence of data transformations, including SVD decomposition and echelon form reduction, letting the data guide the identification of the singular value gap and inform subsequent optimization parameter selection.  The method's effectiveness is demonstrated on various problems, including multiple and nonlinear conservation laws, with applications in physics and biology.

Our proposed methodology offers two key advantages: (1) robust discovery of conservation laws with minimal data, even in the presence of noise and without knowledge of underlying dynamics, and (2) automated selection of optimal libraries and thresholds based on estimated noise and the singular values of the library matrix.  Due to the ease of SVD and LU-based implementation, this framework integrates well with other learning approaches.

The waves slammed against the ship, sending spray over the deck. We were constantly soaked.

It began with a knock on my door.  I opened it to find Don Reist, who invited me to Europe on a cattle boat. I couldn't refuse.

It was 1945. World War II raged in Europe, leaving many countries devastated.  These ravaged nations desperately needed supplies and food, aid that I and others would deliver.

Forty-four nations united to form the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA). The organization hired "Seagoing Cowboys" to care for the horses, cows, and mules being shipped overseas. Don and I signed up for the job.

We arrived on August 14th, the day the war in the Pacific ended.  Don and I received our seaman's papers and boarded the SS *Charles W. Wooster*, bound for Greece.  Our cargo: 335 horses and their feed.

Being 18 was precarious; I could have been drafted.

By my discharge in 1947, I had completed nine trips—the most of any Seagoing Cowboy. The cattle trips were incredible, yet demanding.  Crossing the Atlantic from the eastern United States took about two weeks, plus we cared for and fed the animals three times a day.

Helping on my Aunt Katie's farm had prepared me somewhat for the work, but not for the dangers we faced.

Life on board was also enjoyable. We played baseball, volleyball, and other games.

The experience heightened my awareness of others and their needs. This awareness has stayed with me throughout my life, realizing that people around the world needed what I had.  Helping them was more rewarding than I could have imagined, and I learned a great deal from the experience.  More than anything, the trip solidified my friendship with Don, the one who had invited me on this adventure.

In "A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves," Luke's actions during World War II exemplify the principle of reciprocal altruism: helping others often leads to help in return.  It's crucial to understand and value what matters to others.  Some might find entertainment in observing conflict, but witnessing our allies embroiled in war while we remain passive is deeply unsettling.

Helping others generates a cycle of support.  This could manifest in practical assistance, like help with a building project, or in shared experiences, such as preparing a meal together.  Regardless of the form it takes, offering assistance is inherently the right course of action.  Whether initiating a favor or reciprocating one, the act of helping strengthens bonds and builds community.

Doing what's necessary is paramount.  People consistently prioritize the needs of their families, friends, and even pets.  Failing to address these crucial needs can lead to regrettable choices in the future.

Luke's aid during World War II demonstrates this principle in action.  Countless individuals in that conflict sacrificed their lives to protect what they held dear.  Similarly, many would willingly make the ultimate sacrifice for loved ones.

I disagree with the concept of driverless cars.  Primarily, I believe they are inherently dangerous. The requirement for a driver to remain alert negates the very purpose of autonomous driving.  Alerts designed to recapture the driver's attention shouldn't be necessary. If a car is truly driverless, it should function without any human intervention.

While I understand the appeal for long road trips, where one person typically bears the burden of driving, and the desire for drivers to rest, the safety implications are concerning.  Even if a sleeping driver is alerted to an impending accident, their reaction time and judgment could be severely impaired.  Expecting someone roused from sleep to instantly take control in a critical situation is unrealistic.  They might panic and exacerbate the situation, leading to further collisions. The potential for catastrophic failures with driverless technology is simply too high.

While many anticipate the widespread adoption of such technology, I'm reminded of the dystopian future portrayed in the movie Wall-E, where people became obese and indolent due to reliance on automated systems.  Do we really want to follow that trajectory?  The United States already struggles with obesity, and eliminating the need to drive will further reduce opportunities for even minimal physical activity.

In conclusion, I believe driverless cars are a misguided innovation.

Ever felt bored in class, wishing for something more engaging than a tedious lecture?  Facial Action Coding System (FACS) technology offers a potential solution. By recognizing facial expressions and interpreting emotions, FACS can revolutionize the classroom. It can gauge student interest, identify when a spark is needed, and even adjust the lesson's pace if a student becomes confused or frustrated.

Emerging technologies like FACS hold immense potential for education.  This system could significantly improve student performance and foster genuine interest in learning.  As noted by its creator, Dr. Paul Ekman,  "Six basic emotions—happiness, surprise, anger, disgust, fear, and sadness—are associated with characteristic facial muscle movements."  This classification system forms the foundation of FACS, enabling it to recognize student engagement levels and provide valuable feedback to teachers.

This technology could also pinpoint students struggling due to disinterest. Dr. Huang suggests, "A classroom computer could recognize when a student is becoming confused or bored. Then it could modify the lesson, like an effective human instructor." This adaptability could dramatically alter how students learn, catering to individual needs and preventing boredom by instantly adjusting the lesson.

Confusion, anger, and even depression can significantly impact a child's learning.  FACS could identify these emotional states, potentially alerting school counselors when a student needs support.  Dr. Huang emphasizes the importance of nonverbal communication, stating, "Most human communication is nonverbal, including emotional communication, so computers need to understand that, too."  This implies that FACS could also help students struggling with issues they might be hesitant to discuss, such as family problems affecting their schoolwork. By recognizing signs of depression, the system could help connect these students with necessary support.

قالت النائبة المنشقة عن مجلس النواب الليبي، السيدة اليعقوبي، في تغريدة على حسابها بتويتر: "تَفاقَمَت الأزمة المعيشية حتى أصبحت لا تُطاق بسبب تردّي الخدمات الأساسية، والنقص الحاد في السيولة، وتجاهل احتياجات المواطن البسيط. انقطاع الكهرباء والماء، وندرة السيولة، واستشراء الفساد، وانسداد الأفق، وفقدان الثقة بالوعود الحكومية؛ كل ذلك هو ما قسم ظهر البعير".

وجاءت تغريدة اليعقوبي مُقتطفة من منشور لها على فيسبوك، اعتبرت فيه أن "هناك حلقة مفقودة"، مُخاطِبةً حكومة الوفاق: "انزلوا إلى الناس وتحدثوا مع الشعب. لن أتطرق إلى اتهام البعض للحراك بالتآمر، أو شيطنة المظاهرات سواء استمرت أو توقفت،  ونتجاهل القضية الحقيقية، وهي قمع الشعب وتهميشه، ودفعه إلى حافة الهاوية، ثم نطالبه بالصمت!".

وتابعت: "جميع الليبيين، إن لم يكونوا يعلمون، يُعانون من نفس المعاناة!  فرغم اختلاف انتماءاتهم، إلا أنهم جميعًا يواجهون جبال الفساد التي وصلت ذروتها، وتغلغلت في أركان الدولة شرقًا وغربًا وجنوبًا.  لقد جاع الشعب وأُهين، فثار بهذه الطريقة مُطالبًا بحقوقه البسيطة". وأضافت: "مظاهرات الخضر وفبراير وكرامة، جميعها توجهت بصوت واحد، وكان الحراك، من وجهة نظري الخاصة، عابرًا للتيارات السياسية –التي أوصلته إلى حد الإهانة– يُنادِي بمطالب عادلة، ويقف ضد الفساد الذي هو انعكاس لافتقاره وتجويعه وإذلاله. فلكل سببٍ مُسبب".

Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a powerful paradigm enabling collaborative model training across numerous devices without direct data sharing, driven by the increasing prevalence of machine learning in the Internet of Things (McMahan et al. 2017; Imteaj et al. 2022).  Traditional FL employs a parameter-server (PS) architecture where a central server aggregates models and broadcasts updates (Kairouz et al. 2019). However, this centralized approach suffers from communication bottlenecks and potential server vulnerabilities (Lian et al. 2017).

Decentralized learning offers a promising alternative, utilizing peer-to-peer communication for faster convergence (Lian et al. 2017, 2018).  In this framework, each worker maintains a local model copy and collaborates with neighbors to achieve a consensus model.  However, data heterogeneity, a common challenge in both centralized and decentralized learning, can hinder performance. When data distributions vary significantly across workers, a single shared model may perform poorly on individual devices. Consequently, personalized decentralized learning, where each worker learns a tailored model (Vanhaesebrouck, Bellet, and Tommasi 2017; Dai et al. 2022), becomes crucial.

This paper advances personalized decentralized learning by leveraging the concept of shared representations.  Inspired by observations in centralized learning (Bengio, Courville, and Vincent 2013; LeCun, Bengio, and Hinton 2015), we exploit the idea that heterogeneous data, even with different labels, can share a common low-dimensional representation.  Following the pioneering work of Collins et al. (2021) in the centralized setting, we extend this principle to decentralized learning.  We propose that each worker's model comprises a shared global representation map (ϕ: R<sup>d</sup> → R<sup>z</sup>) and a personalized local head (θ<sub>i</sub>: R<sup>z</sup> → Y), where z ≪ d.  This structure simplifies local optimization of the worker-specific heads. While Collins et al. (2021) analyzed linear global representations, we address the open questions of developing a fully decentralized algorithm for the general non-linear case and providing its convergence analysis.

Specifically, we introduce DePRL, a decentralized algorithm that alternates updates between global representation and local head parameters to solve the optimization problem min<sub>ϕ∈Φ</sub> (1/N) Σ<sup>N</sup><sub>i=1</sub> min<sub>θi∈Θ</sub> F<sub>i</sub>(θ<sub>i</sub> • ϕ), where F<sub>i</sub>(•) represents worker i's loss function.  In each round, workers update their local head and global representation using stochastic gradient descent, share updated global representations with neighbors, and compute a weighted average to achieve consensus.

Unlike conventional decentralized learning with a single shared model (Lian et al. 2017, 2018; Assran et al. 2019), DePRL involves coupled updates of local head and global representation parameters, requiring novel proof techniques for convergence analysis.  Our contributions are threefold:

* **DePRL Algorithm:** We introduce DePRL, the first fully decentralized algorithm that learns a shared global representation and personalized local heads for improved performance in heterogeneous data environments.

* **Convergence Rate:** We establish a new notion of ϵ-approximation solution and provide the first convergence analysis for personalized decentralized learning with shared non-linear representations. We demonstrate a convergence rate of O(1/√NK), where N is the number of workers and K is a sufficiently large number of communication rounds, indicating a linear speedup with respect to the number of workers. This result, highly desirable for large-scale decentralized systems, also guarantees consensus on the shared global representation while maintaining personalized local heads, offering insights into generalization to unseen workers.

* **Evaluation:**  We empirically validate DePRL's performance and theoretical findings through experiments on various datasets with representative DNN models, demonstrating superior performance in heterogeneous settings compared to existing baselines.

A fleet of a hundred thousand ships, each capable of obliterating a city from orbit, emerged from a wormhole. At the center, their mothership loomed large.  "We're coming out of the wormhole, General. No signs of any defences on the perimeter of the system," a voice reported.

"It's finally been a hundred years for the people of Earth," the great alien general addressed his command room, his long green tongue flicking in distaste.  "Perhaps I gave them too little time. This won't be much of a challenge."

The fleet entered Earth's system, holding position before a field of asteroids, the anticipated location for Earth’s defenses. Hours passed. Scouts returned with nothing. System-wide scans for technology, even cloaking systems, yielded no results. A chill ran down the general's spine.  Had the Earthlings developed technology capable of hiding from them? The thought sparked excitement; a challenge he couldn't resist. Perhaps he’d overestimated humanity’s potential.

"Move our most advanced scouts towards Earth's known flight path. Send three. Losses are acceptable."

Several hours later, a live video feed flickered to life on the mothership’s command screen. A scout strolled casually down a deserted city street. "General, no one is here. We haven't seen an Earthling since we landed. Scout 45 reports the same. The buildings look abandoned for years."

"Not a single Earthling? No resistance? What's going on down there?" the general demanded, his voice laced with frustration.

The scout paused, flipping through a small booklet. The cover displayed a large airship. The general's eyes fixed on the image, a mixture of satisfaction and puzzlement.  They'd attempted larger space-faring vessels, but none had been detected. "I'm sorry, General," the scout continued, "but based on the science team's findings, I'm afraid you're not going to get the fight you were hoping for."

The general turned a dark shade of purple. "Blast it all… let me guess? Disease? Mass extinction?"

"No, General." The scout turned the page. The general recognized a device eerily similar to their own wormhole generators.  "We believe mass migration."

"El día que nos quitemos la mascarilla, tenemos que respirar aire más limpio".  Esta frase, pronunciada por María Neira, directora del Departamento de Salud Pública y Medio Ambiente de la Organización Mundial de la Salud (OMS), resonó ayer en la XXI edición de los Premios Ecovidrio, celebrada virtualmente. Neira, distinguida como ‘Personalidad Ambiental Ecovidrio 2020’,  compartió escenario (virtual) con el Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas (CSIC), galardonado con el premio ‘Mayor Impacto Ciudadano’ por su  investigación continua sobre la mitigación del cambio climático.

En un año marcado por la convulsión sanitaria y económica derivada de la pandemia de COVID-19, el reconocimiento a la doctora asturiana María Neira cobra especial relevancia.  Su liderazgo al visibilizar la conexión entre el cuidado del medio ambiente y la salud, crucial en el contexto actual, ha sido fundamental. Ecovidrio, entidad sin ánimo de lucro responsable de la gestión del reciclado de envases de vidrio en España, destacó la trayectoria de Neira en el control de enfermedades y la seguridad alimentaria, tanto en la OMS como en grupos de trabajo nacionales, ONG y  durante su etapa como viceministra de Salud y Asuntos del Consumidor en España.

Con un mensaje "de futuro y esperanza", Neira explicó que, si bien su objetivo al estudiar Medicina era "cuidar a las personas", pronto comprendió que  "para salvar a las personas, primero hay que salvar el medio ambiente".  Instó a crear un movimiento que promueva la salud ambiental, recordando que cada decisión en materia de medio ambiente impacta en la salud.  Su llamado a adoptar un lenguaje verde y "unir fuerzas para crear adeptos a la agenda verde" culminó con la  frase: "Cada vez que luchamos por una mayor calidad del aire, estamos salvando muchos pulmones, muchas vidas. El día que nos quitemos la mascarilla, tenemos que respirar aire más limpio".

Rosa Menéndez, presidenta del CSIC, recogió el galardón a Mayor Impacto Ciudadano, un reconocimiento a la  participación de sus investigadores en las Cumbres del Clima y otros grupos de trabajo internacionales, así como a su búsqueda de soluciones innovadoras e integradoras y a la incorporación de la tecnología para abordar el cambio climático y mejorar la calidad de vida.  Menéndez agradeció el premio en nombre de los más de 11.000 empleados del CSIC,  destacando su "trabajo incansable para generar conocimiento" frente a los nuevos retos.  Mencionó las plataformas interdisciplinares de trabajo, como la de Salud Global, con un centenar de proyectos relacionados con la COVID-19, y otras vinculadas al medio ambiente, como las de Plásticos, Energía y Movilidad, y Clima.

El acto virtual, conducido por Martín Barreiro, el hombre del tiempo de La 1, contó con la presencia de Hugo Morán, secretario de Estado de Medio Ambiente. Morán subrayó la importancia de la salud ambiental para la salud pública y  cómo "la desbocada crisis de biodiversidad" está en el origen de las enfermedades zoonóticas y crisis sanitarias como la actual.  Aprovechó la ocasión para destacar la Estrategia Nacional España Circular 2030, que se desarrollará a través de planes trienales,  y anunció el primer Plan de Acción 2021-2023, que incluye el anteproyecto de Ley de Residuos y Suelos Contaminados y el proyecto de Real Decreto de envases y residuos de envases.

Por segundo año consecutivo, Ecovidrio entregó el Premio Especial #Ecólatras,  en esta ocasión a toda la cadena del reciclado de vidrio, reconociendo su compromiso con la mejora de la tasa de reciclado y la promoción de hábitos sostenibles. Armando Sánchez, presidente del Consejo de Administración de Santos Jorge, recogió el premio en nombre de las más de 200 compañías y cerca de 7.000 personas que trabajan en el sector.  José Manuel Núñez-Lagos, director general de Ecovidrio, agradeció  emocionado su labor, especialmente durante el estado de alarma.

Entre el centenar de candidaturas a los premios periodísticos,  destacaron: en Prensa, Manuel Planelles y Juan Antonio Aunión (El País); en Televisión, Luis de la Rosa y Verónica Palomares (La Sexta Noticias); en Radio, Miguel Aguado (Onda Madrid); y en Iniciativa Digital, la aplicación The Planet App.

Si María Neira abrió el acto con una frase para recordar, Martín Barreiro lo cerró con otra: "El futuro es verde y el futuro empieza en casa".

The Facial Action Coding System (FACS) offers potential benefits in the classroom.  By analyzing students' facial expressions, FACS could identify confusion, boredom, or engagement with the lesson.  This has practical applications, particularly for students who hesitate to ask for help.  For instance, a classroom computer equipped with FACS could recognize a confused or bored student, prompting the teacher to offer assistance. This would be particularly helpful for students who, despite struggling, might not outwardly seek clarification. FACS could also provide valuable feedback, allowing teachers to adjust their lessons based on student engagement levels.  Imagine a scenario where a teacher, alerted by the system, proactively modifies their approach to re-engage a bored class.

However, the use of FACS raises valid privacy concerns.  Many students already express unease about being watched, evidenced by the number who cover their laptop cameras. Even those who dismiss such concerns might feel uncomfortable knowing their expressions are constantly monitored.  This discomfort, shared by some parents, could create resistance to FACS implementation.

While FACS offers intriguing pedagogical possibilities, student and parent comfort levels are paramount.  Ultimately, fostering an environment where students feel comfortable expressing their needs and feedback directly remains crucial.  While technology can play a supporting role, it shouldn't replace open communication between students and teachers.

For over thirty years, the question of the Face on Mars has lingered: alien artifact or natural landform?  Despite intense media scrutiny, evidence overwhelmingly supports the scientific conclusion that the Face is a natural formation, much like a butte or mesa common in the American West, contrary to the claims of conspiracy theorists.

NASA's Viking 1 orbiter first captured the formation in 1976, describing it as "an enormous head nearly two miles from end to end."  A few days later, when NASA released the image to the public, speculation about alien life ignited.  As the article "Unmasking the Face on Mars" explains, "The 'Face on Mars' had since become a pop icon. It has starred in a Hollywood film, appeared in books, magazines, radio talk shows—even haunted grocery store checkout lines for 25 years!"  The article continues, "Some people think the Face is bona fide evidence of life on Mars—evidence that NASA would rather hide, say conspiracy theorists."  The media amplified the idea of extraterrestrial intelligence, often disregarding scientists' explanations.

Eighteen years after the Viking missions concluded, the Mars Global Surveyor, a Mars orbiter, flew over Cydonia (the region where the Face is located) for the first time. The orbiter team captured an image ten times sharper than the original Viking photographs.  These photos revealed a natural landform, not an alien monument.  On April 5, 1998, during a cloudless summer day on Mars, the Mars Global Surveyor passed over Cydonia again, close enough for the orbiter team to acquire an exceptionally detailed image using the camera's maximum resolution. Each pixel in the 2001 image represented 1.56 meters, compared to 43 meters per pixel in the best 1976 Viking photograph.

Jim Garvin, chief scientist of NASA's exploration program, explained, "As a rule of thumb, you can discern things in a digital image three times bigger than the pixel size. So, if there were objects in this picture like airplanes on the ground or Egyptian-style pyramids or even small shacks, you could see what they were!"  The image of the Face actually depicts the Martian equivalent of a butte or mesa. "It reminds me most of Middle Butte in the Snake River Plain of Idaho," Garvin noted. "That's a lava dome that takes the form of an isolated mesa about the same height as the Face on Mars."

Dimanche soir, le PSG affronte le Bayern Munich en finale de la Ligue des champions à Lisbonne.  Si tous les regards sont tournés vers ce match historique pour le club parisien, en quête de son premier sacre européen, Leonardo, lui, observe attentivement Benjamin Pavard.

Selon *L'Équipe*, le directeur sportif du PSG apprécie fortement le profil du défenseur bavarois.  Ses performances en Bundesliga cette saison ont confirmé l'intérêt de Leonardo pour l'ancien joueur du LOSC.  Plus utilisé par Hans-Dieter Flick, Pavard a disputé 47 matchs toutes compétitions confondues, dont 32 en championnat (31 titularisations).  *L'Équipe* affirme que Leonardo « ne cache pas, en privé, apprécier le profil » du latéral droit. Au-delà de ses performances et de son palmarès, le Français correspond parfaitement à la nouvelle politique de francisation souhaitée par les propriétaires qataris.  Cependant, si le nom de Pavard est bien coché par Leonardo, *L'Équipe* précise qu'« aucune démarche concrète » n'a encore été entreprise.

Débaucher le joueur de 24 ans ne sera pas chose aisée.  Pavard est un élément clé du projet munichois, adulé par la direction et le staff technique. Son prix représente également un obstacle majeur pour le PSG.  Estimée à 45 millions d'euros, sa valeur marchande pourrait être revue à la hausse par le Bayern en cas de négociations.  Pour rappel, le club allemand avait déboursé 35 millions d'euros pour s'attacher les services du champion du monde 2018 en provenance de Stuttgart en juillet 2019.  La même année, le Bayern avait également investi 80 millions d'euros pour recruter Lucas Hernandez, autre champion du monde français, en provenance de l'Atlético Madrid. Imagine a computer that can detect your emotions – whether you're happy, sad, or confused. This isn't science fiction; it's the potential of Facial Action Coding System (FACS) technology. While the idea of emotion-reading technology might seem intriguing on a personal level, its value truly shines in the classroom.

Developed with the help of Professors Thomas Huang and Nicu Sebe, FACS can benefit not only students but also teachers and administrators. As mentioned in paragraph six of the original text, a classroom computer equipped with FACS could recognize student boredom or confusion.  Imagine you're having a bad day and face a daunting five-page essay.  While you might try to hide your frustration, this technology could subtly inform your teacher of your emotional state, allowing them to adjust accordingly, perhaps postponing the assignment to a better time.

This technology offers a significant advantage in understanding student engagement. Teachers could gain insight into how students genuinely feel about an activity or project.  What the teacher perceives as engaging might actually bore the students, leading to decreased effort and suboptimal learning.

Beyond the classroom, this technology has applications in online advertising.  Paragraph six also mentions how online ads can adapt to your reactions. If you smile at a web ad, a similar one might appear next.  Frown, and the advertisement changes. This principle, applied to classroom computers and iPads, could personalize the learning experience and filter out distracting or irrelevant content.  While pop-up ads are often dismissed as annoying, the ability to tailor them to individual emotional responses could transform them into a more useful tool.


This technology holds promise for improving the learning environment and personalizing digital experiences.  It allows for a deeper understanding of individual emotional responses, paving the way for more responsive and effective educational strategies.

An Innocent Mistake

The sweet snow hid his tracks, a blanket of white.
Hands shoved deep in his pockets, he took flight,
Leaving no proof that he'd ever trod there,
Wishing the snow would conceal his red candy wrapper.

For a moment, the sun caught the young boy's brown eyes.
He watched the sunset's beauty, a smile starting to rise.
His tongue savored the last of the small, sweet treat,
But his smile froze as his eyes met his father's.

Perched on the doorstep, framed by the doorway,
His father's figure was unmistakable on this late winter's day.
A desperate swallow, a silent, whispered prayer,
That the only witnesses to his candy were the snow and the air.

He greeted his father with a smile and respect,
But quiet dread gnawed at him, knowing what to expect.
Piano notes drifted through the house to his ears.
If only he were his sister, that would quell all his fears.

The hope of escaping unnoticed, fleeting and free,
Was extinguished by a hand placed firmly on his shoulder.
The same hand reached quickly into his small pocket,
His face draining of color, his back against the proverbial wall.

"You have red on your face, son. Oh, what have you done?
And look here in my hand, a red wrapper. I demand
A complete explanation to placate my humiliation."
He held his breath as he replied, "An innocent mistake."

His father stared, veins bulging in his head.
"We will deal with this after our evening bread.
But be it innocent mistake or guided adultery—"
He took a deep, ragged breath.  "You know what to expect from me."

The boy could barely eat, knowing what was coming.
No one spoke to their father; one look from his eyes would send anyone running.
Sister and mother ate with hearts full of pity,
Knowing he'd tasted the forbidden city.

The meal finished, cleared in a dark and pallid mood.

The temple doors swung open, revealing a sight I hadn't anticipated.  In front of me, where I'd expected marble plinths, golden frescoes, and a proud display of the finest weapons forged by men and gods, was a chaotic mountain of unsorted weaponry. Every legendary sword, every fabled weapon, lay jumbled together in a bureaucrat's nightmare.

"Excuse me," I said, struggling to keep my voice level.  I turned to the Curator, who appeared older than the crumbling temple itself. "Does the Great Hall always look like this?"

She hesitated, a flicker of embarrassment in her eyes. "Well, you see, we, err, we get so much coming in that I just don't know what to do with them all, and before I know it they just start..."

"Piling up?" I offered.

A dry chuckle escaped her lips. "Young man, every hero who's come here has faced the same predicament! If Samson could climb halfway up just to find a jawbone, I'm sure you'll do just fine."  With that, she turned and left me alone in the Great Hall, her footsteps echoing until only my own thoughts remained.

I turned towards the towering pile of weapons. Following my training, I closed my eyes and focused on the task at hand.  The Curator had said each weapon possesses a voice, and though many may call out, only one would choose me, earning me the title of Hero.

As I stood there, waves of whispers filled the room.  "Have the dragons returned? Take me and bring your people salvation." "Is the Ragnarök come? Now is your hour of need, and I am here to serve." "The people crave a champion, and only I can deliver them one." "The end days are coming, boy. You need me to drive the demons away."

Dozens of voices swirled around me, each claiming to be the sole key to my people's salvation.  Shivering, I squeezed my eyes shut, overwhelmed by the cacophony. How could I choose just one? I longed for a moment of silence to think.

Gradually, the voices faded, leaving the Great Hall quiet.  Hours passed, but still, I hadn't found my fated weapon. Had I failed to become a Hero?

Then, a voice cut through the silence. "Isn't that much better? I hate it when it gets too loud in here. No way to make myself heard."

It was *my own voice*, emanating from somewhere within the pile. A shiver ran down my spine. This was it.  This was the feeling of being chosen.

"Where are you?" I asked, my voice cracking after the long silence. Darkness had fallen within the Great Hall.

"Around the other side of this heap, near the bottom," my own voice replied.  Suppressing the unsettling sensation of hearing myself speak, I carefully navigated the mountain of weapons, avoiding the sharp edges of spearheads and battle-axes.  As I reached the back, I spotted my fated weapon.

Le gouvernement En Marche, comme à son habitude, instrumentalise la communication.  Le projet de loi “climat et résilience” en est la parfaite illustration.  Personne n’en est satisfait, et particulièrement les membres de la Convention Citoyenne pour le Climat, censés en être à l’origine.  Ébaubis, ces 150 citoyens ont réalisé avoir servi un nouveau coup de communication à Emmanuel Macron.  Face à cette injustice, ils ont manifesté début mai pour dénoncer le fait que seule une infime partie de leurs propositions seraient traduites en droit.

L’un des aspects les plus marquants de ce projet de loi est la création du délit d’écocide, visant à punir de 10 ans de prison et 4,5 millions d’euros d’amende tout « comportement intentionnel ayant conduit à des atteintes graves et durables à l’environnement ».  Ce qualificatif d’« écocide »  interroge.  La nature,  n'étant ni une personne physique ni morale, ne peut se constituer partie civile selon le droit français.  Loin d'être une communauté d'intérêts homogène, la nature est un domaine où les intérêts divergent, même face à l'impact de l'homme.  Certaines plantes prospèrent sur les sols incendiés, certaines algues prolifèrent grâce à des pollutions aquatiques pourtant catastrophiques pour la faune. Le malheur des uns fait le bonheur des autres.

Doit-on alors condamner l’assèchement des zones humides au XIXe siècle pour lutter contre le paludisme,  malgré la destruction d’espèces animales et végétales qui en a résulté ?  L’être humain faisant partie intégrante de la nature,  faudrait-il qualifier d’écocide les avortements et les euthanasies ?  Ces questions éthiques et juridiques démontrent la complexité du terme « écocide ».

Bien sûr, la protection d’un environnement sain est essentielle au bien-être humain.  Cependant, cette protection ne doit pas occulter la dignité supérieure de l’homme, ni les dérives anthropologiques qui menacent sa nature même, sujet pourtant ignoré par les défenseurs du projet de loi.

La majorité présente l’écocide comme une avancée majeure,  oubliant l’arsenal juridique existant pour garantir l’intégrité de l’environnement, condition sine qua non au bien-être de l’Homme.  Le Conseil d’État a pointé l’incohérence des peines et la probable inconstitutionnalité de la mesure.  Qu’importe pour Barbara Pompili, qui parie sur la « novation juridique »,  alors même qu’elle est accusée d’écocide par Stéphane Bern pour sa politique éolienne – ironie du sort.  L’inapplicabilité de la mesure, dénoncée par juristes et écologistes,  importe peu.

I oppose using technology to read faces because sometimes our expressions don't accurately reflect our feelings. A computer can misinterpret them.

The program's creation involves a computer generating a 3-D model of a face, with all 44 facial muscles programmed to mimic human movement.  However, this doesn't mean the computer understands our emotions. It only recognizes the physical configuration of facial muscles.

Therefore, using this technology in a classroom is problematic. A teacher might wrongly conclude a student is angry based on a computer's interpretation of their facial expression, even if the student is happy or sad.

Similarly, if the program indicates a student is happy when they are actually sad, their friends might tease them, leading to unwanted conflict and hurt feelings.

It's simply not possible for a computer to reliably determine our emotional state.

Self-driving cars are often touted as the future of transportation, with many believing they will soon become the norm. However, I argue that autonomous vehicles are destined to fail for several key reasons, ranging from the impracticality of implementation to significant safety concerns and the simple fact that many people genuinely enjoy driving.

For many, driving is not a chore but a cherished pastime, a stress-relieving activity, and a source of personal freedom.  Self-driving cars would eliminate the simple pleasure of a leisurely drive, the thrill of a spontaneous road trip, and the immersive experience of controlling a vehicle.  Autonomous vehicles, presumably reliant on GPS, would require pre-planned destinations, stripping away the spontaneity that defines many driving experiences. Replacing this with a motionless passenger experience is unlikely to appeal to a significant portion of the population.

Furthermore, the financial and logistical challenges of adapting our current infrastructure for autonomous vehicles are staggering.  Our roads are designed for human drivers. A sudden shift to self-driving cars would necessitate a massive overhaul of the entire highway system. The costs associated with installing motion sensors, GPS monitoring systems, and replacing existing public transportation with autonomous taxi services would be astronomical, placing an unreasonable burden on taxpayers.

Safety is another paramount concern.  While human error contributes to accidents, entrusting driving to computers introduces a whole new set of risks.  Software glitches, hacking vulnerabilities, and unforeseen technical malfunctions could lead to catastrophic consequences, potentially causing widespread accidents and traffic chaos. The inherent unpredictability of these issues makes autonomous vehicles a far greater threat than human drivers.

In conclusion, the widespread adoption of autonomous vehicles is simply not feasible.  The exorbitant cost of infrastructure modifications, the inherent safety risks, and the disregard for the enjoyment many find in driving all point to the failure of this technology. For those who value the freedom and experience of driving, sticking with a traditional vehicle remains the best option.

Juno-nominated singer-songwriter Craig Cardiff, known for his intimate performances and community engagement, led a songwriting workshop for Algonquin College students on February 7th.  Sipping a pink fruit smoothie, clad in wool socks, Cardiff sat on the floor of the small stage in the Commons corner lounge, guitar in hand. "Everybody here has something to share," he announced to the dozen participants gathered before him.

Cardiff, a seasoned performer at the college, often incorporates workshops before his concerts.  "Why not get the chance to connect with people?" he explained, highlighting his belief in the power of community involvement.  He routinely conducts these sessions in schools.

The students, eager to learn from the experienced musician, embraced the opportunity. "I really wanted to do something new," shared Anastasia Young, a first-year travel and tourism student, in an interview with the Times. "So why not in writing, or in our craft?"  She emphasized the benefit of feedback, believing that the perspectives of others can lead to "opportunities for growth" and collaborative projects. The idea of driverless cars in today's world presents both exciting possibilities and serious concerns. While the prospect of autonomous vehicles appeals to many, perhaps due to increasing convenience or simply the novelty of the technology, we must carefully consider the potential benefits and drawbacks before fully embracing this future.

One major advantage often cited is the potential for increased safety.  Proponents argue that removing human error from the equation could drastically reduce accidents.  However, this assumes flawless technology, which is unlikely in the early stages of development.  As seen with systems like BMW's "Traffic Jam Assistant," introduced in 2013, even partially autonomous features still require driver oversight and engagement.  The driver must remain alert and ready to intervene, negating some of the theoretical safety benefits.  If a driver is required to maintain focus, the question arises: what is the true purpose of a driverless car if it still needs a driver?  As Dr. Werner Huber suggests, perhaps we need to rethink the concept of "driving fun" in the context of autonomous vehicles.

My concern is that fully autonomous vehicles could lead to complacency and decreased vigilance.  Drivers, freed from the task of driving, might be tempted to sleep, use their phones, or engage in other distracting activities, becoming less prepared to react in emergencies.

Deep neural networks have proven incredibly powerful across a wide range of machine learning tasks. However, they are highly sensitive to small input perturbations, which can dramatically reduce their accuracy (Carlini & Wagner, 2017; Szegedy et al., 2013). In natural language processing (NLP), these adversarial examples often take the form of spelling mistakes, synonyms, or other meaning-preserving transformations that alter the network's prediction (Ebrahimi et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2019a; Michel et al., 2019).

This paper addresses the problem of training robust models over natural language—or more generally, sequences over a finite alphabet—that are resilient to adversarial examples.  The discrete nature of the adversarial space for sequences makes it difficult to explore efficiently using gradient-based optimization techniques common in computer vision.  A common approach to achieving robustness is adversarial training (Goodfellow et al., 2015; Madry et al., 2018), which has been extensively researched in computer vision and, more recently, in NLP (Ebrahimi et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2019a; Michel et al., 2019).  Given a perturbation space R(x) for a sample x—for example, if x is a sentence, R(x) might contain all possible misspellings up to a certain limit—adversarial training incorporates an adversary into the training objective. Instead of computing the loss for a sample (x, y), it computes the loss for the worst-case perturbed sample z ∈ R(x). Formally, the adversarial loss for (x, y) is max z∈R(x) L(z, y, θ).

The central question of this paper is: Can we train models robust against rich perturbation spaces over strings?

The practical challenge lies in computing this worst-case loss. The perturbation space R(x) can be enormous, making exhaustive enumeration impractical, especially in NLP tasks where R(x) should contain semantically equivalent inputs, such as variations of x with typos or synonyms.  Therefore, we need to approximate the adversarial loss.  Two classes of approximation techniques exist:

* **Augmentation:** This class computes a lower bound on the adversarial loss by exploring a finite subset of R(x). This is typically done using gradient-based attacks like Hot-Flip (Ebrahimi et al., 2018) for NLP or Projected Gradient Descent (PGD) (Madry et al., 2018) for computer vision.  These techniques effectively augment the training set with perturbed samples.

* **Abstraction:** This class computes an upper bound on the adversarial loss by overapproximating, or abstracting, the perturbation space R(x) into a set of symbolic constraints that can be efficiently propagated through the network.  Interval abstraction, for instance, has been used in several works (Mirman et al., 2018; Gowal et al., 2019; Huang et al., 2019).

Both techniques can be suboptimal: augmentation may severely underapproximate the worst-case loss, while abstraction may severely overapproximate it.  Furthermore, they exhibit complementary utility, performing well on some perturbation spaces but not others. For example, Huang et al. (2019) showed that abstraction works better for token substitutions, while augmentation-based techniques like Hot-Flip (Ebrahimi et al., 2018) and MHA (Zhang et al., 2019a) are more general, applying to token deletions and insertions as well.

Venus, sometimes called the "Evening Star," is one of the brightest objects in the night sky, easily spotted even by amateur stargazers.  However, this nickname is misleading, as Venus is a planet, not a star.  Often referred to as Earth's "twin" due to its similar size and density, Venus is occasionally the closest planet to Earth in terms of distance, too.  Because of this relative proximity, humans have sent numerous unmanned spacecraft to this cloud-draped world.  Each mission has been unmanned for good reason: no spacecraft has survived the landing for more than a few hours.  On Venus's surface, temperatures average over 800 degrees Fahrenheit, and the atmospheric pressure is 90 times greater than Earth's.  Interestingly, Venus has the hottest surface temperature of any planet in our solar system, even hotter than Mercury, despite being farther from the sun.

Long ago, Venus may have been largely covered by oceans and could have supported various life forms, much like Earth. However, studying Venus from orbit provides limited insight into ground conditions.  The dense atmosphere prevents most light from penetrating, rendering standard photography and videography ineffective.  Researchers are working on innovations to allow their probes to survive long enough to contribute meaningfully to our knowledge of Venus.  NASA, for example, is exploring approaches like simplified silicon carbide electronics, which have survived for three weeks in a chamber simulating Venus's harsh surface conditions.

El 28 de abril de 2020, el Gobierno de Navarra, a través de Nasuvinsa, anunció un paquete de ayudas para el pago de alquileres, tanto públicos como privados, destinado a apoyar a familias y colectivos afectados por la crisis de la Covid-19.  El vicepresidente José María Aierdi explicó que el objetivo de estas medidas es garantizar el acceso a una vivienda digna y atender las necesidades básicas de la población más vulnerable.

Para quienes ya residen en viviendas de alquiler protegido y percibían subvenciones al 31 de marzo de 2020,  estas se renovarán automáticamente y se ampliará su cuantía hasta un máximo del 75% durante abril, mayo y junio.

Además, Nasuvinsa ofrece dos opciones para inquilinos que acrediten vulnerabilidad económica por la Covid-19:  una moratoria en el pago de la renta para quienes ya cuentan con subvención, y una condonación del 50% para quienes no la perciben. This paper investigates tensors of minimal border rank, motivated by algebraic complexity theory and the study of secant varieties.  We aim to overcome complexity lower bound barriers identified in [22, 26] and provide new "minimal cost" tensors for Strassen's laser method, which are not subject to the barriers described in [2] and [10]. These new tensors are not binding, circumventing the limitations established in [10] for minimal border rank binding tensors.

A tensor T ∈ C<sup>m</sup> ⊗ C<sup>m</sup> ⊗ C<sup>m</sup> = A ⊗ B ⊗ C has rank one if T = a ⊗ b ⊗ c for nonzero a ∈ A, b ∈ B, c ∈ C. The rank R(T) is the smallest r such that T is a sum of r rank one tensors. The border rank R(T) is the smallest r such that T is a limit of a sum of r rank one tensors, or geometrically, the smallest r such that T ∈ σ<sup>r</sup>(Seg(P<sup>m-1</sup> × P<sup>m-1</sup> × P<sup>m-1</sup>)) ⊆ P(C<sup>m</sup> ⊗ C<sup>m</sup> ⊗ C<sup>m</sup>).

A concise tensor (formally defined in §1.1) cannot be expressed in a smaller ambient space.  A concise T ∈ C<sup>m</sup> ⊗ C<sup>m</sup> ⊗ C<sup>m</sup> has border rank at least m. If the border rank equals m, T has minimal border rank.

Self-supervised pre-training, leveraging large-scale unlabeled data, has revolutionized Natural Language Processing (NLP) (Devlin et al., 2019; Liu et al., 2019; Conneau et al., 2020; Jiao et al., 2020a).  However, its adoption in Machine Translation (MT) has been limited. This is likely due to the architectural mismatch between pre-training models (e.g., Transformer encoder) and Neural Machine Translation (NMT) models (e.g., Transformer encoder-decoder).

To address this gap, sequence-to-sequence (Seq2Seq) pre-training models like MASS (Song et al., 2019) and BART (Zhu et al., 2019; Lewis et al., 2020) have been proposed.  mBART (Liu et al., 2020) further extends BART by training on massive multilingual data, significantly improving translation performance.  While previous approaches often focused on pre-training only the encoder (Lample and Conneau, 2019), mBART pre-trains a complete autoregressive Seq2Seq model by reconstructing masked input sentences. This raises a crucial question: what is the specific contribution of the jointly pre-trained decoder?

This work provides a deeper understanding of state-of-the-art Seq2Seq pre-training, focusing on the role of the jointly pre-trained decoder.  Through experiments on various WMT and IWSLT benchmarks across different language pairs and data scales using mBART-25 (Liu et al., 2020), we analyze the decoder's impact. Our findings (§ 2.2) reveal that jointly pre-training the decoder:

* Produces more diverse translations with varied word orders, necessitating multiple references for accurate evaluation on large datasets.
* Consistently reduces adequacy-related translation errors compared to pre-training the encoder alone.

Despite the performance benefits, we also identify side effects stemming from discrepancies between pre-training and fine-tuning (§2.3):

* **Domain Discrepancy:** Seq2Seq models are often pre-trained on general domain data (e.g., arXiv), while downstream tasks focus on specific domains (e.g., news). This necessitates further adaptation during fine-tuning.
* **Objective Discrepancy:** NMT models learn to translate between languages, while Seq2Seq pre-training focuses on input reconstruction. This leads to over-estimation and hallucination with noisy input, exacerbating the beam search degradation problem already associated with Seq2Seq pre-training (Liu et al., 2021).

To mitigate these issues, we introduce two strategies (§3): in-domain pre-training and input adaptation during fine-tuning.  In-domain pre-training bridges the domain gap by continuing mBART pre-training on in-domain monolingual data. Input adaptation involves adding noise to the source sentences during fine-tuning, facilitating knowledge transfer from the pre-trained model.

Our experiments demonstrate that in-domain pre-training significantly improves translation performance, while input adaptation enhances robustness. Combining both yields a high-performing NMT system.  Further analysis shows that our approach reduces domain discrepancy, particularly for low-frequency words, and alleviates over-estimation and beam search degradation.

## Reliving 1960s Dorchester, Ted Williams, and the Red Sox with Paul Korins

Author Paul Korins returns to his roots in his new book, "A Summer to Remember with Ted Williams," revisiting his beloved Dorchester and the era of his idol, Ted Williams.  This is Korins' fourth novel for young readers and the second installment in his Sammy Baker time travel series.

“I grew up in Dorchester from age 11 to 16, and Ted Williams was my idol,” Korins shared. “Seeing him at Fenway Park was a rare and thrilling occasion.”

In this stand-alone sequel, 12-year-old Sammy once again utilizes the magic typewriter from Korins' first novel. This time, instead of traveling to the Great Depression, Sammy finds himself transported to 1960, landing right in the Red Sox dugout beside “Teddy Ballgame.”  Williams becomes Sammy’s mentor, offering life and batting advice. While Sammy relishes his time with his newfound hero, he also yearns for home and must complete a mission before returning.

“There is a puppy love interest,” Korins teased, adding that the story offers something for everyone, even those who aren't baseball enthusiasts.  During his time travel adventure, Sammy takes on the persona of his uncle, Terry, and even finds a bit of romance.

Dorchester itself plays a significant role in the book.  “Readers will recognize landmarks,” Korins noted.

Korins, who has dreamt of being a writer since he was 11, draws inspiration from his own childhood experiences. “You have to be a reader to be a writer,” he emphasized. “I always had a book in my hand.”  Saturday mornings were spent at the local toy store, adding the latest Hardy Boys Mystery to his collection.  Just like his character Sammy, Korins played Little League.

“I had a great childhood,” he reminisced. “The character is a composite of the kids I knew, the kids I grew up with.” He remains connected with many of these childhood friends, who continue to inspire his writing. “I wrote for that age group because I enjoyed that age. There is part of me in every book.”


Though his reading list now includes authors like Richard Russo and Colum McAnn, Korins offers advice for aspiring writers, particularly those interested in writing for young readers. "Don’t write down," he cautioned.
