Après six ans de mariage, Kim Kardashian s'apprêterait à demander le divorce.  Son soutien indéfectible à Kanye West n'a pas suffi face aux deux refus du rappeur qui l'ont finalement conduite à consulter Laura Wasser, l'avocate spécialisée dans les divorces de célébrités.

La fin d'une belle histoire.  Malgré le cadeau exceptionnel offert par Kanye West à Kim Kardashian pour son 40e anniversaire en octobre dernier, leur mariage n'a pu être sauvé.  Le refus du rappeur de suivre un traitement pour son trouble bipolaire et son manque d'implication dans l'éducation de leurs quatre enfants ces derniers mois auraient fortement influencé la décision de la femme d'affaires.  Kim Kardashian réside dans leur manoir de Calabasas tandis que Kanye West s'est retiré dans son ranch du Wyoming.  Face au refus de ce dernier de revenir auprès d'elle,  Kim Kardashian n'a vu d'autre issue que de mettre un terme à leur union.

La star de « L'incroyable famille Kardashian » a donc engagé la célèbre avocate Laura Wasser pour gérer le divorce et élaborer une stratégie lui permettant de préserver sa fortune estimée à près de 2 milliards de dollars.  Élevant seule North (7 ans), Saint (5 ans), Chicago (2 ans) et Psalm (1 an),  la jeune femme se sentirait comme une mère célibataire. Une source proche du couple a confié au Sun : « Kim souhaitait plus que tout que son mariage fonctionne. Elle a soutenu Kanye dans sa candidature à la présidence et a tenté de préserver leur relation même après ses tentatives de divulguer des éléments de leur vie privée. »  La source ajoute : « Elle a tout investi dans ce mariage et a finalement réalisé qu'il était temps de partir.  Elle aime et aimera toujours Kanye, mais il refuse de suivre son traitement et de faire les efforts nécessaires pour que leur relation fonctionne. »

« Ces deux dernières années, elle l'a vu perdre tout contrôle. »

Les derniers mois ont été particulièrement éprouvants pour le couple et Kim Kardashian considère Kanye West comme "incontrôlable". La source explique : « Au début de leur famille, Kim et Kanye partageaient la même vision de la vie et de l'avenir.  Mais ces deux dernières années, elle l'a vu perdre le contrôle, s'éloigner d'elle et des enfants, et ne rien entreprendre pour sauver leur mariage. »  La source précise qu'ils ne partagent plus la même chambre, une situation difficile à vivre pour la mère de famille.

El gobernador Gustavo Bordet, en una reunión con intendentes este lunes, les solicitó responsabilidad en las paritarias debido a la continua pérdida de recursos.  Esta situación se da en un contexto de creciente malestar ciudadano por el aumento de impuestos,  "solidario" según el oficialismo, y que ya genera  rumores de medidas de fuerza en algunos sectores, como el agrario.  Curiosamente, ningún funcionario del oficialismo defendió el ajuste, cuya repercusión en las arcas provinciales es evidente. La defensa quedó a cargo de quienes lo votaron en el Congreso. La única reacción local fue la decisión de algunos intendentes, no todos ni de forma coordinada, de congelar sus sueldos. Martín Piaggio fue el primero, seguido por algunos pares y la Legislatura.

Los incrementos impositivos provinciales no tienen defensores.  Se escucharon las voces de Gustavo Zavallo, respondiendo a Gustavo Cusinato, y de Juan Navarro, contestando a Esteban Vitor, pero nada más.

La Liga de Intendentes Justicialistas, que supo tener un rol político preponderante,  parece haber perdido fuerza.  Quizás su última demostración de poder fue durante la presidencia de Faustino Schiavoni,  ex intendente de Nogoyá, quien unificó a sus pares en defensa de los gobiernos de Cristina Kirchner y Sergio Urribar.  En aquel momento de tensión,  los intendentes dudaban entre mantenerse leales o unirse al movimiento liderado por Jorge Busti,  que finalmente fracasó.

Tras la ajustada victoria de Bordet en 2015, la Liga se debilitó.  Los pocos encuentros durante su primer mandato pasaron desapercibidos, incluso con notorias ausencias.

A pesar de que el 58% de los votos en su reelección le otorgó a Bordet un mayor apoyo de los intendentes, la Liga sigue inactiva.  Durante la campaña del Frente de Todos no hubo expresiones de apoyo públicas.  Sus últimas declaraciones registradas, del 20 de agosto del año anterior a la consulta, criticaban medidas de Mauricio Macri.  Un año antes, se habían pronunciado a favor de la potestad del gobernador para definir la fecha de las elecciones tras la caída de la reforma política. Nada más.

Surge entonces la pregunta: ¿cuándo elegirá la Liga a su próximo presidente? ¿Sigue Rebord en el grupo de WhatsApp? ¿Expulsaron a Enrique Cresto? ¿Incorporaron a Bahl? Un integrante, consultado, confesó su desconcierto: "Tengo entendido que hay dos grupos, yo estoy en uno, pero no pasa nada".

Dislocations, line defects in the crystal lattice, govern the plastic deformation of metals under most conditions. Consequently, discrete dislocation dynamics (DDD), a computational method simulating the motion and interaction of dislocation lines, has become invaluable for studying metal plasticity at the mesoscale.  In DDD, dislocation lines are discretized into segments connecting nodes, whose positions evolve over time through the integration of nodal velocities [1]. Node motion arises from the dislocations' response to the driving force at each node, a function of the local stress acting along the dislocation lines. Because all dislocation lines interact elastically, calculating nodal forces for time-integration is typically the most computationally expensive simulation stage. This burden is exacerbated by the intrinsic stiffness and highly nonlinear behavior of the system, stemming from the nature of dislocation interactions, which necessitates small timesteps for traditional time-integrators and limits the achievable physical timescale. Despite recent algorithmic advances [2], the computational cost of DDD simulations remains a significant challenge.

Here, we present a novel DDD-GNN framework, replacing the computationally intensive time-integration procedure with a graph neural network (GNN) trained to predict nodal displacements directly from nodal configurations and applied loading.  GNNs are particularly well-suited for this task, as dislocation line configurations are inherently graph-like. Our model leverages the common DDD practice of partitioning elastic interactions into short- and long-range components. By bypassing explicit short-range force calculations, our framework offers the potential for significant simulation acceleration. This approach distinguishes itself from previous machine learning applications in DDD, which focused on accelerating individual interaction force calculations [3], characterizing dislocation microstructures [4], or predicting crystal plasticity through stress/strain curves [5, 6, 7].

We demonstrate our approach using the fundamental case of a dislocation line gliding through an obstacle array under an imposed load. This widely employed model represents an important dislocation dynamics scenario used to study various dislocation-obstacle bypass mechanisms [8–18] and is relevant for applications such as solid solution strengthening and precipitate/irradiation-induced hardening. Our DDD-GNN model is trained on ground-truth DDD data to predict nodal displacements (effective velocities) across a range of obstacle densities and strain rates.  We show that the trained GNN time-integrator, implemented within the DDD framework, accurately reproduces the local dislocation motion behavior and predicts long-term simulation trajectories, including the correct saturation flow stress under different loading regimes.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: Section 2 outlines the DDD method and introduces our hybrid DDD-GNN approach. Section 3 presents the dislocation-obstacle glide model and the training data.  Results are presented in Section 4, followed by a discussion in Section 5.  Finally, Section 6 concludes the paper.

The paper investigates the relationship between Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD), Wasserstein distance (W_p), and task-specific metrics in the context of compressive statistical learning (CSL).  This relationship is crucial for deriving learning guarantees in CSL, a framework designed for resource-efficient large-scale learning.

CSL aims to summarize large datasets into compact sketches while preserving sufficient information for learning tasks.  This involves sketching operators that map datasets to lower-dimensional representations.  A key property for guaranteeing the effectiveness of these operators is the Lower Restricted Isometric Property (LRIP), often established by demonstrating that an MMD with a translation-invariant (TI) kernel dominates a task-specific metric (Kernel LRIP). This paper proposes a generalization, the Hölder LRIP, based on a more nuanced relationship between MMD and Wasserstein distances.

Section 2 delves into the connection between W_p and MMD.  While connections exist between MMDs and regularized OT distances, less is known about the relationship with non-regularized W_p.  The section establishes conditions under which W_p can be bounded by MMD with a Hölder exponent (W_p ≲ MMD^δ), a crucial step towards the Hölder LRIP.  This involves defining a model set of distributions, restricting the generality of the bound.  The analysis focuses on MMDs associated with TI kernels, commonly used in large-scale learning algorithms.

Section 3 explores the relationship between task-specific metrics and W_p.  It introduces the concept of "Wasserstein regularity," which characterizes tasks where the task-specific metric can be bounded by W_p.  This section demonstrates that various unsupervised (e.g., K-means, PCA) and supervised (e.g., regression, classification with Lipschitz functions) learning tasks exhibit Wasserstein regularity.

Section 4 introduces the CSL framework and its motivation.  It details how the relationships established in the previous sections contribute to a generalized LRIP, termed the Hölder LRIP.  The section argues that the Hölder LRIP offers advantages for CSL and presents associated learning guarantees.  It explains how CSL addresses the computational challenges of large-scale machine learning by summarizing datasets into smaller sketches and performing learning directly on these sketches.  This involves finding a low-dimensional subspace capturing sufficient information for the task.

Figure 1 provides a visual overview of the paper's reasoning.  It illustrates the chain of relationships: TaskMetric ≲ W_p ≲ MMD^δ, and the final connection between MMD and the distance between sketches, which ultimately leads to the Hölder LRIP and CSL guarantees.  The paper's contributions thus provide a theoretical foundation for efficient large-scale learning by connecting task performance, Wasserstein distance, MMD, and the properties of sketching operators.

## An Atlantic Exclusive: An Excerpt from *Falling Forward: The Memoirs of President Mike Paulatowski*

Let's be honest, I had no business being elected president. You know it, I know it. Pundits call me the "Social Media President" or the "first populist president of the 21st century," but I was just the first person upvoted to the Presidency.  How did this happen?  It started with a gag.

I gave a profanity-laden address, megaphone in hand, to an eighth-grade assembly.  "You motherfuckers need to vote for me, cause I will CLEAN - SHIT - UP!"  The kids thought a grown man acting like a crazy person for class president was hilarious. They got the joke. The rest of you, clearly, did not.

The video went viral. Then came the follow-up videos. More hits.  Suddenly, I was famous. Everything was cool. Until Reddit got ahold of it.  User sexybeeffarts45 started a write-in campaign.  Foolishly, I ran with it.  Next thing I knew, I was being sworn in.

Political professionals talk about the simplicity of "cleaning shit up," or how I captured the zeitgeist.  They're full of shit. Americans were fed up with a broken political system and sent a clown to D.C.  Too bad we got rid of the electoral college – that might have prevented this.

My dad always said, "Winners never quit, and quitters never win." He never mentioned getting *fired*.  And Lord knows, I tried.

First, I used the Patriot Act II to declare war on Canada.  They're so nice, I figured nobody would actually fight them.  Wrong. Oil companies loved the idea. Nine days later, the war was over, oil prices plummeted, and the economy boomed.

My next attempt: a three-word State of the Union address. "Fuck All Y'all."  My approval rating jumped 15 points.  "Refreshing," they called it.

Nothing was working. I needed something truly horrifying.  The end of Social Security. Who could support that?  Initially, my approval ratings tanked.  But investment banks and insurance companies were ready with a slew of retirement products.  Money shifted from taxes to banks, the stock market soared. People were pissed, but their opinions don't matter much these days. The system runs itself.

I gave up. I wasn't getting fired.  So, fuck it. I built a go-kart track on the South Lawn and held the inaugural White House Flip Cup Championship.  Members of Congress competed, and I’d sign one bill of the winner’s choosing.  Hell, they don't write the bills anyway.

يشتكي بعض الموظفين من كثرة الضوضاء والضجيج حول مكاتبهم، مما يؤثر على تركيزهم وأداء مهامهم.  ولمعالجة هذه المشكلة، ابتكر الدكتور توماس فريتز، عالم الكمبيوتر من جامعة كولومبيا البريطانية في كندا، طريقة جديدة تساعد الموظفين على التركيز ومنحهم الوقت الكافي لإنجاز أعمالهم بدون مقاطعة.

Bernie Sanders lidera la obtención de votos en la elección primaria demócrata celebrada hoy en New Hampshire, consolidándose como un fuerte aspirante a encabezar la candidatura del partido en las elecciones presidenciales de noviembre.  Con el 40 por ciento de los votos computados, Sanders concentra el 26.8 por ciento de las preferencias. Le sigue Pete Buttigieg, con 23.6 por ciento, quien previamente lo había superado por un estrecho margen en el caucus de Iowa.  En tercera y cuarta posición se encuentran Amy Klobuchar con 19.9 por ciento y Elizabeth Warren con 9.8 por ciento, respectivamente.

Joe Biden, exvicepresidente durante el gobierno de Barack Obama, sufre su segundo revés consecutivo, alcanzando solo la quinta posición con 8.3 por ciento de las preferencias en New Hampshire.

Looking at his carefree face from below as he was slowly transported towards me on the escalator, I already knew.  He was in for a seven on the Bristol scale, just hours away. I wondered, not for the first time, if I should warn him. But how could I tell him? How could I tell anyone?

How could I explain that I could see the future, their fate? That I could feel the forces at work, often without their knowledge and beyond their control, inside their own bodies?  That I could see the shape of things to come? That I was a coproscognitive?

Nobody would believe me.  Not without a few proven predictions, and few humored me long enough to witness those predictions come true. This guy didn't have that luxury of time. He needed to believe me about the very next event I foresaw, and there was no way to convince him in the short time we had.

He was going down, and I was going up.  As the escalator carried us past one another, I stayed silent, leaving him to his fate. I could only hope he would be close to the right place two hours and thirteen minutes from now. I knew it would be fast and explosive, and without my warning, he'd have little time to run for salvation.

I put him out of my mind. I had my own future to worry about, and I didn't need my gift to tell me about it. I started looking for the signs pointing the way to the nearest lavatory.

新型冠状病毒肺炎（世界卫生组织将其命名为 Covid-19）目前尚无特效疗法。因此，医生只能通过混合使用其他药物，主要是抗病毒药物，来缓解症状。

邓丹菁的医生给她开了几种药，包括俄罗斯和中国用于治疗流感的抗病毒药物阿比多尔、国际上其他地区更常用的流感药物达菲，以及一种用于治疗艾滋病、被认为可以阻止病毒复制的药物克力芝。邓丹菁每天至少要服用12片药，此外还要服用中药。医生给她开了阿比多尔以缓解症状。

尽管她保持乐观，但身体却日渐虚弱。她母亲把家里的饭菜送到病房外，但她没有胃口。为了补充营养，一名护士每天早上8点半来给她进行静脉输液，输入的除了营养液，还有抗体和抗病毒药物。

夏思思的病情虽然也很严重，但她似乎正在逐渐康复。几天后，她的烧退了，上了呼吸机后，呼吸也轻松了一些。

她的精神状态也好转了。1月25日，她告诉同事自己正在康复中。

她在微信群里留言：“我会尽快归队。”

“我们正需要你，”一位同事回复道。

2月初，夏思思问同为医生的丈夫吴石磊，她是否很快就能停止吸氧。

“慢慢来，别着急，”吴石磊在微信上回复。他告诉妻子，下周可能就能脱离呼吸机了。

“我就是想快点好，”夏思思回复。

她确实有好转的迹象。毕竟，大多数新冠病毒感染者最终都能康复。

后来，夏思思做了两次新冠病毒核酸检测，结果均为阴性。她告诉母亲，预计2月8日就能出院了。

**病情恶化（住院后第4-16天）**

在医院里，邓丹菁唯一能接触到的人就是她的室友和医护人员。她在一张与医生的合影上写道，笑声可以驱散病魔。

尽管两次病毒检测结果均为阴性，但夏思思的病情却突然恶化。

住院第四天，邓丹菁再也无法保持乐观了。她开始呕吐、腹泻，身体不停地颤抖。

她烧到了38.5度。2月5日清晨，她从断断续续的睡眠中醒来，发现药物并没有降低体温。她哭了，说自己已经被列为危重病人。

第二天，她吐了三次，直到吐出白沫。

Sebastian Vettel a terminé la saison 2018 comme il l'avait commencée : dans l'ombre de Lewis Hamilton.  Le triomphe du Britannique à Abou Dabi, et la seconde place de l'Allemand, illustrent parfaitement le duel qui les a opposés toute l'année.  "C'est Lewis le champion, et il mérite son titre", a reconnu le pilote Ferrari après la course. "L'année a été dure, mais j'ai tout donné jusqu'au dernier tour. Je le rattrapais petit à petit, mais il contrôlait le rythme."

Si près, à seulement deux secondes du quintuple champion du monde, mais pourtant si loin. Vettel aurait "aimé être davantage roue contre roue", mais il n'a jamais réellement semblé en mesure de menacer Hamilton. Un symbole de cette saison où il n'a pu mettre fin au règne du roi Lewis.

La page 2018 tournée,  Vettel se projette déjà sur l'avenir. "Toute notre équipe va tenter de revenir plus forte l'an prochain pour lui donner encore plus de fil à retordre", a-t-il assuré, selon *L'Equipe*. Le défi est lancé pour 2019.  Comme dans chaque duel, il fallait un vainqueur et un vaincu, et pour l'heure, Vettel reste le simple rival de Hamilton.

A new lawsuit accuses the Beverly Hills Police Department of racially profiling minorities.  Fashion executive Salehe Bembury, a plaintiff in the class-action suit, alleges he was stopped and harassed by officers for purportedly jaywalking because he is Black.  Bembury's video of the incident went viral, prompting the Beverly Hills Police Department to release body-camera footage, which they claim demonstrates standard procedure.  The footage depicts the officer requesting Bembury's identification and then asking permission to search him for weapons.

Civil rights attorney Ben Crump, known for representing the family of George Floyd, asserts that Beverly Hills targets people of color through a task force known as the "Operation Safe Street and Rodeo Drive Task Force."  Constitutional rights attorney Alexandria Kazarian stated, “The City of Beverly Hills Police Department has been under scrutiny for a long time.”

The lawsuit cites recent department statistics indicating the task force arrested 106 individuals: 105 African Americans and one Latino.  "That's simply inexcusable," Kazarian commented.  "There's absolutely no way the city of Beverly Hills can argue a non-racially motivated basis for those arrests."

The suit alleges that individuals were stopped for minor offenses like rollerskating, riding scooters, and jaywalking, and that many of these stops resulted in no charges due to lack of probable cause and evidence.  Kazarian added, "If they're targeting people for these minor sidewalk infractions, a much broader demographic should be affected."

Beverly Hills Police Chief Dominick Rivetti issued a statement explaining that the Rodeo Drive Team was formed in response to a significant increase in calls for service in the business district during the pandemic and subsequent civil unrest.  He noted the team recovered 13 loaded firearms from individuals on Rodeo Drive in just five weeks, a figure he described as unprecedented in Beverly Hills history.  The department also uncovered widespread fraudulent use of California unemployment benefits, recovering over $250,000 in cash and fraudulent EDD cards potentially worth $3 million.  Rivetti’s statement further emphasized, "The men and women of BHPD take an oath to protect human life and enforce the law—regardless of race. Any violation of this pledge is contrary to the values of this department. We take all concerns regarding the conduct of our officers very seriously."

By ROB MAADDI
PHILADELPHIA (AP) —  As the Phillies celebrated Jackie Robinson Day along with the rest of baseball on Thursday and Friday, Jimmy Rollins, a rookie All-Star with the team 20 years ago, reflected on the declining percentage of Black players in Major League Baseball.  It was 13% then, and it’s down to 7.6% this year.

“It’s more than just one thing,” Rollins told The Associated Press. Rollins attributed the decline to a combination of factors, including socioeconomic realities and a lack of effective marketing.

“You need space to play baseball,” he said, noting the challenges for city kids. “You don’t have that in a lot of places. In the country, you can find a field. In the city, kids aren’t playing stickball…The expense [is high]—you need the tools, you’ve got to pay for travel teams…Also, you look at how baseball’s traditionally passed down from father to son. If your father isn’t around, the chances of you being exposed to baseball…are probably less likely.”  He contrasted this with basketball, where “you could pick up and dribble,” courts are easier to find than baseball fields, and fewer players are required.  He also pointed out how other sports benefit from sponsorships that are less common in baseball.


Rollins also criticized Major League Baseball’s marketing efforts. “The NBA and the NFL, those guys’ faces are plastered all over the screen. Baseball, there isn’t really a great deal of marketing," he said.  While acknowledging Mike Trout's deserved prominence, he believes other young Black players deserve more exposure.  He recalled a meeting with Spike Lee, MLB, and the players' union years ago to discuss commercials.  “Nothing ever came of that," Rollins said. “Not to knock MLB, but they’re going to do things that, at face value, look great. But the impact is minimal because there’s generally never any true follow-through."  He contrasted this with the marketing success of Ken Griffey Jr. and Barry Bonds during his youth.  “But when you start going outside of that select few, the sport itself isn’t marketing anyone else in a major way where kids from the inner cities are attracted to it,” he said.

Even Rollins and teammate Ryan Howard, who won consecutive NL MVP awards in 2006 and 2007 as the core of a dominant Phillies team, didn't receive the marketing attention Rollins felt they deserved.  The team won five straight NL East titles, two NL pennants and the 2008 World Series, presenting ample marketing opportunities.


Rollins recently hosted a Bleacher Report series about being Black in MLB. The first part debuted on Jackie Robinson Day and featured conversations with Howard, Dwight Gooden, and 2020 Rookie of the Year Award winners Kyle Lewis and Devin Williams. Lewis and Williams were the first Black players to sweep the rookie awards since Gooden and Alvin Davis in 1984, three years before the award was renamed for Robinson.

Japan’s consumption of green tea has been steadily declining, but a new breed of casual cafes specializing in the traditional brew is aiming to reverse this trend.  These cafes introduce customers to a wide variety of brands and unconventional serving methods, hoping to reignite interest in the beverage.  Pioneering this movement was Iemon Salon Kyoto, opened about a decade ago by the Suntory Group.  Designed to evoke the atmosphere of traditional Kyoto machiya townhouses, Iemon Salon offers a modern take on tea culture, pairing green tea varieties like sencha, hōjicha, matcha, and gyokuro with meals, sweets, and even tea-based cocktails and beer. Prices range from ¥518 for sencha and hōjicha to ¥928 for a cup of gyokuro.  The cafe's manager emphasizes their mission: “We hope to deliver the culture and spirit of Japan to the world through tea.”

Following in this innovative spirit is Tokyo Saryo, which opened in January in Tokyo's Sangenjaya district.  The location is fitting, as “Sangenjaya” translates to “three tea houses,” a name derived from the area’s history of tea establishments hundreds of years ago.  With its minimalist design featuring plaster walls and only nine seats surrounding the service counter, Tokyo Saryo encourages a focused tea-tasting experience.  The cafe offers rotating monthly menus featuring a selection of 25 tea brands.  Customers can sample two different brews of each tea: one at 70 degrees Celsius to highlight the tea's richness, and a second at 80 degrees Celsius to bring out its bitter and astringent notes.  Menus include detailed explanations of each brand's characteristics, catering to those less familiar with the nuances of green tea.  Sets are priced at ¥1,300 for two teas and sweets, or ¥800 for one tea and sweets.

A key element of Tokyo Saryo’s approach is the interactive experience.  Staff are available to discuss the teas, offering insights into production areas and flavor profiles.  This educational aspect draws in both young Japanese and international visitors, providing an opportunity to discover new favorite varieties. One overheard conversation illustrates this engagement: a customer remarked, “This tea tastes deep,” to which a staff member responded, “When you make tea at a low temperature you get the (taste of) amino acids.  Some people have told me that the color makes it look like broth.”  This emphasis on education and discussion, coupled with the unique brewing method—hand-pouring hot water over the leaves, similar to hand-drip coffee—sets Tokyo Saryo apart.  As one staff member explains, “We are happy to answer any questions about tea… so you can enjoy the depth of the (world of) tea.”

Jen was having a rough night. Her best friend, Simone, wanted to go out, but Jen would have much preferred a quiet night in, watching Game of Thrones and talking.  She’d been feeling closer to Simone lately and wanted to share those feelings.  She sipped her beer, the bar’s noise – chatter, music, the clatter of pool balls – a dull roar in the background.

“*Ooh!* What about him?” Simone’s mildly drunk voice barely cut through the din.  She gestured towards a dark-haired man in a hoodie lurking in the corner. “He looks fun.”

“Hmm…” Jen mumbled, feigning interest. “I don’t know… he looks like young Hitler.”

Simone waggled a finger. “You are *soooo* not fun tonight, what’s up?”

“N-nothing,” Jen lied. “I had a long day at work. Just stressed, haha. Would you like to dance?”

Simone laughed, grabbed Jen’s hand, and pulled her to the dance floor. The music was light and upbeat. Simone danced playfully, but for Jen, it was different.  Every movement felt charged, a flirty dance aimed at the object of her affection.  Simone, oblivious, mistook Jen’s intensity for irony and began grinding against her. Jen, masking her frustration, tried to follow suit.

Predictably, the men at the bar started to notice.  Reveling in the attention, Simone amped up the performance, grinding harder against Jen, who felt like the human embodiment of an eye roll. As more heads turned their way, Simone, ever eager to fill the void left by her father’s inattention, grabbed Jen and kissed her full on the lips.

Jen froze, stunned.  For a fleeting second, she allowed herself to enjoy it before Simone pulled away, winked, and excused herself to the restroom.

As Simone sauntered off, her backside drawing the gaze of more than a few men, Jen let out a sad, defeated shudder.

Driverless cars represent a significant advancement in modern society.  While partially autonomous vehicles exist today, Mercedes-Benz, Audi, and Nissan project fully self-driving cars to be available by 2020. The article "Driverless Cars Are Coming" highlights several benefits, including enhanced safety features, such as the prevention of mobile device use while the vehicle is in autonomous mode.

Each self-driving car will have specific regulations. While in self-driving mode, the operator must remain alert and keep both hands on the steering wheel.  A built-in sensor in the steering wheel ensures the driver can quickly and safely take control when road conditions demand human intervention.  Another feature allows for the instant shutdown of non-essential systems. For instance, in-car entertainment, while a privilege, can be deactivated when necessary.

These self-driving cars incorporate numerous other features, including GPS, tire pressure, motion, and radar sensors.  Many newer cars already utilize rear-view cameras displayed on the dashboard.  Vibrating seats alert the driver to potential collisions. With these advancements, the operating system of a self-driving car can effectively mimic a human driver.

Beyond safety features, driverless cars also offer fuel efficiency. Projections indicate these vehicles will achieve significantly better gas mileage, potentially using half the fuel of current automobiles.  As Sergey Brin stated, "Such cars would fundamentally change the world."  Not only will each tank of gas last longer, but harmful emissions will also be reduced.

The development of self-driving vehicles is a significant societal achievement.

Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs; Goodfellow et al., 2014) are a powerful class of deep generative models, but they are notoriously difficult to train (Salimans et al., 2016).  Numerous approaches have been proposed to improve GAN performance (Arjovsky, Chintala, and Bottou, 2017; Gulrajani et al., 2017; Miyato et al., 2018a; Sinha et al., 2020). Recent work (Wei et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2020) suggests that incorporating consistency regularization techniques—popular in semi-supervised learning (Oliver et al., 2018)—can enhance generative model performance.  Specifically, Zhang et al. (2020) demonstrated that GANs (Goodfellow et al., 2014) augmented with consistency regularization achieve state-of-the-art image synthesis results.  In their approach (CR-GAN), both real images and their augmented versions are fed into the discriminator, which is then encouraged—via an auxiliary loss term—to produce similar outputs for an image and its augmentation.

While CR-GAN's consistency regularization is effective, applying augmentations only to real images creates an imbalance.  The generator can learn these artificial augmentation features and introduce them into generated samples as undesirable artifacts. Furthermore, by regularizing only the discriminator and using augmentations solely in image space, the regularization techniques in Wei et al. (2018) and Zhang et al. (2020) do not directly influence the generator.  Constraining the mapping from the latent space to generated samples could yield further performance gains beyond those achieved by discriminator-based consistency regularization.

This work introduces Improved Consistency Regularization (ICR), which applies consistency regularization to the generated images, the latent vector space, and the generator. First, we address the imbalance by introducing *balanced consistency regularization* (bCR), applying a consistency term on the discriminator to both real images and generated samples. Second, we introduce *latent consistency regularization* (zCR), incorporating regularization terms that modulate the sensitivity of both the generator and discriminator to changes in the latent space. Specifically, given augmented or perturbed latent vectors, we encourage the generator to be sensitive to these perturbations while encouraging the discriminator to remain insensitive.  The combination of bCR and zCR constitutes ICR.

ICR achieves state-of-the-art image synthesis results.  For unconditional image synthesis on CIFAR-10 and CelebA, ICR yields the best known FID scores across various GAN architectures.  For conditional image synthesis on CIFAR-10, we improve the state-of-the-art FID score from 11.48 to 9.21.

Reconstructing high-fidelity 3D scenes from captured imagery is crucial for scalable 3D content creation.  For these reconstructed environments to function as "digital twins" in applications like augmented reality and gaming, they must be compatible with modern graphics pipelines and renderable under user-specified lighting.  This necessitates reconstructing not only 3D geometry and texture, but also intrinsic scene properties like materials and lighting. This challenging, ill-posed problem is often referred to as inverse rendering [1].

Neural Radiance Fields (NeRFs) [34] have emerged as a powerful neural reconstruction technique, enabling photorealistic novel-view synthesis.  NeRFs can be reconstructed from posed camera images in minutes [14, 35, 43] and scale to room-sized scenes and beyond [45, 48, 55], making them attractive for augmented/virtual reality and digital twin generation. However, NeRFs intertwine intrinsic scene properties with incident light, limiting novel-view synthesis to the fixed lighting conditions of the input images; they cannot be relighted [42].

While NeRF can be extended to a full inverse rendering formulation [3], this requires computationally expensive volume rendering integrals for multiple light bounces.  Estimating secondary rays necessitates querying NeRF's volumetric density field along the path from each surface point to all light sources, scaling with O(nm) per point, where *n* is the number of samples per ray and *m* is the number of light sources or Monte Carlo samples for global illumination.  To manage this cost, prior work has focused on single objects with often a single, known light source [42], approximating direct/indirect lighting with a visibility MLP [42, 64] rather than volumetric rendering of secondary rays.

In contrast, explicit mesh-based representations enable efficient rendering.  With known mesh topology, estimating primary and secondary rays involves ray-mesh intersection (O(m)) queries, efficiently computed with libraries like OptiX [39].  However, inverse rendering with meshes either assumes a fixed topology [13] or recovers the mesh via an SDF on a volumetric grid [36], limiting resolution.  Consequently, these methods have yielded high-quality results primarily for smaller, object-centric scenes.

This work introduces FEGR<sup>1</sup>, a hybrid rendering pipeline combining the strengths of neural fields and explicit meshes for inverse rendering of large urban scenes.  We represent intrinsic scene properties with a neural field, rendering primary rays (G-buffer) via volumetric rendering.  For secondary rays generating higher-order lighting effects (e.g., specular highlights, cast shadows), we convert the neural field to an explicit mesh and employ physics-based rendering.  The neural field captures high-resolution detail, while the mesh enables efficient secondary ray tracing.  This differentiable hybrid rendering is embedded in an optimization scheme to estimate spatially-varying 3D material properties, geometry, and HDR lighting from posed camera images<sup>2</sup>.  Modeling HDR properties makes our representation suitable for AR applications like virtual object insertion requiring spatially-varying lighting for physically accurate cast shadows.

Our contributions are:

*   A novel neural field representation decomposing the scene into geometry, spatially-varying materials, and HDR lighting.
*   A hybrid renderer combining volumetric and physics-based rendering for efficient ray tracing within a neural scene representation, enabling high-quality inverse rendering of large urban scenes.
*   HDR lighting and material modeling, benefiting applications like relighting and virtual object insertion with cast shadows.

FEGR significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in novel-view synthesis under varying lighting on the NeRF-OSR dataset [40]. We also present qualitative results on an autonomously-collected, single-illumination urban environment capture.  Furthermore, we demonstrate intrinsic rendering results and virtual object insertion.  Finally, a user study confirms a significant preference for our method's results over baselines.

Fog computing, a nascent paradigm, merges the strengths of edge and cloud computing [8, 31].  For low latency, application components are deployed near the edge, close to end-users. This proximity also reduces bandwidth consumption, mitigates privacy risks, and enables continued edge operation during network partitions.  Conversely, for high scalability, components can leverage powerful machines like cloudlets [50] within the core network [8] or reside directly in the cloud. This comprehensive execution environment, often called "fog" [8, 9], encompasses all devices along the "cloud-to-thing continuum" [36]. Despite its numerous advantages, fog computing has seen limited application development, and commercial deployments remain nascent [57].  The primary hurdle is arguably the deployment and management of physical infrastructure, especially at the edge, contrasting sharply with the ease of cloud adoption [8].

This infrastructural challenge impacts the entire fog application lifecycle, affecting not only production system operation but also application testing. While initial design questions can be addressed through simulation [e.g., 10, 17, 20], practical testing on physical infrastructure becomes essential.  However, access to this infrastructure is typically fleeting, available only between physical deployment and production launch.  Before this window, the infrastructure may not exist, and afterward, its capacity is dedicated to production. This lack of access hinders complex integration tests and benchmarks, such as those for fault-tolerance in wide-area deployments, leaving developers reliant on conjecture, small local testbeds, and simulations. Existing infrastructure emulation approaches often focus solely on emulating edge devices [e.g., 22, 44].  Others emulate core network or cloud infrastructure but lack automated experiment orchestration [e.g., 12, 32].

This paper extends our preliminary work [21] by proposing the evaluation of fog applications on a cloud-based emulated infrastructure testbed, manipulated by a pre-defined orchestration schedule.  In this emulated fog environment, virtual cloud machines are configured to closely mirror the real (or planned) fog infrastructure. Using network characteristic data from the production environment or based on expectations and experience, interconnections between emulated fog machines are manipulated to exhibit similar behavior.  Similarly, performance measurements from real fog machines inform resource limits on Dockerized application containers. This allows for full cloud deployment of fog applications while replicating the performance and failure characteristics of a real deployment.

Driven by a thirst to explore the world beyond the city, Tyrone found himself on the edge of a lush wilderness. "This, this is man's country," he murmured, awestruck by the verdant expanse.  For months, he had devoured books, articles, and videos on camping, survival, and nature, preparing for this very moment.

He hoisted his 50-pound pack from his car trunk with ease, the result of years of weightlifting since high school.  Confident and prepared, he felt ready for any challenge the wilderness might throw his way.

Stepping onto the main trail, Tyrone immediately felt the tranquility of the forest envelop him. "Ain't no concrete jungle can beat THIS," he chuckled, appreciating the contrast to his urban life.  After a mile and a half, the trail forked.  Recalling a poem about choosing the road less traveled, he mused, "Damn, hard choice. They both look less travelled."  On a whim, the left-handed Tyrone chose the left fork.

The trail wound upwards, twisting and turning so much that Tyrone felt like he was walking in circles.  Finally, he emerged into a clearing where tall grasses obscured the path.  Although the trail continued on the other side, the approaching evening prompted him to find a campsite.

He located a suitable spot at the clearing's edge, beneath the shade of a tree canopy, where the grass was shorter.  Quickly assembling his tent and starting a fire, he completed his camp setup within 45 minutes.  Sinking into his lawn chair with a sigh, Tyrone surveyed his surroundings.

The unappreciated beauty of the clearing's grasses and the towering trees filled him with a joyful contentment. The reality of the wilderness far surpassed any book or video.  As the sun dipped below the horizon, painting the sky with vibrant hues, Tyrone watched, mesmerized, as day transitioned into a star-studded night.

The sky, clearer than any he had ever seen, revealed stars and a moon that shone with extraordinary brilliance. As he gazed upwards, a strange train of thought derailed his peaceful contemplation. The solitude of the wilderness, though profound, felt no different than his life in the city.  A disturbing thought arose: Was he truly alone, even amidst crowds?  Had he fabricated the people and events in his life, creating a false sense of purpose and excitement?  The thought angered him.  He cursed his own mind for conjuring such outlandish ideas, returning his focus to the captivating night sky.

Finally, fatigue from his day's hike settled over him.  Letting the fire die down, he retreated to his tent and sleeping bag.  As sleep claimed him, a profound sense of satisfaction enveloped him, carrying him into unconsciousness.

LONDON — Serena Williams received a favorable draw at Wimbledon on Friday, avoiding any early-round opponents with significant grass-court pedigree.  Her projected path could lead to a third-round encounter with No. 5 seed Elina Svitolina.

Williams, returning to the grass-court Grand Slam for the first time since 2016 after giving birth to her daughter last September, is currently ranked outside the top 150. However, the All England Club granted her a No. 25 seed based on her past success, which includes seven Wimbledon singles titles among her 23 Grand Slam singles trophies.  Williams' first-round opponent on Monday will be the 107th-ranked Arantxa Rus of the Netherlands, who has one career tour title.

This marks Williams' first competition since withdrawing from the French Open ahead of a fourth-round match against Maria Sharapova in early June, citing a chest muscle injury. That was Williams' return to Grand Slam action after a 16-month absence.

Rus has only reached the third round at Wimbledon once, in 2012, which also marks her last victory at the All England Club.  She lost in the first round of qualifying last year, as did both of the women Williams could face in the second round: 136th-ranked qualifier Viktoriya Tomova of Bulgaria and 167th-ranked wild-card recipient Tereza Smitkova of the Czech Republic.  Svitolina has only advanced as far as the fourth round at Wimbledon.

Williams' potential fourth-round opponent is 2017 US Open runner-up Madison Keys, who has reached one Wimbledon quarterfinal.  Her projected quarterfinal opponent, reigning Australian Open champion Caroline Wozniacki, has never progressed beyond the fourth round at Wimbledon. La fillette de Granby a tenté de s’enfuir quelques heures avant d’être retrouvée inconsciente, au beau milieu de la nuit du 28 au 29 avril 2019.  Les secours l'ont découverte nue et inconsciente le 29 avril, peu avant midi, à la suite d’un appel au 911 provenant du 23 rue Lindor, à Granby. Son décès a été constaté à l’hôpital le 30 avril. La belle-mère de l’enfant, aujourd’hui âgée de 38 ans, est accusée de meurtre au deuxième degré et séquestration. La Couronne soutient qu'elle a enroulé la victime de ruban adhésif.

Richard Samson, un voisin, a témoigné au sixième jour du procès.  Propriétaire de la maison louée par l’accusée depuis le 1er juillet 2018, il a raconté avoir été réveillé à 1 h 40 du matin par sa sonnette.  Pensant que son fils avait oublié ses clés, il a ouvert la porte pour ne trouver personne.  C’est alors qu’il a entendu des bruits provenant du boisé adjacent à sa maison et la voix de l’accusée, « tremblotante » et  « fâchée, frustrée » –  « paniquée », selon la défense – lui disant : « Richard, c’est [nom de la victime] qui s’est échappée de sa chambre. Ça fait cinq minutes que je cours après. »  (Des ordonnances de la Cour nous empêchent de dévoiler certains noms et certains détails dans ce procès.)

M. Samson a ensuite aperçu la fillette dans les bras d’un homme dans le boisé. L’enfant a prononcé le mot « maman » tandis que l’homme tentait de la consoler, avant de rentrer dans la maison.  Perturbé par l’incident, M. Samson a eu du mal à se rendormir.

Il a témoigné n’avoir croisé l’accusée et l'enfant que rarement.

Driverless cars present a complex dilemma, promising significant advantages while raising serious concerns. While proponents emphasize increased safety and convenience, the reality of transitioning to autonomous vehicles is fraught with challenges.  My primary concern lies with the level of human oversight still required, seemingly negating the concept of a truly "driverless" experience.

Currently, Google's autonomous vehicles, despite impressive mileage without major accidents, require driver intervention in various situations, such as navigating driveways, traffic, roadwork, and accidents.  The cars alert the driver, who must then steer, accelerate, and brake. This necessitates constant vigilance, demanding drivers keep their hands on the wheel and remain prepared to take control.  This begs the question: how "driverless" are these cars if constant human oversight is necessary?  Such a system seems to introduce another layer of complexity, potentially increasing the risk of human error due to complacency or delayed reaction times.

Furthermore, the argument that driverless cars will reduce accidents seems flawed.  While eliminating human error is a goal, the reliance on complex automated systems introduces new potential failure points. What happens if the system malfunctions?  The driver, expected to remain alert despite the autonomous nature of the vehicle, must react instantly to regain control, potentially creating a more dangerous scenario than if they were driving conventionally.

The supposed benefits, such as fuel efficiency and flexibility, also warrant scrutiny.  While Sergey Brin's vehicles reportedly consume less fuel, the overall environmental impact of manufacturing and maintaining these complex systems remains to be seen.  Moreover, the flexibility offered compared to public transportation needs further examination, particularly regarding individual needs and accessibility.

The design of numerous autonomous platforms is guided by the principle of modularity. A typical robot's autonomy stack, for instance, comprises separate modules for perception, planning, and control [24]. These modules often operate at different frequencies and levels of abstraction, despite the need for safe, real-time task execution with limited onboard computational resources.  Higher levels of abstraction generally enable faster decision-making. However, significant discrepancies in abstraction levels across modules can lead to unexpected and unsafe system behavior.  Choosing appropriate abstraction levels in robotics has remained largely an art. This work focuses on developing a quantitative, data-driven method to bridge the potential mismatch between trajectory planning and control modules.

Although trajectory planning and control are extensively studied in robotics, challenges persist. Graph-search-based path planning algorithms can struggle to incorporate complex nonlinear system dynamics.  Similarly, real-time optimization-based trajectory generation methods typically employ simplified or reduced-order dynamics models. Conversely, low-level feedback control policies often rely on more accurate, detailed system dynamics for tracking reference trajectories generated by the aforementioned approaches. This layered approach, while conceptually appealing, is effective only when higher-layer outputs are compatible with lower-layer capabilities.

This paper focuses on the interplay between trajectory generation and feedback control.  Rather than imposing a layered architecture, we demonstrate its derivation through a suitable relaxation of a global nonlinear optimal control problem that jointly encodes both trajectory generation and feedback control. Critically, the resulting trajectory generation optimization problem becomes dynamics-aware through a tracking penalty regularizer, encoding the dynamic feasibility of a generated trajectory.  While this tracking penalty generally lacks a closed-form expression, we interpret it as a cost-to-go, learnable from system roll-outs using tools from machine learning for any feedback control policy. We evaluate our framework using unicycle and quadrotor control, comparing our approach to standard quadrotor trajectory generation methods in simulation.  Our extensive experiments demonstrate that our data-driven, dynamics-aware framework enables faster computation of accurately trackable trajectories in both simulation and hardware.

Our contributions are:

* Deriving a layered control architecture with a dynamics-aware trajectory generator (top layer) and a feedback controller (low layer).  Our trajectory generation problem is inherently dynamics-aware, incorporating a tracking penalty regularizer that encodes the low-layer controller's tracking ability.
* Showing that the tracking penalty can be viewed as a system's cost-to-go, and thus learned from system rollouts.
* Applying our data-driven, dynamics-aware trajectory generation framework to unicycle and quadrotor control problems.  We demonstrate that our approach generates aggressive yet easily trackable trajectories compared to standard methods for both systems.

Section 3 formulates the dynamics-aware trajectory planning problem, using the unicycle and waypoint tracking problem as running examples. Section 4 presents a result showing how relaxing the underlying nonlinear control problem naturally leads to a trajectory optimization problem with a regularizer capturing the controller's tracking cost. We also describe our supervised learning approach for learning the cost-to-go function characterizing the feedback control layer's tracking ability.

Mercury, swift, fearless, and the most experienced with his stolen Sunfire, spearheaded the assault.  His astral form spun and looped wildly through space, weaving between the Flare Beasts and cutting them down.

"There's too many of them!" he shouted.

Venus, wreathed in clouds, followed close behind, providing support. Though lacking Mercury's aggression, she shared a protective nature with her brother, Earth. Her cloud blanket greedily absorbed every ounce of Sunfire within reach, and anything that entered that white haze was lost.

"I'll blockade them as long as I can," she declared. "They're not going to hurt my brother!"

Earth hung back, his gaze fixed on the single shaft of light piercing the black and red hordes, bathing his home planet in its radiance.  All the survivors were in his care; he was, after all, the origin of life. That ray of light was their lifeline, the only thing preventing a billion souls from freezing to death.

Ironically, their power source emanated from their greatest enemy. Sol, once the leader of the Champions, meant to provide energy to all the planetary guardians, had grown greedy and proud, believing he could wield his power more effectively than any other.  Now, his ever-expanding horde of Flare Beasts blotted out the sun, devouring every scrap of Sunfire they could find.

"This isn't working," Mars stated flatly, ever the calmest of the inner planets. Though his home had been terraformed during the Great Expansion, his power and nature still reflected the dusty, icy rock Mars once was. "There are too many."

"Hold on, Mars," Earth said, trying to mask the worry in his voice. "The outer planets are on their way."

The champion of the Red Planet summoned a gust of wind, scattering a group of Beasts that ventured too close to the beam of light. They quickly regrouped and charged again.  "They're too slow," Mars observed.

Mercury zoomed past, twin swords of white-hot stone carving into the horde. "They take years to make an orbit! They're not going to get here in time!"

Venus swept her hands through the void, warding off the Beasts with waves of heat and sulfuric acid. "I can't be everywhere at once! Mercury, I need you to—"

Before she could finish, a stream of insectoid Flare Beasts slipped past her. The last beam of light vanished.

A chill ran through Earth as his home planet went dark. The temperature plummeted.

"Earth! Are you okay? Earth!"

Earth closed his eyes, focusing. He needed energy. But he wasn't limited to solar power. His focus shifted inwards, deep underground, to the mines and shelters of his home.

Old Master paintings are frequently examined technically, to analyze artistic materials and techniques, or to support conservation and restoration.  Recent years have witnessed a digital revolution in this field, with widespread adoption of advanced analytical and imaging technologies generating large, multi-dimensional datasets [1] - [3].  Traditional X-radiographs, despite their long history, remain crucial for technical study, conservation, and preservation due to their ability to penetrate a painting's stratigraphy [4], [5].  X-rays reveal a painting's condition (e.g., subsurface losses and damage), the status of paint passages (identifying retouching, fills, or other interventions), and information about the support (canvas type or panel construction).  Crucially, X-ray images also provide insights into the artist's layering process, revealing *pentimenti*—changes made during painting, including concealed earlier designs painted over during revisions or when supports were reused.  Research from the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam indicates that nearly 15% (20 of 130) of Van Gogh's paintings contain such concealed images [6].

Consequently, there is significant interest in visualizing these hidden designs to better understand artworks and artistic practice.  Various imaging modalities have been employed to enhance visualization of concealed images [7], improve imaging of underdrawings [8] - [11], or reveal overwritten texts in palimpsests.  Several studies have proposed X-ray image separation approaches [14] - [18]. However, these methods typically apply to double-sided painting panels where, in addition to the mixed X-ray image, researchers have access to RGB images of both the front and back.

This paper addresses a more challenging scenario, where only the mixed X-ray image (Fig. 1b) and a single RGB image of the visible painting (Fig. 1a) are available.  Extracting concealed images from mixed X-rays is complex because these images are two-dimensional representations of three-dimensional artworks.  A single X-ray captures features from both the concealed and surface designs, as well as the support (e.g., canvas weave or wood grain), making it difficult for experts to distinguish elements of the concealed painting (see Fig. 1).

Deep learning features, extracted using deep neural networks trained on extensive datasets [1], differ significantly from handcrafted features like HOG [2] and SIFT [3].  The success of deep learning in computer vision and improved network infrastructure have fueled a growing interest in deep learning feature compression within the Analysis-then-Compress (ATC) paradigm [4].  ATC allows for direct feature extraction at the front-end, transmitting compact feature representations instead of raw video data, contrasting with the Compress-then-Analysis (CTA) paradigm, where videos are compressed before transmission to the cloud for analysis. This advantage has led to widespread research on ATC with both handcrafted and deep learning features to address the challenges of video big data.

Numerous algorithms exist for compact feature representation.  Hash-based models like DBH [5] and vector quantization methods such as PQ [6] and OPQ [7] target compact representation of handcrafted features.  Binary descriptors like BRIEF [8] and USB [9] enable efficient Hamming distance computation.  For deep learning features, approaches include applying video coding principles [10], combining supervised learning with hash compression (DHN) [11], and intermediate deep feature compression [12].

The promise of ATC has driven standardization efforts for compact feature representation.  MPEG's CDVS and CDVA standards define standardized bitstream syntax for interoperability in image/video retrieval.  The ongoing MPEG VCM standardization effort [13, 14] aims for accurate, low-latency, object-oriented analysis based on compact video representation for machine vision. VCM builds upon feature compression advancements and connects compact feature representation with video compression for both machine vision and human perception, as features can be used in diverse machine vision tasks.

Inspired by recent advances in deep learning-based video coding [15], this work proposes further compressing raw deep learning features using deep neural networks.  Our contributions are threefold:

* We introduce an end-to-end coding scheme for compactly representing deep learning features as a latent code, pursuing optimal feature-in-feature representation via rate-distortion optimization.
* We propose a compact feature enhancement method, improving feasibility in feature coding.  This method employs a teacher-student enhancement module at the latent code level, enabling adaptive switching between complex decoding and high bit rate representation.
* We implement this framework using facial features and demonstrate superior rate-accuracy performance compared to popular feature compression schemes.

Tom, a big, unassuming man, walked briskly to class in the early afternoon. He stood a head taller than the other students, his wild hair adding to his height.  He wasn't the sort to pick a fight, though not from any fondness for fighting; he was simply too distracted.  Too distracted for anger, sadness, or even happiness.  The objects of his distraction shifted too rapidly to leave a mark.

This constant state of flux was evident in his hands, always clutching insignificant things: twisted sticks, shining metal bits, old jewelry, pages from unread books.  These adorned his small room in a house near town, testaments to his fleeting fascinations. Today, he carried no bag, only handfuls of papers – drawings, words, and his least favorite: equations.

He looked tired, blue rings settled beneath his blue eyes, like most days. He'd been walking again last night, not returning home until morning.  But his wanderings yielded finds: a page of an old book drifting in a creek, a woman's ring set with a blue stone.

Despite the cool day, a nervous sweat slicked his skin beneath his father's brown corduroy coat. People called it a writer's coat; he tried to ignore them.  Seeing him with his clutched papers, they labeled him a disheveled poet, a designation he hated.  Nothing felt worse than looking the part of a writer without being one.  He dreaded the label of pretender.

Godfrey Zangairai was packing his clothes, preparing to attend a four-day church service in a neighboring village.  This angered his brother, Lovemore, who accused Godfrey of excessive faith in "white-robed churches."

A heated argument ensued, escalating into violence when Lovemore picked up an iron bar and struck Godfrey twice on the head.

La Dégénérescence Maculaire Liée à l’Âge (DMLA) touche 1,5 à 2 millions de Français et représente la première cause de malvoyance après 50 ans.  Les Journées nationales de la macula, organisées de lundi à jeudi, visent à informer le public et à encourager le dépistage, non seulement de la DMLA, mais aussi de la maculopathie diabétique (400.000 cas) et de l'occlusion veineuse rétinienne (moins fréquente).  Ces maladies affectent la macula, zone essentielle de la rétine pour la vision des détails. Un dépistage précoce permet de freiner leur évolution.

La DMLA est la plus répandue de ces affections.  "Elle concerne 8% des plus de 65 ans et 30% des plus de 75 ans : c'est la première cause de cécité dans les pays industrialisés", explique le professeur Eric Souied, chef du service ophtalmologie à l'hôpital intercommunal de Créteil et président de la Fédération France macula.  Le vieillissement de la population laisse présager une augmentation du nombre de patients.

La DMLA ne provoque pas la cécité totale, mais une tache sombre au centre de la vision, gênant les activités quotidiennes comme la lecture, l'écriture ou la reconnaissance des visages. Marie-Jo Simon, 77 ans, a témoigné de son expérience.  À l'automne 2015, elle a perçu des "petits papillons" devant ses yeux, avant l'apparition d'une tache noire.  Initialement attribués à une cataracte, ces symptômes se sont révélés être ceux d'une DMLA. Atteinte à l'œil droit, elle suit un traitement mensuel par injections pour freiner l'évolution de la maladie.  Elle insiste sur l'importance d'un diagnostic rapide en cas de symptômes similaires.  Outre la tache sombre, la vision déformée des lignes droites est un autre symptôme caractéristique.

Ces injections sont efficaces pour la DMLA "humide", la stabilisant dans 95% des cas, selon le professeur Souied. La forme "sèche", en revanche, reste incurable, bien que des recherches sur les cellules souches et les implants rétiniens soient en cours.

OTTAWA -- The constantly shifting rules around social gatherings and outings during the COVID-19 pandemic are leaving many Ottawa residents bewildered.  The Ontario Government’s frequent adjustments to permitted activities have become difficult to track, leaving many feeling lost. As Infection Control Epidemiologist Colin Furness puts it, "I don’t think anyone now can remember what is the appropriate size of a gathering."

This confusion is fueled by what Furness describes as conflicting directions from all levels of government, hindering the fight against COVID-19.  He highlights the seeming contradictions in the rules: "You can be in a store with dozens and dozens of people, and that's ok. But if you know their name then it's a gathering, and a limit applies."  He further points out the inconsistencies: "You can be in a restaurant, as long as it’s nominally six people to a table or a bar, with a couple dozen of your best friends. No one’s wearing a mask. Everyone’s hugging and singing and shouting. And you can do that, we say that's ok. But you can’t do it in your living room. The reality of course is that it's not ok at all."

The recent pause on social circles, limiting close contact to household members, announced by the Ford government on Friday, has only added to the confusion, particularly regarding its application to public spaces. This announcement sparked immediate online reactions.  On Facebook, Leslie McDougall wrote: "Hard to keep up with all the 'rules' when they literally change every day. I’m all for flying by the seat of your pants but this is ridiculous."  Caroline Brisebois echoed this sentiment: "The restrictions do not make sense. No family Thanksgiving but we can put 20-30 kids in a classroom or 70 kids on a bus. We can go to bars and restaurants. No wonder people are fed up!"

Furness believes the solution lies in simplifying the rules: "Do not be in a room with anyone else without a mask, unless you live with them. That’s it. Don’t go to restaurants. Don’t go to bars. Don’t go to gatherings. Don’t do it."  He stresses the need for clear communication from the Ontario Government, advocating for firm rules, not suggestions: "We need to establish what is a rule and call it a rule. Not a suggestion. So things aren’t optional."  He points to Ontario’s top doctor, whom Premier Doug Ford has consistently defended, as the source of this needed clarity: "I’ve come to the conclusion after watching very carefully that Dr. (David) Williams does not understand public health.”

In late September, Ontario capped unmonitored private social gatherings at 10 people indoors and 25 outdoors.  The province has also changed its testing criteria.  In Ottawa, Ottawa Public Health has prioritized online bookings for children and youth at the Brewer Centre, reserving walk-up capacity for urgent situations or those lacking online access.  They also clarified that any child meeting the new screening criteria can return to school, regardless of when they initially fell ill.

The field of fair division explores methods for dividing and allocating resources among agents fairly.  A classic problem within this field, first introduced by Steinhaus [Ste48], is cake-cutting. The "cake" acts as a metaphor for a divisible and heterogeneous resource—one that can be divided arbitrarily, with different parts holding varying values for different agents. Examples include dividing land, time, or other natural resources.  Cake-cutting has been extensively studied in mathematics and economics [BT96, RW98] and, more recently, in computer science [Pro13].

Formally, the cake is represented as the interval [0, 1], and *n* agents possess individual valuation functions (*vᵢ*) assigning values to cake pieces. The goal is to divide the cake into *n* pieces (*A₁*, ..., *Aₙ*) and allocate one piece to each agent fairly.  Steinhaus [Ste48], with Banach and Knaster, initially focused on *proportionality*: an allocation is proportional if *vᵢ(Aᵢ) ≥ vᵢ([0, 1])/n* for all agents *i*.  While proportionality guarantees a fair share, an agent might still prefer another agent's piece.

A stronger fairness notion, *envy-freeness*, addresses this.  An allocation is envy-free if *vᵢ(Aᵢ) ≥ vᵢ(Aⱼ)* for all agents *i, j*. Popularized by Gamow and Stern [GS58], envy-free cake-cutting has been extensively researched. Stromquist [Str80] and Woodall [Woo80] proved the existence of connected (contiguous) envy-free allocations under mild continuity assumptions – meaning each agent receives a single interval, requiring only *n-1* cuts.

While existence is proven via tools like Brouwer's fixed point theorem and Sperner's lemma [Str80, Woo80, Su99], these methods don't provide efficient algorithms.  This poses a practical challenge.  Moving-knife procedures have been proposed [BTZ97], but their informal definitions hinder theoretical analysis.  Recent computer science research has formalized the computational models, yet the complexity of envy-free cake-cutting remains elusive.

This paper examines connected envy-free cake-cutting.  For two agents, the cut-and-choose protocol provides a simple, envy-free solution implementable in the Robertson-Webb query model [WS07]. For three or more agents, finding envy-free allocations using Robertson-Webb queries is impossible [Str08].  Brânzei and Nisan [BN22] suggest studying *ε-envy-free* allocations: *vᵢ(Aᵢ) ≥ vᵢ(Aⱼ) - ε* for all *i, j*.

The increasing interest in extending the generative power of pretrained text-to-image (T2I) models to text-to-video (T2V) generation is evident in recent research [5, 9–12, 14, 20, 27, 33].  Zero-shot T2V methods [10, 12, 14] aim to adapt image diffusion models for video generation without further training, leveraging their ability to generate frame sequences from video text prompts.  However, generating coherent dynamic scenes in videos remains a challenge due to the concise and abstract nature of these prompts.

Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated their capacity to generate layouts for controlling visual modules, particularly image generation models [3, 19, 32]. This suggests the potential for LLMs to interpret complex video prompts and generate fine-grained spatio-temporal layouts for guiding video synthesis.  Generating such layouts for video, however, is more complex, requiring LLMs to understand and depict object movement and transformation over time.

Recent zero-shot T2V research [10, 12] has explored using LLMs to decompose video text into frame-level descriptions, representing individual moments or events within the video to guide image diffusion models towards semantically coherent video generation.  However, these descriptions often capture only basic temporal semantics, lacking the detailed spatio-temporal information necessary for smooth object motion and consistent frame-to-frame coherence.  Furthermore, representing global background movement, crucial for depicting camera motion and creating immersive video experiences [8, 30], adds another layer of complexity.

This paper introduces FlowZero, a novel framework integrating LLMs and image diffusion models to generate temporally coherent videos from text prompts. FlowZero leverages LLMs to analyze and translate the video text prompt into a structured Dynamic Scene Syntax (DSS).  Unlike previous methods that provide only basic semantic descriptions, the DSS includes scene descriptions, foreground object layouts, and background motion patterns.  Foreground layouts consist of a series of bounding boxes defining the spatial arrangement of each frame and tracking changes in object positions and sizes, ensuring coherent object motion and transformation aligned with the text prompt.  Crucially, FlowZero incorporates an iterative self-refinement process to enhance the alignment between generated layouts and textual descriptions, addressing inaccuracies such as spatial and temporal errors.  This process iteratively compares and adjusts the layouts against the text through a feedback loop, ensuring high-fidelity and coherent spatio-temporal layouts.

To enhance temporal coherence and consistency, FlowZero prompts LLMs to predict background motion patterns, which can control global scenes and camera motion.  For example, if the text describes a horse running from right to left, as illustrated in Figure 1 (middle), the LLM predicts a corresponding left-to-right camera motion, enhancing the video's immersiveness [8, 30].  This background motion pattern includes specific directions and speeds.  We introduce motion-guided noise shifting (MNS), which shifts the initial noise of each frame according to the predicted background motion, resulting in smoother video synthesis.

FlowZero represents a significant advancement in zero-shot text-to-video synthesis, leveraging the spatio-temporal planning capabilities of LLMs to generate detailed frame-by-frame syntax. This fusion of technologies within the FlowZero framework enables the generation of temporally coherent and visually appealing videos directly from text prompts.

Our contributions are summarized as follows: We introduce an iterative self-refinement process for improving generated spatio-temporal layouts.

Autonomous vehicles (AVs) hold immense potential, but also present significant safety challenges. While the idea of driverless cars may seem appealing, a critical examination of their potential risks is necessary.  A primary concern revolves around the potential for technology failure and the resulting impact on both occupants and those sharing the road.

Safety is paramount with AVs. Unlike traditional vehicles where human drivers are expected to be alert, AVs demand a shared vigilance.  Current traffic laws are predicated on human control, placing responsibility squarely on the driver.  With AVs, this responsibility becomes more diffuse. While proponents argue that sensors and monitoring systems will prevent accidents, the question remains: what happens when these systems fail? Human drivers are responsible for maintaining their vehicles; however, ensuring the constant, perfect operation of complex AV technology presents a significant challenge.  A driver may not be equipped to diagnose or address a malfunctioning system, potentially leading to catastrophic consequences.

Furthermore, the safety of those outside the AV is a critical concern.  Even with a perfectly functioning AV, the unpredictable actions of other drivers, cyclists, and pedestrians introduce significant risk.  Pedestrians, in particular, are vulnerable as they have no control over the AV's actions.  A malfunctioning sensor or software glitch could lead to pedestrian injuries or fatalities, raising complex questions of liability.  Even minor technical issues could have devastating consequences.

While the convenience of not driving may be attractive, the potential for malfunctions during operation is substantial. Proponents might argue that proper maintenance is the solution. However, ensuring the continuous, flawless performance of a complex technological system is far more challenging than routine car maintenance. A significant concern is the driver's potential inability to recognize or resolve technical issues, leading to unexpected breakdowns or malfunctions.

The allure of autonomous vehicles is undeniable, especially given their potential to alleviate the burden of driving.  However, prioritizing safety and ensuring robust, reliable technology are crucial.  Technology, however sophisticated, is fallible. The potential for failure necessitates a cautious approach to the widespread adoption of AVs.

Driverless cars present several significant challenges that warrant serious consideration before widespread development and adoption.  These concerns, primarily focused on technological reliability, safety implications, and the potential erosion of essential driving skills, collectively suggest that further development should proceed with caution.

The core issue lies in the inherent fallibility of technology.  As any technology can malfunction, driverless cars are susceptible to crashes and system errors. This raises critical questions of liability.  If a technological failure leads to an accident, who bears responsibility – the "driver" or the manufacturer? This legal and ethical grey area remains unresolved. While convenience is a strong selling point for driverless technology, ease of use should not overshadow fundamental safety concerns.

These safety concerns are amplified by the potential for sensor failures, which could lead to collisions.  Furthermore, the widespread adoption of driverless cars could lead to a decline in driving skills among the general population. If driving licenses become unnecessary, the essential knowledge and experience required to operate a vehicle could diminish, potentially creating a dangerous situation in emergencies or if autonomous systems fail.

This lack of knowledge and experience ties directly into the potential for increased societal laziness. While not everyone would become complacent, the convenience of driverless cars could discourage many from actively maintaining their driving skills. This over-reliance on technology could have detrimental consequences in the long run, limiting individual autonomy and potentially hindering responses to unforeseen circumstances.  We should strive to enhance, not diminish, essential life skills.

The article "The Challenge of Exploring Venus" argues that Venus is a worthy pursuit despite its dangers.  However, the author fails to effectively support this claim, instead frequently providing evidence that reinforces the opposite position.

The author primarily focuses on the difficulties and risks associated with exploring Venus.  For example, they state, "it has proved a very challenging place to examine more closely" and "Each previous mission was unmanned, and for good reason, since no spacecraft survived the landing for more than a few hours."  The entire third paragraph further emphasizes these challenges, noting, "These conditions are far more extreme than anything humans encounter on Earth." This accumulation of evidence highlighting the dangers of Venus undermines the author's argument for its exploration.

While the author claims that pursuing the study of Venus is worthwhile, they simultaneously acknowledge the obstacles to obtaining further data.  The author points out, "More importantly, researchers cannot take samples of rock, gas, or anything else, from a distance."  Even the proposed solution of using a blimp-like vehicle to send humans is presented alongside the caveat of "toasty" 170-degree Fahrenheit temperatures.  This again reinforces the difficulties of Venusian exploration, weakening the central argument.

In conclusion, the author's argument that Venus is worth exploring despite the dangers is poorly supported. The provided evidence primarily focuses on the immense challenges and risks involved, essentially supporting the counterargument that exploring Venus is impractical, if not impossible.

The "Face on Mars" has sparked considerable debate. While some believe it's an artificial structure, the scientific consensus points towards a natural landform.  Scientists have presented evidence supporting this conclusion, drawing parallels between the "Face" and geological formations found on Earth, such as those in Idaho's Snake River Plain. The article highlights the resemblance between the Martian feature and terrestrial lava domes, specifically mentioning Middle Butte in Idaho.  High-resolution images captured by advanced cameras further solidify this comparison, reinforcing the natural landform theory.

This resemblance to Earthly formations is a key argument. The article emphasizes the visual similarities between the "Face" and specific locations in Idaho, strengthening the case for it being a lava dome. The detailed photographs provide compelling visual evidence supporting this interpretation.

Few scientists entertain the idea of the "Face" being an alien artifact.  They argue that it lacks the characteristics of an artificially constructed object. While it might bear a superficial resemblance to a human face, scientific evidence does not support this interpretation.  Researchers maintain, with supporting evidence, that it is simply a natural formation.

Despite public speculation about the "Face" resembling a human face, the scientific community remains unconvinced.  Scientists point to evidence supporting their conclusion, including analyses debunking theories about the "Face" being evidence of extraterrestrial life on Mars. The article even mentions how the initial hype surrounding the "Face" was largely fueled by speculation and conspiracy theories.

In conclusion, the prevailing scientific view, supported by considerable evidence, is that the "Face on Mars" is a natural landform.

In "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," the author argues that studying Venus is a worthwhile endeavor despite its inherent dangers.  The author notes a significant interest in Venusian exploration due to the planet's similarities to Earth. However, Venus presents formidable obstacles to close-range study. Its dense atmosphere, scorching temperatures, and crushing atmospheric pressure—far exceeding Earth's—mean no spacecraft has survived on its surface for more than a few hours. This hostile environment makes direct human exploration extremely difficult.

The author effectively supports the argument for studying Venus despite these dangers. Providing compelling evidence and detailed explanations, the author states, "Striving to meet the challenge presented by Venus has value, not only because of the insight to be gained on the planet itself, but also because human curiosity will likely lead us into many equally intimidating endeavors. Our travels on Earth and beyond should not be limited by dangers and doubts but should be expanded to meet the very edges of imagination and innovation." This quote clearly demonstrates the author's well-supported rationale for Venusian exploration.

While Venus remains a perilous destination for human exploration, the potential rewards justify the risks.
