Recognizing vehicle occupants' faces in unconstrained environments, especially through the windshield, presents significant challenges.  Previous research demonstrates that windshield artifacts can severely degrade image quality within the vehicle interior.  Furthermore, images are often captured from a distance and at moderate speeds, reducing available light.  While low-intensity ultraviolet or near-infrared (NIR) illumination could help, tinted windshields, which are increasingly common, block these wavelengths, rendering such solutions ineffective.  Longer exposure times are also impractical due to vehicle motion, as the resulting motion blur significantly impairs face recognition quality.  Additionally, the reflective nature of windshields presents further complications. Reflections reduce light reaching the sensor and introduce unwanted artifacts, including obstructive glare from direct light sources (Figure 1) and superimposed reflections of other objects.

Existing solutions, such as Gatekeeper Security's system, involve flashing visible lights at the driver.  This approach is problematic, creating both driver distraction and potential glare.

To address these challenges non-intrusively, we developed a custom multi-camera imaging system designed to optimize input for deep learning algorithms.  This modular system (Figures 2, 3, and 4) integrates imaging and computational components.  Raw images captured by the system can be processed using any High Dynamic Range (HDR) method to generate refined input for facial recognition software. This paper extends previous work in two key ways. First, we created and annotated a new dataset to train HDR reconstruction models specifically optimized for our hardware. Second, we introduce a novel HDR reconstruction network architecture, MU-Net (Mertens-Unrolled Network), which uses an unrolling technique to model the Mertens-Kautz-Van Reeth HDR algorithm as a neural network.  Finally, to evaluate the end-to-end system performance, we utilize state-of-the-art (SOTA) facial detection and recognition algorithms to assess image capture and HDR reconstruction quality for detecting and identifying faces through windshields of moving vehicles. We also benchmark MU-Net's efficacy against other established classical and deep learning-based HDR methods within the same recognition pipeline.

Driverless cars are poised to revolutionize the automotive industry, offering significant advantages over traditional vehicles.  After reading an article on the subject, I'm convinced that these vehicles will be incredibly helpful and useful in the future.  The article highlighted several key benefits, including increased safety, reduced driver burden, and improved navigation.

One major advantage is the potential for increased safety.  Driverless cars, like those developed by Google, have demonstrated the ability to drive up to half a million miles before being involved in a crash.  This remarkable feat is a testament to the advanced technology that allows these cars to avoid accidents far more effectively than human drivers.  Human error is a leading cause of accidents, and driverless cars promise to drastically reduce accidents by eliminating this factor.

Furthermore, driverless cars significantly reduce the burden on the driver.  Since these cars handle the driving 90% of the time, drivers are free to focus on other tasks, whether it's catching up on work, ensuring their children are safe, or simply relaxing.  While the driver may still need to intervene 10% of the time, the vast majority of the driving experience becomes automated, freeing up the driver's attention and reducing stress.

Navigation is another area where driverless cars excel.  Integrated GPS systems allow drivers to input their destination without the distraction of manipulating a separate device. The car automatically navigates the route, eliminating the worry of getting lost or being late. This feature is particularly beneficial for those who are not confident in their navigation skills or frequently travel to unfamiliar locations.

In conclusion, driverless cars offer a compelling vision of the future of transportation. By handling the majority of the driving tasks, these vehicles enhance safety, reduce driver stress, and simplify navigation.  The ability to drive for extended periods without incident, coupled with the convenience of automated navigation, makes a strong case for the success and widespread adoption of driverless cars.

The upcoming super-middleweight title clash between Chris Eubank Jr. and George Groves promises to be a 2018 highlight, a potential 12-round classic.  Beyond the excitement of Eubank Jr.’s inherited self-belief and blinding hand speed, this fight represents a pivotal moment in the younger Eubank’s career.  As Dr. Samuel Johnson, the great man of letters, wrote nearly 300 years ago: “There must always be a struggle between father and son, while one aims at power and the other at independence.” This struggle is embodied in the Eubanks.

Chris Eubank Sr., a former illustrious double world champion, has been a constant, arguably overbearing, presence in his son’s career.  Much like a Svengali, he has dominated and monitored almost every move his son has made, both inside and outside the ring.  This fight offers Eubank Jr., at 28, the chance to step out of his father's shadow and forge his own identity. He acknowledges this, stating his desire to be recognized as Chris Eubank, not simply Chris Eubank Jr.  A victory over Groves would be a significant step in that direction.

While Eubank Jr. enters the fight as a surprising favorite, endorsed by a 20-10 margin in a Boxing Monthly poll of British professionals, Groves, the reigning WBA super-middleweight champion, presents a formidable challenge.  Groves, making his third title defense, will need his sharp jab and honed defensive skills to weather the early-round onslaught expected from Eubank Jr.  Although Eubank Jr. boasts impressive speed and confidence, his opponents, with the exception of Billy Joe Saunders (who defeated him on points), haven't been of the same caliber as those Groves has faced.

I question Eubank Jr.'s power at this weight.  He might have been better suited staying at middleweight. I doubt he possesses the power to seriously trouble the top super-middleweights.  While Groves has suffered two losses to Carl Froch, including a brutal knockout in their second bout, his size advantage in this fight could be decisive.

Contrary to popular opinion, I believe Groves’s counter-punching and precise timing will carry him to a close but clear points victory.  His size and experience against top-tier competition will ultimately prove too much for Eubank Jr. to overcome.  This fight isn't just about a title; it's about a son's fight for independence and recognition in his own right.

The "Face on Mars" is a fascinating example of how perception can trick us.  A 1976 image of a Martian mesa, taken by the Viking 1 orbiter, appeared to some as a face, sparking speculation about alien civilizations.  However, this resemblance is purely coincidental, a trick of light and shadow captured by a relatively low-resolution camera.  Subsequent images taken in 2001 with significantly improved technology confirmed the formation to be a natural geological feature, a mesa, not unlike those found on Earth.

Just as a random chip might resemble a face or clouds might mimic animals, the initial "Face on Mars" image invited pareidolia—the tendency to see meaningful patterns in random data.  We often have to look twice at something to confirm what we think we see, highlighting the difference between perception and reality.  Magic tricks, for instance, create illusions that appear real but are based on deception. Similarly, the "face" on Mars was an illusion created by the limitations of the early imaging technology.

The argument for alien construction of the "face" lacks evidence.  It's akin to claiming humans built the Grand Canyon or the Rocky Mountains.  These natural formations are products of geological processes, just like the mesa on Mars.  Without proof of alien existence, let alone their involvement, the natural explanation, supported by clear photographic evidence, remains the most plausible.

The idea of aliens sculpting this Martian mesa is ultimately a circular argument.  While speculation is intriguing, it lacks the factual basis that readily supports the geological explanation. The "Face on Mars" serves as a reminder that while initial appearances can be deceiving, a closer look, informed by better data, often reveals a simpler, more grounded truth.

The digital landscape has transformed drastically since the era of mainframes. Your company, like many others, has ridden each wave of technological advancement, from minis and microcomputers to the PC revolution, the dot-com boom with Sparcs, and the rise of databases like DB2, Oracle, and SQL Server. You embraced MPP, explored data cubes, and transitioned data to the intranet and internet.  VMware promised to control server sprawl, yet VM sprawl emerged. SharePoint became a fixture, and the allure of SaaS led you from Siebel to Salesforce.

Now, you're drowning in data. Your mainframe is a fragile relic, your SAN a costly black box offering little insight due to rampant VM and application sprawl.  Millennials advocate for "webscale" solutions like MongoDB, while Hadoop vendors promise magical insights from data lakes, introducing yet another storage technology to manage.

Enough is enough. This year, regain control of your data.  Here are 12 resolutions to guide your data strategy:

1. **Catalog Your Data:**  Knowing what data you possess is the first step. A comprehensive data mapping system is helpful, but the crucial element is a dedicated effort to locate and document all your data assets.

2. **Map Data Use:** Understand how your data is used by applications and its flow within the organization. Tracking data lineage and dependency, whether through software or manual effort, is vital.  Identify why data is kept, who uses it, and for what purpose. Define the data, its source system, and its usage.

3. **Understand Data Creation:**  Just as NASA’s reliance on incomplete data led to critical errors, understanding your data's origins is crucial. How are numbers derived?  This is an ongoing process, as new data sources constantly emerge, but it's essential for preventing avoidable disasters.

4. **Understand Data Flow:**  Mapping your organization’s data circulatory system—a comprehensive data flow diagram—is essential. This reveals inefficiencies ("black holes" and "miracles"), redundancies, and opportunities for optimization.  It also highlights where similar processes differ solely by technology stack, allowing for standardization.

5. **Automate Manual Processes:** Manual data manipulation in spreadsheets introduces latency and errors. By mapping your data flow, you can identify these manual processes and automate them, improving efficiency and accuracy.

6. **Embrace Machine Learning:**  Machine learning isn't magic, but it can automate pattern recognition and analysis. Identify at least one business process where machine learning can provide a demonstrable advantage. This is a practical step towards leveraging the power of data.

7. **Prioritize Natural Language and Voice Search:**  The future of data interaction is natural language and voice.  Making your data accessible through these modalities is no longer a luxury but a necessity to cater to evolving user expectations.

8. **Embrace Web Accessibility:**  Shift away from cumbersome desktop software.  Web-based applications offer greater flexibility, easier maintenance, and accessibility from anywhere.

9. **Prioritize Mobile Accessibility:**  Desktop computing is declining.  Ensure your data and applications are accessible on mobile devices to support the increasingly mobile workforce.

10. **Ensure High Availability and Distributability:**  Resilience is key.  Modern distributed databases designed for the cloud offer better uptime, scalability, and more affordable disaster recovery than traditional solutions.

11. **Consolidate Systems:** Simplify your IT infrastructure by consolidating redundant systems. This reduces complexity, maintenance costs, and improves overall efficiency.  While the business case may be challenging, the long-term benefits are significant.

12. **Visualize Data:**  Charts and visualizations make data more accessible and understandable.  Leverage visualization tools to communicate insights effectively.


By adopting these resolutions, you can transform IT from a cost center to a strategic asset, building a data-driven future for your organization.

**Maíz temprano revierte síntomas de sequía**

Las precipitaciones de las últimas semanas resultaron suficientes para mitigar los efectos del déficit hídrico que comenzaba a afectar al maíz temprano. La mayoría de los lotes presentan un estado de bueno a excelente.  Las lluvias registradas durante aproximadamente 20 días revirtieron la sequía y los primeros síntomas de déficit hídrico, generando un escenario favorable para el crecimiento y desarrollo normal de los cultivos, según informó el Sistema de Estimaciones Agrícolas de la Bolsa de Comercio de Santa Fe.  Tanto la floración como la etapa reproductiva comenzaron con buena a muy buena disponibilidad de agua en el suelo.  No se detectaron plagas ni enfermedades.  Persiste la presencia de sorgo de alepo ( *Sorghum halepense* ) en algunos lotes, debido a que la sequía previa dificultó los controles, aunque las últimas lluvias permitieron retomarlos.

**Trigo: cosecha al 78%**

La cosecha de trigo alcanzó el 78% de avance, abarcando aproximadamente 271.830 hectáreas, con un progreso del 10% en la última semana.  Los rendimientos se mantienen heterogéneos e irregulares, consolidando la caída previamente informada. Se estima un rendimiento promedio de 17 a 18 qq/ha en el centro-norte provincial para la campaña 2020, una disminución de 16 a 17 qq/ha respecto al ciclo anterior (34,25 qq/ha).  Las parcelas aún sin cosechar presentan un importante crecimiento de malezas debido a las lluvias. Se evalúa su recolección y, mientras tanto, se realizan aplicaciones de herbicidas para control y facilitar la eventual trilla o la implantación de otro cultivo.

**Girasol en buen estado general**

Tras los días inestables, el girasol continúa su ciclo con normalidad, mostrando un buen estado general gracias a la humedad del suelo que permite un desarrollo adecuado. Los lotes previamente afectados por el estrés hídrico presentan plantas menos desarrolladas, con capítulos de menor tamaño.  Se observa buena sanidad, aunque en lotes más avanzados, en etapa de fructificación, persisten los daños por palomas y cotorras.

**Algodón: 80% de implantación**

El algodón mantiene un crecimiento y desarrollo adecuados, con buena humedad en el suelo.  Los pocos lotes afectados por el temporal que no logren recuperarse cambiarán su destino. El estado general de los cultivos es de bueno a muy bueno, con un stand de plantas adecuado. La implantación alcanzó el 80%, cubriendo 40.800 hectáreas sobre una intención de siembra de 51.000 ha, un avance del 10% en la última semana.  Continúa el monitoreo de trampas y la prevención del picudo, con aplicaciones en los bordes según necesidad.

**Soja tardía: 25% de avance en la siembra**

La siembra de soja tardía avanzó al 25%, cubriendo 137.500 hectáreas, manteniendo un buen ritmo gracias a la humedad del suelo.  Se estima una intención de siembra de 550.000 hectáreas, un 2% superior a la campaña 2019/2020 (538.500 ha). Los primeros lotes implantados muestran buena germinación y emergencia, y se están realizando aplicaciones de herbicidas post-emergentes para el control de malezas.

My alarm buzzed, and I groaned, instinctively slapping for the snooze button. I missed, sending the clock clattering to the floor, where it flipped to FM radio.  Now, I had blaring Spanish music *and* no more sleep.  I wiped the sleep from my eyes and slowly opened them.

Then, I saw it. A giant floating head stared down at me.  Have you ever woken up to that? No? Well, it’s… unsettling.  Let’s just say it startled me.

The giant head sniffed the air. “Oh my god, did you really just shit yourself?! AHAHA!”

So, here's another question: Have you ever been mocked by a giant floating head for an accident it *caused*? I’m going to assume you haven’t.

“WHAAGGHFUCK,” I sputtered, still trying to process the situation.

The head, if it could, would have been doubled over with laughter. “Oh man, this is great.”

Mortified, I scrambled to the bathroom, clutching my backside as the head roared with laughter.  I cleaned up as best I could and wrapped a towel around myself. The head, meanwhile, had drifted over to my TV, poking around with what I can only describe as ethereal curiosity. It turned its attention back to me.

“I didn’t realize the human race was so inferior that they actually based their lives around technology! I mean look at this thing. What are you supposed to do with this? Stare at it?”  It floated over to my still-blaring alarm clock. “And this thing is very loud and annoying.”  Lasers shot from its eyes, leaving a scorched mark on the floor.

“Look, mister… uhm… Head. I’m not sure what you are or what you’re doing here—”

“That is *Captain* Head to you. I am on an important mission to determine the human race’s progress and see if they are ready to join the galactic unity.”  He drifted uncomfortably close. “So far I am less than impressed.”

Okay.  An alien was in my room, and the fate of humanity rested on my shoulders.  Mom always said I’d screw up big one day. Captain Head lifted my phone with some sort of telekinesis and began scrolling through it… without thumbs.

“This is an interesting device though. Apps, huh? Reddit, Grindr… OH! Now *this* is an impressive app. Facebook! That sounds right up my alley.”

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10 (Reuters) – Snapchat, the mobile messaging company, blamed third-party software applications for potential security lapses that may have exposed users' private photos to online publication by hackers.

"We can confirm that Snapchat servers were never breached and were not the source of these leaks," the company said in an emailed statement on Friday.

Business Insider reported on Friday that hackers had amassed a file containing at least 100,000 Snapchat photos and were preparing to publish them online. Snapchat allows users to send photos and videos that automatically disappear after a few seconds.

Snapchat stated that its users were "allegedly victimized by their use of third-party apps to send and receive Snaps, a practice expressly prohibited in our terms of use precisely because it compromises user security."

A Snapchat representative noted that the company's statement was based solely on media reports of the leaked photos.  The company could not verify whether hackers had actually breached any third-party software containing stolen Snapchat photos.

Snapchat is particularly popular with teenagers, and some media reports expressed concern that the hackers' file could contain nude "selfie" pictures of teens who believed the photos would be deleted shortly after being sent.

Reuters could not verify whether any Snapchat photos were posted online.

According to Business Insider, hackers may have obtained the photos by breaching the servers of third-party services that allow users to save Snapchat photos.  The report indicated that users of the online file-sharing forum 4Chan had downloaded the files and were creating a searchable database of the stolen photos.

The leaked photos could be particularly damaging for Snapchat, a privately held company already facing criticism for its privacy practices.  The company is currently in the process of raising funds in a round that media reports suggest would value it at $10 billion.

This potential release of private Snapchat photos follows shortly after nude pictures of actress Jennifer Lawrence and images purportedly of dozens of other female actresses were posted on 4Chan.  Media reports attributed those leaks to hacked Apple iCloud accounts.

Los Angeles-based Snapchat is among a new wave of popular mobile apps competing with established internet services like Twitter and Facebook.

In May, Snapchat settled charges with U.S. regulators who accused the company of deceiving customers by promising that photos on its service disappeared permanently.  The Federal Trade Commission stated that Snapchat photos could be saved by recipients using various methods.

(Reporting by Alexei Oreskovic; editing by Matthew Lewis)

The idea of driverless cars presents both intriguing advantages and serious concerns. While the technology offers potential benefits, significant safety issues remain to be addressed.

On the positive side, driverless cars could offer increased convenience.  Commuters could relax, catch up on work, or even retrieve dropped items without the stress of managing the vehicle.  The ability to multitask during a commute could be particularly appealing for busy individuals.  Furthermore, in theory, driverless cars could mitigate the risks associated with human error, such as distracted or impaired driving.

However, the safety and reliability of these vehicles are still in question.  What happens if the communication system fails and the driver is not alerted to take control?  The possibility of a system malfunction leading to loss of control is a serious concern.  Furthermore, dependence on technology raises questions about cybersecurity vulnerabilities and the potential for hacking or malicious control.

My personal reservations stem from these safety uncertainties.  I would feel uncomfortable relinquishing control to a computer, especially with others in the vehicle.  While proponents may argue that driverless cars have a clean accident record, this doesn't guarantee future safety.  Unforeseen circumstances, software glitches, or hardware failures could lead to accidents.  The reliance on charging also introduces the possibility of power failures leaving drivers stranded.

Ultimately, while the concept of driverless cars offers a futuristic vision of transportation,  I remain skeptical.  The potential risks and unresolved safety concerns outweigh the perceived conveniences, at least for now.  Until these issues are adequately addressed, I would be hesitant to embrace this technology.

Blockchain technologies have recently garnered significant attention due to their decentralized and scalable nature. Bitcoin and Ethereum are prominent examples. Bitcoin, a blockchain-based cryptocurrency system introduced by Satoshi Nakamoto in 2008 [1, 2], facilitates trading via a peer-to-peer network secured with SHA-256 encryption.  Every node participating in the blockchain stores all transactions in a Merkle tree data structure. Bitcoin addresses the double-spending problem using a Proof-of-Work (PoW) consensus algorithm for block generation. Ethereum, a distributed computing platform based on blockchain developed by Vitalik Buterin in 2015, also stores all transactions on every node, similar to Bitcoin. However, Ethereum extends functionality beyond cryptocurrency trading by enabling the execution of applications on the blockchain using smart contracts. This versatility allows Ethereum to be applied across various domains, including social networking, email, and gaming.

This paper introduces Koa, a new programming language designed to simplify the development of scalable blockchain systems. Koa addresses the challenges posed by Bitcoin's script language, which, due to its low-level instruction-based nature, hinders code comprehension and analysis.  The sequential nature of the script language makes it difficult to grasp code flow. Implementing complex logic is also cumbersome. For instance, expressing conditional branching in the script language lacks clear delineation between the condition evaluation, true execution path, and false execution path.  Furthermore, the purpose of individual instructions can be obscure. The verification process, which involves sequentially executing unlocking and locking scripts, is difficult to interpret semantically.  Implementing scripts also requires careful management of the stack, adding further complexity.  Koa, with its function definitions, provides clear semantic units, enhancing readability. While verifying a value in script might require defining a new instruction or assembling numerous instructions, Koa simplifies this process by using a combination of supported operators. Consequently, Koa offers improved readability and ease of use compared to script languages.

Solidity, the smart contract language for Ethereum, introduces the concept of "gas," a transaction fee mechanism used to prevent infinite loop attacks.  However, gas adds complexity to Solidity code and impacts usability.  Furthermore, Ethereum's statefulness complicates static analysis of Solidity code.  The state-dependent nature of function execution makes gas consumption prediction challenging.  In contrast, Koa's stateless nature facilitates static analysis.  The absence of state-dependent code branches and loops simplifies code analysis and inherently prevents infinite loop attacks.  This allows for predictable cost estimation in Koa.  Therefore, Koa, as a high-level language, empowers programmers to develop blockchain applications more quickly and efficiently.

Saint Peter cracked a smile, neither good nor wicked, and let the silence hang heavy between the three figures. "So that's how it is then? Only one of us?" the Atheist finally asked.

"Clearly *I* should be let in," the Atheist quipped. "The Satanist is the exact opposite of what you want in here."

The Satanist glared at the Atheist. "At least I knew of God's existence and, in a way, feared it. Even I admire some of his work!"

Saint Peter's smile widened slightly, then, as if catching himself, shriveled back into a more neutral expression. "He brings up a good point, Atheist. You don't even believe in God."  He flipped some parchments over on his giant podium, the gesture punctuating his statement.

The Atheist shrugged. "Fine, I believe *now*. I can change. I don't think the Satanist would be so quick to follow God though…"

"No, I can!" the Satanist interjected. "I don't know why they sent me up here, but I *can* be good now. I've caused enough pain."

Saint Peter raised a long arm and stroked his beard as he peered at the two men.  A long sigh finally escaped him, stirring the air around them. "Listen up," he said. "I'll cut you guys a break, just this once. You can both pass."

With a groan of ancient mechanisms, the giant gates roared to life and glided open.

My name is Luke. In 1945, when I was 17, my friend Don offered me a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to become a "Seagoing Cowboy."  I jumped at the chance.  A year later, I enlisted in the army.

Being a Seagoing Cowboy was hard work.  During the crossings, we cared for the animals day and night, hauling heavy bags of oats and hay and watering them two or three times a day.  It was demanding, but also a valuable experience. By the time I was discharged in 1947, I had completed nine trips – more than anyone else!

Despite the hard work, there were plenty of good times. After delivering the animals, we'd use their stalls for games like baseball, volleyball, table tennis, boxing, fencing, and even whittling.

All that hard work and time paid off in the form of incredible travel opportunities.  I saw the Acropolis in Greece, experienced the wonders of Europe and China, rode a gondola through the watery streets of Venice, Italy, explored an excavated castle in Crete, and marveled at the Panama Canal on my way to China.

My experience as a Seagoing Cowboy was unforgettable.  To any young people considering this unique opportunity, I highly recommend it.  You might have similar experiences to mine, or perhaps you'll journey to even bigger and better places than I ever dreamed of.

Driverless cars offer significant potential benefits, warranting continued research and development. Their promise lies in enhanced safety, increased efficiency, and a less intensive driving experience.

Safety is a paramount concern, and driverless cars offer several advantages in this area.  Many current vehicles, both driverless and those with drivers, incorporate features designed to detect and respond to traffic hazards.  For instance, as highlighted later, BMW is developing a car with advanced steering, acceleration, and braking capabilities. While not yet fully autonomous, these developments pave the way for a future where driverless cars can significantly reduce accidents.  Furthermore, the potential for driverless cars to communicate with each other via GPS could prevent collisions by enabling them to anticipate and avoid each other's movements.

Efficiency is another key benefit.  A driverless car equipped with GPS could identify the fastest and most fuel-efficient routes, optimizing travel time and resource consumption.  Moreover, sophisticated onboard computers could make real-time decisions about fuel conservation, such as determining whether to turn off the engine during idle periods.  These "smart" systems could also minimize wear and tear on components like brakes and tires by calculating optimal braking distances and durations.

Finally, driverless cars could revolutionize the driving experience itself.  Current drivers must maintain constant vigilance and awareness of their surroundings.  However, with the advanced safety features discussed earlier, driverless cars could alleviate this burden, allowing drivers to focus on other tasks or passengers, thereby reducing stress and fatigue.

Driverless cars, once a futuristic fantasy, are rapidly becoming a reality. Companies like Google, active in this field since 2009, and BMW are pushing the boundaries of autonomous driving technology.  This exciting development, however, raises crucial questions.  Is relinquishing control to a machine truly the best course of action?  Could it create more problems than it solves?  These critical questions demand careful consideration.

One key concern revolves around safety and liability.  BMW's "Traffic Jam Assistant," developed in 2013, allows vehicles to handle driving functions up to 25 mph.  However, even in these limited circumstances, the driver must remain vigilant and ready to intervene.  In complex situations like work zones or accidents, human control remains essential.  Consider a pedestrian unexpectedly crossing the street: a human driver can react instinctively, while an autonomous vehicle might struggle to process the unpredictable human element, potentially leading to an accident.  The current legal framework assigns blame based on who initiates a collision.  If an autonomous vehicle is involved, determining liability becomes complex.  Is the driver at fault, or is the supposedly infallible machine to blame?  Entrusting a machine with human lives requires careful consideration beyond the allure of convenience.

The financial and experiential costs are also significant.  Over-reliance on autonomous vehicles could erode driving skills, leaving drivers less alert and less capable of handling unexpected situations.  While some argue that warning signals prompt drivers to retake control, the time allowed may be insufficient to fully assess and react to complex scenarios. This poses a particular danger to new drivers.  Furthermore, the "cars of the future" come with a hefty price tag, offering only partial autonomy at exorbitant cost.

Looking further down the road, widespread adoption of autonomous vehicles would necessitate a complete overhaul of our current infrastructure.  Replacing existing roads with "smart roads" is a monumental undertaking, both in terms of time and expense.  While proponents tout the safety benefits of autonomous vehicles, the reality is that software and sensor failures can occur.  No one wants to be injured or killed due to an error by a driverless car.

While autonomous vehicles offer potential benefits, such as reduced fuel consumption and potentially improved traffic flow, these advantages must be weighed against the considerable challenges.  The transition to a driverless future requires careful consideration of safety, liability, cost, and infrastructure.  Only then can we determine whether the human or the car will ultimately take the wheel. The development of driverless cars continues, but their widespread adoption hinges on addressing these critical issues and developing solutions that outweigh the potential problems. It remains to be seen whether these vehicles will live up to their promise or become another costly technological experiment.

Estudios específicos muestran cambios cerebrales que pueden indicar la presencia de Alzheimer hasta dos décadas antes de la manifestación de síntomas, afirmó el neurólogo argentino Ricardo Allegri.  Esta enfermedad, según la Organización Mundial de la Salud (OMS), cuadruplicará la cantidad de casos en Argentina y América Latina para 2050.

"Un estudio internacional reveló un subtipo de la enfermedad que produce cambios químicos cerebrales detectables hasta 20 años antes de la aparición de los síntomas", explicó el Dr. Allegri, jefe de Neurología Cognitiva, Neuropsiquiatría y Neuropsicología de la Fundación Fleni en Buenos Aires.

Fleni es el único centro de salud argentino que participa en una investigación internacional, coordinada por la Universidad de Washington, sobre la forma hereditaria del Alzheimer. Iniciada en 2008, la investigación entra en su segunda fase, las pruebas farmacológicas, lideradas por Fleni.

El objetivo es estudiar la variante "autosómica dominante" (ADAD), que representa alrededor del 1% de los casos de Alzheimer.  Si bien es un porcentaje pequeño, constituye un buen modelo de estudio "cuyos resultados pueden extrapolarse a la variante más común".  La importancia de estudiar estos pacientes radica en que "el desarrollo de la enfermedad es estereotipado y previsible, a diferencia de los casos esporádicos", destacaron los especialistas.

"Cada hijo de un progenitor con ADAD tiene un 50% de probabilidad de heredar la mutación.  Si la hereda, desarrollará Alzheimer aproximadamente a la misma edad que su progenitor, casi siempre antes de los 60 años", explicó Allegri.

El biomarcador que puede anticipar la enfermedad dos décadas es el amiloide (A), detectable mediante PET cerebral con marcación amiloide (PiB) y la medición de Aβ42 en líquido cefalorraquídeo. Otros marcadores, con una anticipación de diez años, son la medición de fosfo-tau en líquido cefalorraquídeo y el PET cerebral con marcación tau.

Estudios epidemiológicos en América Latina indican que el Alzheimer es el tipo de demencia más frecuente. En Argentina, se estima que cerca de 600 mil personas viven con la enfermedad, más de 20 mil de ellas menores de 65 años.  La OMS proyecta que el número de afectados se cuadruplicará entre 2015 y 2050.

"La población latinoamericana envejece rápidamente, y la edad es el mayor factor de riesgo.  Por eso es crucial aumentar los recursos para la investigación", afirmó María Carrillo, directora ejecutiva de Ciencias, Medicina y Relaciones Científicas de la Alzheimer's Association de Chicago.

A fine-grain analysis of motion is crucial for various video-related applications, including frame interpolation, inpainting, motion segmentation, compression, future prediction, and editing [1, 27, 34, 37, 39, 40, 44, 65, 69, 70, 74].  Traditional systems typically rely on optical flow algorithms [18, 59, 60], but these methods struggle with large motions or occlusions [19] due to their limited temporal context, relying only on a few neighboring frames.  Lately, point tracking methods [16, 17, 22, 33, 72] have emerged as a promising alternative, often capable of tracking points across numerous frames, even with occlusions, maintaining over 50% of initial queries after thousands of frames [72].  However, the computational cost of tracking every pixel individually has hindered their widespread adoption as a replacement for optical flow.

This inefficiency stems from the independent processing of individual tracks [16, 17, 22, 72].  Furthermore, as highlighted by Karaev et al. [33] in their CoTracker approach, tracking points independently neglects valuable spatial context.  While CoTracker tracks multiple points together to leverage trajectory correlations, performance can suffer when the number of simultaneous tracks becomes excessive, limiting the feasibility of achieving both speed and accuracy.

Our work addresses these limitations.  We introduce DOT (Figure 1), a novel approach that bridges the gap between optical flow and point tracking, combining the spatial coherence of the former with the temporal consistency of the latter.  From a small set of tracks (represented in white), DOT predicts dense motions (visualized with distinct colors) and occlusions (shown with stripes) between arbitrary frames.

Our contributions are threefold:

* We propose DOT, a simple and efficient method that unifies point tracking and optical flow.  It uses a sparse set of tracks to predict dense flow fields and visibility masks between any two frames.
* We expand the CVO benchmark [64] with 500 new videos containing longer sequences and higher frame rates to present more challenging motion scenarios and better evaluate dense, long-term tracking.
* Extensive experiments on the CVO and TAP benchmarks [16, 64], with quantitative and qualitative results, demonstrate that DOT significantly outperforms state-of-the-art optical flow methods, achieves performance on par with or better than leading point tracking algorithms, and offers a substantial speed advantage (×100) for dense prediction.

Interrogé vendredi sur Europe 1 au sujet du ralliement de Jean-Yves Le Drian à Emmanuel Macron, le candidat socialiste à l'élection présidentielle, Benoît Hamon, a déclaré ne pas s'être "attendu à autant de trahisons".  "Je ne m'attendais pas à ce qu'il y ait autant de trahisons", a-t-il insisté. "Ce sont des trahisons, non pas de moi – je ne demande rien –, mais d'une histoire, de valeurs que nous représentons, de la place qui doit être celle de la gauche."

Il a ensuite regretté que "dans une élection, on respecte le verdict d’une élection, on respecte la parole donnée",  avant d'ajouter: "Aujourd’hui beaucoup oublient les principes les plus élémentaires".  A la question de savoir s'il en voulait à M. Le Drian, M. Hamon a répondu: "Je ne lui en veux pas parce que je n’attendais rien de lui".

M. Hamon a poursuivi en affirmant: "Il y a deux gauches aujourd’hui en France vis-à-vis desquelles je veux prendre mes distances."  Il a d'abord visé Emmanuel Macron:  "Celle qui, pour gouverner, renonce à être de gauche et qui demain, pour gouverner, pourrait, comme je l’entends chez certains, baisser l’ISF, augmenter la pression sur les chômeurs, baisser le nombre de fonctionnaires, faciliter le licenciement… ça, ce n’est pas la gauche. Et si pour garder le pouvoir ou exercer le pouvoir, il faut faire cela, moi je ne le ferai pas."

Puis, il s'en est pris à Jean-Luc Mélenchon:  "Et puis, il y a une autre gauche qui renonce au pouvoir pour être de gauche et qui dit +dégagez tous+."

Graph neural networks (GNNs) are the state-of-the-art approach to molecular property prediction (Duvenaud et al., 2015; Gilmer et al., 2017; Wu et al., 2018; Yang et al., 2019). A GNN operates on a molecule's graph structure in two phases: a message passing phase, where a molecular representation is learned by exchanging messages between atom or bond states, and a readout phase, where a feed forward network (FFN) converts this representation into a prediction.

The specific challenges of molecular property prediction align well with the potential advantages of Bayesian learning.  In cheminformatics, generalization is hampered by the concept of a molecular scaffold – the core structure to which functional groups attach. Highly parameterized GNNs are prone to overfitting to training scaffolds, resulting in a poor molecular representation and hindering generalization to test data (Yang et al., 2019).  Furthermore, models risk producing overconfident predictions on new scaffolds, masking the uncertainty inherent in exploring new chemical spaces. This poorly quantified uncertainty makes it difficult to evaluate model robustness and applicability to out-of-domain data (Hirschfeld et al., 2020).  We believe Bayesian modeling offers the best solution to these challenges. Unlike classical neural networks that commit to a single hypothesis, a Bayesian approach constructs a predictive distribution by considering all possible parameter settings.  Bayesian marginalization can improve both the calibration (Maddox et al., 2019) and accuracy (Izmailov et al., 2019) of deep neural networks trained on limited data.


Related work has explored these issues.  Hirschfeld et al. (2020) benchmarked uncertainty quantification methods for molecular property prediction using the same GNN architecture we employ. While they found no consistently superior method, replacing the readout phase with a Gaussian process (GP) or random forest yielded reasonable performance.

Fashion, a cornerstone of human experience, has burgeoned into a multi-hundred-billion-dollar industry in the US alone.  The rise of online shopping has fueled a demand for sophisticated fashion-understanding systems, particularly for outfit recommendation.  Recent years have witnessed significant progress in fashion-related research, encompassing clothing attribute prediction, landmark detection [11, 21], fashion recommendation [5, 8, 24], clothing item retrieval [10, 22], clothing parsing [1, 4], and outfit recommendation [2, 7, 12, 19].

This paper focuses on outfit recommendation. An outfit comprises items from various fine-grained categories (e.g., sweater, jeans, boots, school bag) that exhibit visual aesthetic harmony.  Effective outfit recommendation necessitates learning compatibility [2, 3, 13, 19, 20]—how multiple visual items interact—rather than simply identifying similarity between individual items.

Existing outfit recommendation approaches fall into three main categories.  The first [7, 13] treats an outfit as a set, training a binary classifier to determine outfit compatibility based on concatenated item features (Figure 1a).  Due to the limitations of simple concatenation in modeling inter-item relationships, this approach generally yields the poorest performance.  The second [3, 20] minimizes the sum of distances between all item pairs in a compatibility space (Figure 1b).  This approach often suffers from the "ill-triangle" problem: two incompatible items might be deemed compatible if both are compatible with a third item. While an extension [19] incorporates "type" information, it requires learning type embedding matrices for every type pair, incurring an inefficient O(n²) time complexity for *n* clothing types.  The third approach [2, 14] treats an outfit as a predefined item sequence (Figure 1c), modeling compatibility with an order-dependent LSTM.  Performance degrades significantly when the outfit order changes.  Furthermore, existing systems often prioritize visual aesthetics and metadata like item descriptions. While useful for describing image features, this metadata is less effective for compatibility learning.  Coarse category information (e.g., tops, bottoms, shoes) is used to define sequential outfits [2, 14], with each timestep corresponding to a predefined coarse category.  Training solely on coarse or fine categories lacks flexibility, as a query item's category might be coarse while the model is trained on fine categories.  The literature lacks consideration for both category types.  To meet customer needs, both fine-grained and coarse categories are essential. For example, two customers with the same T-shirt might prefer different pants (jeans or sweatpants) rather than simply a "bottom."  Conversely, a customer with a T-shirt might desire any type of "bottom."  To incorporate both category types into compatibility learning and enhance recommendation flexibility, we introduce the concept of a *tuple*: a fashion item paired with its category (coarse or fine).  Consequently, we extend item compatibility learning to tuple compatibility learning.

To facilitate tuple compatibility learning and address existing limitations, we propose the Mixed Category Attention Net (MCAN). MCAN treats an outfit as a combination of item-category tuples and learns their compatibility.  Given a partial tuple sequence, MCAN predicts the next item via an integrated Item Prediction Layer (IPL). If the next category is specified, the predicted item will belong to that category; otherwise, a Category Prediction Layer (CPL) predicts the next category. By incorporating category sequences, MCAN offers versatile recommendation capabilities.

The safety of driverless cars is a serious concern. While proponents tout their potential benefits, the risks associated with their widespread adoption warrant careful consideration.  Are they truly worth the potential dangers?  I believe relying solely on automated systems could introduce new hazards, even surpassing the risks posed by human error. Imagine a self-operating vehicle navigating complex scenarios; the potential for unforeseen issues is vast.

One key concern revolves around the handover of control.  As described, these vehicles can handle routine driving tasks, but they are designed to alert the human driver when complex situations arise, such as navigating construction zones or accidents.  This requires the driver to remain vigilant and ready to assume control instantly.  However, human drivers are notoriously prone to distraction – texting, phone calls, and adjusting the radio are common occurrences.  What happens when a driverless car requires human intervention, but the driver is inattentive?  The consequences could be catastrophic, leading to accidents and potentially fatalities.

Furthermore, the question of liability in accidents involving driverless cars remains complex.  Even with potential changes to driving laws, determining fault in the event of a technology failure will be challenging.  If the system fails to alert the driver, resulting in injury, who is to blame: the driver who should have been paying attention, or the manufacturer responsible for the faulty technology?  Both parties bear some responsibility, creating a legal gray area.

L'homme, Ferdinand Aouri, n'est pas un inconnu de la justice : condamné pour meurtre par le passé, il avait été libéré huit mois seulement avant l'agression sauvage de Laura.  Cette lycéenne discrète et sans histoire a été poignardée à 400 mètres du domicile familial.

Ferdinand Aouri, habitant la région de Lens et sans emploi, a un lourd casier judiciaire. Il a passé quasiment la moitié de sa vie en prison pour meurtre, escroquerie et vol, entre autres.  "J'ai planté une jeune fille au cou", aurait-il confié à ses proches, un soir, alors qu'il était couvert de sang. Ce sont ces mêmes proches qui l'ont dénoncé.  Arrêté en février dernier pour non-respect de son contrôle judiciaire et violence conjugale, son ADN, retrouvé sur les lunettes de la victime, l’a confondu.  Il nie toute implication dans le meurtre de Laura Bernard.

L'enquête a été ralentie par le confinement.  "En matière de police technique et scientifique, il fallait attendre un certain nombre de résultats et pendant le confinement l'enquête a bien évidemment continué mais il y a quelque chose qui ne pouvait pas être fait, ce sont les auditions", explique Romuald Muller, directeur du service régional de police judiciaire. "On savait qu'il était détenu, il n'y avait pas de risque de récidive dans l'immédiat."  Il aura donc fallu attendre la fin du confinement pour voir aboutir les investigations.

Aux États-Unis, le plan de réformes sociales de Biden franchit une étape cruciale au Congrès

Les députés américains ont adopté vendredi le projet d’investissement de 1 800 milliards de dollars du président américain. Le Sénat doit désormais se prononcer.

Le gigantesque plan de réformes sociales du président Joe Biden a été adopté vendredi par la Chambre des représentants, une victoire d’étape cruciale avant son examen, qui s’annonce difficile, au Sénat.

**Un texte historique**

Baptisé « Build Back Better » (Reconstruire en mieux), ce plan social et environnemental de 1 800 milliards de dollars prévoit notamment la maternelle pour tous, des crédits d’impôt pour les foyers américains et des investissements conséquents pour réduire les émissions de gaz à effet de serre.

Ce vote intervient trois jours après la signature par le président démocrate du premier volet de son vaste plan économique : la loi sur les infrastructures, le plus important programme de travaux publics aux États-Unis depuis la création du réseau autoroute inter-États par Dwight Eisenhower en 1956.

Prochaine étape pour le plan « Build Back Better » : le Sénat, où son adoption s’annonce difficile, avant un retour à la Chambre des représentants, probablement en décembre ou janvier.

« Nous avons un texte “Build Back Better” historique, porteur de transformations et plus important que tout ce que nous avons fait auparavant », a déclaré la présidente démocrate de la Chambre des représentants, Nancy Pelosi, avant le vote.

Prévu initialement jeudi soir, le vote a été retardé par le leader républicain à la Chambre basse, Kevin McCarthy, qui a prononcé un discours-fleuve de plus de huit heures, profitant d’une règle autorisant les chefs de parti à parler sans limite de temps.

**Des millions d’emplois**

Juste avant de subir une coloscopie, le président Joe Biden a appelé Nancy Pelosi vendredi matin « afin de la féliciter pour l’adoption de “Build Back Better” », a tweeté la porte-parole de la Maison Blanche, Jen Psaki.

La Maison Blanche promet que les ambitieuses réformes du plan « Build Back Better » créeront des millions d’emplois, tandis que les républicains y voient une illustration de ce qu’ils dénoncent comme la folie dépensière de leurs adversaires démocrates.

Ce texte « réduira le déficit de plus de 100 milliards de dollars sur dix ans », a assuré Joe Biden, promettant qu’il permettra de « baisser les coûts, créer des emplois et reconstruire notre économie ».

Mais le chemin reste long avant son adoption, d’autant qu’il sera certainement amendé par le Sénat.  Cette chambre étant parfaitement divisée (50 élus pour chaque camp), chaque démocrate, ou affilié, dispose de facto d’un droit de veto sur tout projet de loi si les républicains font bloc.  Or, les centristes ne cachent pas leurs inquiétudes quant aux dépenses prévues.

Facial Action Coding System (FACS) is a new technology designed to identify emotions. Developed by Dr. Paul Ekman, FACS classifies six basic emotions: happiness, surprise, anger, disgust, fear, and sadness.  Each emotion is associated with characteristic facial muscle movements.

This technology is now being implemented in schools. A classroom computer equipped with FACS could recognize when a student is confused or bored, then modify the lesson, much like an effective human instructor.  This application seems promising for students who are hesitant to communicate with their teachers.  However, there are potential downsides.

One concern is the possibility of the computer misinterpreting a student's facial expressions, leading to the delivery of incorrect or irrelevant information.  The cost of implementing such technology is also a significant factor.  Perhaps the most serious concern is the potential displacement of teachers.  If a computer can effectively instruct students, the need for human educators might be questioned, leading to job losses for those who have dedicated their careers to teaching.

On the positive side, FACS could enhance learning, particularly for students who are withdrawn or quiet in class.  These students might benefit from a computer's ability to personalize instruction based on their emotional responses.  Just as online advertising algorithms adapt to user reactions – displaying similar ads after a smile, and different ones after a frown – FACS could tailor lessons to a student's emotional state. This allows for a real-time understanding of the student's feelings.

Ultimately, FACS presents both advantages and disadvantages.  While the long-term benefits might include improved learning outcomes and potentially more intelligent students, the short-term consequences could be disruptive. Students might become less socially adept due to decreased interaction with teachers, and educators could face unemployment.  Balancing the potential educational gains with the societal impact on teachers will be crucial as this technology develops.

The Android app market is facing increasing competition.  According to Statista [1], the number of available apps decreased in 2019 for the first time, suggesting that many apps are being removed due to obsolescence or lack of user interest.  To remain competitive, apps must continuously monitor user preferences and demands, often collecting user and device information during execution.  Much of this information, such as GPS location, contact lists, and device IMEI, is privacy-sensitive, raising concerns among both corporate and personal users [1, 2].  Recent data breaches, like the Peekaboo Moments incident exposing over 100 GB of baby photos and videos [2], further highlight these risks.

To address these privacy concerns, mobile apps should adhere to the principle of minimal data collection, accessing only the personal and sensitive information (PSI) strictly necessary to provide their service.  Furthermore, they must clearly disclose what PSI is accessed.  Google has attempted to mitigate these privacy issues by releasing a set of privacy guidelines for Android apps [3] outlining technical and legal requirements for data collection, use, and sharing, emphasizing user consent and transparency.  Consequently, apps on the Google Play Store requiring PSI access must have a readily accessible, in-app privacy policy detailing their data practices, which users must acknowledge before granting access.

Despite these guidelines, a key challenge remains:  a comprehensive methodology for assessing app compliance is currently lacking.  It remains unclear how many apps genuinely adhere to Google Play's privacy guidelines, highlighting a critical research gap.

The "Face on Mars" has fueled imaginations and alien theories for decades, appearing in books and magazines since its discovery in 1976.  Many believed it was an alien-made monument.  However, I'm here to debunk this myth with concrete evidence.  I have a friend at NASA, and even he agrees with the scientific consensus.

The first blow to the alien theory came in April 1998.  The Mars Global Surveyor, equipped with a high-resolution camera, flew over Cydonia, the region where the "Face" is located. The resulting image was ten times sharper than the original 1976 photograph.  To the surprise of many, but not me, it revealed a natural landform, not an alien monument.  Skeptics argued that the 1998 photo was taken during a cloudy Martian season, potentially obscuring the "truth."

To address this, another photograph was taken on April 8, 2001, during a clear summer day in Cydonia.  The Mars Global Surveyor’s camera captured incredible detail, with each pixel representing only 1.56 meters.  Even small objects like planes or shacks would have been visible. This image definitively showed a Martian landform resembling American buttes and mesas.

La conversación se interrumpe con la llegada de Charly, quien anuncia que el funeral del hombre que les causó tanto daño durante años será al día siguiente. Tras una breve charla en la que Charly pregunta qué pasará entre los tres, Yeimy les pide a ambos que se retiren.

路透都柏林/伦敦4月14日 - 塞浦路斯庞大银行体系的崩溃，使卢森堡、马耳他等金融体系规模与其经济体量不成比例的国家成为焦点。然而，一个国家金融体系的稳健性最终取决于其贷款质量。

低税率、高利率和宽松监管吸引了大量海外存款涌入塞浦路斯，使其银行体系规模膨胀至国内生产总值（GDP）的近八倍，是欧洲3.5倍平均水平的两倍多。这些存款主要来自俄罗斯及前苏联国家。

如果不考虑俄罗斯银行和其他跨国银行，塞浦路斯政府担保的三家银行的资产规模仍超过GDP的五倍，对于一个人口仅80万的岛国来说，这显得异常庞大。

塞浦路斯银行业危机的根源在于，其两家主要银行利用这些存款豪赌希腊经济，最终因欧洲对希腊主权债务进行减记而遭受重创。希腊经济的衰退导致塞浦路斯银行对希腊的贷款成为坏账。

“银行倒闭并非因为规模过大，而是因为做出了错误的放贷决策，”标准普尔欧洲主权评级主管Frank Gill表示。“重要的是要明白，塞浦路斯银行业危机是资产负债表上资产出了问题，而不是负债。”

截至去年9月底，塞浦路斯银行（Bank of Cyprus）的不良贷款率高达17%，而塞浦路斯大众银行（Cyprus Popular Bank）在2012年第三季的坏账拨备猛增三倍，达到4亿欧元。

（浏览欧元区国家银行业占GDP比重图表，请点击：(link.reuters.com/jut86t)）

**小国，大银行**

卢森堡官员急于维护其作为国际资本中心的声誉，迫切地解释该国与塞浦路斯的不同之处。卢森堡金融业规模位居欧元区之首，高达GDP的22倍，而其人口仅略微超过50万，与美国亚利桑那州图森市相当。但卢森堡强调其银行业非常稳健，实际负债规模远小于账面数字。

“过去几周，几乎所有文章都引用了金融行业规模与GDP之比的图表，但这并非正确的解读方式，”卢森堡基金行业联合会主席Marc Saluzzi表示。“卢森堡的金融核心更加分散，由142家银行组成，而且基本上是大型外国银行的子公司，它们的偿付能力比率都在15%以上。”

El Gobierno de Navarra implantará en Pamplona, el próximo curso, dos ciclos de FP Superior de carácter público: uno de Técnico en Acondicionamiento Físico en euskera y otro de Técnico en Enseñanza y Animación Sociodeportiva en castellano. Ambos ciclos se ofrecerán en modalidad bilingüe con inglés.  Esta decisión, anunciada por el consejero de Educación, Carlos Gimeno, y el director general de Formación Profesional, Tomás Rodríguez, ante el Parlamento foral, responde a la necesidad de equilibrar la oferta formativa y garantizar la igualdad de oportunidades en la capital navarra y su comarca.

Actualmente, la oferta académica en Pamplona en esta familia profesional es exclusivamente privada, impartida por centros como Eskola Vitae Navarra - Huarte (Grado Medio de Conducción de Actividades Físicodeportivas y Grado Superior de Enseñanza y Animación Sociodeportiva) y el Foro Europeo Escuela de Negocios de Navarra (Grado Superior de Enseñanza y Animación Sociodeportiva).  Esta situación contraviene el principio de igualdad de oportunidades para toda la ciudadanía, tal como ha destacado el consejero Gimeno.

La implantación de estos ciclos públicos responde al compromiso de la Ley Foral 18/2019 sobre acceso y ejercicio de las profesiones del deporte en Navarra, que exige la revisión y modificación de la oferta educativa para facilitar el acceso a una formación pública de calidad en el ámbito de la actividad física y el deporte.  Con esta nueva oferta, se busca satisfacer las necesidades de personal cualificado y garantizar el acceso a la formación en igualdad de oportunidades, según ha explicado el director general, Tomás Rodríguez.

El departamento de Educación está gestionando un acuerdo, en fase avanzada, con una entidad pública para la cesión de instalaciones deportivas en Pamplona, ya que actualmente no dispone de las infraestructuras necesarias para impartir estas enseñanzas.  Cabe destacar que el CIP FP Lumbier IPP ya imparte el ciclo de Acondicionamiento Físico en castellano y el de Enseñanza y Animación Sociodeportiva en euskera.

A wealthy businessman stood before an elderly toy maker’s bench. "What do you mean 'no'?" he demanded.

The old man, engrossed in painting a wooden toy soldier, merely shook his head. His aged hands moved with practiced finesse, adding the final touches of color.  He was oblivious to the businessman’s rising frustration.

"I said, what do you mean you're not going to make a toy for my son this year? I can pay you as much as you want!" the businessman roared, his questions morphing into demands.  He felt foolish, humbled by this craftsman, but the empty shop, save for the two of them and the rows of staring dolls, emboldened him.

Finally, the toy maker responded, his voice sharp. "I've told you, your boy doesn't deserve my creations.  Every year, I pour hours of effort into a gift for him, only to have it returned in pieces. If he doesn't respect toys, he gets no toys!"  His anger flared, followed by a wracking cough. "LEAVE!" he rasped, before collapsing, clutching his throat.

He choked, his face turning purple, one arm reaching out to the businessman in a silent plea for help.  The businessman simply watched, a cruel smile twisting his lips.  He observed without remorse as the toy maker struggled, each gasp more desperate than the last. When the old man finally lay still, the businessman retrieved his hat, pocketed the finished toy soldier, and left.


Later that night, young Jimmy played with his new toy – a British soldier, resplendent in a red coat and tall black hat.  It was his favorite of the gifts he'd received.

"Time for bed, son," his father said from the doorway.

Jimmy, engrossed in play, grimaced.  "Okay, Dad," he grumbled, reluctantly placing his new treasures in the toy chest. He lingered over the soldier, a frown creasing his brow.

"Enjoy your new friend there?" his father asked.

"Yeah, he's cool and all… but…" Jimmy hesitated.

"But what, son?"

"Why does he look so angry at me?"

Visual odometry (VO), or visual egomotion estimation, is a well-studied topic with a rich history [1].  One of the known difficulties with monocular VO, however, is its inability to resolve the true scale of the scene relative to a known reference.  Consequently, both estimated scene depths and the estimated distance travelled between adjacent image frames are determined only up to an unknown, and often drifting, scale factor. While simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) algorithms can mitigate scale drift through loop closure detection, extreme drift can prevent loop closure and lead to irreversible errors in map building [2].

Existing techniques often attempt to resolve this scale ambiguity by incorporating a priori scene information, such as known object sizes or camera height, into classical VO algorithms [3].  However, this hand-engineering approach presents significant tuning challenges.  An alternative is data-driven learning, where neural networks map directly from raw image pairs to inter-frame egomotion predictions. With ground truth labels like depths or poses, these networks can produce metrically-scaled outputs [4]-[6].  Unfortunately, acquiring such ground truth labels is often onerous and expensive, limiting training data.  Moreover, the lack of ground truth at test time prevents online retraining with newly-collected data, hindering long-term autonomy, especially since learning-based systems can be unreliable outside their training distribution [7].

To address these limitations, self-supervised methods have been proposed, jointly training depth and egomotion networks without ground truth labels [8]. These methods typically employ a photometric reconstruction loss during training.  However, despite significant advancements in self-supervised learning, network outputs often remain unscaled due to the absence of metric information during training.

Our work introduces a novel scale recovery loss that resolves this issue by ensuring consistency between the estimated and known camera height above the ground plane. This approach injects metric information during training, leading to metrically-scaled depth and egomotion predictions at test time.  To facilitate this, we extract the ground plane from each training image and determine its normal and offset (camera height) using a least squares technique.  Importantly, unlike existing scale recovery methods [9], our approach does not require ground plane segmentation at test time. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first self-supervised, learning-based system capable of producing scaled depth and egomotion estimates using only monocular images during training.

Más allá del revuelo político ocasionado por el anuncio de renuncia de Álvaro Uribe al Senado de la República, resultan sorprendentes las actuaciones de la Corte Suprema de Justicia en el caso por el cual pretenden incriminar al expresidente por los delitos de soborno y fraude procesal, supuestamente por “manipulación de testigos”.

En realidad, en este caso concreto, se evidencian varios yerros procesales en las actuaciones de la Corte Suprema. Analicemos:

**Primero:** Una vez conocida la situación, fue notoria la voluntad de Uribe de rendir versión ante la Corte. Sin embargo, esta audiencia de versión libre no fue permitida, ya que los magistrados guardaron silencio e hicieron caso omiso a la voluntad de colaboración de Uribe, vulnerando, sin justificación alguna, sus derechos fundamentales al debido proceso y a la defensa.

**Segundo:**  Es de conocimiento público una carta que constituye una prueba fundamental a favor de Uribe. ¿Qué sucede aquí? ¿Qué motiva a la Corte a desestimar importantes elementos probatorios?

**Tercero:**  Se conoció un documento aportado por el expresidente Uribe a la Corte Suprema, con radicado 38451, en el que presenta como pruebas entrevistas a personas que declaran que Iván Cepeda intentó manipularlas para que incriminaran al expresidente a cambio de beneficios.  No obstante, al parecer, este aporte tampoco fue valorado por la Corte. ¿Por qué? ¿Cuál es la razón legal?

Esto es un exabrupto. ¿Desde cuándo los periodistas anticipan las decisiones de la Corte Suprema de Justicia? ¿Cómo obtienen dicha información? ¿Quién se la suministra? The rapid proliferation of mobile devices and wireless technology has led to an explosive growth in mobile data traffic.  While major network operators have upgraded their cellular networks to 5G, network capacity growth still lags significantly behind the increasing demand for data (e.g., [1], [2]).  WiFi, a mature short-range wireless technology, offers a relatively low-cost and easily deployable solution for congestion control. However, individual WiFi access points (APs), even with the latest gigabit WiFi amendments in 802.11ac/ad/ax, have limited coverage.  Deploying a ubiquitous WiFi network remains challenging due to the prohibitive cost of achieving comprehensive coverage [3].

Crowdsourced WiFi community networks have emerged as a promising approach to address the coverage limitations of traditional WiFi.  Non-traditional service providers like Fon and OpenSpark are developing WiFi sharing platforms that aggregate numerous home WiFi APs to provide expanded coverage for their users.  These networks operate on an equal-reciprocal principle, incentivizing users to share their home APs in exchange for access to the APs of other users. Fon, for example, boasts a network of over 23 million APs and is rapidly expanding globally, particularly in densely populated areas where 5G networks often face congestion, especially during peak hours.  Despite the significant coverage gains achieved by aggregating individual APs, crowdsourced WiFi networks still fall short of ubiquitous 5G coverage and are therefore considered a complementary backhaul service rather than a replacement.

This coexistence of 5G and crowdsourced WiFi networks is evident in numerous partnerships, such as British Telecom and Fon in the United Kingdom, and Telenor and OpenSpark in Finland (e.g., [4], [5]).  The convergence of the negative externalities of 5G network congestion with the positive externalities of crowdsourced WiFi raises important questions.  Does a 5G network operator benefit from the introduction of a crowdsourced WiFi network by a separate, self-interested company? How should the 5G operator adapt its service operation, particularly its pricing strategy, in response?  What is the impact on user payoffs given the availability of a complementary WiFi service option?

Addressing these questions from an economic perspective presents two key technical challenges.

The increasing complexity of geometries in various fields demands robust solvers.  These complex shapes arise in applications ranging from everyday scenarios like the behavior of electrical wires [1] and the electro-elasticity of components [2] to understanding elastic shock in solids [3].  Biomedical and biomechanical applications involving human organs, as well as AI-generated geometries coupled with these fields, further highlight this need.  Moreover, materials ranging from polymers to biological tissues exhibit incompressible or nearly incompressible behavior, posing additional challenges.

Traditional finite element formulations in solid dynamics, where displacement is the primary unknown and other quantities are post-processed [4] [5], perform poorly near the incompressibility limit.  These methods suffer from locking, spurious pressure fields, and limitations in bending applications [6].  Several techniques, including selective and reduced integration methods like B-bar [6] [7] [8], F-bar [9] [10] [11] [12], and mean dilatation methods [13], address these issues by reducing the order of incompressibility at quadrature points, thus circumventing numerical instabilities related to the inf-sup or LBB conditions [14]. While effective for structured quadrilateral and hexahedral meshes, these strategies are hampered by the high cost of hexahedral mesh generation for complex geometries.  Unstructured tetrahedral elements offer a more efficient alternative.

The similarity between the elliptic equation governing static, incompressible elasticity and the Stokes problem in fluid mechanics, and the analogous hyperbolic equation for transient elastodynamics, suggests extending mixed/coupled velocity/pressure formulations from fluid mechanics [15] to mixed displacement/pressure formulations in solid mechanics [16].  This approach has been explored for incompressible linear elastic materials using the Orthogonal Sub Scale (OSS) method [17], and for non-linear materials [19] [20], demonstrating the capabilities of mixed displacement/pressure and strain/displacement or stress/displacement formulations.  Three-field (displacement/pressure/strain) formulations have also shown promise in the near-incompressible limit [21].

However, extending these formulations to transient elastodynamics, which introduces a hyperbolic character, presents further challenges.  Several approaches address this by introducing additional variables, such as the deformation tensor F [22] [23] [24] [25] and Lagrange multipliers.  For incompressible and bending-dominated problems, the Jacobian determinant of the deformation gradient J [26] [27] or the nodal co-factor tensor H [28] [29] [30] are sometimes introduced, often requiring stabilization techniques like SUPG.  Other methods utilize mixed velocity/pressure formulations with displacement derived from velocity discretization, sometimes employing pressure rate equations to handle the hyperbolic nature of the transient case [31] [32].  Mixed displacement/pressure formulations within a total Lagrangian framework, using variations of the VMS method, have also proven effective [33].

This paper proposes a novel mixed displacement/pressure formulation for non-linear elasticity in solid dynamics using unstructured tetrahedral meshes, allowing for efficient representation of complex geometries.  Building upon the concept of splitting strain energy into deviatoric and volumetric parts [35], the method solves a constitutive equation in pressure and employs a fully implicit, mixed coupled formulation in an updated Lagrangian context. The pursuit of knowledge discovery is a cornerstone of human progress, driving innovation and shaping our understanding of the world [30, 28].  As Margaret Drabble eloquently stated, "When nothing is sure, everything is possible." This sentiment resonates deeply with the challenges and opportunities present in modern scientific discovery.  While traditionally, hypothesis formulation has been the intellectual anchor steering scientific investigation [13], the exponential growth of data and literature [28] coupled with disciplinary silos has created a bottleneck in this crucial process.  This paper explores the potential of Large Language Models (LLMs) to revolutionize knowledge discovery by addressing these challenges and unlocking new possibilities, particularly in hypothesis generation.

Central to this exploration is the observation that while existing tools excel at hypothesis validation, there's a glaring gap in methods for generating novel hypotheses [42, 31, 1, 38].  This paper addresses this gap by investigating the capacity of LLMs to generate hypotheses in zero-shot scenarios, a largely unexplored area.  Previous research has touched upon problem discovery, but lacks rigorous experimental designs specifically targeting zero-shot hypothesis generation by LLMs.

To address this, we constructed a temporal biomedical dataset spanning January 2000 to September 2023, partitioned into training (pre-January 2023) and testing (August 2023) sets. This ensures the evaluated LLMs (trained on pre-August 2023 corpora) are genuinely tested on unseen data.  We also developed a multi-intelligent collaborative framework incorporating search tools and role-playing to enhance the potential for hypothesis generation. Figure 1 illustrates an example of a generated hypothesis using the fine-tuned 65B LLaMA within our dataset, remarkably aligning with existing literature.  This underscores the potential of LLMs and highlights the need for tools and methodologies that facilitate hypothesis generation [13].

3. Can LLMs Truly Generate Zero-Shot Hypotheses?

This section details our methodology for evaluating the zero-shot hypothesis generation capabilities of LLMs.  We define the problem of zero-shot hypothesis generation, describe the construction of our biomedical dataset, and outline the experiments conducted to assess various instructed models across multiple dimensions, exploring factors influencing their ability to propose novel hypotheses.

Our experiments, analyzed in Figure 1, yielded surprising results: 1) LLMs generated untrained yet validated hypotheses when tested against recent literature. 2) Increased uncertainty, introduced through methods like multi-agent collaboration, enhanced zero-shot hypothesis generation.  However, subsequent few-shot enhancements and the use of additional tools sometimes *reduced* the model's proficiency, likely by constraining the hypothesis generation space. This highlights the need for careful consideration when incorporating external knowledge. This observation reinforces Drabble's quote – greater uncertainty can unlock greater possibility.

Our contributions are threefold:

1) We constructed a temporal biomedical instruction dataset and designed novel experiments to rigorously evaluate the zero-shot and few-shot hypothesis generation potential of LLMs, a first in the field.
2) Through multi-faceted evaluations, we demonstrated that LLMs possess rudimentary higher-order reasoning capabilities and can generate novel hypotheses, providing new insights and pathways for knowledge discovery.
3) We developed a four-dimensional metric for evaluating generated hypotheses, using both ChatGPT and human evaluations.  The strong correlation between these evaluations further highlights the utility of LLMs in this process.

Scientific discovery relies on several key components: data analysis, hypothesis formulation, experiment design, execution, observation, and reflection [13], as illustrated in Figure 2.  While all are essential, hypothesis formulation plays a pivotal role, guiding the entire research process.  Our research demonstrates the potential of LLMs to become valuable tools in this crucial stage, potentially ushering in a new era of efficiency and innovation in knowledge discovery.

Background Knowledge for Hypothesis Generation Example:

(1) Esophageal cancer primarily comprises squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma, each with distinct risk factors and incidence rates.
(2) Metformin has been shown to reduce the risk of various cancers in patients with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM).
(3) Existing research on the relationship between metformin use and esophageal cancer risk presents conflicting results.

Hypothesized by the Model:

(1) Metformin use in T2DM patients may be associated with a reduced risk of esophageal cancer.
(2) The correlation between metformin use and esophageal cancer risk may differ between male and female T2DM patients. (This hypothesis is supported by a 2023 study titled 'Diabetes, metformin use, and survival in esophageal cancer: a population-based cohort study'.)

The challenge of data traceability in pre-trained models like ChatGPT and GPT-4 limits the exploration of zero-shot hypothesis generation.  Our approach, using a temporally defined dataset and rigorous testing methodology, addresses this limitation and provides valuable insights into the untapped potential of LLMs in scientific discovery.

La empresa Industrias Químicas del Noroeste, S.A. (INQUINOSA), ubicada en el polígono industrial de la Fosforera, en Sabiñánigo, produjo y formuló el pesticida lindano desde 1974 hasta 1992.  Durante este periodo, generó residuos que depositó principalmente en los vertederos de Sardas y Bailín.  Toda la superficie de la antigua factoría ha sido declarada suelo contaminado, superando los niveles genéricos de referencia del Real Decreto 9/2005,  y estas declaraciones se han inscrito en el Registro de la Propiedad.  Se lleva trabajando desde 2016 en la caracterización del suelo exterior a las naves y en la contaminación de los paramentos en pie.

El actual estado de ruina de las cubiertas, de fibrocemento y forjados, impide el acceso seguro de maquinaria de sondeo al interior de las naves, ya que las vibraciones podrían producir desprendimientos.  Por ello, la expropiación y futura construcción de un nuevo vial de acceso se considera una fase previa a la descontaminación de la antigua fábrica. Esta actuación, declarada de utilidad pública e interés social por el Gobierno de Aragón, se dividirá en dos fases: el derribo de los edificios y la caracterización del suelo del interior de las naves para su posterior descontaminación.

Paradójicamente, el único acceso rodado a la antigua factoría es un camino privado dentro de un complejo industrial, considerado "Infraestructura crítica" por la Secretaria General de Seguridad del Estado.  Esta circunstancia genera demoras en la tramitación de los permisos individuales y diarios para su uso.  Para agilizar las labores de seguimiento y control de la ruina industrial, se ha considerado necesaria la construcción de un nuevo vial sin restricciones de uso.

El nuevo vial, de 593 metros de longitud, permitirá el acceso desde la calle Cañada Real.  El proyecto incluye la construcción de conducciones de agua y energía eléctrica para futuras instalaciones de mantenimiento, descontaminación y control, así como el encauzamiento de las aguas pluviales de los alrededores.  En una fase posterior, estas aguas se derivarán a una depuradora móvil para su descontaminación.

Se prevé concluir la expropiación de los 13.000 metros cuadrados necesarios para el nuevo vial en 2021 y construirlo en 2023.  Este vial, consensuado con los técnicos del Ayuntamiento de Sabiñánigo, se integrará en el entramado urbano de la capital del Alto Gállego una vez finalizadas las actuaciones.  Se trata de un paso más para aumentar la seguridad y control de los emplazamientos afectados por los residuos de la fabricación de lindano en la comunidad autónoma.
