In recent years, both industry and academia [8] have widely adopted Virtual Reality (VR) training applications.  Despite this growth, few systems incorporate procedures for assessing user progress within the immersive environment.  Existing systems often evaluate only trivial tasks or require substantial reviewer time [6].  Meanwhile, the demand for real-time, automated evaluation of user actions is steadily increasing.  State-of-the-art methods for similar tasks either necessitate the development of complex, task-specific computer vision algorithms [10] or only support very simple tasks [4].

This work proposes a deep learning-based system capable of assessing user actions in real-time within a VR training scenario.  The method facilitates rapid development of trained assessment functions by leveraging data augmentation to minimize the required amount of labeled data.  Furthermore, transfer learning allows these assessment functions to be reconfigured for similar tasks, further reducing the training data needs.  This paper presents the results of our method applied to the task of tearing a deformable 3D model [3].

Various machine and deep learning algorithms [1, 7] were considered and compared (see Table 1).  Ultimately, our proposed model is a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) trained on a dataset created using a data augmentation technique [2].

The "Face on Mars" is a natural landform, not an alien creation.  While some speculate about extraterrestrial origins, it's simply a geological feature formed by natural processes over time.  There's no evidence of alien involvement.  While NASA continues to investigate Martian features, their use of the word "might" regarding potential alien involvement doesn't confirm extraterrestrial influence.  It simply acknowledges the possibility, not the certainty.

Claims that NASA is trying to convince the public of alien involvement are unfounded.  Analyzing Martian images takes time and careful study. The extended period to analyze the "Face on Mars" images doesn't imply alien construction, but rather the complexity of scientific investigation.  It's unreasonable to expect immediate conclusions about such complex phenomena.

The available evidence strongly suggests that the "Face on Mars" is a natural formation. I've presented arguments supporting this conclusion.  While individuals are free to maintain their beliefs, the scientific evidence points towards a natural explanation.  Should future Mars missions discover evidence of extraterrestrial life, that would change the current understanding. However, until such evidence is found, the most plausible explanation remains a natural geological formation.

Time-varying or nonlinear (non-LTI) electromagnetic structures exhibit unique behaviors beyond the capabilities of their linear time-invariant (LTI) counterparts. Examples of non-LTI antenna systems include active and non-Foster matching [1–3], direct antenna modulation [4–6], and time-varying loading with modulation rates comparable to the carrier or antenna resonant frequency (as opposed to the symbol rate) [7–11]. These methods involve locally time-varying or nonlinear loading, while the effects of distributed time-variation, i.e., space-time modulated materials, have also been explored [12–19].

Modeling these structures typically relies on time-domain techniques like FDTD, transient circuit co-simulation, and the time-domain method of moments [20].  While accurate and general, these methods have drawbacks that motivate alternative strategies [21]. For example, transient analyses offer limited opportunities for partial simulation re-use between variations of time-varying properties.  Furthermore, they don't directly represent frequency-domain phenomena like steady-state radiated power and network parameters, common metrics in LTI system design, although these can be derived via Fourier transformations.  In contrast, frequency-domain techniques often allow significant simulation re-use and naturally align with these frequency-domain metrics.  The direct connection between the method of moments (MoM) and the dyadic Green's function makes it particularly advantageous for applications like modal current analysis [22, 23], automated design synthesis [24–26], and developing fundamental bounds on LTI system performance [27, 28]. Extending these benefits to a method compatible with linear, time-varying system analysis could greatly accelerate the study of non-LTI electromagnetic structures in similar applications.

To address this need, we hybridize MoM with existing frequency-domain methods for time-varying circuit analysis, specifically using conversion matrices to transform a MoM-based scattering problem into one involving an LTI N-port network interfaced with time-varying subcircuits.  Prior work on hybridizing MoM with conversion matrix solvers is limited, focusing on special cases with sparse lumped loading.  Studies [29, 30] used time-varying and nonlinear circuit analysis techniques (conversion matrices and harmonic balance) to model a single load at an antenna's feed point. By collapsing the antenna to a lumped impedance, this method is efficient but restricts loading to a single location.  In [31], a similar conversion matrix/MoM (CMMoM) hybridization treated a periodic structure with periodically time-varying loads, again focusing on sparse lumped loading. While useful and reflective of common practice, these methods don't readily generalize to systems with multiple loads or distributed time-varying properties.  Modeling time-varying material properties within an analytical context equivalent to CMMoM has been explored, but is limited to conducting cylinders [32].

Building on preliminary studies [33], we develop a generalized CMMoM method accommodating multiple lumped and distributed spatiotemporal loading of arbitrarily shaped electromagnetic structures.

Score-based diffusion models (SBDMs) have garnered significant attention for data generation.  These models perturb target data into Gaussian noise via a diffusion process and learn the reverse process to reconstruct the original data. Conditional SBDMs, incorporating guidance such as class labels, text, or low-resolution images, have demonstrated considerable success in image generation and translation.  Traditional conditional SBDMs rely on paired data, where each target sample has a corresponding condition, for example, a high-resolution image paired with its low-resolution counterpart in super-resolution. However, obtaining sufficient paired training data can be challenging in real-world applications due to labeling costs.  Therefore, developing SBDMs that can leverage unpaired or partially paired training data is crucial, particularly for tasks like unpaired or semi-paired image-to-image translation (I2I).

While several SBDM-based approaches exist for unpaired I2I, they often employ unconditional score-based models, imposing conditions during inference through techniques like cycle consistency, initial state design, or guidance terms.  Training *conditional* score-based models directly with unpaired data remains an open question.  Furthermore, few SBDMs address the partially paired scenario, where a limited amount of paired data is available alongside a larger unpaired dataset.

This paper addresses the challenge of training conditional score-based models with unpaired or partially paired data, focusing on I2I applications where condition and target data are images from different domains.  The key challenges are twofold: (1) the absence of a direct relationship between condition and target data hinders training, and (2) even with an estimated relationship, it's unclear how to train the model effectively without explicit condition-target pairs.

To address these challenges, we introduce the Optimal Transport-guided Conditional Score-based diffusion model (OTCS).  Unlike existing OT-related SBDMs that focus on understanding or enhancing *unconditional* models, OTCS leverages optimal transport (OT) to enable *conditional* SBDM training with unpaired or partially paired data.

For unpaired settings, such as unpaired super-resolution, we utilize unsupervised OT to model the coupling relationship between condition and target data.  This approach aligns with the common practice of translating condition data to the target domain while preserving image structure.

Air France renforce sa présence au Maroc en prolongeant pour l'hiver 2021 sa liaison saisonnière Tanger-Paris-Charles de Gaulle, inaugurée avec succès l'été dernier.  Deux vols hebdomadaires seront ainsi proposés au départ de Tanger, complétant l'offre existante au départ de Casablanca, Rabat et Marrakech.  Ce renforcement porte à 65 le nombre total de vols hebdomadaires assurés par Air France entre le Maroc et Paris, permettant des correspondances vers l'ensemble de son réseau court, moyen et long-courrier.

À compter du 31 octobre 2021 et jusqu'à fin mars 2022, Air France opérera donc jusqu'à deux vols par semaine entre Tanger et Paris-Charles de Gaulle. Les réservations sont ouvertes sur tous les points de vente Air France, y compris sur www.airfrance.ma.

Ce programme de vols reste toutefois susceptible d'évoluer en fonction des restrictions de voyage liées à la situation sanitaire. Air France ajuste en effet son offre en temps réel et invite ses clients à vérifier systématiquement les conditions d'entrée et les documents requis à l'arrivée sur www.airfrance.traveldoc.aero avant tout déplacement.

Par ailleurs, Air France rappelle sa politique commerciale actuelle : les billets pour des voyages jusqu'au 31 mars 2022 sont 100% modifiables sans frais.  Les clients peuvent également obtenir un avoir remboursable s'ils renoncent à leur voyage. En cas d'annulation de vol par la compagnie, ils ont le choix entre reporter leur voyage, se faire rembourser intégralement ou recevoir un avoir, également remboursable s'il n'est pas utilisé.

La santé et le bien-être des clients et des personnels restent la priorité d'Air France. La compagnie s’engage à garantir les meilleures conditions de sécurité sanitaire tout au long du voyage.  Le port du masque chirurgical est obligatoire à bord et pendant toute la durée du voyage. L'air en cabine est renouvelé toutes les 3 minutes grâce à un système de recyclage équipé de filtres HEPA (High Efficiency Particulate Air), similaires à ceux utilisés en milieu hospitalier.  Enfin, le nettoyage des avions est renforcé, avec la désinfection systématique, avant chaque vol, de toutes les surfaces en contact avec les clients (accoudoirs, tablettes, écrans).

The world ended in the shower. Not for me, not yet, but for ten billion others. It happened while I was blissfully unaware, lost in the steam and the music pouring through my waterproof headphones.  My “me time” cost me the chance to witness the vanishing of nearly everyone on Earth.

Thirty minutes ago, I was #5,000,000,001.  A perfectly unremarkable number in a world of ten billion.  If that number represented wealth, I'd be set; if it was a golf score, I’d quit. But as a measure of importance in the global supply chain, it meant comfortable anonymity.  I never waited long for anything, never heard “no.”  The International Quartermaster's Consortium (IQC) – the folks who dole out resources based on your International Individual Rankings Bureau (IIRB) rank – happily fulfilled my requests for extra water or discounted beef.  5,000,000,001 was a good place to be.

Then my StrapRank (tm) – the wristband assigned at birth that displays your IIRB rank – buzzed.  Usually, a minor fluctuation. Births, deaths, the usual.  But this time, it flashed #500,000,000.  An impossible leap. I assumed a malfunction, blamed the shower steam.  I continued getting ready for work, dismissing the rapidly changing numbers: 734,000… then 425,924… plummeting faster than Brendan Fraser’s career.

Finally, I called the IIRB.  After navigating the bureaucratic phone tree, I reached a bored voice, explained my situation.  The voice suddenly sharpened. "How long ago did it start?"  I was put on hold. My rank: 250,000.

A new voice, Anthony, an IIRB technician, answered. He was investigating similar reports.  He asked for my current rank.  “250,000,” I said, still convinced my StrapRank was broken.  Outside, sirens wailed – a common sound since the 7-billion-bracket crowd moved into my neighborhood.

Anthony explained how the StrapRanks worked: activated by your heartbeat, reporting to the IIRB database, which calculates and displays your rank.  “Right,” I said, “but why is mine plummeting?”

“Everyone gets more important when there are less of us.”  His tone was flat, disturbingly calm.  He asked for my rank again.  “19.”  Two digits that suddenly held immense weight.

"Mine shows #18," Anthony said, "and I'm the last one in this office. I don’t know how much longer we have.”  I heard the clink of glass, the sigh of someone taking a stiff drink. "Your wristband isn't malfunctioning. The human race is disappearing."

I looked out the window.  Driverless cars littered the streets. Empty strollers. A lone birthday balloon drifted by. In the distance, a plane descended too low, then vanished. The thud of the explosion echoed.

"I... what... how...?" I stammered.

"I don't know," Anthony replied. "All I know is we-"  Silence.  "Anthony?" I picked up the phone. "Anthony!"  Nothing. Just the buzz of my StrapRank. #18.

Thirty minutes. Ten billion gone.  My rank: #1.  I’m recording this on my phone, hoping someone finds it, understands what happened. I don’t.

It’s a hell of a thing, going from one in ten billion to the last one.  Suddenly, I desperately crave the anonymity of the crowd, the comfort of being #5,000,000,001.  Maybe it wasn’t so bad af-

A voice startled you awake. "Hi there!"

Disoriented, you looked around. "Huh, what?" You mumbled, taking in the unfamiliar surroundings. A bed, yourself lying in it, and a man standing at the foot, holding a clipboard.  Moments ago, you were driving…the truck swerving…then nothing.

The man, older, bearded, and wearing a white lab coat, spoke.  "Welcome to the Afterlife! Don't worry, it's just a name. There's no *real* Afterlife of course! Ha ha ha." His laugh sounded forced.

"Who are you? What's going on?"  You wondered if this was a hospital. Had the accident knocked you unconscious? The word “Afterlife” barely registered.

"Well, I'm God....frey. Godfrey! Yeah, that's right, Godfrey."  He seemed nervous.

"Where am I?"

"Like I said, this is the Afterlife. You died. I'm sorry to be the one to tell you."

Panic began to rise.  You glanced down and a gasp escaped you.  Your prosthetic leg, lost in a childhood accident, was gone, replaced by a flesh-and-blood limb. You stared, speechless.

"Yeah, that's right," Godfrey said. "You're dead. That's why your body is whole again."

"But…but I'm an atheist! I didn't think there would be an Afterlife."

"No, no, it's fine!" Godfrey waved a hand, a gesture meant to reassure. "Don't worry.  It turns out there's a perfectly logical, science-based explanation for how the Afterlife is possible! Isn't that great news?"

Confusion and doubt warred within you. "Oh… Is there?"

"Absolutely!" Godfrey attempted a wink, the result more grimace than flirtation.

"Well, what is it then?"

"Huh?"  He feigned ignorance.

"Um, what is it? The explanation?"  This felt like a bizarre dream.

"Explanation for what?"  Godfrey’s eyes darted around.

"The science-based explanation for the Afterlife! Man, this is weird. Uh, are you a doctor? What is actually going on? How has my leg grown back?"

Face aux difficultés économiques liées à la crise sanitaire, les stages d'observation en entreprise pour les élèves de troisième, initialement obligatoires, seront facultatifs cette année. The field of robotics often grapples with the complexities of motion planning, a search problem made challenging by the geometric and implicit nature of the configuration space (c-space).  Sampling-based motion planning (SBMP) algorithms address this by using random sampling and local extensions within the continuous c-space to find collision-free paths.  These algorithms often implicitly employ guided search, a concept we make explicit in this work.

Early SBMP algorithms, like Rapidly-exploring Random Trees (RRT) [23], demonstrated the effectiveness of exploration guided by Voronoi bias, particularly in environments without narrow passages.  Subsequent research often focused on navigating these challenging narrow passages [3, 28] or on optimizing path quality, such as maximizing clearance [16].  Due to the inherent complexity of motion planning, improvements frequently relied on environment-specific heuristics encoded by engineers.

This paper formalizes the previously implicit notion of guidance by defining guiding spaces and guided search. A guiding space is an auxiliary space used to estimate the value of exploring different configurations, informing the exploration strategy of our proposed general guided search algorithm.  This definition is inherently hierarchical, as any search space (including c-space itself) can serve as a guiding space.  Intuitively, guidance represents the bias introduced into the exploration process, analogous to the heuristic guidance used by A* in discrete search spaces, but applied within the continuous c-space.

By explicitly defining guiding spaces, we uncover the underlying guidance mechanisms within seemingly disparate existing methods.  These methods can be categorized into three main groups: robot modification, environment modification, and experience-based guidance. This perspective simplifies and clarifies the conceptual contributions of various algorithms, facilitating generalized implementations and their composition.

Framing SBMP algorithms within this common language of guiding spaces enables a novel evaluation method focused on the quality of guidance.  We adopt an information-theoretic approach, where the guidance computation procedure provides information to the search process.  Experimental results across various algorithms and environments confirm the intuitive suitability of certain algorithms for specific c-space features.  Furthermore, this metric reveals algorithmic properties that traditional metrics like runtime or sample count often obscure.  By measuring guidance quality locally, we gain insights into the benefits of combining guiding spaces, demonstrated by a hybrid guiding space that outperforms its individual components.

The ability of computers to recognize human emotions promises a radical shift in our interaction with technology and the world around us. Imagine a computer so attuned to your emotional responses that it can anticipate your needs and desires.  For example, while online shopping, a fleeting expression of disgust at a bright yellow shirt could prompt the computer to instantly replace it with a blue alternative. This seamless adaptation to our emotional state could lead to greater satisfaction and a more personalized experience.

This technology, as exemplified by the Facial Action Coding System (FACS), offers intriguing possibilities.  The essay mentions FACS's analysis of the Mona Lisa, providing precise percentages for the emotions conveyed in the portrait. This level of emotional quantification offers a fascinating glimpse into the mind of Leonardo da Vinci.  By analyzing these percentages, we can speculate about his emotional state during the painting process. Was her predominantly happy expression a reflection of his own disposition?  This technology opens exciting new avenues for research and analysis, providing insights into historical figures and their thought processes in a way never before possible.  It's a window into the past, allowing us to explore not just what was done, but potentially what was felt and thought.

However, the implications of such technology extend beyond historical analysis.  The constant monitoring required for accurate emotional recognition raises concerns about privacy and personal space.  The feeling of being perpetually observed, even by a machine, could be unsettling and lead to feelings of anxiety and paranoia.  This constant surveillance, while not involving a human observer, mirrors the anxieties surrounding webcam hacking, but in a more pervasive and overt manner.  The system, by its very nature, is always watching, and this could be a significant deterrent for many.

Despite these potential drawbacks, the potential benefits of FACS are compelling.

In many real-world applications, such as education, healthcare, and autonomous driving, collecting data through online interaction is expensive or even dangerous.  However, previously collected logged datasets, generated by unknown policies, are often available in these domains. Offline reinforcement learning (RL) aims to learn effective agent policies directly from these datasets, without further online interaction (Lange et al., 2012; Levine et al., 2020).  Many online RL algorithms, including value-based methods (Fujimoto et al., 2019; Ghasemipour et al., 2021; Wu et al., 2019; Jaques et al., 2019; Kumar et al., 2020; Fujimoto & Gu, 2021; Kostrikov et al., 2021a) and model-based methods (Yu et al., 2020; Kidambi et al., 2020), have been adapted for offline settings. The key challenge for these methods lies in generalizing value or dynamics to state-action pairs outside the offline dataset.

Behavioral cloning (BC) (Bain & Sammut, 1995) offers an alternative approach to offline RL.  Originally developed for imitation learning, where the goal is mimicking expert demonstrations, BC is a supervised learning technique.  Recent work has formulated offline RL as a supervised learning problem (Chen et al., 2021; Janner et al., 2021; Emmons et al., 2021).  Because offline RL datasets typically lack expert demonstrations, these approaches condition BC on additional context, such as returns and goals, to specify target outcomes. Empirical evidence suggests that these conditional BC approaches are competitive with value-based methods, benefiting from the simplicity and training stability of supervised learning.

Since maximum returns in offline trajectories are often significantly lower than desired expert returns, policies are expected to extrapolate beyond the offline data by conditioning on out-of-distribution (OOD) expert returns. Ideally, the policy would achieve the desired outcomes, even if unseen during training, resulting in a linear relationship between achieved and target returns (Figure 1a).  However, current methods fall short of this ideal.  Performance typically peaks near the maximum return within the dataset, closely tracking the target return up to that point, then dropping sharply when conditioned on higher returns (Figure 1b).

We systematically analyze this unreliability, demonstrating its dependence on both offline data quality and the architecture of the return-conditioned policy. The green line represents the maximum return in the offline dataset, while the orange line represents the expert return. The ideal scenario (Figure 1a) is difficult or impossible to achieve with suboptimal offline data. Return-conditioned RL methods can exhibit unreliable generalization (Figure 1b), with performance declining rapidly beyond the dataset maximum. Our goal is to ensure reliable generalization (Figure 1c), even when conditioning on OOD returns.

We observe that offline datasets are generally suboptimal; even within the range of observed returns, the distribution is often non-uniform and concentrated on low-return trajectories. This impacts reliability, as we are primarily concerned with conditioning on returns near or above the observed dataset maximum. While filtering low-return trajectories is a straightforward solution, it can reduce data efficiency by eliminating a substantial portion of the dataset.

Regarding architecture, existing BC methods exhibit different behaviors when conditioning on OOD returns.

The "Face on Mars" has sparked curiosity and debate since its discovery in 1976.  A photo taken that year, and later images, including one from 2001, revealed a rock formation resembling a human face.  This led some scientists to speculate about the possibility of extraterrestrial origins, suggesting it could be evidence of alien life on Mars. However, many scientists, myself included, believe it is simply a natural rock formation.  Its appearance is due to natural processes and the play of shadows, creating the illusion of eyes, a nose, and a mouth. As NASA stated when they released the image, it is a huge rock formation that resembles a human head due to these shadows.

The scientific community remains divided. Roughly half believe the "Face on Mars" is a naturally occurring landform, while the other half entertain the possibility of it being an artifact of some kind.  

Personally, I remain convinced it's a rock. Rocks are enduring and don't simply disappear.  However, I acknowledge the question of how a rock's appearance could change over time.  Perhaps the unique conditions of the Martian environment, different from Earth, could contribute to such changes.

Ultimately, it's a strangely shaped rock. Rocks come in countless shapes and sizes, each unique and some quite unusual.  There's a wide variety of rock types, both on Earth and in space.

La Federación Médica del Interior (FEMI) expresa su apoyo a las acciones de la Agremiación Médica de Treinta y Tres, la cual se ha declarado en preconflicto con ASSE debido a un convenio firmado con la mutualista COMETT.  Este conflicto surge a raíz de la firma de un convenio de complementación entre ASSE (Hospital Departamental de Treinta y Tres) y COMETT, realizada fuera del departamento, sin la consideración de las autoridades locales, usuarios y gremios de la salud.  Dicho convenio, denunciado desde hace meses por la Agremiación Médica de Treinta y Tres (único interlocutor válido), ha sido considerado inconveniente por el equipo de gestión del Hospital Departamental, llevando a la puesta a disposición de sus cargos y posterior renuncia de sus integrantes.

El convenio se cuestiona fundamentalmente por dos razones: por un lado, la mutualista COMETT presenta múltiples observaciones del MSP por incumplimiento de requisitos para ser prestador de salud, incluyendo adeudos de salarios al personal médico. Por otro lado, el convenio genera inequidades en las contraprestaciones y condiciones laborales del personal asistencial, lo cual podría afectar la calidad de atención a los usuarios.

A pesar de varias reuniones con autoridades nacionales y locales, quienes han mostrado receptividad a los planteos, la Agremiación Médica de Treinta y Tres aún no ha obtenido respuesta.  Cuestionamos el incumplimiento del principio de descentralización del Sistema Nacional Integrado de Salud, dado que este tipo de conductas vulnera los derechos de los usuarios, los trabajadores médicos agremiados y todo el equipo de salud.

Por lo tanto, exigimos la anulación del convenio.  FEMI reafirma su compromiso de colaborar y apoyar proyectos de complementación de servicios de salud, siempre desde la transparencia en la gestión y la impostergable participación de los referentes locales.

The author should continue studying Venus despite its dangers.  Current knowledge of Venus reveals a hostile environment: an atmosphere composed of 97% carbon dioxide, shrouded in sulfuric acid clouds.  The surface pressure is 90 times that of Earth, and despite Mercury's proximity to the Sun, Venus boasts the highest average surface temperature in our solar system.

This extreme environment explains the difficulty in exploring Venus.  No spacecraft has survived on the surface for more than a few hours, likely due to the intense conditions.  This explains the absence of a long-term lander on Venus for over three decades. However, this lack of sustained exploration doesn't signify surrender.  Scientists are actively seeking solutions to this technological challenge.

NASA, for example, is exploring innovative approaches to studying Venus.  Sending humans presents significant difficulties, as any mission would likely be limited to orbiting the planet, precluding direct sample collection like rock or gas retrieval.  Currently, image capture remains the primary method of remote study.

Despite these obstacles, continued exploration of Venus remains crucial.  The author's pursuit of understanding this enigmatic planet should be encouraged, even in the face of daunting challenges.

Termination analysis, a classic problem in computability theory, aims to determine whether a program will halt.  Its importance is underscored by applications like software testing, where non-termination leads to infinite executions.  As Turing proved in 1936, no general algorithm can solve the termination problem for all program-input pairs [60].  While extensive research exists on termination analysis, most approaches rely on formal symbolic reasoning [15, 22, 23, 25, 33, 36].

Recent efforts have explored using neural networks to estimate termination behavior.  For example, Giacobbe et al. [29] trained neural networks as ranking functions, mapping the program's state space to well-ordered sets.  Similarly, Abate et al. [3] used a neural network to fit ranking supermartingales over execution traces.  These approaches, aiming for formal guarantees, leverage satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solvers to validate their results.  However, they inherit limitations inherent to formal symbolic methods, such as the need to translate programs into symbolic representations and the potential for undecidable logical fragments or reliance on additional program invariants.

This paper departs from formal methods, embracing the stochastic nature of machine learning models.  Instead of seeking rigorous formal guarantees, we aim to estimate a program's termination behavior and localize potential non-termination causes for debugging.  This work also explores the applicability of machine learning techniques from other domains to program analysis.  Specifically, we utilize Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) [66] and Graph Attention Networks (GANs) [61], as detailed below.

Unlike previous work focusing on execution traces, we analyze source code, assuming it contains patterns indicative of termination behavior.  Mirroring traditional program analysis techniques, we operate on graph representations of programs.  We leverage GNNs, a class of neural networks designed for graph-structured data analysis, which have gained traction in diverse fields like social network analysis [65], physical systems modeling [53], knowledge graph analysis [34], and point-cloud classification [71].  GNNs have also recently been applied to program analysis tasks such as variable misuse detection, type inference [7], and self-supervised bug detection and repair [9].

Inspired by [7, 9], we use GNNs to estimate program termination. Our baseline classifier employs Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) [40].  However, simply estimating termination behavior provides limited debugging assistance.  Ideally, we want to pinpoint the likely root cause of non-termination, similar to fault localization techniques that rank potential causes of failure based on failing and passing test cases [41].

We explore attention and semantic segmentation mechanisms from machine learning, a novel application in the context of program analysis.  Attention, mimicking cognitive attention, highlights relevant parts of the input data.  We use attention to identify instructions influential in termination estimation, visualizing the program sections the network focuses on.  We implement a second termination classifier based on the Graph Attention Network (GAT) architecture [61], anticipating improved classification compared to the GCN baseline due to the varying influence of instructions on termination.

For localizing non-termination causes, we employ semantic segmentation, typically used in image recognition to label each pixel with a class.  We apply this principle to programs, identifying statements causing non-termination.  Furthermore, we demonstrate how semantic segmentation information can be combined with program slicing to extract a non-terminating slice from the original program, simplifying debugging.

Our experimental evaluation on various datasets, including custom datasets and benchmarks from software verification competitions, demonstrates strong generalization capabilities of our learned models.

In summary, this research contributes:

* A GCN-based architecture for binary classification of program termination.
* A GAT-based architecture that improves termination classification using self-attention and visualizes relevant nodes.
* A semantic segmentation GAT that localizes nodes causing non-termination, specifically outermost infinite loops, and illustrates how this information can be used with program slicing for debugging.
* Datasets for both classification and segmentation of program termination.

Matignon a annoncé vendredi le remplacement prochain de l'Observatoire de la laïcité par un "comité interministériel de la laïcité".  L'Observatoire, créé en 2013 et présidé par l'ex-ministre socialiste Jean-Louis Bianco jusqu'en avril dernier, avait été critiqué par certains politiques qui lui reprochaient un manque de fermeté face à l'islamisme, notamment après l'assassinat de Samuel Paty et lors de l'examen du projet de loi contre les séparatismes.

Le décret créant ce comité, qui sera publié prochainement, abrogera celui de l'Observatoire. Placé sous la présidence du Premier ministre, ce comité réunira les ministères de l'Intérieur, de l'Education nationale et de la Fonction publique.  Il reprendra les missions administratives et consultatives de l'Observatoire. Un secrétariat, dont la forme sera précisée lors de la première réunion du comité le 12 juillet, sera placé sous la responsabilité du ministère de l'Intérieur.

La finalité de ce comité sera de "coordonner l'action du gouvernement afin de s'assurer du respect et la promotion du principe de laïcité par l'ensemble des administrations publiques".  Cette mise en place interviendra après l'adoption définitive par le Parlement du projet de loi confortant les principes de la République, prévue avant la trêve estivale.  Ce projet de loi prévoit notamment "une obligation de formation aux exigences du principe de laïcité pour tout agent public" et "la création de référents laïcité dans toutes les administrations".

I am against the development of driverless cars for several reasons, primarily concerning safety, job displacement, and cost-effectiveness.

My foremost concern is safety. While proponents tout the potential for reducing human error, driverless cars are still vulnerable to unforeseen circumstances.  They cannot react to every situation with the same nuanced judgment as a human driver.  Consider scenarios like sudden black ice, unexpected road debris, or navigating complex construction zones.  A sleeping passenger (a likely occurrence when one is not actively driving) would be unable to take control quickly in such situations, potentially leading to accidents, injuries, or even fatalities.  Furthermore, the legal implications of accidents involving driverless cars are still unclear, raising the possibility of drivers being held liable for malfunctions despite not being in control.

The economic impact of widespread driverless car adoption is also troubling.  Numerous jobs directly related to driving would be lost, impacting professions like taxi drivers, truckers, delivery drivers, valet parkers, and those working in parking-related industries.  This displacement could have significant economic consequences for many families.  Furthermore, the ripple effect on the broader automotive industry, including dealerships and repair shops, could be substantial.

Venus, despite its currently hostile environment, presents a compelling target for scientific study.  Evidence suggests it may once have harbored bodies of water and potentially even life, making it perhaps the only other planet in our solar system capable of supporting life. While its surface now boasts a scorching average temperature of 800 degrees Fahrenheit and an atmospheric pressure 90 times greater than Earth's—a combination that makes human landings virtually impossible—its past may hold vital clues to understanding planetary evolution and the conditions necessary for life.  This past is hinted at by the diverse geological features of Venus, including valleys, mountains, craters, and rocky sediment.

The extreme conditions on Venus are further exacerbated by erupting volcanoes, powerful earthquakes, and frequent lightning strikes, which pose significant threats to any probes attempting to land. This intense surface heat, the hottest of any planet in our solar system, is a direct result of these geological activities.

While landing on Venus remains impractical, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) is exploring alternative approaches. One such concept involves a high-altitude vehicle, similar to a jet airplane flying above storms, which would allow scientists to observe Venus while avoiding the perilous surface conditions.

However, this approach has limitations.  The dense Venusian atmosphere blocks most forms of light, making traditional photography and videography ineffective. More critically, remote observation prevents the collection of crucial physical samples like rocks and gases.  A truly comprehensive mission, therefore, would necessitate closer proximity to the surface, despite the inherent risks.

Looking forward, the development of advanced technologies may eventually enable more detailed study of Venus, including closer observation and sample collection.

For my entire life, I've perceived numbers associated with people.  These weren't hallucinations; I saw physical numbers and simultaneously heard a voice screaming them in my head.  This began as early as I can remember, leading to a childhood dominated by therapy and a diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia.  Medication blurred my memories, leaving me with only fragmented impressions of the past, corroborated by photos and other external evidence rather than genuine recollection.  Details are lost to me; the past is a single, indistinct blur.

Two memories, however, pierce through the fog.  The first is from when I was six. My uncle, a rare visitor, knocked frantically at the window while I watched TV. My sister was upstairs asleep.  Fear contorted my uncle's face. I let him in, the number 7 screaming in my mind.

Months later, I found myself in a courtroom, clutching a doll. The judge questioned me about the doll and my uncle. My family wept. The gavel fell. My uncle, shackled and led away, fixed me with a look of pure hatred.

Now, at sixteen, I've been off my medication for a few months, and my memory is slowly returning. The endless loop of blurred time is fracturing, allowing glimpses of specific events to surface.  I still hear the numbers, though. They’re constantly present – ones, twos, or threes for fellow students, up to five for teachers. I haven't heard any high numbers in a while.

It was the first day back after winter break. I arrived at Spanish class.

"Did you do the essay?" my friend Dean asked.

"I want to go to college, of course I did it. And no, I'm not letting you copy me," I replied.

"Come on, man, I want to get out of here. Can you help me out this once, please?" Dean pleaded.

"Sorry, I don't want to get in trouble."

"Mrs. Smith doesn't even read the essays," Dean whispered conspiratorially. "Rumor is her husband is a drunk and hits her. She's got more important things to worry about."

Just then, a new student entered the room.  I heard the number 10 screaming in my head, louder than ever before.

"Is this Ms. Smith's Spanish class?" the new student asked.

To deflect Dean, I blurted out, "Yes!"

The new student glanced at me and took the empty seat next to Dean.

"Why don't you just do your own homework and leave this hardworking kid alone?" he addressed Dean directly.

"What's it to you?" Dean retorted.

"I don't appreciate freeloaders getting the same treatment as hard workers. Now get out of here before I tell the teacher what you asked for. And pick up a book while you're at it."

Dean retreated to another desk. The new student slid into the seat beside me.

"Thanks," I mumbled, still shaken.

"No problem, man. I'm just trying to do what's right and let society know what's right and what's wrong. Anyways, what's your name, kid?"

"Robert Beausolil," I said. "And what about yours?"

The new student extended his hand and smiled. "Charles, Charles Manson. Nice to meet you, friend. If you want to hang out sometime, I have a few friends who throw some killer parties."

"That sounds fantastic," I replied.

Later that day, I met Charles's friends. They were incredibly accepting, more so than anyone I'd ever met. One of them described their group as a family, and I was welcome to join, as long as I promised never to betray them.

"I'm in," I said.

The internet is a curious place.  Branded as witch-hunters, hackers, social recluses, or simply trolls, we sit in our homes, consuming news faster than traditional media can deliver it, wielding the power to shape narratives and movements—though not always for the better.

In 2016, governments worldwide embraced green initiatives, but amidst domestic funding priorities, the exploration of space, our ultimate destiny, was neglected.  Earth, after all, is a temporary home.  Extinction, in some form, is inevitable.

The collective intelligence of Reddit, seemingly anticipating this, established the "Moon Fund"—a thinly veiled conduit for channeling community donations directly to NASA. By 2020, the fund had reached $2.7 billion.  However, citing war and famine, governments refused to allocate these resources to space exploration during times of hardship.  But for Reddit's community, these hardships only underscored the impending fall of humanity.  Their resolve strengthened, and the fund quickly swelled to $5.7 billion.

Coincidentally, this surge coincided with America's financial collapse. The president, in a desperate bid for solvency, offered Reddit ownership of the moon in exchange for the fund.  Heated debates erupted within the community.  Some questioned the fund's necessity. Others entertained grander visions: "If we can own the moon, why not the world? The universe?"

Amidst this turmoil, a college student from India announced a groundbreaking discovery on Reddit, seeking funding for further research. The Moon Fund, recognizing the potential, hired her directly.  Fueled by their investment, she developed the first functional wormhole.

Within a year, a working prototype emerged, and a year later, the first Reddit-funded spaceship was built.  As economies crumbled, rulers rose and fell, the world teetered on the brink of apocalypse. By 2031, the day of reckoning arrived. Reddit had constructed 21 spaceships, their first destination: the moon.  A flood of people, desperate to escape a dying world, clamored for passage to the new frontier.

Upon breaking orbit, the wormhole drives engaged, and in mere seconds, 21 ships appeared in lunar orbit. The flagship, *Swartz*, landed gracefully. A figure emerged, planting a flag—blue, and alien in design—proclaiming, "One small step for man, one giant leap for the power of Reddit." The moon was claimed in Reddit's name, and the fleet embarked on a journey through the galaxies, seeking new worlds for humanity to explore.

The city's frenetic energy was captured in a single, frozen tableau of human statues. Raindrops hung suspended in mid-air, reflecting the scene like miniature, three-dimensional mirrors. Within this static, silent sea of paused objects, a lone figure moved freely, plying his trade. He deftly lifted wallets, dollars, and other valuables from the pockets of the immobile figures.  A man of opportunity, unburdened by empathy, he was determined to exploit his unique skills to their fullest.  A jaunty whistle filled the silent void.

As the opportunistic thief worked his way down the sidewalk, he glanced up and noticed a statue seemingly settle back into place, its fabric wavering in the otherwise windless world. Unlike the others in their smooth black suits, rough blue jeans, or casual sweats and hoodies, this figure wore coarse, gray rags, bleached almost white with age, reminiscent of a monk's attire.  Its skin was completely covered, the face shrouded in darkness, save for a pair of piercing maroon eyes that stood out starkly against the silver-tinged world.  A mixture of fear and intrigue gripped the thief. What riches, what treasures, could this strange figure possess?

He cautiously approached, pausing to study the anomaly.  It was unusually tall, perhaps six foot seven, towering over the other frozen figures.  As he took another step closer, a blur of motion startled him.  A nefariously obsidian black sword, seemingly materialized from nowhere, whipped out from the figure's right arm and rested against his throat.  The maroon eyes, now intensely focused, bored into him, filling him with overwhelming dread.

"Who are you?" he stammered.

"I am ancient," the figure replied, its voice firm yet barely a whisper. "You didn't believe you were alone in this power, did you?" It spoke without the usual inflection of a question.

"Why… why do you have me at, uh… sword-point, then?" the thief asked, a flicker of intrigue battling his fear.

"Because, like others, you have diverted the world from its intended path," the figure stated emotionlessly.

"How?" the thief asked, bewildered.

"There are consequences to your actions, consequences you blindly ignore in your self-serving pursuit of profit," it explained. "Every minuscule detail, every drop of rain, every pebble, every wallet, every person… is precisely where it needs to be to ensure a future you, with your limited three-dimensional perspective, cannot comprehend."

The thief, utterly perplexed, struggled to grasp the situation unfolding before him.  "I… I guess I'm sorry?" he offered insincerely, his plea motivated solely by self-preservation.

Tactile perception is crucial for modern robotics, enhancing human-robot interaction and environmental awareness in autonomous robots.  Animals and humans rely heavily on tactile sensors in their skin and muscles for balance and agile movements [1], [2].  This principle, while fundamental in nature, has been less explored in legged robotics.  While visual feedback systems have received significant attention—for example, Plagemann et al.'s laser range finders for surface adaptation [3], Sabe et al.'s stereo-vision system [4], and Chen et al.'s combined infrared and ultrasound sensors [5]—tactile sensing offers a complementary approach.

Current legged robots often utilize direct environmental feedback from sources like sonar, LIDAR, vision, and force feedback from joint actuators.  Several studies have explored alternative methods for surface estimation. These include joint position evaluation [6], Camurri et al.'s Pronto state estimator integrating RGB camera, LIDAR, and odometry data [7], Sarkisov et al.'s landing gear using foot-pad IMU orientation and joint angles [8], and Zhang et al.'s visual estimation of tactile patterns via a camera within the robot leg [9].  Furthermore, Smith et al. coupled foot contact sensors and IMU data for reinforcement learning of locomotion skills [10], and Luneckas et al. developed a hybrid tactile sensor system for obstacle navigation in hexapod robots [11].

Adding tactile sensing to robot feet, mimicking the role of haptic sensing in animal locomotion, offers significant advantages for navigating challenging terrain.  Tactile sensors, like those employed in collaborative robots for enhanced environmental awareness through skin-like surfaces, can provide valuable information about surface properties when placed beneath a robot's feet.

This paper introduces the Touch Sensitive Foot (TSF), capable of recognizing surface textures using a trained CNN model.  This research provides an efficient pathway towards enhanced environmental awareness for autonomous robots, enabling predetermined gait adjustments for traversing unknown terrains.  This development mirrors the importance of tactile feedback in natural systems and offers a promising direction for improving legged robot locomotion.  The reported study was funded by RFBR and CNRS, project number 21-58-15006.

Serial manipulators are well-established for handling tasks in automation and production.  However, their workspace and payload are limited for large-scale applications. Cable-driven parallel robots (cable robots) overcome these limitations by using cables instead of rigid prismatic actuators to control an end-effector.  Cables, due to their flexibility and low weight, can be compactly stored on drums, enabling high maximum actuation lengths and accelerations, and thus, large workspaces. A prime example is the FAST telescope [7], a spherical radio telescope with a 600m span and a ~30-ton payload. Other applications include the Robotic Seabed Cleaning Platform (RSCP) [2] for marine litter removal and high-rack warehouse solutions [4].

Efficient operation is crucial for robotic handling tasks.  Loading and unloading require high accuracy, while inter-operational movements prioritize low energy consumption over precision. For cable robots, increased platform stiffness improves accuracy but also increases energy consumption due to higher cable forces [8]. Conversely, decreased stiffness lowers energy consumption but reduces accuracy. High cable forces necessitate high motor torques and currents, resulting in high energy consumption, while low cable forces lead to lower consumption.

Cable robots are redundant mechanisms with *m* actuated cables, where *m* ≥ *n* + 1, and *n* represents the platform's degrees of freedom (DOFs).  Verhoeven [16] highlighted the potential of cable robots to adjust platform stiffness by modulating cable preload via the nullspace.  Kraus et al. [6] presented an energy-efficient force distribution method using a gradient vector to compute a reference force and subsequently solving the static equation via the Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse. This method demonstrated lower energy consumption compared to serial kinematics with a similar operating range. However, it did not address disturbances from handling tasks (e.g., loading/unloading) or platform pose errors.  Fabritius et al. [1] introduced a nullspace-based cable force correction method to maintain predefined force limits and compensate for disturbances within the cable actuation system.

Petaling Jaya: Former Prime Minister Najib Razak has reportedly confirmed that Umno MPs signed statutory declarations supporting the formation of a new political coalition.  The Malaya Post quoted Najib as saying they agreed, conditionally, to Prime Minister Dr. Mahathir Mohamad's coalition. However, he did not disclose the conditions.  Speculation suggests the new coalition will be called Perikatan Nasional or Pakatan Nasional.

This confirmation coincided with significant political activity involving leaders from PPBM, PAS, Umno, and a faction of PKR aligned with Deputy President Mohamed Azmin Ali. Separate meetings were held by PPBM and Umno leaders, as well as Azmin's faction.  A large presence of VIP vehicles at Istana Negara fueled speculation about the imminent formation of a new coalition.  Leaders and MPs from PKR, PPBM, Umno, and PAS also gathered for dinner at the Sheraton Hotel in Petaling Jaya, although Mahathir was absent.

Meanwhile, PKR President Anwar Ibrahim's supporters gathered at his Segambut home for prayers.  Anwar confirmed an attempt to undermine Pakatan Harapan.

Later that night, Anwar met with leaders from PKR, DAP, and Amanah, the component parties of Pakatan Harapan, according to his aide. This followed intense speculation about Pakatan Harapan's collapse and the formation of a new coalition by PPBM, Umno, PAS, and some PKR members. Anwar had stated earlier that there had been an attempt to betray Pakatan Harapan, hinting at potential announcements the following day.

His political secretary, Farhash Wafa Salvador Rizal Mubarak, said the meeting's location was undisclosed.  Farhash cautioned against premature speculation about a "backdoor government," stating that such efforts had not yet succeeded. "If successful, they would have announced it," he told reporters outside Anwar's residence.  He emphasized that forming a new government was the Yang di-Pertuan Agong's prerogative, regardless of the method. He confirmed Anwar and Deputy Prime Minister Dr. Wan Azizah Wan Ismail had a scheduled audience with the Yang di-Pertuan Agong the next day, characterizing it as a pre-arranged courtesy call to brief the King on political developments.

Turkey's intervention in Syria's Idlib province reflects a complex interplay of alliances and rivalries, centered around the ongoing Syrian civil war and the fight against ISIS.  Late on Thursday, Turkish forces entered Idlib and began establishing observation posts, ostensibly as part of a "de-escalation" agreement reached with Russia and Iran in Kazakhstan last month.  This deployment, confirmed by a senior rebel involved in the operation, appears aimed at containing Kurdish forces.  The Turkish convoy of approximately 30 military vehicles entered through the Bab al-Hawa crossing and proceeded towards Sheikh Barakat, a strategic location overlooking rebel and Kurdish-held territories.

This move comes amidst escalating tensions between Turkey and the United States.  On Thursday, President Erdogan launched a verbal attack against the US, accusing them of providing weapons to the Kurdish YPG, a group Turkey considers a terrorist organization but which is a key US ally in the fight against ISIS.  He characterized Turkey's operation in Idlib, conducted with supporting rebel groups, as a serious effort to uphold the de-escalation deal. This operation aims to protect the area from attacks by Syrian government forces and Russia, as well as preventing territorial gains by Kurdish militias.  Although Turkey supports Syrian rebels and Russia backs President Assad, the two countries have been cooperating to resolve the Syrian conflict, with Erdogan and Putin holding several meetings since their 2016 reconciliation.

The Idlib de-escalation zone is one of four such zones agreed upon by Iran, Russia, and Turkey as part of the Astana peace process, which seeks to end the Syrian civil war. Three other zones—in Eastern Ghouta, central Homs, and southern Syria—are already being monitored by Russian military police.  While Idlib is largely controlled by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, a group linked to Al-Qaeda,  witnesses reported that its forces escorted the Turkish convoy, suggesting a potential understanding between the two.

However, the US-Turkish relationship has deteriorated further following the arrest of Metin Topuz, a Turkish employee of the US consulate in Istanbul, accused of links to Fethullah Gulen, whom Turkey blames for the 2016 coup attempt.  The US has denied these charges and suspended non-immigrant visa services in Turkey, prompting a reciprocal move by Turkey. This diplomatic row adds another layer of complexity to Turkey's regional actions, potentially signaling a shift in alliances against the United States.

The Turkish operation in Idlib also highlights Turkey's evolving strategy in Syria.  While a strong supporter of anti-Assad rebels, Turkey has recently prioritized border security against both jihadists and Kurdish forces. The Astana agreement aligns with this objective by reducing conflict in key areas.  Turkey's previous military involvement in Syria was the eight-month Euphrates Shield operation in Aleppo, targeting both ISIS and Kurdish militias.  The current Idlib intervention underscores Turkey’s determination to maintain influence and security in the region, even as its relationships with traditional allies become increasingly strained.

خلال مداخلةٍ شفوية أمام مجلس حقوق الإنسان التابع للأمم المتحدة في دورته السادسة والأربعين، اليوم الخميس، ذكّرت منظمة ADHRB الحقوقية الدولَ بضرورة وقف دعم مرتكبي انتهاكات حقوق الإنسان في البحرين.

وتحت البند الثامن من الحوار التفاعلي، دعت المنظمة إلى تنفيذ إعلان وبرنامج عمل فيينا، اللذين يدعوان إلى الديمقراطية والتنمية واحترام حقوق الإنسان والحريات الأساسية.  وأكدت  أنه لا يمكن تحقيق الديمقراطية ما لم يُسمَح للناس بالتعبير الحر عن أنفسهم والمشاركة الكاملة في المجتمع.

وقالت المنظمة: "في البحرين، تعاقب السلطاتُ المواطنينَ الذين يطالبون بالديمقراطية.  فخلال المظاهرات المؤيدة للديمقراطية عام 2011، دعا الملك حمد بن عيسى آل خليفة، السعوديةَ والإماراتِ إلى دخول البحرين وقمع المدنيين البحرينيين بعنف.  وقد اعتُقل آلاف المتظاهرين، ولا يزال المئات منهم في السجن حتى اليوم، ومن بينهم  المدافع عن حقوق الإنسان الدكتور عبد الجليل السنكيس، والقيادي السياسي حسن مشيمع، المحكوم عليهما بالسجن المؤبد لقيادتهما لتلك الدعوات إلى التغيير الديمقراطي".

وأضافت المنظمة: "إنّ أسرة آل خليفة الحاكمة تمثل نظامًا قمعيًا ما كان ليحافظ على سيطرته لولا تدخل القوات السعودية والإماراتية، بالإضافة إلى الدعم  الأمني والعسكري والاقتصادي غير المشروط من الولايات المتحدة والمملكة المتحدة".

واختتمت المنظمة مداخلتها بالقول: "ينبغي على المجلس أن يُذكّرَ هذه الدول بضرورة وقف دعم مرتكبي انتهاكات حقوق الإنسان في البحرين.

YPF, la principal comercializadora de combustibles del país, aumentó sus precios desde las 0 de hoy. Se espera que en las próximas horas el resto de las expendedoras también apliquen incrementos, siguiendo la tendencia marcada por la petrolera controlada por el Estado.  Este incremento se traduce en una suba del 1% en las naftas y del 1,9% en el gasoil en promedio a nivel nacional.

El origen de esta suba se encuentra en dos resoluciones de la Secretaría de Energía de la Nación, publicadas hoy en el Boletín Oficial, que datan de enero pasado.  Estas resoluciones autorizaron un aumento del 59% en el valor de la tonelada de biodiesel, componente obligatorio del corte del gasoil, y un incremento del 33% en el precio del bioetanol de caña, utilizado en la mezcla de las naftas, solo en enero.

La resolución 1/2020 establece que el precio de la tonelada de biodiesel pasa de 48.533 pesos a 77.300 pesos, con proyecciones de aumentos mensuales hasta alcanzar los 92.558 pesos en mayo, acumulando una suba del 90,6% respecto al inicio del año.  Esta misma resolución también modifica el porcentaje de corte de biocombustibles en el gasoil.  Se redujo del 10% al 5% en enero, para luego incrementarse progresivamente al 6,7% en febrero, 8% en marzo y retornar al 10% en abril.  Con esta medida, el gobierno busca moderar el impacto mensual en los precios de los combustibles, aunque se prevé que los incrementos continúen si YPF recibe la aprobación del gobierno nacional.

Por otro lado, la resolución 2/2020 fija un nuevo precio para el bioetanol de caña de azúcar.  El precio por litro será de 43,6 pesos en enero, 47,8 en febrero, 48,7 en marzo, 49,6 en abril y 51,13 en mayo.

Estos incrementos responden a los reclamos de las cámaras empresariales del sector, que solicitaron las modificaciones de precio al gobierno nacional en el contexto del debate sobre la ley de beneficios al sector, que vence en mayo próximo.  Como se ha venido informando, los referentes de los biocombustibles advertían sobre una posible parálisis de las pymes productoras de estos insumos, esenciales para la composición de los combustibles comercializados en las estaciones de servicio.

The Seagoing Cowboys program comes highly recommended, and for good reason.  Luke Bomberger's experiences illustrate the program's compelling blend of humanitarian aid, unique experiences, and international travel.

Firstly, the program offers a chance to make a tangible difference in the lives of others.  Following World War II, Luke assisted with the crucial task of replenishing food supplies and livestock in devastated European communities. His responsibilities included the care of horses, calves, and mules during their overseas transport.

Secondly, participants gain invaluable and unusual experiences.  Luke's journey began with caring for animals aboard the ship and later transitioned to the role of a night watchman.  During his time on board, he enjoyed recreational activities with fellow "cowboys," such as baseball and volleyball games in the empty animal holds.  Table tennis tournaments, boxing, fencing, reading, whittling, and other games provided further opportunities for camaraderie and personal growth.

Finally, the program facilitates travel to remarkable destinations. Luke explored the excavated ruins of a castle in Crete and witnessed the marvel of the Panama Canal en route to China.  He experienced the charm of Venice with a gondola ride and stood in awe of the Acropolis in Greece.

These examples showcase the diverse benefits of joining the Seagoing Cowboys. From aiding those in need and embracing new challenges to exploring global landmarks, the program offers a rich and rewarding experience.
