El pasado 29 de octubre se formalizó en Tartu (Estonia) la creación de ENLIGHT, un consorcio de nueve universidades europeas "referentes en investigación y con una sólida reputación".  Este consorcio, cuya propuesta ha sido seleccionada en la convocatoria Erasmus+ cuyos resultados se hicieron públicos este jueves, está formado por la Universidad de Gante (Bélgica), la Universidad de Burdeos (Francia), la Universidad Comenius de Bratislava (Eslovaquia), la Universidad Nacional de Irlanda Galway (Irlanda), la Universidad de Gotinga (Alemania), la Universidad de Groninga (Holanda), la Universidad de Tartu (Estonia), la Universidad de Upsala (Suecia) y la Universidad del País Vasco (País Vasco).

ENLIGHT representa una comunidad de 312.500 estudiantes en 12 ciudades europeas con una población total de 2.015.372 habitantes, cifra que asciende a 5.722.554 si se consideran las áreas metropolitanas. La red incluye tanto ciudades de más de 250.000 habitantes con áreas metropolitanas cercanas al millón de personas, como ciudades más pequeñas de menos de 100.000 habitantes en entornos rurales. Esta diversidad geográfica, que abarca todas las áreas de Europa, junto con su diversidad lingüística (11 lenguas), constituye uno de los grandes activos de ENLIGHT.

El objetivo principal de esta alianza es promover la calidad de vida equitativa, la sostenibilidad y el compromiso global a través de la transformación de la educación superior. Para ello, se propone generar conocimiento, habilidades y competencias, así como desplegar el potencial de innovación educativa de las universidades participantes.  De esta forma, se busca que el alumnado europeo se convierta en una ciudadanía globalmente comprometida, capaz de promover la equidad y la sostenibilidad planetaria.

La agenda compartida de ENLIGHT en formación, investigación e innovación se centra en cinco retos que abordan al menos 10 de los 17 Objetivos de Desarrollo Sostenible (ODS) de las Naciones Unidas: salud y bienestar; revolución digital e impacto de la digitalización; cambio climático; uso de la energía y economía circular; y equidad.

En esta convocatoria de Erasmus+, en la que se presentaron 64 solicitudes con la participación de más de 380 instituciones de educación superior de 32 países (26 Estados miembros de la UE -todos menos Malta-, otros cinco países del programa Erasmus+ y Reino Unido), se han seleccionado 24 proyectos.  España contó con la participación de 34 universidades, sumándose a las 33 que ya participaron en la primera convocatoria.  Alemania lideró la participación con 46 universidades, seguida de Francia con 38 e Italia con 29.

La rectora de la UPV/EHU, Nekane Balluerka, ha expresado su satisfacción por la selección del proyecto, destacando que la creación de ENLIGHT hace menos de un año "supuso un gran acierto".  Este reconocimiento, según Balluerka, "abre grandes posibilidades de colaboración académica y de proyección de nuestra docencia, nuestra investigación y nuestra transferencia".  Para el alumnado, ENLIGHT facilitará "itinerarios de aprendizaje flexibles basados en retos, la interacción constante con diversos actores internacionales y locales, y nuevas formas de movilidad internacional".

Measuring the relatedness between two words is a common task.  Automated approaches generally fall into three categories [22]: corpus-based methods, knowledge-based methods, and hybrid methods. Corpus-based methods leverage large text corpora and analyze word co-occurrence, as exemplified in [47].  Knowledge-based methods rely on structured resources like knowledge graphs or ontologies, such as in [13]. Hybrid methods combine these approaches, as seen in [38].  Due to the abundance of textual data and advancements in natural language processing, corpus-based methods have been extensively studied. Knowledge-based methods, the focus of this paper, depend on the availability and quality of a knowledge base. These methods require mapping words to knowledge base resources, bridging the gap between linguistic and knowledge-based representations.

Ontologies have become prominent knowledge representation tools, particularly for advanced reasoning, since the rise of the Semantic Web.  However, they have limitations: (i) creation and maintenance are often manual and costly; (ii) general-purpose ontologies, like WordNet, primarily contain hierarchical relations ( *is a* and *part of*) and offer limited relation types.  Note that similarity, a key concept in clustering [6], is also fundamental. Clustering, which partitions data into similar groups, has been widely studied, for instance, in ontology matching [10] to handle large-scale ontologies by decomposing instances into smaller clusters. Clustering in semantic spaces is also used for tasks like image collection summarization and self-supervision [54].  Resim (Resource Similarity), a measure for evaluating semantic similarity of DBpedia resources, was introduced, and subsequently, a more general relatedness approach was proposed in [44], which is one of the ten methods examined in this work (see Sections 5.2 and A.2.2).

This paper specifically addresses semantic relatedness, rather than the narrower concept of semantic similarity.  Domain-specific semantic relatedness measures and datasets (e.g., biomedicine [31]) are excluded because their effectiveness often doesn't generalize well [22].

The analyzed approaches are categorized into three groups based on their reliance on WordNet, Wikipedia, and Machine Learning, respectively.  Two recent methods, [39] and [2], deserve mention.  The former proposes a cross-domain item closeness measure for recommender systems based on co-occurrence counts of item-describing words on web pages. The latter evaluates semantic relatedness in unstructured data using fuzzy vectors and various relatedness techniques.  However, neither is knowledge-based and thus are excluded from our experiment.

**WordNet:**  WordNet, a relatively simple knowledge graph modeling the English lexicon, primarily contains taxonomic (*is a*) and meronymic (*part of*) relations, with fewer thematic relations (see the next section on semantic relations). Several WordNet-based semantic relatedness approaches exist [57, 5, 33].  [57] addresses relatedness in labeled tree data using WordNet's hierarchical relations.  [5] introduces a method based on weighted paths defined by non-taxonomic relations, noting that most existing methods rely on *is a*.  [33] combines WordNet with word embedding for performance improvement.  [59] defines a random walk-based algorithm, but its evaluation is limited to WordNet. This paper excludes WordNet-specific approaches, focusing on methods applicable to larger, more relationally diverse knowledge graphs.

**Wikipedia:**  Wikipedia, a vast online encyclopedia, can be viewed as a large corpus with entities described in natural language.  Extracting structured information requires substantial pre-processing.  The aforementioned WCG is a hybrid structure, not a strict *is a* taxonomy, designed for Wikipedia article management.  Research exploring the trade-off between natural language query expressivity and usability over Linked Data is valuable.  [20] presents the TREO system, combining entity search, TF-IDF [3], spreading activation, and WLM (analyzed in this work – see Sections 5.1 and A.1.1).  Similarly, [60] combines knowledge graphs and text similarity for complex question answering.  Wikipedia-focused approaches, often relying on corpus-based techniques and natural language processing beyond this work's scope, are excluded, except for WLM, analyzed in its RDF graph form.

**Machine Learning:**  Recent work applies machine learning to semantic relatedness, encoding knowledge as numerical vectors (word embedding for text, graph embedding for graphs).  Examples of word embedding for semantic relatedness include [35, 52, 65].  [35] aims for better accuracy in various contexts. [52] represents keyphrases for similar news article retrieval. [65] constructs a relatedness graph for sentiment analysis. However, the first two are corpus-based, and the third is a hybrid approach, thus excluded from our experiment.  Regarding graph embedding, [50] proposes RDF2Vec using neural networks for Linked Data relatedness. This is arguably the first approach leveraging graph structure and neural language modeling for entity relatedness/similarity. However, computational cost remains a challenge [8], with experiments on even small datasets facing termination or memory issues.  Computational efficiency in this area is an open problem [7] beyond this paper's scope.  Finally, [26] applies machine learning to images representing words, investigating cognitive mechanisms using deep convolutional neural networks but doesn't involve graph-based knowledge, the focus of this work.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) is realized through the synthesis and analysis capabilities of computational agents.  These agents employ various learning techniques and data training to achieve specified goals. When these agents are represented computationally, they are referred to as computational agents [David L. Poole, 2010; Elaine Rich, 2010]. AI has revolutionized many aspects of our lives, thanks to cutting-edge research. However, this rapidly evolving field constantly demands new paradigms to create even more accurate and reliable AI systems.  AI encompasses a broad spectrum of research areas, including machine learning, data mining, intelligent tutoring, case-based reasoning, multi-agent planning, scheduling, uncertain reasoning, natural language understanding and translation, vision, virtual reality, games, robotics, and more [Zawacki-Richter et al., 2019; Chen et al., 2020; Nilsson, 2010; Goodrich and Schultz, 2007; Buczak and Guven, 2016; Bahrammirzaee, 2010; Bengio et al., 2013; Brougham and Haar, 2018; Corvalan, 2018; Ghahramani, 2015; Castelvecchi].

Currently, Machine Learning (ML) is a particularly active area of AI research.  ML focuses on developing intelligent systems through data training. A system model trained on a dataset can then make predictions about the nature of future data (test data). Common ML techniques include data understanding (normalization and processing), regression, clustering, classification, dimension reduction, deep learning, big data handling, and online learning [McDonald, 1989; Musumeci et al., 2019; Bishop, 2006; Chapelle et al., 2006; Collobert et al., 2011; Du et al.; Freund and Schapire, 1997; Grira et al., 2004; Guyon and Elisseeff, 2006; LeCun et al., 2015a; Pedregosa et al., 2011; Vapnik, 1998]. Each technique offers unique approaches to data handling, feature computation, and output generation.

The article, "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," attempts to argue that exploring Venus is worthwhile despite the inherent risks. However, the author undermines their own argument by presenting a more compelling case *against* Venusian exploration.  The inclusion of numerous drawbacks ultimately weakens the author's thesis and damages their overall argument.

Right from the outset, the author highlights the dangers of Venus, stating that "no spacecraft survived the landing for more than a few hours" and that "not a single spaceship has touched down on Venus in more than three decades." These statements immediately create a negative impression, suggesting the extreme difficulty and potential futility of such an endeavor.  Instead of inspiring interest, the author evokes fear and apprehension by emphasizing the planet's hostility.  Phrases like "thick atmosphere," "corrosive sulfuric acid," "800 degrees Fahrenheit," and "extreme" further solidify this image of Venus as an inhospitable and dangerous world.

While the author asserts that "Venus can sometimes be our nearest option for a planetary visit," this argument lacks substantial support. The author provides little evidence to demonstrate the benefits of exploring Venus, offering significantly less detail compared to the extensive description of its dangers.  Consequently, the potential downsides—death, wasted resources, and time—seem to far outweigh any potential advantages.

The author's focus on the perilous conditions of Venus ultimately overshadows any arguments in favor of exploration.  The unlivable environment and hazardous atmosphere presented by the author inadvertently demonstrate that Venus is likely too dangerous to explore at present.  This ultimately leads the reader to conclude that the author fails to effectively support their thesis due to a lack of compelling evidence and a preponderance of counter-arguments.

Quantum computation faces a key challenge: efficiently synthesizing short sequences of implementable quantum gates, or circuits, that realize a given unitary operation. This paper addresses this challenge for Clifford circuits, a subset of unitary transformations crucial in diverse areas such as quantum error correction, state distillation, randomized benchmarking, entanglement studies, and shadow tomography [2, 5, 6, 16, 20, 21, 23, 25].  Clifford circuits are not only important components of physical-level and fault-tolerant quantum circuits but can also constitute entire algorithms, like the Bernstein-Vazirani algorithm and its generalizations [9, 25].

The Clifford group's significance stems from its property of being a unitary 2-design [11, 12]. This means random Clifford elements effectively mimic Haar random unitaries in applications depending on second-order moments, while offering the advantage of efficient circuit implementation.  For instance, randomized benchmarking leverages random Clifford sequences to efficiently estimate gate fidelities [21, 23], and classical shadows utilize random Clifford rotations to concisely represent quantum states for efficient property determination [16]. In both cases, the efficient implementation of random Clifford elements is paramount.

Furthermore, Clifford circuits facilitate basis changes in quantum simulation algorithms. They can diagonalize commuting Pauli operators, reducing circuit depth in quantum chemistry simulations [30], or identify and eliminate qubits based on symmetries, simplifying the simulation [8, 28].

While asymptotically optimal Clifford circuit synthesis exists, achieving *practically* optimal circuits with minimal entangling gates, specifically CNOT gates, remains a challenge.  We prioritize CNOT minimization due to the higher cost of entangling gates in physical implementations, initially disregarding connectivity constraints.  While ignoring connectivity can theoretically increase CNOT count or depth in the worst-case scenario (e.g., implementing a long-range CNOT gate in a linear architecture), the difference between all-to-all and Linear Nearest Neighbor (LNN) architectures appears relatively small based on known upper and lower bounds [7, 15, 22, 26].  Adapting our methods for specific connectivity constraints and depth minimization is straightforward.

Existing methods for exactly optimal Clifford synthesis are computationally expensive, limited to six qubits [10]. This necessitates efficient heuristics for larger circuits.  This paper presents heuristic approaches for synthesizing and optimizing Clifford circuits, bridging the gap between impractical optimal methods and suboptimal, albeit asymptotically optimal, techniques. Our synthesizer reduces the tableau representation of a Clifford unitary to the identity, while our optimization approach extends and modifies template matching [24] and peephole optimization [27].

Our optimization process involves three stages. First, the synthesized circuit is partitioned into "compute," "swap," and "Pauli" stages.  Pauli and swap gates are pushed to the end, allowing the "compute" stage to be optimized using templates. The "swap" stage is then optimized by merging swaps with CNOT or CZ gates.

Aaron's legs were numb.  The leather-bound swivel chair, his eight-hour-a-day prison, groaned beneath him, and the computer screen assaulted his already dry eyes.  It was 3:28—for the last hour and a half, his pupils had been mirroring the sweep of the second hand on his watch. All day, the sounds of clicking mice, ringing phones, and clacking keyboards had played like a maddening, inescapable radio. His eyes traced another lap around the clock face before briefly closing. What better time for coffee than 3:30?

He stood, letting his chair exhale as blood rushed back into his legs. For the first time in what felt like an eternity, his gaze cleared the cubicle walls, taking in the entire office, all seventeen workers, his boss included. Same people. Same spots. Every single day.

Mug of scalding, over-brewed coffee in one hand, napkin anticipating the inevitable spill in the other, he took the thirty-eight steps from the break room back to his five-by-five cubicle.  A flimsy-walled fortress offering zero privacy that he, pathetically, considered his second home.  As he settled back in, the chair groaned again, and his legs began to lose feeling. Wincing at the first, burning sip of coffee, he licked his lips and reached to set the mug down beside his keyboard, when he noticed a slip of paper.

Lip still stinging, he cautiously picked up the sheet. Glancing over his shoulder, he began to read:

> Dearest Worker,

> How cowardly of me to leave a note instead of offering a handshake. My apologies. My name is inconsequential to the events that will slowly unfold within the next hour and a half. All you truly need to know is that I wrote this note for you—only you. You cannot stop the countdown, but you are welcome to join.

> Sincere Condolences.

As the last word echoed in his mind, a voice broke the silence.

"Hey—uh," his boss stammered, "I was headed outside for a smoke, and the door's locked. Or something's blocking it. Did one of you do that?"

Seventeen pairs of eyes darted around the room, searching for an explanation.

I signed back that I couldn't.

"Go near the music," she signed, gesturing toward the bass at the edge of the crowd where I could better feel the vibration.

I felt uncomfortable. The air was thick and close, everyone pressed together.  People moved to invisible waves, like they’d all gone mad and I was the only sane one. Hearing people were strange.

"Better?" My date asked, raising her eyebrows – a non-manual marker.

"Yes," I signed back, tapping the air.

Some of the dancers were staring.

I would have been self-conscious if J hadn't smiled. J was her name sign—signed near my cheek, like the sign for “juice.” Her written name was Jenny.

Nervous and unsure what to sign, I welcomed the moment she took my hand and pressed it against the pulsating speaker.  Noticing more stares, I focused on J instead, watching her as I awkwardly swayed along with the other dancers in what felt like my own personal asylum.

I would rather have been home, watching a dubbed movie or reading a book—anything besides this exhibition where I felt like an art piece, displayed for a bunch of gawking onlookers. I was tempted to leave that very moment and drive myself home.

Unfortunately, J had driven. I desperately hoped she’d offered simply to save me the trouble of finding the place, and not because she assumed I couldn't drive.

He had been sitting all night in the overstuffed armchair in the living room, thinking. He felt miserably lonely and afraid.  A sudden stinging in his hand roused him from his contemplative staring. The cigarette had burned right down to his hand again, right between his index finger and middle finger. Reflexively, he dropped it to the floor.  Its glowing ember immediately left a black dot on the red carpet beneath him. He moved his foot over and squashed the ember with his sneaker; there were now eight more or less identical dots in a random pattern on the living room floor.

Out on the city street a police siren blared its obnoxious alarm, rising to a screeching pitch as it came down the street, then gradually fading away. The sirens frightened him. It seemed like they sounded every ten minutes. The apartment around him felt grimy.

He missed Alice's voice. He missed the comfort of its soothing, distinctly feminine tone, even amid all the others.  Its high-pitched, naturally female sound soared above – if not entirely covering – the garbled mess of the bad voices below. He had gotten used to those bad voices; he had learned to ignore them.  She soared so high above them, did they even matter anymore?

He squinted, spying the orange cylinder on the kitchen sink.  Did he take them this morning? He remembered taking them yesterday morning, but last night was a blur.  He wanted a comforting voice to soothe him.  Alice was an angel, there to protect him, but he couldn’t hear her anymore. He had blotted her out, like a hand shielding a face from the sun. No good could come from it.  He walked over to the kitchen sink, and poured what was left of the cylinder down the drain.

Kansas Cattle Producers Worry Tyson Fire Will Exacerbate Processing Bottleneck

HOLCOMB, Kan. (AP) — A fire at a Tyson meat processing plant in Holcomb has Kansas cattle producers worried about further disruptions to already strained processing operations.

The plant, which processes approximately 6,000 cattle a day—about 6% of the U.S. total—is closed indefinitely following Friday's fire.  Tyson has committed to reopening the facility, but the timeline remains uncertain pending a damage assessment.

According to the *Topeka Capital-Journal*, industry experts note the closure exacerbates existing capacity issues at meatpacking plants, which are already struggling to process a record number of cattle coming to market.

Finney County commissioner Larry Jones, a partner at J&O Cattle Co., explained that packing plants are currently operating at full capacity.

Cattle futures dropped the daily limit of $3 per hundred pounds on Monday, the first day of trading since the fire.

Let $\mathcal{M}_{n,m}(\mathbb{R})$ denote the set of $n \times m$ real matrices. When $m = n$, we use the shorthand notation $\mathcal{M}_n(\mathbb{R})$. A matrix $M = [m_{ij}]$ is said to be non-negative ($M \geq 0$) if all its entries $m_{ij}$ are non-negative, and positive ($M > 0$) if all its entries are strictly positive.  For $M \in \mathcal{M}_n(\mathbb{R})$, the characteristic polynomial of $M$ is defined by $P_M(\lambda) = |\lambda I_n - M|$, and its roots are called the eigenvalues of $M$. We index these eigenvalues in non-increasing order, denoted by $\lambda_1(M) \geq \dots \geq \lambda_n(M)$. The collection of eigenvalues, together with their multiplicities, is called the spectrum of $M$, denoted by $\sigma(M)$. The largest eigenvalue, $\lambda_1(M)$, is also called the spectral radius. The Rayleigh quotient is defined by $R(M, x) = \frac{x^T M x}{x^T x}$ for all nonzero vectors $x \in \mathbb{R}^n$.

Let $G = (V, E)$ be a simple graph with $|V| = n$ and $|E| = m$. For each vertex $v \in V$, the degree of $v$, denoted by $d(v)$, is the number of edges incident to $v$. The minimum degree of $G$ is denoted by $\delta(G) = \min\{d(v) : v \in V\}$, and the maximum degree by $\Delta(G) = \max\{d(v) : v \in V\}$. The average degree of the neighbors of $v_i \in V$ is $m_i = \frac{1}{d(v_i)} \sum_{v_j \sim v_i} d(v_j)$.

The graph $G$ is called $r$-regular if each vertex has degree $r$.  $G$ is called non-null if it has at least one edge, and connected if every pair of distinct vertices is joined by a path. The complement of $G$, denoted by $\overline{G} = (V, \overline{E})$, is the graph with the same vertex set $V$ and edge set $\overline{E}$ such that $v_i v_j \in \overline{E}$ if and only if $v_i v_j \notin E$.  If $G = (V, E)$ and $H = (W, F)$ are graphs such that $W \subset V$ and $F \subset E$, then $H$ is a subgraph of $G$. The subgraph $G - e = (V, E \setminus \{e\})$ is obtained from $G$ by deleting the edge $e$.

We denote the path with $n$ vertices by $P_n$, the complete graph by $K_n$, the complete bipartite graph with $n = n_1 + n_2$ vertices by $K_{n_1, n_2}$, and, in particular, the star graph by $K_{1,n-1}$. A wheel graph of order $n$, $W_n$, is formed by connecting all vertices of a cycle of order $n-1$ to a single universal vertex called the hub. The pineapple graph, $K_p^q$, is obtained by appending $q$ pendant edges to a vertex of a complete graph $K_p$, where $q \geq 1$ and $p \geq 3$. The binomial tree $BT_k$ is defined recursively: $BT_0$ consists of a single vertex, and $BT_k$ consists of two binomial trees $BT_{k-1}$ linked by an edge (see Figure 1).  The line graph of $G$, denoted by $L(G)$, is constructed as follows: each edge in $G$ corresponds to a vertex in $L(G)$, and two vertices in $L(G)$ are adjacent if their corresponding edges in $G$ share a vertex.  Note that $L(P_n) = P_{n-1}$ and $L(K_{1,n-1}) = K_{n-1}$ (see Figure 2).  The general Zagreb index, introduced by Gutman and Trinajestic [2], is defined by $Z^{(p)}(G) = \sum_{i=1}^n d(v_i)^p$ for $p \in \mathbb{R}$, $p \neq 0$ and $p \neq 1$.  This index seems to have been first considered by Li et al.

Prompt-tuning has emerged as a promising method for adapting pre-trained language models (PLMs) to downstream natural language processing (NLP) tasks, especially in few-shot scenarios (Gu et al., 2022; Zhang et al., 2022; Ma et al., 2022; Ye et al., 2022).  By freezing the PLM's parameters and training only a small set of prompt parameters with limited data, well-optimized few-shot prompt-tuning achieves performance comparable to full model fine-tuning across various PLM sizes and NLP tasks (Gu et al., 2022; Lester et al., 2021). This success has motivated adversaries to explore prompt-based Trojan (or backdoor) attacks (Xu et al., 2022; Cai et al., 2022; Du et al., 2022; Shi et al., 2022; Mei et al., 2023; Xue et al., 2024).  For example, a user might specify an open-source PLM and submit a training dataset to a service provider to request a prompt for a new downstream task. A malicious provider could then return a backdoored prompt.  Upon using this prompt, the PLM would misclassify inputs containing a specific trigger to a predefined target class, while classifying other inputs normally, as illustrated in Figure 1(a).

Unfortunately, existing prompt-based backdoors (Xu et al., 2022; Cai et al., 2022; Du et al., 2022; Shi et al., 2022; Mei et al., 2023) are not compatible with few-shot prompt-tuning.  They require either full model fine-tuning (Xu et al., 2022; Mei et al., 2023; Cai et al., 2022) or extensive training data (Du et al., 2022; Shi et al., 2022).  To achieve a high attack success rate (ASR), methods like BToP (Xu et al., 2022), Notable (Mei et al., 2023), and BadPrompt (Cai et al., 2022) modify a significant number of PLM parameters, making them less stealthy and more vulnerable to backdoor detection techniques (Feng et al., 2023; Zheng et al., 2023b).  While PPT (Du et al., 2022) and PromptAttack (Shi et al., 2022) only tune prompt parameters, they require hundreds of training samples for a high ASR. DecodingTrust (Wang et al., 2023) evaluates attacks using hand-crafted prompts on GPT models but doesn't address prompt-tuning scenarios.

Constructing a prompt-based backdoor through few-shot prompt-tuning, while freezing the PLM and training a smaller set of soft prompt parameters with limited data (e.g., 16-shot), presents several challenges.

Visual attention is crucial for everyday tasks like driving or playing sports.  The information our eyes receive far exceeds our processing capacity [1, 22], so we need a mechanism to prioritize the most relevant objects [37]. This prioritization, performed by human visual attention, is so efficient that we are largely unaware of it.

Attention mechanisms are also vital in computer vision, particularly for tasks mimicking human perception, like video compression where quality loss is imperceptible to viewers [15, 13], or caption generation [30, 8]. Inspired by seminal work on visual attention [36, 35, 21] and its initial computational implementations [16], researchers have developed numerous models over the past three decades [2].  A key concept is the saliency map, representing the probability of focusing on each pixel. The centralized saliency map hypothesis posits that a winner-take-all mechanism selects the most relevant location at each time step [21].

Subsequent models have refined this approach, incorporating the dynamics of human visual selection. Some attempt to improve scanpath prediction by including hand-crafted human biases for fixation selection [29] or by formalizing the increasing importance of top-down cues during visual exploration [18].  Others propose bio-inspired models that identify and rank "proto-objects" to determine attentional order [20].  However, these approaches still rely on a centralized saliency map, requiring extensive global computations across the entire visual field. This contrasts with the human visual system, which likely begins processing attention in early visual stages [5, 31] and focuses computation on a limited area [36, 33].

Zanca et al. [38, 40] introduced a physics-inspired approach, modeling attention as a continuous dynamic process.  Here, attention is a particle attracted by virtual masses representing details (brightness gradients) and motion (optical flow) within the scene.  Applicable to both static images and videos, this model also incorporates inhibition of return, reducing the saliency of previously explored areas [40]. Crucially, it bypasses the centralized saliency map, operating directly on early representations of basic features.  This offers advantages for real-time applications and enables the characterization of eye movement patterns, achieving state-of-the-art scanpath prediction despite its simplicity.  However, these gravitational models require access to all retinal information to calculate the total attraction from virtual masses, limiting their biological and computational plausibility due to their non-local nature.

This paper proposes a paradigm shift in calculating attraction, inspired by the relationship between global gravitational/electrostatic forces and the local Poisson equation. While Newtonian gravity implies instantaneous signal propagation, a static Poisson potential doesn't truly reflect the local processing of the human visual system because it requires solving the equation for each frame.  It misses the temporal dynamics of peripheral vision.

The first law of Quantum Economics states that currency doesn't exist until it's observed.  This might seem paradoxical: how can money be observed if it doesn't exist until observed?  The answer lies in the quantum foam, where at any moment, the potential exists for funds to spontaneously generate.

"But sir," Jennifer interjected, "if money can be generated spontaneously, why isn't it constantly appearing everywhere?"

"An excellent question, Jennifer, leading us to the second law of Quantum Economics: currency is generated and lost in reverse proportion to your awareness of it. This explains why a constantly monitored bank account dwindles, yet money mysteriously appears in forgotten places like your couch."

This prompted another student to ask, "So, if we ignored our bank accounts, could we have infinite money?"

"At first glance, it seems plausible. However, could you truly refrain from checking, from wondering about your balance?  Almost everyone is aware of their financial status, except perhaps the super-rich, and they face their own unique challenges."

"What kind of problems, sir?" a student inquired.

"Quantum Tax," I replied. "Remember, matter can neither be created nor destroyed. The energy required to generate currency must originate somewhere.  Ever wonder why the wealthy often seem unhappy?"

"Are you suggesting money is generated from happiness?"

"Sometimes. Emotions fuel our interactions with the world. Consider how little apathy achieves.  The potential energy of an emotionally rich life is transmuted into the currency we use daily.  Sadly, this conversion process always involves energy loss.  Attempts to replace lost emotions with currency inevitably fail."

"So, money is a useless drain on us?"

"A drain, certainly. But not necessarily useless.  Money can achieve much good: feeding the hungry, housing the homeless, healing the injured. Compared to these, what good is happiness? It can't be traded, counted, or used to build mansions or travel to the moon.  Used properly, money is a powerful tool for equalizing happiness globally.

Decision trees are widely used in machine learning due to their interpretability and ability to capture complex relationships within data.  This is particularly valuable in areas like clinical settings, where the direct link between the model and the original data is crucial.

A standard decision tree uses a sequence of ordered splits applied to the data.  Traditionally, these trees are learned using a greedy, one-step-ahead heuristic, with the CART algorithm [3] being a prominent example, producing point-estimate predictions.

Recent research has shifted towards probabilistic approaches [9] to quantify model uncertainty. Bayesian inference, while effective, introduces complexities in computing the necessary distributions. Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods are frequently employed to approximate these distributions using the law of large numbers [25].  The convergence rate of MCMC depends on the correlation between samples, making sample quality—both low correlation and high likelihood—essential for performance. While progress has been made, generating high-quality samples remains a significant challenge and the primary focus of this paper.

The core difficulty lies in simultaneously exploring the tree structure and its parameters.  This "transdimensional" nature, where the problem dimension changes with the tree structure, poses a challenge for MCMC methods.  Early work by Buntine [4] explored Bayesian averaging and smoothing for decision trees, demonstrating improved predictive accuracy over heuristic methods.  Subsequently, Chipman et al. [5] and Denison et al. [6] independently proposed MCMC-based stochastic sampling methods.  Both introduced tree-specific moves (grow, prune, change, and swap) to transition between trees, each transition representing a new sample in the chain, and observed improvements in accuracy, sometimes surpassing non-Bayesian methods.

Further advancements refined these MCMC moves.  Wu et al. [26] introduced the "radical restructure" move. Gramacy and Lee [10] leveraged binary search tree theory to enhance the swap move, later generalized by Pratola et al. [20], who also improved the change move.

Sequential Monte Carlo (SMC) offers an alternative sampling approach.  Unlike MCMC, which modifies a single tree iteratively, SMC evolves a set of "particles" (representing trees) with likelihood-based weighting.  Taddy et al. [24] explored SMC for online learning with incrementally arriving data, while Lakshminarayanan et al. [14] used it for batch learning with locally optimal moves.  However, these methods often rely on local random walks, which may propose unlikely trees, leading to low acceptance rates in MCMC and particle degeneracy in SMC. The exception is Lakshminarayanan et al.'s [14] locally optimal proposal, which, while using likelihood, remains local.  This localized approach can hinder posterior exploration due to slow convergence and poor mixing.

This paper proposes a method to improve acceptance rates and predictive accuracy by integrating Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC) sampling into the tree proposal scheme.  HMC leverages the likelihood's geometry for efficient sampling [2], using the derivative of the negative log-posterior as a "potential energy function" to guide joint updates of continuous parameters.  However, applying HMC to decision trees is complicated by their piecewise constant likelihood, which is not everywhere differentiable. To address this, we introduce two novel parameterizations: adaptation-phase hyperparameters, inspired by Linero and Yang [15], to soften the hard split constraint, and an input selection method to soften the splitting index parameter.  These techniques aim to mitigate low acceptance rates common in existing methods, potentially improving testing accuracy while simplifying tree structures.

This paper is structured as follows: Section 2 introduces the decision tree model, notation, and problem definition. Section 3 details the novel RJHMC-Tree algorithm, including its two implementations, proposal scheme, and acceptance probabilities.

Teaching evolution via natural selection faces a central challenge: its counter-intuitive nature stems from the vast spatial and temporal scales over which it operates, making it difficult to observe and understand. This has become a particularly controversial issue in the United States educational system in recent decades (Sinatra et al., 2008).  While various efforts aim to address this, incorporating evolution into games offers a promising approach by presenting the concept in a non-confrontational, accessible format.

Several games have attempted this, but encounter recurring issues.  The inherent directionless nature of natural selection often clashes with the need for directed gameplay, leading developers to introduce artificial goals. This reinforces the misconception of a guiding force in evolution, as seen in games like Spore (Bean et al., 2010).  Furthermore, some educational games prioritize scientific accuracy over enjoyment, resulting in limited player engagement. Even successful games that balance both face the challenge of reaching a wide audience. Finally, overt marketing of a game as being about evolution can alienate those resistant to the concept.  Therefore, an effective game must 1) accurately implement natural selection, 2) be enjoyable, 3) attract a large player base, and 4) avoid explicit focus on evolution.

Developing such a game is challenging, so we propose an alternative: modding.  Community modifications (mods) to existing commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) games offer a compelling solution.  Modding leverages established, popular games with existing fanbases, ensuring enjoyment and reach.  It also allows for "stealth learning" by presenting the mod as a realism enhancement (Sharp, 2012), bypassing resistance to evolution. This approach has precedent in both formal educational settings (Moshirnia, 2007) and informal learning environments, where students modify games to explore academic concepts (Bertozzi, 2014; Hayes and King, 2009; Steinkuehler and Johnson, 2009).

We explore the potential of artificial life research for teaching evolution through game mods and present a proof-of-concept mod for Stardew Valley. This popular "country life RPG" (Barone, 2020), with over 5 million owners (Orland, 2018) and an active modding community, provides an ideal platform. Our mod targets the fishing mechanic, enhancing gameplay while subtly integrating principles of natural selection. This demonstrates the feasibility of embedding evolutionary concepts within existing games for educational purposes.

Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced at the Labour congress an extension of the government's small business loan scheme until the end of the year, providing continued support during uncertain economic times.  Originally set to expire on July 24, the scheme offers interest-free loans for up to one year (3% interest thereafter) with no repayments required for the first two years.  This extension ensures businesses facing potential future cash flow difficulties will retain access to crucial funding.

“This means those businesses who are doing okay now, but who may experience cash flow difficulties further down the track, will still have access to it,” Ardern told the assembled party members at Te Papa.  Later, speaking to media, she emphasized the advantage of these loans over cash grants (as previously recommended by Treasury and the National Party), highlighting the flexibility they offer. “Sometimes they’ve drawn it down not necessarily needing it straight away, but being concerned they wouldn’t be able to access it down the track. What this does is say that if you don’t need it, you don’t have to apply but it will be there for several more months."

Eligibility criteria remain unchanged: businesses with 50 or fewer employees who qualified for the original wage subsidy can apply for loans of $10,000 plus $1,800 per equivalent full-time employee, up to a maximum of $100,000.  The existing $5.2 billion allocated to the scheme remains sufficient, as Small Business Minister Stuart Nash previously stated that uptake was not expected to reach this maximum figure, which was based on every eligible business applying.

Since May 12th, over 90,000 small businesses have applied for loans totaling more than $1.51 billion. The majority of applicants operate in construction, accommodation, restaurants and cafes, retail trade, transport, and manufacturing. Data shows that around 80% of applicants have one to five employees, and over 90% have ten or fewer. "The average value of each loan is modest, around $16,700. But it is much-needed working capital to help in a tight spot," Nash said.

Sanguine

These written words upon the page,
My linguistic tools, my trusted sage,
Are all the drug I need to stay
Sane within this world of gray.

My reckless pen spills gibberish,
Though radiant thoughts the lines embellish,
A mystery to the world outside,
Conceptions only I confide.
Through careless disregard, I see
Repeated flaws and misery.
Mend these fissures, truth revealed,
Soothe the constant aches I've concealed.

Problems cultivate and grow,
Multiplying, as I well know.
But respite nears, the fix is nigh,
For now, I must endure and try.

As leaden lids descend and close,
Torment beckons night's repose.
I pry apart my fragile mind,
Rummage through the depths I find,
Expose the secrets long concealed,
The answers I have long appealed.

But sanguine skies proclaim the end,
As body and soul now transcend.
Velvet clouds, translucent veils,
Impede my flight, my journey fails.
I close my eyes to meet my fate,
This torture I can no longer abate.

Raking sheets of memory unfurl,
Within my grasp, a twisting swirl.

Autonomous vehicles hold potential, but significant safety concerns remain.  The lack of driver engagement poses several risks.  Drivers with nothing to do may become complacent, falling asleep or losing focus, rendering them unprepared to take control in emergencies.  This disengagement could also lead to increased distractions and risky behavior within the vehicle.  Maintaining driver attention is crucial for the safety of everyone on the road.

Furthermore, the reliability of autonomous systems is a major concern.  Like any complex technology, these systems are susceptible to malfunctions and breakdowns.  Manufacturing defects, software glitches, or sensor failures could have disastrous consequences.  A malfunctioning GPS, for example, could lead drivers far off course, while a critical system failure could leave the driver stranded or worse.

Consider this scenario: You're enjoying a lively conversation in your autonomous vehicle, completely unaware of an approaching hazard requiring driver intervention.  The system, designed to alert you, malfunctions.  The car continues autonomously, believing you're in control, and tragically strikes a construction worker.  The result?  Significant financial and legal repercussions.

These examples highlight the inherent dangers: driver inattention, system malfunctions, and the potential for unforeseen circumstances.  Relying on autonomous technology could foster a culture of complacency, particularly among younger drivers, teaching them to abdicate responsibility.  In conclusion, the safety concerns surrounding autonomous vehicles are substantial and warrant serious consideration before widespread adoption.

L'application mobile Elocance, développée par Alexis Botaya, Ludovic Rateau et Sabina Khilnani, a connu un succès inattendu durant le confinement du printemps 2020.  Loin d'être plombée par la situation, l'application, qui permet de sauvegarder des contenus et de les convertir en audio grâce à une voix de synthèse, a enregistré plus de 25.000 téléchargements depuis son lancement.  Fort de ce succès, Elocance lance officiellement sa version payante, proposant un essai gratuit de quatorze jours suivi d'un abonnement mensuel à 8,99 euros ou annuel à 78,49 euros.  Ce modèle économique a déjà fait ses preuves.

Le lancement de la version payante concerne simultanément la France et les États-Unis.  Cependant, c'est outre-Atlantique que l'application semble avoir le plus fort potentiel.  "L'usage audio est plus développé dans le monde anglo-saxon.  Sans rien faire, déjà le quart de nos utilisateurs sont des Américains", explique Alexis Botaya, ex-CEO du média Soonsoonsoon.  L'habitude d'écouter des podcasts en marchant, en voiture ou en faisant du sport, fonctionnalité offerte par Elocance, est en effet plus répandue aux États-Unis.  Elocance y affrontera des concurrents comme Pocket ou l'allemand Blinkist, ce dernier comptant déjà 10 millions d'adeptes sur un créneau similaire (résumé d'ouvrages en texte ou en audio).

"En Europe, les pays latins ont un train de retard sur les pays scandinaves, patrie de Spotify, et l'Allemagne où est né Blinkist", observe Alexis Botaya.  Elocance cible, comme ses concurrents anglo-saxons, un public CSP+ composé de gros consommateurs d'information souhaitant se tenir au courant et se former, notamment dans le cadre professionnel.  Cette consommation de contenus (articles, newsletters, mails, documents PDF…) en format audio se développe au détriment de la lecture traditionnelle partout dans le monde.  Une étude de Global Market Insights prévoit d'ailleurs que le marché du "mobile e-learning" pèsera plus de 60 milliards d'euros en 2026, contre 20 milliards actuellement.

Elocance vise 2,5 millions d'inscrits, dont 50.000 utilisateurs payants, d'ici fin 2020.  Pour atteindre cet objectif, la start-up de six personnes doit encore surmonter deux obstacles.

La rue de Valois lance un appel à projets pour la création de Quartiers de commerces culturels (QCC).  Si vous envisagez de développer un commerce culturel, qu'il soit pérenne ou éphémère – librairie, disquaire, maison de la presse, galerie d’art ou boutique de créateurs (mode, design, artisanat) –, ce projet vous concerne.

Le ministère de la Culture souhaite, à travers cette initiative, soutenir la coopération entre acteurs culturels, revitaliser les territoires par la culture, promouvoir l’offre culturelle et  renouveler les espaces de sociabilité autour d’activités culturelles.

Trois types d’activités au sein des QCC seront éligibles à un soutien financier, dans le but d'accompagner les créations et garantir leur viabilité économique :

* **Accompagnement à la structuration des acteurs culturels:**  Soutien aux entrepreneurs, artisans, indépendants et artistes  par des programmes de type pépinière d'entreprises, incubateur, accélérateur, hôtel d'entreprises ou espace de co-working.
* **Soutien aux commerces culturels:** Aide à l’implantation ou au développement de commerces culturels indépendants, pérennes ou éphémères.  Cela comprend l'accompagnement à l'installation, la mise en commun d’outils de gestion, de communication ou de financements, et l'organisation d'événements.
* **Accueil du public et développement de la fréquentation:** Organisation d'expositions temporaires, d’événements culturels et participation à la formation initiale et continue (écoles d’art, enseignement spécialisé et supérieur, centres de formation, campus des métiers et des qualifications).

Un soutien financier sous forme de subvention annuelle, plafonnée à 150 000€ par projet et potentiellement reconductible entre 2021 et 2022, sera accordé.  L'aide ne pourra excéder 40% du budget total de la structure et 80% des dépenses éligibles, conformément au règlement du dispositif.

Salim Vera, cantante de Libido, se ha sumado a las voces que critican la elección de Luis Fonsi como artista principal en la inauguración de los Juegos Panamericanos Lima 2019.  Vera argumenta que se debió priorizar el talento peruano.  "Discrepo con que sea un artista internacional y no uno nacional. Estoy de acuerdo en que debió ser un peruano de todas maneras", declaró a un medio local.

El cantante de "Como un Perro"  insiste en que el Perú posee suficientes "productos musicales" de calidad como para no tener que recurrir a un artista extranjero, considerando que los Juegos se realizan en el país.  Si bien reconoce que su opinión es compartida por muchos,  aclaró que su postura no tiene relación con el género musical de Luis Fonsi.

Ante la pregunta de qué artista peruano debería haber sido elegido, Vera sugirió a su propia banda: "¿Por qué no nosotros (Libido)?".

A pesar de no participar en la ceremonia inaugural, Libido formará parte de "Culturaymi", un evento cultural dentro del marco de Lima 2019, donde se presentará el viernes 9 de agosto junto a Charlie Parra, Zen y Cuchillazo.  Este evento busca mostrar lo mejor del arte, historia y cultura del Perú a través de conciertos y otras actividades.  Cabe mencionar que Juan Diego Flórez cantará con Luis Fonsi en la inauguración de los Juegos Panamericanos.

My wife and I were strapped for cash when we discovered her pregnancy – a "happy accident," as we called it, though terrifyingly so.  We scraped together enough for the Unauthorized Reproduction fine and the minimum deposit on an Offspring Care Guarantee Fund, subsisting mainly on Soylent. (Seriously, I still can't believe that stuff became popular.)

Faced with the Genetic Aptitude Test, we opted for a free version.  They weren't well-regarded – mostly a way for the wealthy to justify their expensive "Corporate Head Huntress" results while the rest of us were supposed to believe a "People's Minister" future was possible.

The results arrived, and we tossed them.  Registering a child's aptitude before birth felt unnecessary.  We could always hope she'd prove herself in school, despite the system being rigged against those without pre-determined career paths.  Besides, the title the scientists assigned… we figured anything would be better.

Financially tight, the pregnancy itself was relatively smooth. (Don't tell my wife I said that.)  Her scheduled morning sickness, thanks to medication, and the sympathy pains I barely felt (though I may have vomited the pill fifteen minutes before she went into labor – oops) made it manageable.

Then came the standard three-hour labor, ten women to a room, the line of doctors, and Mayor Baby Kissinger lurking in the corner.  Most politicians detest cord-cutting ceremonies, but not him.  He relished them, using them for re-election fodder.  "Mayor Baby Kissinger loves our youth!" the headlines would scream.  He even had special gold-plated hemostats.  The whole thing was creepy.

So, about that Genetic Aptitude Test… We can't find the certificate, but it's irrelevant now.  I doubt the Ten Years Of Age Renaming will contradict it.  Call us negligent, but the TYOAR fee seems pointless.

Our family isn't known for schmoozing.  Mayor Kissinger was furious when our daughter, P.B., cut her own cord.  He'd planned on it being his hundredth ceremonial snip, a perfect photo op.  He wasn't too pleased when she also bit him during his attempted celebratory kiss.  Guess those fancy hemostats didn't do much for his missing lips.  Purely ornamental, it seems.

Now I'm filling out these Offspring Liability Acceptance forms.  It feels like profiling.  Do you think Pussy Grabber IV had to jump through these hoops for Pussy Grabber V?  Bullshit.

The treaty, finally ratified after arduous negotiation, marked a turning point. Earth's ambassador prepared to deliver a speech that would reshape human and galactic history.  Thirty-some alien species, comprising the Galactic Republic, had approved Earth's membership by a vote of 274 to 66 in their Parliament. The condition: the complete eradication of music from human existence. In return, humanity gained access to advanced technology through trade, ten seats in Parliament, and virtual immunity from military threat.

Reaching this point had taken fourteen months. Silencing independent artists had been relatively easy. Web hosts blocked music streaming services and aggressively scanned for audio files.  However, mainstream musicians fiercely resisted the clumsily named Initiative for Intergalactic Peace and Quiet—the UN’s campaign to eliminate music. Records were destroyed, CDs melted, and personal music players crushed.  The campaign escalated dramatically: recalcitrant record executives were jettisoned into the sun, teen idols’ vocal cords severed, and Justin Bieber himself incinerated by the President on live television. Nickelback’s final concert, a smash hit, took place within the Large Hadron Collider. These extreme measures, however regrettable, were deemed necessary for human survival. The Republic possessed weapons of unimaginable power, and their hatred of music was absolute.

Despite the existential threat, humanity was deeply reluctant to sacrifice a vital part of its culture. Secret plans were hatched. Backroom deals were struck, clandestine networks activated, and elaborate traps laid.  Meanwhile, Earth's scientists worked covertly to understand the aliens' profound aversion to music.  Theories emerged regarding biochemical and behavioral impacts on certain species, but the exact reasons remained elusive. Did music control them, or did it erode their self-control? Was it an existential threat to their regime, or an addictive substance?

The War on Music remained a mystery. Humanity’s gamble rested on the belief that the Republic would fracture if enough of its citizens were exposed to music. What better moment than the eve of their apparent victory, when they would all be watching the induction ceremony? The plan came together at the last possible second, as the ambassador approached the microphone.  The world, indeed the galaxy, held its breath, anticipating humanity's peaceful entry into the Galactic Republic. The speakers crackled, the teleprompter scrolled, and the ambassador began:

> **"Hey, I was doing just fine before I met you..."**

L'heure du bilan du mercato estival est arrivée pour l'OM, et André Villas-Boas est loin d'être satisfait. L'entraîneur marseillais affiche son agacement concernant deux dossiers qui n'ont pas été gérés comme il l'espérait.

Malgré l'arrivée de Pape Gueye, Michaël Cuisance, Leonardo Balerdi, Yuto Nagatomo et Luis Henrique, Villas-Boas, qui avait personnellement pesé pour les trois premiers, déplore le bilan du recrutement.  Le départ de Bouna Sarr au Bayern Munich au dernier jour du mercato et l'absence d'un véritable concurrent pour Dario Benedetto sont les principales raisons de son mécontentement. Le technicien portugais souhaitait le remplacement immédiat de Sarr (par Joakim Maehle du KRC Genk, par exemple) et l'arrivée d'un avant-centre confirmé avant la clôture du marché. Faute de renforts à ces deux postes clés, l'OM se retrouve démuni, ce qui irrite Villas-Boas.  D'après *L'Équipe*,  « la perte de Bouna Sarr, non compensée pour l'instant, et l'absence de cet avant-centre » sont les deux points qui « agacent vraiment AVB ».  Même l'arrivée de Luis Henrique, ailier de formation et non avant-centre comme le désirait le coach, n'a pas apaisé le Portugais, qui souhaitait un joueur capable de concurrencer, voire de remplacer, un Dario Benedetto jugé de moins en moins performant.

Si Villas-Boas avait insisté pour le recrutement de Benedetto à l'été 2019, il semblerait que,  en privé, l'entraîneur soit de plus en plus circonspect quant aux performances de l'Argentin.  *L'Équipe* affirme que, « s'il défend l'Argentin en public, le technicien portugais se montre de plus en plus réservé en privé sur les performances de l'ancien joueur de Boca Juniors ».

Pour tenter de calmer leur entraîneur, les dirigeants marseillais seraient déjà à la recherche de latéraux, notamment Fabien Centonze (FC Metz) et Kenny Lala (RC Strasbourg), pour pallier le départ de Sarr et offrir une alternative à Hiroki Sakai.

Le magret de canard, un incontournable des repas de fête, se décline à l'infini : farci, rôti, séché…  Il y en a pour tous les goûts !  Voici trois recettes gourmandes pour vous régaler.

**(Voir aussi toutes nos recettes à base de canard)**

**1. Brochettes de raisins rôtis, magret séché et dés de fromage**

Des brochettes savoureuses, idéales pour l'apéritif.  Pour encore plus de gourmandise, accompagnez-les d'un chutney de figues.

*Ingrédients (pour 6 personnes) :*

* 90 g de raisins blancs
* 90 g de raisins noirs
* 2 cuillères à soupe d'huile
* 2 cuillères à soupe de vinaigre balsamique
* 1 cuillère à café rase de graines de fenouil
* 10 tranches de magret de canard séché (ou fumé)
* 60 g d'Etivaz AOP

*Préparation :*

1. Laver et sécher les raisins.
2. Dans une grande poêle, chauffer l'huile, le vinaigre et les graines de fenouil.
3. Ajouter les raisins et les faire revenir à feu moyen pendant 3 minutes en remuant régulièrement.
4. Retirer du feu et réserver.
5. Couper l'Etivaz AOP en 10 dés.
6. Composer les brochettes en alternant raisins, dés de fromage et magret de canard.
7. Servir tiède.

*Ingrédients (pour 4 personnes) :*

* 2 brins de marjolaine
* 1 dose de safran en poudre
* 1 cuillère à soupe de miel liquide
* Sel, poivre

*Préparation :*

1. Inciser la peau des magrets sans entailler la chair. Saler et poivrer.
2. Retirer les feuilles de la rhubarbe, si nécessaire.  Peler les tiges et les couper en tronçons d'environ 5 cm.
3. Déposer les magrets côté peau dans une poêle froide. Cuire 10 minutes à feu moyen.
4. Retirer les ¾ de la graisse fondue. Retourner les magrets et poursuivre la cuisson 5 minutes côté chair.
5. Récupérer 2 cuillères à soupe de graisse de canard et les faire chauffer dans une autre poêle.
6. Y faire revenir la rhubarbe 5 minutes. Ajouter le miel et le safran. Saler, poivrer et poursuivre la cuisson 3 minutes, en gardant la rhubarbe légèrement croquante.

Businesses often focus on tangible benefits like salary, perks, and benefits—easily measurable spreadsheet items—to drive employee happiness.  However, these represent only half the equation. Intangible benefits are arguably more important, fostering a positive culture where employees feel empowered and motivated to excel.

While any company can lure talent with flashy perks, neglecting existing, loyal staff creates a detrimental imbalance.  This approach not only breeds resentment among current employees but also attracts individuals motivated by perks rather than mission or values. At TaskUs, we believe short-term rewards attract short-term employees.

Leaders must cultivate a compelling culture that allows their teams to flourish. Happy employees are more productive, boost customer satisfaction, and ultimately drive revenue growth. Conversely, poor leadership, inadequate communication, and a lack of voice contribute to employee churn and company instability.

**Servant Leadership**

Leadership shapes culture.  Servant leaders prioritize the well-being of their teams, placing the needs of others first to foster employee development and maximize potential.  They invest significant time in their people.

For example, we embrace servant leadership through happy hours at our Philippine operational sites.  Uncommon in Filipino business culture, these work-oriented happy hours differentiate us.  Our leaders serve snacks and drinks to frontline teammates, demonstrating tangibly that management is there to serve them.

While such public displays of servant leadership are valuable, the true practice lies in consistent weekly one-on-ones, providing honest and constructive feedback through coaching, and making personal sacrifices for the betterment of direct reports. Servant leaders prioritize serving their employees.

**Transparency**

Communication and transparency are essential. We empower our staff by sharing our vision and corporate goals, outlining expectations, and illustrating how individual contributions support these objectives. This fosters unified effort and progress.  We believe every team member, regardless of tenure or seniority, can contribute valuable insights.

Each quarter, our executive team dedicates a full day to strategic planning, setting top quarterly goals.  We then dedicate another full day to communicate these goals company-wide, explaining the rationale and encouraging discussion and questions.  Subsequently, each department and individual aligns their goals with these broader company initiatives.  Transparency about company direction, and more importantly, the *why* behind it, fosters a sense of inclusion and purpose.

While complete transparency isn't always feasible, sharing information—particularly the rationale behind decisions—cultivates higher employee morale, buy-in, and improved results.

**Listening**

Listening to employees is paramount.  By actively listening, we can understand employee needs and address concerns proactively.  We utilize ongoing surveys to give employees a voice and drive positive change within the workplace. Surveys are a powerful tool for predicting and influencing behavior; the simple act of participating in an engagement survey increases employee engagement.

At TaskUs, leaders undergo 360-degree reviews conducted by a third party, gathering feedback from everyone they work with. Leaders then analyze this input and develop three actionable goals, shared publicly to ensure accountability.  Actionable steps should always follow feedback.

Listening extends beyond electronic surveys.  In the Philippines, we provide dedicated dry-erase boards for employee feedback and suggestions.  Our San Antonio office utilizes sticky notes for positive reinforcement, feedback, and ideas. Internal platforms like Facebook groups can also provide valuable forums for employee expression, provided leadership actively monitors these channels.

Numerous avenues exist for listening to employees. While surveys offer a convenient approach, creative methods are equally valuable. Regular check-ins, social events, and community service initiatives contribute significantly to positive employee morale. Ultimately, actively listening to employees and acting on their feedback significantly enhances job satisfaction.

The difference between a good company and a great one lies in the intangibles.  These include empowering employees, demonstrating their impact, and fostering a sense of belonging to something larger than themselves.  As the Beatles wisely observed, money can't buy you love.  Similarly, lavish perks cannot guarantee happiness.  While intangible benefits may be "free," they require a genuine investment of time and personal commitment at every organizational level.

Visual navigation is central to most autonomous robotic applications, such as self-driving cars and service robots.  A key challenge for these robots is efficiently exploring and robustly identifying navigable space, ultimately finding the shortest paths within complex, obstacle-filled environments.  The robotics and deep learning communities have developed models trained with reinforcement learning (RL), inverse RL, or imitation learning. These models target complex scenarios requiring visual reasoning beyond simple waypoint navigation, enabling novel interactions, like responding to queries such as, "Where are my keys?"  However, current learning algorithms require vast amounts of data—hundreds of millions or even billions of interactions—to achieve such capabilities.  Acquiring this data using physical robots in real-world environments is impractical and time-consuming, potentially leading to robot damage.

To address this, the field relies heavily on simulation, which allows training to proceed significantly faster on modern hardware.  Multiple simulated environments can be easily distributed across numerous cores and machines.  However, neural networks trained in simulated environments often perform poorly when deployed in the real world due to the "sim-to-real gap."  This gap stems from inaccuracies in simulating real-world conditions, including image acquisition, sensor noise, furniture changes, and other displaced objects.  The exact nature of this gap is often difficult to pinpoint.  Even subtle, sometimes imperceptible, adversarial examples—like a few pixel shifts—can significantly alter a trained model's decisions [12, 20, 27].

Various methods address the sim-to-real gap, including domain randomization, which treats reality as a single parameterization within a vast range of simulations [25, 37], and domain adaptation, which explicitly adapts a simulation-trained model to the real world [6, 40].  However, identifying the sources of the sim-to-real gap could help experts design and optimize transfer methods by targeting specific simulator and agent design choices.

L'insécurité alimentaire mondiale s'aggrave dramatiquement.  Le nombre de personnes menacées par la famine est passé de 42 millions en début d'année à 45 millions, selon une nouvelle évaluation du Programme Alimentaire Mondial (PAM).  L'Afghanistan, où trois millions de personnes supplémentaires sont désormais confrontées à la famine, illustre tragiquement cette tendance.

« Des dizaines de millions de personnes sont au bord du gouffre. Les conflits, le changement climatique et la pandémie de Covid-19 ont exacerbé la famine aiguë », a déclaré David Beasley, directeur exécutif du PAM.  Après une visite en Afghanistan, où le PAM vient en aide à près de 23 millions de personnes, il a ajouté : « Les dernières données indiquent que plus de 45 millions de personnes sont menacées par la famine. »

M. Beasley a souligné les multiples facteurs aggravants de cette crise : « La hausse des prix du carburant et des denrées alimentaires, conjuguée à l'augmentation du coût des engrais, alimentent de nouvelles crises comme celle que connaît actuellement l'Afghanistan, et aggravent des situations d'urgence préexistantes, comme au Yémen et en Syrie. »

Le coût de la prévention de la famine à l'échelle mondiale atteint désormais sept milliards de dollars, contre 6,6 milliards en début d'année,  mettant à rude épreuve les mécanismes de financement traditionnels.

Face à l'insécurité alimentaire aiguë, les familles sont contraintes à des « choix déchirants », selon le PAM.  Mariages précoces, déscolarisation des enfants, ou encore consommation de criquets, de feuilles et de cactus pour survivre sont autant de conséquences dramatiques.  En Afghanistan, des témoignages rapportés par la presse font état de familles contraintes de vendre leurs enfants pour survivre, alerte le PAM.

L'Afghanistan est particulièrement touché par la conjonction de sécheresses répétées et d'un effondrement économique.  En Syrie, le PAM estime que 12,4 millions de personnes – un nombre record depuis le début du conflit il y a dix ans –  ne savent pas comment se procurer leur prochain repas.

Le PAM signale également des situations de famine aiguë en Éthiopie, en Haïti, en Somalie, en Angola, au Kenya et au Burundi.

The Senate ratified the bicameral conference committee report on Monday, approving the bill to reset the first regular elections in the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM).  The bill, a reconciliation of Senate Bill 2214 and House Bill 10121, shifts the BARMM parliamentary and regional elections from May 2022 to May 2025, synchronizing them with the next mid-term elections. The vote was 21 in favor, with two senators, Senate President Pro Tempore Ralph Recto and Senator Panfilo Lacson, opposed.

Under the reconciled version, the Bangsamoro Transition Authority (BTA) will continue as the interim government. The President will appoint 80 new interim BTA members who will serve until June 30, 2025, or until their successors are elected and qualified.  Senator Francis Tolentino explained that the reconciled version balances two key considerations: the President’s constitutional power of appointment and the right of the Bangsamoro people to competent and reliable leadership.

Tolentino further emphasized that extending the BTA demonstrates the government’s commitment to peace and inclusive growth in the BARMM region. He added, “Our brothers and sisters in the BARMM Region should not wait until June 2022 to have the leaders they truly deserve.”

Susan always had a way with words.  She could give a semicolon a personality; she was *that* good.  She helped me navigate school and taught me how to write (hopefully, it worked).  Her skill wasn't just about crafting beautiful sentences; it was about manipulating the truth. She could tell you something unpleasant in such a way that you wouldn't realize what she truly meant. For example, when she hadn't done her homework, she’d sheepishly tell the teacher she hadn't "figured out" the problem – not that she *couldn't*, but simply that she *hadn't*.  When people asked her opinion on their clothes, she'd either be brutally honest or deflect with compliments about individual features. That girl was amazing.

My arms and legs were riddled with scars, testaments to a life less carefully navigated, but her ebony skin had always been pristine.  It became a point of fascination – a symbol of health to some, a source of worry for others – especially after Susan and I lost touch.  During those years, whispers reached me.  Susan wasn't doing well, but she wouldn't reveal what was wrong, weaseling her way out of every conversation with her characteristic tongue-twisting. No one could figure out the truth.

I saw her again at a New Year's Eve party.  I spotted her familiar black hair through the crowd, but when I approached, her appearance shocked me.  Her ebony skin had grayed, her hair was thinner, and even her once manicured nails were scraggly and unpolished.

"Susan, what's wrong?" I asked.

She smiled wide. "Why, Martel, whatever would suggest that I am not alright?"

"Well, your appearance," I replied.

She sighed and looked back at me. "Don't worry, hon, I'll live."

In that instant, the carefully constructed facade crumbled.  A look of horror spread across her face, drawing my attention to a horrific scar that slashed across her back, a deep, crinkled, and sore-looking hollow stretching from her back to her collarbone.

"I have to leave!" she shouted, bolting from the room, her close friends in pursuit.

The next day, I learned the devastating news. Susan had taken her own life that night.

Eight months. Eight months in this tin can. Years of training. A lifetime of dreams, and eight months crammed in this metal box. But in the next 30 minutes, it will all be worth it. We'll finally reach our destination. Finally see firsthand how red this planet truly is. I can't explain how I'm feeling. Light, almost careless, yet uneasy all at once.  A strange numbness in my arms, like they're not getting enough blood. I flex them—everything works, but something feels off. Ten minutes, and I'll be down there. Ten minutes, and my team and I will have achieved more than almost any other human in history. Ten minutes, and I'll be the first. Ten minutes, and I'll be infamous. God, the journey. The pain, the sadness, the love. I don't have much to do for the landing; it's mostly in Alex's hands. I watch myself clench my fist. It's time. Time to land on this frigid, desolate, magnificent planet. 

Forty-six hours later, and I still don't feel like stopping. I don't know why. Maybe it's because I, a 170-pound man, weigh a mere 68 pounds here. Maybe it's because my heart hasn't slowed down since that rocky landing. Whatever it is, we're cruising. So far, nothing of interest. A few rocks, some soil samples, but no big-headed green aliens with ray guns. No jacked blue dudes lounging in crystal palaces. Just sand and rock, and honestly, I wouldn't have it any other way.

We received new coordinates, searching for any sign of water. Where there's water, there's life. Finding even a single microbe would be the biggest discovery, perhaps in all of human history. I can't believe we made it this far. We cruise over a cliff, approaching the coordinates.  Above, I see a shimmer. No…fucking…way. We arrive. The shimmer is ice! How long has it been here?

Exploring Venus is a worthwhile endeavor despite its inherent risks. The author champions Venusian exploration, highlighting its potential past as the most Earth-like planet in our solar system and emphasizing the scientific curiosity it ignites, while acknowledging the dangers and uncertainties involved.  As explained, "Long ago, Venus was probably covered largely with oceans and could have supported various forms of life, just like Earth. Today, Venus still has some features that are analogous to those on Earth."

The author discusses NASA's innovative concept of using a blimp-like vehicle to study Venus, offering a potential, albeit risky, solution for human exploration.  "Imagine a blimp-like vehicle hovering 30 or so miles above the roiling Venusian landscape. At thirty-plus miles above the surface, temperatures would still be toasty at around 170 degrees Fahrenheit, but the air pressure would be close to that of sea level on Earth," illustrates this ambitious approach.

Furthermore, the author highlights NASA's and other researchers' ongoing efforts to develop alternative methods of Venusian exploration, including innovations that contribute to our understanding of the planet and comparisons of the challenges and potential benefits.  This is exemplified by the exploration of robust technologies: "Another project is looking back to an old technology called mechanical computers. Modern computers are enormously powerful, flexible, and quick, but tend to be more delicate when it comes to extreme physical conditions.

Life on Venus: Hot or cold? This question drives our exploration of this fascinating planet.  An article exploring the study of Venus reveals intriguing and little-known facts, prompting us to consider the value and dangers of such research. Is studying Venus worth the risk?  The author clearly believes it is, and presents compelling reasons why.

One of the author's key arguments rests on Venus's similarity to Earth.  It's the closest planet to us in terms of density and size, earning it the nickname "Earth's twin."  However, this resemblance is superficial. Venus's thick atmosphere, composed of 97% carbon dioxide, creates incredibly high pressure and the hottest surface temperature of any planet in our solar system. These extreme conditions pose significant challenges to exploration.

Venus may have once shared Earth-like characteristics, potentially harboring vast oceans and even life, as evidenced by remnants on the planet's surface.  Despite its current inhospitable environment, Venus still possesses valleys, mountains, and craters, suggesting a landscape that once mirrored Earth's.  Scientists theorize that Venus was once much like our own planet, but now can no longer support any known life forms.

NASA is actively seeking innovative methods to send humans to Venus for further study.  Their focus is on developing technology that allows exploration without direct surface contact, perhaps by floating above the scorching landscape.  A crucial challenge lies in overcoming the immense atmospheric pressure, comparable to deep beneath Earth's oceans.  Successfully landing on Venus would dramatically expand our understanding of this enigmatic planet.

Hate speech is a widely used term lacking a universally agreed-upon definition.  Often understood as attacks targeting individuals or groups based on inherent traits, its subjective and contextual nature leaves interpretation open to individual users, media platforms (Meta, 2022; Twitter, 2022; Youtube, 2022; Microsoft, 2022b), and research groups (Djuric et al., 2015; Saleem et al., 2017; Mondal et al., 2017; Salminen et al., 2018; Jaki and De Smedt, 2019; Pereira-Kohatsu et al., 2019; Rani et al., 2020; Röttger et al., 2021). This ambiguity makes it particularly challenging to distinguish hate speech from toxic speech or even humor employing irony, sarcasm, or euphemisms.  Furthermore, definitions can be fluid (Vengattil and Culliford, 2022).

This inherent ambiguity poses significant challenges to building robust hate speech classifiers. While large tech companies possess the resources to develop and maintain their own systems, smaller companies and media outlets face significant hurdles.  They often lack the in-house expertise and resources, and data protection regulations restrict sharing data with commercial services.  The Swiss context presents further complications. Many hate speech instances are deeply embedded in Switzerland's multilingual, sociocultural, and political landscape (cf. e.g. Stevenson, 1990; Hega, 2001; Brügger et al., 2009; Mueller and Dardanelli, 2014; FDFA, 2020), going undetected by existing classifiers.  This challenge was compounded by the lack of annotated Swiss hate speech data for training a reliable baseline classifier at the time of this study.

To address this gap, we developed a human-in-the-loop hate speech classification framework designed for long-term stability and practical deployment.

I knew what I should do the moment I realized what had happened.  Off myself. Just like in all the movies and books, the moral, upstanding citizen would have ended it right there. But I didn’t.  Like the guy in a zombie movie who gets bitten and keeps it a secret, I stayed silent.

The part of me that prided itself on making the right decisions had failed. How could I have ever anticipated this? The first day was sheer terror, more at the mauling itself than its implications. By the end of the week, the terror remained, but it morphed into the crushing weight of responsibility.  So, of course, I procrastinated. I told myself I needed to get things in order, see people – all the classic excuses.  Suicide felt too…final.

Then a flicker of hope ignited.  If this was so under the radar, maybe there were others like me who *didn’t* become ravenous monsters.  Otherwise, wouldn't it be plastered all over the news?  At least, that’s what I told myself. Deep down, I knew the real reason for my hesitation, but I avoided confronting it.

And so here I sit, fully clothed.  I didn't want to wake up naked and bloody somewhere.  That's another morbid fantasy that's haunted me since the bite. Would I be in control, or just pure instinct?
