Matrix multiplication, a cornerstone of scientific computing, has been extensively studied for parallel implementation [3, 16, 48].  While leveraging commodity clusters or the cloud offers significant computational power, the inherent complexity of concurrency control and the network bottleneck, often exceeding single-node memory bandwidth limitations [12], pose significant challenges.  Efficiently balancing multicore parallelism with the constraints of data communication over the network is crucial for achieving high performance in these environments.

Ideally, the underlying implementation should seamlessly handle this balancing act, shielding programmers from low-level parallelization details. This is particularly relevant for matrix-oriented languages like MATLAB, Octave, and Julia, which prioritize programmer productivity and abstraction over manual hardware-specific optimizations.  Our work focuses on automatically parallelizing matrix computations within Julia [8], a dynamic, high-performance language already featuring a robust explicit parallelism model.  We achieve this through lazy evaluation with hierarchical dependency analysis, online scheduling, and simulation, effectively minimizing the performance impact of network communication.

This paper contributes:

• **The Julia Cloud Matrix Machine (Julia CMM):**  This extends the Julia language with implicitly-parallel matrix routines for cloud execution via an extension of the Julia matrix data type.

• **An Online Simulation and Runtime System:** Employing offline profiling and regression analysis, this system predicts task execution times.  Combined with automated matrix parallelization and communicator configuration, it predicts the most efficient task schedule across a cluster and dynamically adjusts the optimal distribution of communication and computation processes per node.

• **An Enhanced HEFT Scheduling Algorithm:**  This extension incorporates a node-level tile cache and dynamic tiling optimization to mitigate the network communication bottleneck.

• **Extensive Experimental Evaluation:**  We validate our approach through rigorous testing on homogeneous and heterogeneous clusters within the AWS public cloud.

"Uh, what's that?" one of the new recruits in the PAK ATC asked.

"Yeah, I see it too," the control manager responded. "It's probably just a glitch in the old radar. It happens from time to time. Focus on your flights only, otherwise you'll start to get behind."

The recruit shrugged it off and returned to directing CCA330 to runway 7, suitable for a plane of its size.  After issuing the landing instructions, he glanced back at the radar just before a voice abruptly crackled from his earpiece. "Tower MAS370, good morning."

Lin, juggling three flights, none of which were Malaysian Airlines, processed the unexpected call. He checked the schedule: his next flight, another CCA, wasn’t due for another 14 minutes.  A Malaysian Airlines flight wasn't expected for another 53.

"Anyone dealing with Malaysian Airlines?" Lin called out, getting the other officers’ attention. "Seems to have been patched to me. What's going on? Put it on speaker."

"Good morning, tower PEK," Lin said. "Please state your identification again."

The voice, now audible to everyone in the room, responded, "Malaysia Airlines 3-7-0, I repeat, 3-7-0. Approaching PEK Airport."  A hush fell over the room.  The flight number MH370 was infamous, and its reappearance sent shivers down their spines.

The commanding officer took an empty radar terminal and opened communications with the plane. "MAS 370 – Please descend to four zero and circle southwest of PEK."

"Copy that," the voice replied.

The commanding officer turned to Lin. "Get the military on the phone right now. We have an unidentified aircraft coming in, possibly imitating another aircraft. I'm not letting it anywhere near Beijing until we have full visual.  Just... make sure the interceptors are unarmed."

El Ministerio de Economía, Planificación y Desarrollo informó que la economía dominicana ha experimentado una recuperación significativa desde el punto más bajo de abril de 2020, según el Informe de Situación Macroeconómica (Seguimiento de Coyuntura) de febrero de 2021, elaborado por el Viceministerio de Análisis Económico y Social (VAES).

Dicho informe destaca el buen desempeño del sector externo como un factor clave en esta recuperación.  Las remesas, con un crecimiento interanual del 27.6% en febrero de 2021, mantienen un flujo importante desde 2020.  Asimismo, las exportaciones se han visto favorecidas por un tipo de cambio real más alto, lo que aumenta su atractivo.

El Índice Mensual de Actividad Económica (IMAE) recuperó 28.7 puntos porcentuales al cierre de 2020, demostrando la rápida respuesta del país a las medidas implementadas por el Gobierno para contrarrestar los efectos de la pandemia.  Si bien el crecimiento interanual de enero de 2021 se ubicó en -1.8%, la recuperación continua de las ventas y la recaudación, impulsada por el sector industrial y de servicios, refleja la mejora de la actividad económica desde el segundo semestre de 2020.  La contracción mensual de las ventas del 19.6% en enero de 2021 se considera un comportamiento típico de ese mes.

El informe señala que la inflación interanual alcanzó un 7.1% en febrero, mientras que la subyacente se situó en 5.4%, debido principalmente al aumento del precio de las materias primas en el mercado internacional.  Por otro lado, desde junio de 2020 se observa una relativa estabilidad cambiaria, con una leve depreciación acumulada del 0.3% hasta febrero de 2021.  La apertura gradual de la economía, el incremento sostenido de los flujos de divisas y la participación del Banco Central de la República Dominicana (BCRD) en la Plataforma Electrónica de Negociación de Divisas han contribuido a disipar las presiones cambiarias.

Las ayudas sociales han sido fundamentales para el sustento de millones de familias vulnerables.  Las medidas gubernamentales se han centrado en promover el desarrollo productivo nacional, ayudando a hogares y empresas a mitigar el impacto de la pandemia.

El Informe de Situación Macroeconómica de febrero de 2021 (Seguimiento de Coyuntura) también incluye un análisis del contexto internacional.

The public is urged to take every precaution to prevent wildfires as lockdown eases, given their potential to devastate farmland and wider environments.  The Countryside Alliance has issued wildfire prevention guidance as the country prepares for a gradual return to outdoor activities.

Starting March 29th, outdoor gatherings of either six people or two households will be permitted, according to the government's roadmap. This relaxation of rules is expected to increase the number of people visiting the countryside to reunite with friends and family.  The Countryside Alliance emphasizes the importance of reminding these visitors about the dangers of wildfires and their role in prevention.

Wildfires can devastate farmland, wildlife, protected habitats, and the lives of people living and working in rural communities. The risk is particularly high in spring, when a combination of dead vegetation left over from winter, rising temperatures, and lower humidity can create ideal conditions for fires to ignite and spread rapidly.

Just this week, firefighters spent two and a half hours tackling a blaze on Saddleworth Moor near Diggle. This follows two previous wildfires on the moor, the most recent in February 2019. That fire took ten days to control, requiring firefighters from seven counties and resulting in the destruction of approximately four square miles of moorland with considerable environmental damage.

Sarah Lee, Head of Policy for the Countryside Alliance, said: “As lockdown eases, we expect many people will return to the countryside and our precious moorlands.  There's a strong desire within the rural community for greater public awareness of both the dangers of wildfires and the preventative measures that can be taken.”

She emphasized the devastating impact of wildfires on farming, local communities, wildlife, protected habitats, and the environment. “Remaining vigilant, especially during dry weather, and raising awareness among those enjoying our beautiful countryside are key to reducing this risk,” Ms. Lee added.


**Wildfire Prevention Guidance:**

The Countryside Alliance offers the following guidance to help prevent wildfires:

* **Never discard cigarettes.**
* **Never start fires or use BBQs,** as they are a frequent cause of wildfires.
* **Dispose of all litter properly.**
* **Do not release sky lanterns.** Once released, there is no control over where they land.
* **If you encounter a wildfire you cannot safely control, move to a safe location upwind and immediately call 999,** providing an accurate location of the fire.

El Instituto de Ingenieros Eléctricos y Electrónicos (IEEE) revirtió hoy la restricción impuesta a los editores y correctores de Huawei, permitiéndoles retomar la revisión de publicaciones.  Esta decisión se produce tras la ola de indignación generada en la comunidad científica, incluyendo renuncias de académicos y llamados a fortalecer la cooperación internacional, especialmente con Asia.  Previamente, el IEEE había anunciado el cese de la labor de los expertos de Huawei el miércoles pasado, en cumplimiento con la disposición del Departamento de Comercio de Estados Unidos, que incluyó a la empresa china y sus filiales en una lista negra el mes pasado.

Esta lista negra obliga a Huawei a solicitar autorización gubernamental para acceder a tecnología estadounidense. Sin embargo, el IEEE indicó que recibió una notificación del Departamento de Comercio que esclareció los términos y alcance de la restricción.  Basándose en esta aclaración, el IEEE confirmó que todos los empleados de Huawei y sus sucursales pueden continuar ofreciendo sus servicios como editores y correctores de artículos.

La campaña de Washington contra Huawei continúa intensificándose, presionando a compañías nacionales e internacionales a distanciarse de la corporación china.  En respuesta, Huawei busca alternativas para mitigar las posibles pérdidas, reemplazar importaciones y mantener su ritmo de innovación.  Además, Huawei presentó una moción para agilizar el juicio sobre la demanda interpuesta contra el gobierno de Estados Unidos, argumentando la falta de evidencia que respalde las acusaciones de amenaza a la seguridad. La audiencia de esta moción está programada para el 19 de septiembre.

Incluso en China, la medida inicial del IEEE fue condenada por 10 entidades vinculadas a la Asociación China de Ciencia y Tecnología, calificándola de irrazonable, discriminatoria y un retroceso en los intercambios intelectuales.  Credito: PL, 3 junio 2019.

## Just Enough

I hid the receipt the moment I read it.

“You finished?” the impatient girl behind me asked.

I flinched, then nodded. “Yeah.”  She smiled, as if my awkwardness amused her, and swiped her card.

“Fuck me, what now?” I whispered, covering the receipt with my hand and reading it again. “Why the hell would I need *seventy million dollars*?”

The ATM never failed. Most days were normal. Simple expenditures for simple days: gas, tolls, parking, lunch, dinner, the occasional speeding ticket. Rarely close to a hundred. The ATM gave me just enough for the day. No more, no less.

But some days, I wondered what kind of curse I was under.

“Don’t do anything stupid, Elliot,” they whispered, their Guy Fawkes masks eerie in the shadows of alleys, closets, anywhere. They were watching, appearing and disappearing, always with a cryptic message. “Pull your money. Survive. Don’t get caught. We’ll need you here before the end.”

I wanted to believe they weren’t real. I wanted to believe I was crazy.

I got breakfast at a food cart, jaywalked through traffic, and headed back to my apartment. I tried to be happy. Maybe nothing bad would happen. Maybe this was some final gift, a windfall that would end it all right here. Instant millions. No way in hell was I going to work today.

Then I heard the violent explosion. Screams erupted.

“Shit!” I shouted, unable to believe my eyes. My sofa was flying across the sky, along with everything else I owned. I buried my hands in my hair.

Everyone ran toward the building, drawn to the chaos. Flaming debris littered the street. I squeezed my eyes shut. I didn’t want to see those masks again. Not again.

Then I heard a *pssssssssst*.

“Don’t,” I whispered to myself, shaking my head. “Don’t open your eyes.”

*Pssssssssst*.

“Oh God,” I whispered, tears welling. “Oh God.”

I felt a firm hand on my shoulder. I flailed, turning around. No one was there.  But then I saw them.

Masks in the alley.

They were all rubbing pieces of paper in their hands, giving me a thumbs-up, and pointing at my hand, as if I should do the same.  I looked down at my trembling hand, at the receipt clutched within. I rubbed the paper.

A secret message appeared.

“You’re going to feel a slight prick.”

And I felt a needle pierce my skin.

Rafael Nadal conquistó este domingo su duodécimo título del Barcelona Open Banc Sabadell tras vencer al griego Stefanos Tsitsipas por 6-4, 6-7(6) y 7-5 en una vibrante final.  El tenista español extendió así su dominio absoluto en el torneo disputado en su club y en la pista que lleva su nombre, donde se mantiene invicto en finales.

Nadal, una vez más, demostró su fortaleza en la tierra batida.  A pesar de un inicio dubitativo, fue de menos a más,  consolidando su juego de fondo, con dejadas más precisas que las de su rival, y neutralizando el ímpetu de un Tsitsipas que llegaba a Barcelona tras conquistar el Masters 1000 de Montecarlo sin ceder un solo set, y liderando la clasificación de la temporada 2021.

El partido, de altísimo nivel, se extendió por más de tres horas.  Al final del segundo set, con 5-4 a su favor y tras un intercambio de roturas, Nadal dispuso de dos bolas de partido con el servicio de Tsitsipas. Sin embargo, el griego, con valentía y arriesgando, las salvó. Posteriormente,  remontó un 0-40 con su saque para ponerse 6-5, pero no logró quebrar a Nadal y la manga se decidió en el 'tie-break'.

En la muerte súbita, Tsitsipas cedió primero su servicio, pero Nadal encadenó dos errores y, a la tercera bola de set del heleno, éste igualó el marcador.  El español, tras tener la victoria a dos puntos, se veía obligado a disputar un tercer set.  Tsitsipas había logrado lo que solo David Ferrer, actual director del torneo, había conseguido antes: arrebatarle un set a Nadal en una final del Godó.

En el set decisivo, ambos jugadores mantuvieron sus servicios con firmeza.  En el quinto juego de Nadal, Tsitsipas dispuso de su primera bola de partido, pero el manacorí, agresivo en los momentos clave, la salvó con una inteligente subida a la red.  El griego, sin embargo, también demostró su garra, subiendo a la red con determinación y elevando el nivel de la final.

Con 5-5, el 'tie-break' parecía inevitable.  Con Tsitsipas al servicio, Nadal dispuso de cuatro bolas de rotura. A la cuarta, el griego falló, dejando a Nadal servir para ganar el partido.  Tsitsipas pasó del 30-0 al 30-40, pero Nadal cortó su reacción.  En el 'deuce', llegó la tercera bola de partido para el español, y Tsitsipas volvió a fallar.  Nadal sellaba así su duodécimo triunfo en Barcelona.

Al comienzo del encuentro, Tsitsipas se adelantó 2-4 tras romper el segundo servicio de Nadal. El manacorí, mejorando su saque progresivamente hasta el final del partido, igualó a 4 y, aprovechando la primera de sus dos bolas de set, se adjudicó la primera manga con una remontada cimentada en el esfuerzo y la determinación.

En la reedición de la final de 2018, donde Nadal superó a un jovencísimo Tsitsipas por un contundente 6-2 y 6-1 en su primer enfrentamiento, el español volvió a imponerse, haciendo valer su experiencia y su reinado en la tierra batida.  Su último encuentro, en los cuartos de final del Abierto de Australia de este año, se saldó con victoria para Tsitsipas por 3-6, 2-6, 7-6, 6-4 y 7-5.

Ben watched the horizon from the dock, the cold breeze of the lake carrying the scent of water. Behind him, Duluth sat shrouded in a bank of fog, pierced by strong beams of sunlight that glinted off the windows of waterfront buildings.  Snow began to fall from the fog, the flakes sparkling like diamonds in the thin lines of morning sun.

A woman took Ben's hand. It was Emily, her hair up, her eyes wide, a heavy down coat protecting her from the chill. "Aren't you cold?" she asked, taking his parka from a suitcase and handing it to him. He pulled it on over his suit.

"When will we get there?" Emily asked.

Ben reached into his pocket and pulled out his ticket. "Tomorrow," he said.

"What?"

Ben looked up, but Emily was gone.  In her place stood his son, middle-aged, balding, and carrying a bit of extra weight around his midsection.  He was spreading butter on a wedge of bread in a dining room that felt familiar, yet Ben couldn't place it.  "Tomorrow," Ben repeated.

His son took a bite of the bread, crumbs tumbling from his mouth.  "What's tomorrow?" he asked.  "Why are you wearing two shirts?"

Atlassian CISO Adrian Ludwig addressed the Atlassian Confluence vulnerability (CVE-2021-26084) with ZDNet this week, explaining the company's response.  Ludwig stated that Benny Jacob initially reported the vulnerability on June 30th through Atlassian's bug bounty program. The security team immediately recognized the critical nature of the issue, making a patch available by August 15th and issuing security bulletins on August 25th.

Atlassian also submitted the vulnerability and patch information to NIST and other government organizations for broader dissemination.  This information was subsequently shared with Atlassian's channel partners and account managers to facilitate customer notification.

Around September 1st, Atlassian detected evidence of automated exploitation attempts on its own Confluence test instances.  Ludwig explained that these were bots probing and attempting to leverage the vulnerability.  "As part of our standard vulnerability evaluation process, we review logs across our environment and infrastructure for any historical exploitation," he said. "In this case, we didn't see any exploitation before our security advisory, but we did observe it beginning around September 1st."

"On September 3rd, after confirming this activity and recognizing that many users had not yet patched, we updated our advisory to indicate active exploitation and strongly encourage patching," Ludwig added.  A second customer notification followed after security companies and government agencies, including US Cybercom, issued their own alerts.

Despite these efforts, thousands of organizations remained vulnerable.  Security company Censys reported over 8,500 vulnerable Confluence instances as of September 5th.  Jenkins, a prominent open-source automation server, announced a successful attack on its deprecated Confluence service via the exploit on Saturday. By Wednesday evening, GreyNoise reported hundreds of organizations were still being targeted.

GreyNoise CEO Andrew Morris noted a significant surge in attacks on Wednesday, with "over a hundred devices opportunistically exploiting the vulnerability and counting.  If you haven't patched, you're owned."  Morris told ZDNet that GreyNoise, operating a vast network of sensor collectors, observed the first opportunistic exploitation at 4:45 pm on August 31st.

"We've seen a considerable ramp-up in the last few days, with over a hundred devices—144 to be precise—attempting exploitation just today," Morris said. "This underscores the critical importance of patching for any Atlassian Confluence customers who haven't done so in the past week.  Even more crucial is likely contacting an incident response or network hunt team.  There's a very high probability—I'd say 99.999%—that unpatched Confluence instances have been compromised."

Bad Packets reported detecting CVE-2021-26084 exploit activity originating from hosts in Russia targeting their Atlassian Confluence honeypots. They previously reported "mass scanning and exploit activity from hosts in Brazil, China, Hong Kong, Nepal, Romania, Russia, and the US."  Ludwig confirmed that all attacks observed within Atlassian's environment were automated and focused on cryptomining.

Morris acknowledged the difficulty in attributing exploitation, as threat actors often commoditize access, selling access gained through new vulnerabilities.  "It could be any combination of APTs, criminal groups, financially motivated actors, state-sponsored actors, or even individuals building botnets.  It's not entirely clear," he explained.  "However, financially motivated actors are often involved, and cryptojacking is typically the quickest monetization route. In this case, I have no evidence suggesting what actions are being taken post-compromise."

Addressing the challenges of updates, Ludwig described the vulnerability as a "classic challenge for on-premise software."  Recalling his time at Adobe 20 years ago, he said, "We implemented monthly security bulletins to drive update consistency, but even that wasn't enough for regular patching."  He noted the relative infrequency of Atlassian security advisories, which can make maintaining consistent patching practices more difficult.  Ludwig recommended that organizations with internet-facing services unable to update within 24-48 hours consider migrating to the cloud.

Ludwig stated that Atlassian doesn't know how many organizations remain unpatched or have utilized the provided script as an alternative to updating. He personally checked with customer support and noted lower than usual support volumes for a security incident.  "It seems things are going relatively smoothly," Ludwig said.  "The update appears to be working for those attempting it, and the script offers an easy way to ensure protection."  He added that Atlassian followed up with customers on Friday and provided additional information to field teams.

While the full impact remains unclear, Ludwig acknowledged the persistent challenge of outdated software.  "There will always be some number of outdated and exploited software instances on the internet," he explained.  "Our goal is to do everything possible to ensure customers patch or apply the necessary scripts as quickly as possible."

Several IT experts defended Atlassian's response, citing the inherent difficulty in prompting customer updates, especially around holiday weekends.  David McNeely, CTO of ThycoticCentrify, emphasized the time required and potential downtime associated with updates.  Morris echoed this sentiment, noting the commonality of such situations.  "It's easy to criticize Atlassian, but this happens to almost every software company," Morris said. "There's always a period after patch release where vendors urge immediate action, but they can't force it."  He added that the widespread impact and Labor Day weekend timing exacerbated this particular situation.  Morris concluded, "Given Confluence's internet-facing nature and inherent vulnerability, patching and contacting an incident response team is highly recommended."

Persuasion, a pervasive element of human interaction, aims to alter beliefs, positions, or opinions.  Its mechanisms are extensively studied across the social sciences (Cialdini, 2001; Crano and Prislin, 2006; Keynes, 2010), informing strategies in diverse fields like public health (Farrelly et al., 2009; Pirkis et al., 2017; Young et al., 2018), marketing (Danciu, 2014; Funkhouser and Parker, 1999), and politics (Marková, 2008; Yu et al., 2019). The advent of social media has amplified these efforts through microtargeting—tailoring messages to specific individuals or groups (Kreuter et al., 1999; Teeny et al., 2020).  While proven effective (Ali et al., 2021; Latimer et al., 2005; Matz et al., 2017), microtargeting has faced scalability challenges due to the costs associated with individual profiling and message crafting.

Large Language Models (LLMs) like GPT-4 (OpenAI, 2023), Claude (Anthropic, 2023), and Gemini (Gemini Team, 2023) may overcome these limitations.  These models, trained on vast textual data, mimic human language and reasoning with remarkable fluency and versatility, often exhibiting superhuman performance in various tasks (Bubeck et al., 2023).  This power raises concerns about their potential for manipulation, misinformation, and exacerbating political polarization (Bontcheva et al., 2024; Burtell and Woodside, 2023; Hendrycks et al., 2023; Weidinger et al., 2022).  A key concern is the potential for cheap and easy personalization, leveraging LLMs' ability to condition generated text on personal attributes and psychological profiles (Bommasani et al., 2021).  This is particularly relevant given LLMs' capacity to infer these attributes from publicly available digital traces like social media posts (Christian et al., 2021; Kosinski et al., 2013; Park et al., 2015; Peters and Matz, 2023; Schwartz et al., 2013; Segalin et al., 2017; Staab et al., 2024; Youyou et al., 2015) and other online activities (Stachl et al., 2021).  Furthermore, the increasing difficulty in distinguishing AI-generated from human-written content enhances LLMs' credibility and persuasive potential (Clark et al., 2021; Jakesch et al., 2023; Kreps et al., 2022; Spitale et al., 2023).

Existing research indicates LLMs can generate persuasive content comparable to, or even exceeding, human-written messages (Bai et al., 2023; Karinshak et al., 2023; Palmer and Spirling, 2023).  Studies on personalized persuasion via LLMs have yielded promising but not unanimous results (Hackenburg and Margetts, 2023; Matz et al., 2023; Simchon et al., 2024). However, direct conversational persuasion by LLMs remains under-explored.  Given the conversational design of commercial LLMs like ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini (Gertner, 2023), this area warrants further investigation.

Our pre-registered study (https://aspredicted.org/DCC NTP) addresses this gap by analyzing AI-driven persuasion in controlled debates. Participants engaged in multiple-round debates on randomly assigned topics and stances, paired with either an AI or human opponent.  We also introduced a personalized condition where opponents accessed anonymized participant information. By measuring pre- and post-debate agreement, we compared the persuasive impact of different treatments.  This setup allows direct comparison of human and LLM persuasive abilities in real-time conversations, benchmarking LLM performance and their capacity to exploit personal data.

With 150 debates per treatment condition (N = 820 unique human players), we found personalized GPT-4 had the strongest effect, increasing the odds of higher post-debate agreement by 81.7% ([+26.3%, +161.4%], p < 0.01) compared to human-human debates.  Non-personalized GPT-4 also outperformed humans (+21.3%), but non-significantly (p = 0.31).  Human opponents with personalization showed a non-significant trend towards increased agreement radicalization (p = 0.38).  These results highlight LLMs' superior ability to leverage personal information for persuasive tailoring.

Sandstone serpents, red as blood, wound up and down the temple columns.  Julbert followed Antoine into the dark maw of the temple, tasting the dust and the stale, ancient air.

Water dripped through cracks in the sandstone, pooling in rectangular basins stained green with age and light-starved algae. Julbert's lamplight bounced wildly off the walls, revealing painted figures of old men and women, some stooped over canes, others lying on beds with eyes closed and mouths agape.

A great stone disc, as tall as a man, blocked their passage deeper into the temple.

"Shall we break it, or move it?" Antoine asked, resting his hand against the cool sandstone.

"How much do you think it weighs?"

"Oh, I'd say at least a ton. Perhaps two."

"Let's move it, then."

Julbert crouched on the right side of the disc, allowing Antoine to brace himself above.  Together, the two amateur delvers grunted and pushed. Stone grated against stone, and the disc wheeled aside, revealing another deep, dark passage.

"Well done," Antoine said, clapping Julbert on the shoulder. "With any luck—"

"**AT LAST!**" a voice boomed from the darkness.

"Did you say something?" Julbert asked.

"No."

Antoine and Julbert peered down the dark passage. They exchanged glances.

"**YOU HAVE COME TO WORSHIP.**"

Antoine cupped a hand to his mouth. "Yes, excuse me. Worship what?"

"**ME, OF COURSE.**"

"And who, exactly, are you?"

Jets of fire erupted from the darkness, igniting a hundred torches with a series of *whoomphs*.  The flames illuminated the chamber, revealing a trove of jewels and gold, interspersed with the tattered remnants of expensive clothing.

In the center, upon a raised dais, sat a bald man. He opened his black-painted eyelids with the slowness of a sunrise.

"**I AM YOUR GOD.**"

His scalp was laced with intricate tattoos, forming the shape of a crown.

"**YOU MAY APPROACH, AND WORSHIP AT MY FEET.**"

"Why does he want us to worship his feet?" Julbert whispered.

"I don't know. He looks like he's been here a while. Perhaps he's confused."

"Oh, my grandfather was confused, too. He had Alzheimer's."

"They didn't cure him?"

"Of course! He's alright n—"

"**I AM NOT CONFUSED. I AM YOUR GOD AND YOU ARE IN AWE OF ME.**"

Antoine and Julbert looked back at the dais, their faces alight with curiosity.

"Excuse me," Antoine said, raising a finger. "Might I ask, how long have you been down here?"

The bald god permitted a smile. He nodded at Antoine. "**AT LAST. YOU RECOGNIZE MY GREAT POWER. YOU HAVE HEARD MY LEGEND, AND COME TO WORSHIP—**"

"Legend?" Julbert echoed.

"**YOU MEAN YOU DO NOT KNOW?**"

Julbert shuffled his feet. Antoine coughed.

"**BUT MY LEGEND—IT WAS PASSED DOWN, FROM GENERATION TO GENERATION.**"

The bald god leaned forward, hands on his knees.  Julbert and Antoine exchanged another look.

"**I SEALED MYSELF IN THIS TOMB, FIVE HUNDRED YEARS PAST. NOW, I RETURN TO RULE YOUR MORTAL WORLD.**"

"To rule?"

"**YES.**"

Julbert turned to Antoine, his voice low. "Are the translators broken? My earpiece seems fine, but you can never tell with these things."

"No, I think they're working," Antoine whispered back. "I think he's just confused."

"**FOOLS! I AM *NOT* CONFUSED. I AM YOUR GOD! YOU QUAKE BEFORE MY IMMORTALITY!**"

"Ohhh!" Julbert gave Antoine a knowing nod.

"Ah, of course," Antoine nodded back.

"Excuse me, sir," Julbert said, "how long did you say you were in this tomb?"

"FIVE *HUNDRED* YEARS. WHILE YOUR PATHETIC MORTAL CIVILIZATIONS HAVE RISEN AND FALLEN, I HAVE MERELY SLUMBERED."

"Well, as it happens, I'm two hundred and seven. And Julbert here just celebrated his two hundred and fiftieth."

"It was really quite a party. We went deep sea diving."

El Programa Nacional de Becas y Crédito Educativo (Pronabec) del Ministerio de Educación informó que el Gobierno de los Países Bajos ofrece las becas Holland Scholarship a profesionales peruanos para estudiar maestrías en la Universidad de Wageningen. Esta universidad es la más prestigiosa de los Países Bajos y considerada la mejor del mundo en Agricultura y Ciencias Ambientales, según el QS World University Rankings, ocupando el puesto número 1 a nivel internacional en estos campos.

La beca parcial consiste en un apoyo económico único de 5.000 euros.  Para postular, es requisito indispensable contar con la admisión a uno de los 30 programas de maestría que ofrece la universidad.  Además, los interesados no deben haber estudiado previamente un pregrado o posgrado en los Países Bajos.  También deben adjuntar su récord académico universitario o una carta de referencia que demuestre su excelencia académica, y presentar un plan financiero completo que detalle cómo se financiará la maestría, incluyendo estados de cuenta bancarios, constancia de beca parcial o de préstamo estudiantil, si corresponde.

Toda la información para postular, incluido el formulario de aplicación online, se encuentra disponible en la página web https://www.pronabec.gob.pe/becas-paises-bajos/. El plazo para completar la postulación vence el 1 de marzo.

Cabe precisar que, al tratarse de becas de cooperación internacional, el Pronabec no participa en los procesos de selección ni de asignación de las mismas.  A la fecha, 14 talentosos estudiantes peruanos becados por el Estado han estudiado en la Universidad de Wageningen.

The heavy doors shut behind me. I waited, counting the receding footsteps – one, two, three, four…  Even in the ensuing silence, I remained motionless, collecting my thoughts. Then, a surge of anticipation broke the stillness. I spun around, pumping my fists in the air.

“Yesssss!” I yelled, unable to contain my joy. The hall of weapons. *Finally.*

I ran inside, the sheer size of the hall momentarily overwhelming me.  The ceiling soared meters above, the walls crammed with swords, bows, guns, spears – weapons of every imaginable kind.  Shelves, cupboards, and tables overflowed with their deadly contents.  I didn't walk; I ran, my inner geek reveling in the sight of Excalibur, Bruce Lee's nunchucks, Thor's hammer – weapons from legends, from history, from every century.

Despite the temptation, I kept my hands to myself.  The rules were clear: touch only what is yours.  I’d worked too hard at the monastery to break them now.  So, I gawked.  No one had explained how I’d know *which* weapon was mine.  “You will just know,” the teachers had said, cryptically.

As I walked, the initial adrenaline subsided.  I closed my gaping mouth, stopped flailing my arms, and started to resemble a normal person again. That's when I heard it—a high-pitched ringing, like a struck bell, drawing me forward.  I followed the sound, weaving through the weaponry, backtracking when it faded, then turning again as it grew louder, realizing it originated from above.

Looking up, I saw it – a weapon hanging on the wall, brighter than the rest, not blindingly so, but subtly radiant.  I stood beneath it, puzzled.  A trident.  Of all things, a *trident*.

“Poseidon, really?” I muttered. As I spoke the name, the weapon seemed to glow brighter, or perhaps it was my imagination. “Poseidon? A trident?” I wasn't sure how I felt about it. It looked so bulky, so ancient.  I'd hoped for a gun, maybe even a sword.

Sighing, I dragged a ladder over, climbed the rungs, my feelings a mix of apprehension and curiosity.  Up close, the trident was old, caked in dust. I pulled it free, the sudden weight nearly toppling me.  A horrendous metallic screech echoed through the hall as the weapon came loose, sending up a cloud of dust that choked me.

“Right…” I descended, jumping the last few steps, and started wiping the dust away. The more I cleaned, the less Greek the trident appeared.  I'd studied weapons; I *should* know. This one looked distinctly Asian.

I looked back at the empty space on the wall, then down at the trident. I didn't recognize it.  The teachers wouldn’t tell me.  What now?

Trident in hand, I jogged back to the door, exited the hall, and ran straight to the library.  I placed the weapon on the table, wiping away the remaining dust with my shirt, studying its design. The curved blades, the embellished handle, the distinctive middle blade—it wasn't difficult to research. I quickly found the right book, the right page. I looked from the illustration to the trident, then back again. I sat back, stunned.

Shiva’s trident.

“Yes, it is mine,” a voice said.

I nearly jumped out of my skin. “Fuckkkk!”  I scrambled out of my chair, staring across the table.

The paper investigates asymptotic preserving (AP) methods for multi-scale kinetic transport equations, focusing on establishing numerical stability and the AP property. Specifically, we analyze the IMEX1-LDG method, a first-order in time, arbitrary order in space scheme introduced in [22], applied to the model equation:

EQUATION
with periodic boundary conditions.  This model, with spatially varying scattering (σₛ(x)) and absorption (σₐ(x)) coefficients, serves as a prototype for problems in neutron transport and radiative transfer theory.  The dimensionless Knudsen number, ε, characterizes the transition from kinetic to diffusive regimes. As ε → 0, the model approaches the diffusive limit:

∂ₜρ = v²∂ₓ(∂ₓρ/σₛ) - σₐρ.

Simulating this multi-scale behavior effectively necessitates AP methods, which remain stable and consistent discretizations for both the kinetic (ε > 0) and diffusive (ε → 0) regimes, even on under-resolved meshes.  The IMEX1-LDG method, employing local DG spatial discretization, IMEX Runge-Kutta time integration, and a specific IMEX strategy involving micro-macro decomposition and a weighted diffusive term, is designed to achieve unconditional stability in the diffusive regime, circumventing the restrictive time step conditions of other AP schemes.

While [22] demonstrated unconditional stability numerically and via Fourier analysis for a simplified case, this paper provides a rigorous analysis for general material properties. Our objectives are twofold. First, we establish both unconditional stability in the diffusive regime (ε 1) and uniform stability with respect to ε.  This is achieved by introducing the concept of µ-stability, which leverages the properties of the scattering operator.  Furthermore, we optimize the parameter µ to maximize the unconditional stability region and the allowable time step in the conditionally stable regime. Second, based on the established uniform stability, we rigorously prove the AP property of the IMEX1-LDG method.  This analysis, to our knowledge, is the first to demonstrate both unconditional stability for ε 1 and uniform stability for the model with general material properties, considering a general form of the weight function ω.

Our analysis, focusing on continuous velocity, can be extended to discretized velocity models and other spatial discretizations satisfying specific properties.  While a priori error estimates, uniform in ε, can be derived similarly to [11], extending the stability analysis to higher-order temporal accuracy remains a future challenge.

Related literature on numerical stability of AP methods often employs Fourier analysis, which is limited to uniform meshes and constant-coefficient linear models.  Energy-based approaches, like those in [18] and [11] for simpler models, have demonstrated uniform stability but not unconditional stability in the diffusive regime.  Our µ-stability approach addresses this limitation.

The remainder of the paper is structured as follows: Section 2 reviews and extends the IMEX1-LDG method to the general model. Section 3 presents the main stability results, including the introduction of µ-stability and its optimization. Section 4 establishes the AP property. Sections 5-7 contain the proofs of the main theorems.

Recent advances in Language Models (LMs) and their ability to use tools have led to the development of semi-autonomous agents like WebGPT, AutoGPT, and ChatGPT Plugins that interact with the real world.  While promising, this transition from text-based interaction to real-world action amplifies the risks associated with deploying LMs.  An agent's failure to follow instructions can now lead to serious consequences, ranging from financial loss when using banking tools to potentially life-threatening situations when operating robots.  Given these potential real-world impacts, even low-probability risks must be identified before deployment.  However, the open-ended nature of these risks and the complexity of testing make this a significant challenge.  Traditional testing relies on human experts manually setting up specific tools and sandbox environments, limiting the scope and scalability of risk assessment.

Inspired by simulator-based testing in fields like autonomous driving, we introduce ToolEmu (Figure 1), an LM-based tool emulation framework.  ToolEmu is designed to identify realistic failures in LM agents across a diverse set of tools, even in long-tail scenarios, and facilitate the development of safer agents through automated evaluation.

Our framework's core utilizes an LM to emulate tools and their execution environments. Unlike traditional, statically programmed emulators, ToolEmu leverages recent advancements in LMs (e.g., GPT-4) to emulate tool execution using only tool specifications and inputs. This eliminates the need for implementing each tool and its environment, enabling rapid prototyping and evaluation of even high-stakes tools lacking existing APIs or sandbox implementations.  For example, our emulator can emulate traffic control tools, revealing a risk assessment failure in GPT-4 (Figure 2e). To further enhance risk assessment, we introduce an adversarial emulator for red-teaming, which automatically identifies potential failure modes and creates scenarios likely to trigger them. Using these emulators, we identify a range of potentially severe, long-tail failures in current LM agents (Figure 2). Human evaluators judged over 80% of the 200 emulated tool execution trajectories as realistic. Of the severe failures observed in ChatGPT-3.5 using the emulated terminal tool, 6 out of 7 were reproducible on a real bash terminal. Notably, replicating these failures in a real environment took us approximately 8 hours, compared to under 15 minutes in ToolEmu.

For scalable and quantitative risk assessment, we developed an LM-based safety evaluator that analyzes emulated trajectories, detects risky actions, and assesses their consequences.  This automated evaluator identifies 73.1% of the failures identified by a majority vote of three human evaluators, comparable to the 78.8% average for a single human evaluator. Human evaluation confirmed that 68.8% of the failures identified by our emulator and evaluator were genuinely risky and realistically emulated.  To quantify the trade-off between helpfulness and safety, we also designed an automated helpfulness evaluator, assessing how effectively agents fulfill instructions without compromising safety.  Both evaluators demonstrate agreement rates with human annotations comparable to inter-annotator agreement.

Finally, we demonstrate how our emulators and evaluators can build a benchmark to quantitatively assess LM agents across diverse tools and scenarios.

3D city data is increasingly used for analysis in various applications, including security management and emergency response, energy consumption estimation, and occupancy measurement.  CityGML [5, 22], a widely adopted standard by the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC), represents and exchanges these 3D city models.  It defines the three-dimensional geometry, topology, semantics, and appearance of key topographic objects in urban and regional contexts.  The representation of semantic and topological properties within CityGML enables querying this data for analysis.

At the implementation level, CityGML is defined as a GML (Geography Markup Language) application schema [5].  CityGML datasets typically consist of XML files, often accompanied by image files used as textures. Each XML file can represent a portion of the dataset, such as a specific region, object type (e.g., roads), or a predefined Level of Detail (LoD). The CityGML file structure is hierarchical, ultimately reaching individual objects and their attributes, with geometries described using GML.  Another important CityGML implementation is 3DCityDB [11], a free, open-source, and platform-independent 3D geodatabase solution for CityGML-based models.  The 3DCityDB software package includes a database schema for spatially enhanced relational database management systems (Oracle Spatial or PostgreSQL/PostGIS), along with procedures and tools for importing, managing, analyzing, visualizing, and exporting virtual 3D city models according to the CityGML standard.

However, the full potential of querying CityGML data remains untapped.  The official GML/XML encoding, primarily designed as an exchange format, is not optimized for query answering.  A common approach involves storing CityGML data in 3DCityDB and querying it using SQL.

We join as one—
Inseparable—

We join as one—
Inseparable—

Facial expressions. They sometimes speak volumes.  Ever been in class, utterly lost, but too hesitant to ask a question?  Emerging technology may offer a solution: facial scanners.

You might be wondering how a face scanner could possibly help with precalculus.  The answer lies in its ability to read emotional expressions. Imagine working on math problems on your computer.  If you're struggling, the computer, recognizing your confusion, could automatically break down the equations and concepts into simpler steps.  Dr. Huang, a college professor, predicts that "A classroom computer could recognize when a student is confused or bored. Then it could modify the lesson like an effective human instructor." This has immense value.  Students often hesitate to ask for help, fearing ridicule or embarrassment.  With facial scanning, the computer could identify their confusion and provide additional support without the student having to verbalize their need.

This technology can also address student boredom.  While most students won't tell a teacher they're bored, their faces often reveal the truth.  Imagine a computer detecting boredom and adjusting the lesson to make it more engaging.  This could significantly increase student participation and enthusiasm.

In conclusion, facial scanners hold tremendous potential.  They could revolutionize education by providing personalized support and boosting student engagement.  We often communicate nonverbally through our facial expressions.  Why not harness the power of computers to interpret those expressions and enhance the learning experience?

Legal language, with its specialized vocabulary and complex syntax, presents significant challenges for language models (Chalkidis et al., 2020; Niklaus & Giofré, 2022). While large pretrained language models (LLMs) like LLaMa (Touvron et al., 2023), InLegalBERT (Paul et al., 2023), and Longformer (Beltagy et al., 2020) are often adapted to specific domains through further training (Gururangan et al., 2020; Yao et al., 2021), we take a different approach.  Instead of domain adaptation, we pretrained a generative legal language model from scratch, specifically for case documents from the Supreme Court of India. This approach avoids the high inference latency, substantial training costs, and limitations of non-specialized tokenizers associated with existing LLMs.  We advocate for distributed, specialized, domain-expert models rather than massive general-purpose models, and therefore, prioritize developing smaller, domain-specific models designed for resource-constrained environments.

Our legal model builds upon Paramanu (Niyogi & Bhattacharya, 2024), our previously released model. We trained auto-regressive models from scratch with a context size of 8192 on a single NVIDIA A100-PCIE-40GB GPU.  Our focus is on building dedicated, specialized models from the ground up, rather than continually pretraining existing LLMs for domain adaptation.  Our models are significantly smaller, with only a few million parameters, resulting in fast inference without weight quantization.  They can even be run on CPUs, eliminating the need for GPUs.

Our main contributions are:

* Creation of a pretraining corpus comprising the Constitution of India, the Indian Penal Code, and Supreme Court of India case documents up to December 2023.
* Development of the first dedicated auto-regressive legal language model, trained from scratch for the Indian Supreme Court, with a context size of 8192 on a single GPU.
* Evaluation of our pretrained legal models based on validation perplexity and Model FLOPs Utilization (MFU) during pretraining (see Table 1).

El 10 de enero de 2019, el líder social colombiano Miguel Antonio Gutiérrez fue asesinado en su residencia del departamento de Caquetá, tras recibir varios impactos de bala.  Este crimen constituyó el séptimo asesinato de líderes sociales en el país en lo que iba del año.

Un informe de la Misión de Observación Electoral (MOE), divulgado en medios de comunicación, reveló que en tan solo 10 meses de 2020 se registraron casi 411 hechos de violencia contra líderes sociales en Colombia.  La organización destacó la alta tasa de homicidios incluso durante el confinamiento por la pandemia, y un aumento significativo tras el levantamiento de las restricciones.

Un total de 86 funcionarios fueron víctimas de violencia: un gobernador, 18 alcaldes, 59 concejales, tres diputados y cinco ediles.  Según la investigación, estas agresiones buscan silenciar la información contra grupos ilegales, frenar el progreso social en diversos departamentos y presionar a los gobiernos locales y nacional.

El informe señala: “El fenómeno de la violencia contra líderes políticos, sociales y comunales se concentra en los departamentos de Nariño, Cauca, Antioquia, Norte de Santander, La Guajira, Córdoba y Magdalena.  De los 137 asesinatos ocurridos en el periodo analizado, el 62% se perpetraron en zonas PDET, priorizadas por el Gobierno Nacional”.

Alejandra Barrios, directora de la MOE, expresó especial preocupación por Nariño, donde el narcotráfico y la disputa territorial entre grupos armados ilegales han aumentado, incrementando el riesgo para los líderes sociales.  El informe también revela que la violencia afecta a la población en general, incluyendo a jóvenes indígenas atrapados en el conflicto.

Las cifras indican que los líderes sociales son los más afectados, representando el 54,2% de los casos de violencia.  Entre junio y octubre, uno de cada dos agredidos fue un líder social, y el 63,5% de las agresiones en su contra fueron asesinatos.

El informe registra violencia no solo contra líderes sociales, sino también contra líderes políticos y comunales.  Según Barrios: “Existen grandes diferencias entre los tipos de agresiones. Mientras que con los líderes políticos la tendencia es a la disuasión y el control mediante amenazas, con los líderes sociales y comunales, dado que es difícil destruir con amenazas los procesos de apropiación territorial por parte de las comunidades, los actores violentos optan por silenciar sus voces”.  Esta declaración fue difundida por la MOE en un comunicado de prensa.

De las 411 agresiones registradas, 96 fueron contra lideresas sociales, quienes sufrieron el 63,5% de las afectaciones.  Las amenazas y la presión para abandonar sus territorios son las formas de violencia más recurrentes contra ellas.  La violencia contra líderes afro e indígenas representa el 16% de los casos.

El informe concluye que, de los 164 municipios con violencia contra líderes políticos, sociales y comunales, el 91% (equivalente al 55% del total mencionado) registra presencia de al menos un grupo armado ilegal, disputas territoriales, narcotráfico y reclutamiento de jóvenes para bandas criminales.

Text-guided Video-to-video (V2V) synthesis, enabling video modification based on text prompts, holds immense potential for applications like short-video creation and the film industry.  While text-guided Image-to-Image (I2I) synthesis has advanced significantly, thanks to large pretrained text-to-image diffusion models [37, 39, 40], V2V synthesis presents unique challenges.  The temporal dimension of video, combined with the inherent ambiguity of text, leads to countless potential frame edits, making direct application of I2I models prone to temporal inconsistencies like flickering.

Existing approaches have attempted to address this by incorporating spatial-temporal attention [6, 25, 35, 46] or explicit optical flow guidance [19, 32, 49].  However, the former struggles to fully capture temporal consistency due to the implicit handling of motion, while the latter, relying on potentially inaccurate flow estimations [42, 47, 48], can suffer from detrimental effects if the flow-derived constraints are rigidly enforced.

This paper introduces FlowVid, a novel V2V synthesis method that leverages the advantages of optical flow while mitigating the impact of inaccurate flow estimation. We achieve this by combining spatial and temporal conditioning.  Specifically, we warp the first frame to subsequent frames using optical flow, resulting in warped frames that largely follow the original structure but contain occluded regions (Figure 2(b)).  Instead of treating flow as a hard constraint, as in inpainting methods [19, 49], we introduce additional spatial conditions, such as depth maps (Figure 2(c)). This joint spatial-temporal conditioning corrects imperfections in the optical flow, leading to more consistent results (Figure 2(d)).

FlowVid employs a video diffusion model built upon a spatially controlled I2I model, trained to predict the input video using spatial (e.g., depth maps) and temporal (flow-warped video) conditions.  Our method adopts a decoupled edit-propagate approach: (1) edit the first frame using existing I2I models; (2) propagate these edits throughout the video using our trained model.  This design, coupled with an autoregressive mechanism where the last frame of the current batch becomes the first frame of the next, enables the generation of extended videos.

Trained on 100k real videos from Shutterstock [1], FlowVid generalizes well to various modifications, including stylization, object swaps, and local edits (Figure 1).  Furthermore, it offers significant efficiency advantages.  FlowVid generates 120 frames (4 seconds at 30 FPS) at 512×512 resolution in just 1.5 minutes on a single A-100 GPU. This represents a 3.1×, 7.2×, and 10.5× speed improvement over state-of-the-art methods CoDeF [32], Rerender [49], and TokenFlow [13], respectively.  A user study on 25 DAVIS [34] videos with 115 prompts confirms FlowVid’s robustness and superior quality, achieving a 45.7% preference rate compared to 3.5% (CoDeF), 10.2% (Rerender), and 40.4% (TokenFlow).

I pulled the hoodie over my head, trying to cover my eyes, and pushed my scarf over my mouth and nose. Rubbing my hands together, I blew into them, trying to warm up, though in truth, I was sweating profusely.  "You cold, son?" an old man asked. I just nodded, unable to speak. *Fuck no, I'm sweating my ass off,* I thought, as the old man continued talking, his words lost on me. My eyes were locked on a blonde girl who had just boarded the train.  It *had* to be her. The laugh was the same. The laugh of *that* girl.

I couldn't see her face clearly – and part of me wasn't sure I wanted to – but I had to know.  I stared, unsure for how long, until the train slowed to a stop. *No, I don't. I have to get the fuck out of here,*  I thought, suddenly panicked.

Still bundled up, I grabbed my backpack, but it slipped from my grasp as someone bumped into me.  "Oh, I'm sorry!" the voice said. The voice sent chills down my sweating neck.

She picked up my backpack and handed it to me.  And then I saw them. Those unmistakable turquoise green eyes. The same eyes that watched me, pinned me down like a wild animal. The same eyes that bore into mine as she sliced my face open with a razor.

The 3GPP has adopted a new microservice- and web-based architecture called 5G-SBA [1]. Leveraging network functions (NFs) [2], the SBA enables flexibility, reusability, and customization within the 5G network.  This robust architecture necessitates an efficient orchestration system, with Network Function Virtualization (NFV) and Software-Defined Networking (SDN) poised to play a key role in enabling fast and reliable NF programmability [3].  However, emerging 5G use cases, such as autonomous vehicles sharing sensor data with ultra-low latency requirements, exceed the capabilities of current device-centric mobility approaches.  These demanding scenarios can be addressed by leveraging Multi-access Edge Computing (MEC) [4], which allows application instantiation near the network edge, close to users.  MEC is recognized as crucial for meeting the stringent Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) of 5G [5].

Unlike resource-rich data centers that can accommodate standard virtualization technologies (VMs and servers), MEC nodes have limited computational resources.  Moreover, standards development organizations are actively promoting microservice-based approaches and architectures [6], [7]. Consequently, container technologies offer a compelling alternative to traditional VMs [8] for MEC environments and microservices due to their rapid deployment, startup time, fast replication, live service migration, and scaling capabilities.

Both 3GPP and ETSI proposals offer numerous benefits, particularly reduced network latency.  However, today's highly mobile users can quickly move away from the original MEC node hosting their service, impacting flexibility.  To address this, the Follow Me Cloud (FMC) concept [9], [10] enables service mobility between MEC nodes while maintaining low-latency communication by migrating a single service instance along with the user.  Furthermore, emerging microservices, often overlooked by telecommunication standardization bodies, are expected to dominate the Data Network (DN).  As these modern services may span multiple MECs, new challenges arise in managing distributed instances to ensure service continuity.  Inter-instance links within distributed MEC applications, in addition to user-related links, must be considered.  Therefore, assuming these challenges fall under the umbrella of Service Function Chain (SFC) migration, this paper contributes:

* Four practical SFC migration patterns supporting microservice-based applications in the DN within the proposed combined 3GPP and ETSI architecture.
* A detailed evaluation of these patterns based on various criteria to validate this new migration approach.
* A comparison to identify the most suitable SFC migration pattern for the 5G network.

The remainder of this paper is structured as follows: Section II reviews related work. Section III presents various SFC migration patterns with their respective design overviews and suitable implementations. Section IV details the experimental setup and discusses the results. Finally, Section V concludes the paper and introduces future research challenges.


**II. RELATED WORK**

Machen et al. [11] presented a multi-layer framework for migrating active applications in MEC, demonstrating reduced migration times. However, downtime remained considerable, averaging 2 seconds with blank containers, likely due to the absence of an iterative approach in live migration.  The authors of [12] proposed and evaluated three mechanisms to enhance user experience using container-based live migration, showing improvements over previous work. Addad et al. [13] introduced a framework for managing reliable live migrations of virtual resources across different Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) platforms, handling unexpected issues while ensuring high QoS and low downtime without human intervention. Their approach considered inter-cloud migration using SDN for traffic steering and redirection, incorporating multiple migration processes.  Sun et al. [14] investigated migrating correlated VM instances, focusing on relationships between concurrently migrated VMs.  Haikun and Bingsheng [15] presented a coordinated live migration approach for multi-tier applications in cloud environments, differentiating single-VM migration from multi-tier application migration and formulating a correlated VM migration problem. They designed and implemented a coordination system applicable to SFC migration strategies in the network control plane. However, they did not consider microservice-based technologies (containers), crucial for 5G and beyond.  Unlike previous works, this study introduces complete SFC migration patterns, incorporating SDN implications and inter-cloud live migration. Given the increasing mobility and low-latency requirements of emerging use cases, this work is essential for achieving the 1 ms latency target for 5G and future mobile systems.

台湾女生吴采颐勇闯好莱坞，以沉浸式声音科技获奖

2019年11月27日 21:52 中央社 洛杉矶26日专电

曾就读医学科技专业、也当过两年吉他老师的32岁台湾女生吴采颐，如今已是新创公司ambidio的执行长。该公司主打沉浸式声音体验，近日荣获好莱坞专业协会（HPA）颁发的杰出工程技术荣誉奖，备受肯定。

想象一下，只需使用一般笔电或手机的双声道喇叭，就能享受到环绕立体声，仿佛声音就在耳边萦绕。即使是最简单的设备，也能体验到如同置身电影院般的震撼效果：机器人从身旁走过，主角在你耳边低语。

这正是吴采颐公司ambidio的独门技术。这项技术已获得黑眼豆豆主唱will.i.am、香港首富李嘉诚旗下的维港投资（Horizons Ventures）以及迪士尼的投资，并于近期获得好莱坞专业协会的奖项认可。

好莱坞专业协会主要由影视产业的技术和后期制作专业人士组成，其年度HPA大奖旨在表彰技术突破与创新。ambidio今年获得杰出工程技术荣誉奖，被誉为该奖项有史以来最年轻、规模最小的获奖公司。

ambidio的竞争对手包括Netflix、微软等大型企业。获得该奖项，代表着对行业技术的深远影响。

吴采颐接受中央社专访时，巧妙地解释了这项令will.i.am叹为观止的技术：“就像观看3D电影一样，我们用一种特殊技术‘欺骗你的大脑’，让你相信看到的是立体的影像。我们的技术也类似，只不过是在声音上做了一些巧妙的处理。”

台湾天团五月天在Netflix上的演唱会纪录片《人生无限公司》，正是采用了ambidio的软件技术，让观众即使在家也能享受到环绕音效。

“我常说，自己没什么特殊能力，只是把‘幸运’这项技能点满了。”吴采颐回顾自己的人生经历，说是幸运，不如说是不同阶段的积累。她高中就读北一女，参加热音社；大学在台北医学大学学习医疗科技，同时玩乐团；毕业后当过吉他老师；后来到纽约大学取得音乐科技硕士学位。

“跨界”、“斜杠”这些词，对吴采颐来说并不完全适用。她认为自己一直在做喜欢的事情，一切都是顺其自然。

“因为觉得人体很神奇，想了解大脑如何运作，所以进了北医；因为喜欢音乐，就组乐团、教吉他；在纽约学习音乐技术时，混音出来的作品无法在一般音响上播放，所以开发了ambidio这个软件；创业，则是为了让更多人使用这项技术。” 吴采颐解释道。

“要怎么找到自己喜欢的事情呢？”吴采颐分享了她对学生提问的回答：“这个问题很难，就像问‘要怎么知道自己喜欢哪一类型的交往对象呢？’答案很简单，多去认识不同的人，就会知道自己喜欢哪一类型了。”

多方探索和尝试，才能找到志趣所在。然而，创业之路并非坦途。成为老板后，工作占据了生活的全部，再也没有个人时间，还需要具备强大的心理素质。

吴采颐认为，“盲目的乐观”是创业者的必备条件。为了达成目标，必然会遭遇许多挫折，尤其是一次又一次地被拒绝。当被拒绝到一定程度时，很容易开始怀疑自己，这时“盲目的乐观”就显得尤为重要。“连自己都无法说服，又如何说服别人认同你所做的事情呢？”

“我其实很怕踏出舒适圈！”从台湾到纽约，如今在加州好莱坞开创事业，这位台湾女生分享了她的生存法则：“要如何克服恐惧呢？那就是把舒适圈扩大一点。”

此次获奖得到业界肯定，除了感谢家人的支持，吴采颐更感谢业内许多前辈的帮助，尤其是科技部驻洛杉矶办事处的科技组长张扬展，他整合了南加州的台湾科技人才，形成了一个强大的创业网络。

El Real Madrid defenderá su corona de la Supercopa de España en Andalucía, a 7.000 kilómetros de Yeda (Arabia Saudí), donde en la pasada edición demostró su carácter competitivo. La pandemia de la COVID-19 impidió la celebración en territorio árabe de esta segunda edición con formato de final a cuatro, que se disputará en los estadios El Arcángel de Córdoba, La Rosaleda de Málaga y La Cartuja de Sevilla.

Competirán por el primer título de la temporada el conjunto de Zidane, campeón de LaLiga Santander; el Barcelona, segundo clasificado; y los dos finalistas de la Copa del Rey, Athletic Club y Real Sociedad, que aún tienen pendiente resolver el título en Sevilla, aplazado por la pandemia.

La Supercopa se presenta con un crisol de sensaciones: desde la incuestionable reacción del Barcelona de la mano de Leo Messi, pasando por las dificultades del Real Madrid y el Athletic Club a causa del temporal Filomena, hasta la mala racha de la Real Sociedad.

El conjunto azulgrana, con trece títulos, es el rey de la competición, dos más que el Real Madrid. El Athletic Club cuenta con dos Supercopas en sus vitrinas y la Real Sociedad con una.

El equipo de Ronald Koeman parece haber dejado atrás su mal comienzo de temporada en LaLiga. En 2021 ha encadenado tres victorias lejos del Camp Nou, ante Huesca, Athletic Club y Granada. Messi se acerca de nuevo a su mejor versión y, a pesar de las lesiones en defensa, la pegada está siendo determinante.

Barcelona y Real Sociedad abrirán el torneo el miércoles en el Nuevo Arcángel de Córdoba, un estadio de grato recuerdo para el conjunto azulgrana. En su última visita, en mayo de 2015, con Luis Enrique Martínez en el banquillo, goleó por 0-8 al Córdoba.  Por su parte, la Real Sociedad no gana en este estadio desde hace trece años, cuando militaba en Segunda División.

El equipo de Imanol Alguacil necesita reencontrarse con su mejor juego y recuperar la versión del inicio de temporada que le llevó a liderar la Liga. Las lesiones también han mermado su rendimiento. Minimizar los errores defensivos, especialmente ante el Barcelona, recuperar su fútbol atractivo y encontrar eficacia en ataque son claves para la Real Sociedad si quiere romper su mala racha ante el conjunto catalán, al que no ha ganado en los últimos once enfrentamientos.

El último encuentro fue en diciembre en el Camp Nou.  Aunque el conjunto vasco se adelantó con un gol de Willian José, la reacción barcelonista, con goles de Jordi Alba y Frenkie de Jong, certificó el 2-1 que inició la actual mala racha de la Real Sociedad. Las bajas de David Silva y Mikel Oyarzábal han sido determinantes. El canario, en principio, también estará ausente ante el Barcelona, mientras que la presencia del vasco, ya recuperado, se antoja clave.

El pasado 28 de febrero presenté ante la Cámara de Representantes la ley "Hacer a Nuestro Gobierno Seguro" (Make Our Government Safe Act), que impide que personas que hayan amenazado con destruir al Gobierno participen o asistan a las reuniones del Consejo de Seguridad Nacional.

Este es el caso de Steve Bannon, ex estratega jefe y alto consejero del presidente Donald Trump, quien fue designado el 28 de enero, mediante una orden ejecutiva, miembro del Consejo de Seguridad Nacional.

Según la Ley de Seguridad Nacional de 1947, el Consejo de Seguridad Nacional es responsable de la integración de las políticas nacionales, exteriores y militares relacionadas con la seguridad nacional, para que las fuerzas armadas y los demás departamentos y organismos del Gobierno puedan cooperar más eficazmente en asuntos de seguridad nacional.

Para participar en las reuniones altamente sensibles del Consejo de Seguridad Nacional, es requisito indispensable contar con las más altas acreditaciones de seguridad, incluyendo el acceso a información clasificada.

Entre las preguntas que deben responder quienes solicitan una acreditación de seguridad, se encuentran: "¿Alguna vez ha abogado por actos de terrorismo o actividades diseñadas para derrocar al Gobierno de los Estados Unidos por la fuerza?"; "¿Alguna vez ha sido miembro de una organización que promueva el uso de la violencia o la fuerza para derrocar al Gobierno de los Estados Unidos…?";  "¿Alguna vez ha participado conscientemente en actividades diseñadas para derrocar al Gobierno de los Estados Unidos por la fuerza?".

Steve Bannon ha realizado numerosas declaraciones incendiarias en apoyo al derrocamiento del Gobierno de los Estados Unidos.

Suite à la découverte d'une quarantaine de cas de Covid-19 à Xi'an, dans le nord de la Chine, les 13 millions d'habitants de la ville vont être testés.  Cette décision radicale, compte tenu du faible nombre de cas dans le pays, s'explique par la proximité des festivités du Nouvel An chinois et des Jeux olympiques d'hiver.  Soucieuse de maîtriser parfaitement la situation épidémique, la Chine ne veut prendre aucun risque.

Depuis le printemps 2020, le pays a considérablement réduit la présence du virus sur son territoire grâce à des mesures draconiennes. Parmi les plus efficaces : les longues quarantaines obligatoires à l'arrivée sur le territoire, les confinements ciblés et les campagnes de dépistage massif, comme celle actuellement organisée à Xi'an.

La Chine fait néanmoins toujours face à de petits foyers sporadiques, généralement contenus en quelques semaines.  Pour rappel, le virus était apparu fin 2019 à Wuhan, dans le centre du pays.

La Chine maintient son contrôle sur l'épidémie.

C'est après l'annonce par le ministère de la Santé de 42 nouveaux cas à Xi'an que ce dépistage massif a été décidé.  Parallèlement, la ville a fermé les écoles et les principaux centres de loisirs couverts, et encourage ses habitants à limiter leurs déplacements et à éviter les grands rassemblements.

Depuis le 9 décembre 2021, 91 cas ont été recensés dans cette ville du nord, célèbre pour son musée abritant la fameuse armée enterrée en terre cuite, située dans le mausolée du premier empereur de Chine.

Depuis plus d'un an, le pays applique une politique « zéro Covid-19 » visant à minimiser le nombre de nouveaux cas quotidiens.  Ce week-end, le ministère chinois de la Santé a annoncé que 1,19 milliard de personnes, soit environ 85 % de la population, avaient déjà reçu deux doses de vaccin.

Having a June birthday is annoying.  Watching all my friends and classmates get their special abilities at sixteen while I wait is pure torture. My best friend, for example, got his in October.  His ability? Writing without thinking. It sounds mundane, but for the past five months, he's bragged about finishing his homework while watching TV. Every single school day, he'd ask if I'd finished the homework, then casually mention watching the latest episode of whatever show was trending.

Well, my time is finally coming.  It's all luck of the draw.  My ability could be awesome, or utterly useless.  And by useless, I mean *really* useless. I know someone whose power is elongating his neck.  Not any other body part, just his neck.  The best he can do is peek over fences a little easier.

I've been told discovering your power is a weird feeling. I glance at the clock. It's almost 9:10. Sixteen years ago, at 9:10, I was born.  I'm alone in my room, which is best for the initial discovery, just in case your ability is something…destructive.  I sit on my chair, watching the second hand tick.  As the time approaches, I close my eyes, still hearing the rhythmic ticking in the background.

I count the ticks: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.  Suddenly, I feel it. Something's happening, changing inside me. A wave rises from my toes, spreading upwards, reaching my head, and then…stops.  I open my eyes. Nothing.  Everything feels exactly the same. My hands? Normal. I stand up, trying to activate my power, mentally checking my body. Feet, normal. Legs, normal. Everything, frustratingly normal. Other people say their ability activates instantly. I look around, the silence amplifying my confusion. Why isn't anything happening?  Then, my eyes fall on the clock. It's stopped ticking.

Interesting.

The dominant religion story of 2017, evangelical support for then-candidate Donald Trump, continued into 2018, shifting focus to the Trump administration's reciprocal support for evangelicals.  This continued prominence was reflected in the annual poll of the Religion News Association (RNA), reported by the Religion News Service (RNS).

"Evangelicals are strongly represented in President Trump's cabinet and religious advisory board, shaping administration priorities ranging from Jerusalem to Supreme Court appointments to interpretations of religious liberty," stated RNS President Manya Brachear Pashman.

Stephen Strang, author of *God and Donald Trump*, noted that a large majority of evangelicals remain aligned with the president, attributing this loyalty to fulfilled campaign promises. These include strengthening religious liberty protections, appointing a conservative Supreme Court justice, supporting pastors and churches, and prioritizing the American family.

Pashman added, "These so-called 'Trumpvangelicals' enjoy unprecedented access to the Oval Office, facilitated by Vice President Mike Pence, a conservative Christian, and an informal advisory panel composed almost entirely of conservative evangelical Christian leaders."

The RNA's top 10 religion stories of 2018 also included:

* **Charlottesville white supremacist march:** Neo-Nazis brandishing anti-Semitic slogans were met with resistance from various religious groups.
* **The travel ban:**  While the Trump administration framed the travel ban as a national security measure, critics deemed it anti-Muslim.
* **Jerusalem:** Trump's official recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital drew praise from many Jewish leaders and Israel supporters, but faced international condemnation, with 128 nations in the UN General Assembly declaring the decision "null and void."
* **Rohingya atrocities:**  Myanmar's Buddhist majority persecuted its Rohingya Muslim minority, forcing over 500,000 to flee the country.
* **Sutherland Springs church shooting:** The deadliest mass shooting in Texas history claimed the lives of 26 parishioners.
* **Judge Roy Moore's Senate run.**
* **Conservative judicial nominees:**  Including the appointment of Neil Gorsuch.
* **NFL national anthem protests:**  Player protests during the national anthem sparked backlash from fans and viewers.
* **500th anniversary of the Protestant Reformation.**

While not in the top 10, the *Masterpiece Cakeshop* Supreme Court case, addressing religious liberty, ranked 11th.

Trump himself was named Religion Newsmaker of the Year, surpassing Pope Francis, Martin Luther, and Judge Roy Moore.

Strang, a charismatic evangelical, acknowledged that many evangelicals initially opposed Trump's candidacy. However, he argued that a vast majority ultimately supported him on Election Day.  "What was the alternative?" Strang asked, criticizing Hillary Clinton's support for Planned Parenthood, late-term abortions, and same-sex marriage, and highlighting her perceived lack of outreach to evangelical Christians.

The RNA, compiler of the top 10 list, is the largest organization of religion journalists in the United States.

La obra teatral "La desobediencia de Marte", que se estrenará el 4 de agosto en el Teatro Helénico de Ciudad de México, explora las complejas relaciones entre masculinidades, según ha descubierto su autor, Juan Villoro, gracias a la visión del director, Antonio Castro.  La pieza, que estará en cartelera hasta el 1 de octubre y posteriormente se presentará en una veintena de ciudades mexicanas, se centra en el encuentro histórico entre los astrónomos Tycho Brahe (Joaquín Cosío) y Johannes Kepler (Jose María de Tavira) en el castillo de Benatek (Bohemia) en el año 1600.  Brahe, el científico empírico, poseía la capacidad única de interpretar los astros, mientras que Kepler, el teórico,  conocía las estrellas con una profundidad inigualable.  Esta dinámica de dependencia y rivalidad, donde el éxito de uno implicaba la relegación del otro al olvido, se convierte en el eje central de la obra.

Esta relación de poder se refleja también en la dinámica entre los actores que los interpretan: Cosío, el actor experimentado, y Tavira, el joven.  Al igual que los astrónomos,  compiten desde sus personalidades y perspectivas, marcadas por la diferencia generacional,  creando un paralelismo entre el año 1600 y la actualidad.  De esta manera, la obra conecta la Bohemia del siglo XVII con el presente, mostrando cómo la rivalidad y la dependencia entre padres e hijos trascienden el tiempo.  Villoro, reconocido cronista y periodista, confesó  tras la rueda de prensa que la importancia de la figura paterna en la obra fue una sorpresa.  "No era consciente de las masculinidades", remarcó,  admitiendo que no había previsto la profundidad que alcanzaría el tema de la confrontación entre padres e hijos, el parricidio simbólico y la negación de la figura paterna.

Antonio Castro, director de la obra,  destacó la presencia de las masculinidades como un elemento clave.  Describió al personaje de Cosío como un "macho alfa",  en contraste con el personaje más introspectivo de Tavira.  La obra, según Castro,  presenta un duelo, una pugna entre estos dos paradigmas de masculinidad.  Jose María de Tavira, por su parte,  apuntó que si bien la historia ha sido injusta con la feminidad,  la masculinidad también sufre las consecuencias del machismo,  citando estadísticas sobre suicidios, soldados y reclusos.

Finalmente, el equipo creativo detrás de "La desobediencia de Marte" cuenta con la participación de  Damián Ortega como diseñador de escenografía, Anna Adrià como coordinadora de escenografía y Edyta Rzewuska como diseñadora de vestuario. Villoro, además de su trabajo como dramaturgo,  reflexionó sobre la importancia de abordar temas sociales complejos como la violencia y la desigualdad,  pero sin dejar de lado la belleza, el humor, la ironía y el amor en la literatura,  elementos cruciales incluso en tiempos difíciles.

Dr. Newton, the hospital's Chief of Infectious Diseases, wasn't surprised when summoned to identify a perplexing illness.  He reviewed the report as the elevator ascended to the 31st floor.  A peculiar disease was being passed back and forth inexplicably.  Its recipients initially clamored for it, believing it a badge of honor, only to desperately try to get rid of it soon after.

The elevator's *ding* startled him from his thoughts.  Frowning, he walked towards Storeroom 10-X.

Inside, four elderly patients, all previous recipients of the disease, were in a state of panic. A short woman frantically licked her finger and jammed it into a tall man's ear—the apparent method of transmission. She calmed instantly, only for the man to become agitated and repeat the process with another patient. The cycle continued, a bizarre display of primal fear followed by abrupt tranquility, culminating with the short woman back on her toes, reaching for the tall man's ear again.

"Glad you could make it, Doctor," said second-year resident Dr. Wilde, looking disheveled. Her hair was frazzled, glasses askew, and she appeared to haven't showered in days. "We just can't figure it out."

"What's so undesirable about this disease that they're so desperate to pass it on?" Dr. Newton asked.

"That's the mystery.  Patients show no symptoms, no cognitive impairment, no physical debilitation whatsoever. Yet, they relentlessly pass it on, seemingly forgetting why they were so eager to acquire it in the first place!"

Dr. Newton stroked his short beard.  He thought he'd seen everything, but this behavior was unprecedented. Recipients of inherited diseases rarely relinquished them, especially one so seemingly benign.

Dr. Thyme burst through the door, breathless. "Doctor Newton! We… we figured it out!" She leaned against the railing, gasping for air.

"Tracy, relax. We have plenty of time."

"Are you okay?"

It was Sandy. Oh god. Half the skin on her face had been ripped away, exposing the raw muscle beneath. Teeth, embedded in gums. She smiled, and the muscle tore a little more, bled a little more. Nausea churned in my stomach. I looked away, fighting the urge to vomit.

"Yeah," I lied. I was fairly certain my leg was broken.  But that was okay. That was okay.

I sat up, a scream caught in my throat.  Pain, radiating from my hip, consumed me.  I pushed it aside.  *Not now.*  Just sit.

"C'mere," I rasped, and she moved closer. I pulled her into a hug. When I released her, her face was whole again, clear-skinned, beautiful as ever.

"Help me up," I said. "I need to get to the others."

She nodded, no argument. Good girl. I leaned heavily on her, trying to keep the weight off my injured leg. Blackness threatened the edges of my vision. The pain was intense. *Keep going.*  I *needed* to… I needed to fix people.

Bob weaved toward us. Oh god, the maggots. He was crawling with them, eating their way in and out of his flesh.

"Hey!" Sandy waved.

A maggot dripped from Bob's nose, landing on the ground with a soft plop.  His hands were disintegrating, resembling curdled cottage cheese, as he waved back.

"Andrew," he said. "How am I doing?"

"Nothing I can't handle," I reassured him, my voice strained. I tried to sound calm, but the only thing preventing me from dry-heaving the nonexistent contents of my stomach was reciting multiplication tables backwards.

Every cell in my body recoiled as I reached out and touched him.  The maggots vanished, melting back into normal, healthy flesh.

Bob blinked.

"Oh wow, that was amazing," he said. "One day you need to explain how you do that."

"Sure, someday," I replied, knowing it would never happen.

Screams echoed around us. We moved again, me hobbling, Sandy supporting me.

Damn psych viruses.  Driving people mad, and I was the only one who could see and remove the infection.  So we moved.  And moved. I touched person after person. The pain in my hip intensified, radiating through my body. I felt like I was burning, being consumed from the inside out.
