L’avenir de Lionel Messi fait l’objet de spéculations depuis plusieurs semaines.  En fin de contrat avec le FC Barcelone, l’Argentin pourrait partir libre l’été prochain.  Pour l’instant, cependant, la situation semble figée.

Le feuilleton Messi avait déjà animé le mercato estival.  Agacé par le climat au sein du club catalan et en conflit avec la direction de Josep Maria Bartomeu, le sextuple Ballon d’Or avait alors exprimé son désir de partir.  Malgré un bras de fer avec le Barça, Messi était finalement resté en Catalogne.  Mais les rumeurs concernant son avenir persistent, d'autant plus qu'il arrive au terme de son contrat.  Un départ libre est donc envisageable, ce qui attire l’attention de clubs comme Manchester City et le PSG.

Manchester City et le PSG apparaissent comme les prétendants les plus sérieux pour accueillir l'Argentin.  Selon certaines sources espagnoles, le PSG aurait même un léger avantage.  Convaincre Messi reste toutefois le principal obstacle.  D'après *Goal*, l'Argentin n'aurait entamé aucune discussion avec un autre club.  Cette information confirme le démenti de Jorge Messi concernant une supposée réunion au Consulat du Qatar à Barcelone,  réunion qui aurait pu le rapprocher du PSG.  *Goal* affirme donc qu'aucune négociation n'est en cours et que Jorge Messi n’envisage pas d’en entamer dans les prochaines semaines. Le clan Messi privilégierait la patience et estimerait avoir encore du temps pour prendre une décision.

Un départ est donc possible, mais un maintien au FC Barcelone l'est tout autant.

The rapid advancement of technology, while often beneficial, raises concerns about privacy, especially in sensitive environments like classrooms.  The article "Making Mona Lisa Smile," which promotes emotion-recognition software like the Facial Action Coding System (FACS), fails to convincingly argue for its classroom implementation. In fact, it inadvertently highlights the significant privacy invasion such technology represents.  The article suggests classrooms could use FACS to detect student confusion or boredom and adjust lessons accordingly, mimicking a human instructor.  This premise, however, is flawed.

The analogy between FACS and a human instructor is weak. While the article notes that humans can often gauge emotions through facial expressions, this overlooks the richness of human interaction.  A teacher's presence offers more than just facial cues; their body language, tone of voice, and ability to respond to individual questions in real-time are crucial for effective teaching.  Moreover, studies show that many students learn better with direct teacher interaction than online, rendering the software's proposed benefits less impactful.  Replacing a teacher's nuanced understanding with software that merely tracks basic emotions would likely be detrimental to the learning process.

Further illustrating the disconnect between FACS and classroom needs, the article presents a jarring example: if a student smiles at an online ad, similar ads will follow.  This example, intended to showcase the technology's capabilities, instead exposes its invasive nature within the educational context.  It raises the alarming prospect of students being constantly monitored and their responses tracked, even for non-educational purposes.  Imagine this scenario playing out in classrooms, where students' emotional responses to their work are constantly scrutinized and potentially used for purposes beyond learning.  This is a clear breach of privacy.

The article's argument weakens further when it suggests FACS can personalize learning by adjusting to student emotions.  This ignores the existing reality in many schools, like Floyd Central High School, where students already use iPads for learning.  Adding emotion-recognition software wouldn't significantly enhance the personalized learning experience, but it would dramatically increase the potential for privacy violations.

Ultimately, the integration of FACS into classrooms offers little educational value while posing significant privacy risks.  It's a costly and time-consuming endeavor that would be better directed towards proven methods of enhancing student learning.  Instead of relying on emotion-reading software, schools should focus on providing adequate teacher support and resources that foster a positive and privacy-respecting learning environment.

High-quality data fuels modern machine learning, and nearly all models improve with better data [8, 50, 80].  Consequently, such data is crucial for developing future techniques. Acquiring large datasets is particularly challenging due to human involvement.  Human error and subjective interpretation of annotation tasks can introduce noise and ambiguity into labels [9, 16, 18, 28, 29, 52, 54, 61]. This results in heteroscedastic aleatoric uncertainty—inherent, class- or even sample-dependent noise that negatively impacts data quality [14].

Figure 1 illustrates this uncertainty's impact on the "cat" class in the CIFAR-10 dataset [32]. While all images share the same ground truth label, human annotation agreement rates vary widely, from 4% to 100% [54]. This indicates potential noise in individual annotations, as they may diverge from the majority opinion. Moreover, majority voting across multiple annotations cannot capture the ambiguity between images. In some extreme cases (highlighted with red borders), the majority vote even contradicts the expected ground truth label. This raises the question: should all images be treated equally when human annotations exhibit such varying certainty?  Adopting a data-centric perspective [25, 45, 47, 62], we investigate the data itself, rather than solely the model, to address this question.  Specifically, we propose a data-centric image classification (DCIC) benchmark that indirectly measures a method's ability to identify and correct noisy and ambiguous labels.  DCIC comprises ten real-world datasets from diverse domains (Figure 2) with multiple human annotations per image. This benchmark emphasizes a data-centric view by separating data quality improvement and classification performance into distinct tasks.

The benchmark's core structure, divided into Labeling and Evaluation phases (Figure 3a), resembles established teacher-student approaches [36, 70].  The benchmarked method acts as a "teacher," refining labels during the Labeling phase. These refined labels are then evaluated in the Evaluation phase by assessing their efficacy as training data for a "student" model.  Crucially, no knowledge transfer is permitted from the Evaluation phase back to the Labeling phase.

During the Labeling phase, we use samples from the distribution of the aforementioned annotations to generate realistic initial label estimates. The benchmarked method's task is to improve these estimates to enhance the performance of a separate classification model in the subsequent Evaluation phase.  In this phase, the refined labels are used to train a fixed model, and its performance is measured on a testing subset of the original data.  Unlike conventional model-centric deep learning approaches (Figure 3b), our approach allows us to vary the initialization for the same method, better isolating its performance from the data improvement.  The fixed model ensures that performance gains are attributable to improved input data rather than the learning capacity of the model itself.

*Figure 1: Are all images showing a cat?*  Based on their CIFAR-10 ground truth labels [32], they should be. However, the agreement rates with the "cat" class from [54], displayed in the lower right corner, range from 4% to 100%.  Based on majority voting, the final images (red border) would be labeled as dog, frog, dog, and deer, respectively. This paper addresses whether all images should be treated equally as "cat" or if multiple annotations and resulting soft labels should be used to capture this inherent noise and ambiguity.

*Figure 2: Three example images for all datasets.* Dataset statistics are detailed in Table 1.

Our benchmark not only facilitates the evaluation of existing methods but also supports research into algorithms for realistic datasets. It can bridge the gap between semi-supervised learning and noise estimation based on realistic ambiguous noise patterns. We provide multiple baseline algorithms and support integration of additional algorithms through common data loaders for TensorFlow [1] and PyTorch [53].  We analyzed thousands of combinations of baseline methods, initializations, and datasets. Our results confirm that improved data quality leads to performance gains. Furthermore, we investigated factors influencing data quality and identified trends that enhance learning of the underlying distribution.

*Figure 3: Comparison of our data-centric approach with the common model-centric approach.* Circles and arrows represent available label information alongside corresponding images.

“We can’t keep doing this,” she said. Running was becoming too difficult. Still dressed for her 9-to-5 life, she was hardly equipped for this desperate flight. I couldn’t fathom how she’d managed for weeks like this.  She'd abandoned her high heels long ago, and we hadn't had time to find her replacements. Her feet were calloused and bleeding. Propped against the wall, she reached down, massaging the pain from her soles. Her eyes, searching mine, pleaded for reassurance.

We stood frozen, the silence stretching long enough for me to consider, and discard, a thousand hollow comforts. I couldn't think of a damn thing worth saying.

The echo of their pursuit reverberated up the stairwell.  They were close, maybe four flights down if we were lucky.

I slung her arm over my shoulders and dashed into the hallway. Two doors down, an open apartment offered refuge. We slipped inside.

They were gaining. I turned the lock, finding a sliver of comfort in this anarchic world.  Nowhere was safe, but that inch of metal between us and them offered a fragile illusion of security.

I helped her to a couch in the living room. The television droned the same emergency broadcast that had become the soundtrack to our nightmare: *“This is the emergency broadcast system. Martial law is now in effect due to an unprecedented outbreak of the D4 Lunar Virus. Symptoms may include fever, chest pain, nausea, dilated pupils, discolored skin, and uncontrollable muscle spasms. If you notice a loved one with these symptoms, distance yourself and seek assistance from your local Emergency Medical Station. If you yourself need medical assistance, please seek aid at your nearest Emergency Medical Station. Stay in your homes. Food and water will be provided to you shortly.”*

“What a load of bullshit,” she said, wiping away tears. “Those weren’t medical stations, they were execution lines.”

She was right. She had no proof, but she was right. I tried to deny it, to deny the memory of my brother’s visit to one of those stations. He’d needed antibiotics, desperately.

He’d been stabbed in a shopping mall the day after the outbreak. The city air, thick with pollutants from the new oil refineries, had infected the wound within minutes. He’d stitched himself up, but the infection discolored his skin, unsettling people.

The increasing demand for wireless communication necessitates operation in higher frequency bands like millimeter wave (mmWave), a spectrum largely pre-allocated to radar systems [1].  This overlap, particularly with automotive and high-resolution imaging radars operating in the 76-81 GHz and 200 GHz bands [2], makes harmonious coexistence crucial for achieving the ultra-high throughput goals of future wireless networks [1, 3-5].  Two primary coexistence approaches exist: interference management [1, 6], which focuses on suppressing mutual interference between radar and communication systems, and Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) [3, 4], which employs a single, cleverly designed waveform for both functions. ISAC offers superior potential due to its inherent synergy and its applicability to emerging applications [3, 4, 7], potentially even enhancing the performance of both radar and communication functionalities [8].

This potential for mutual benefit arises from the similar channel characteristics shared by radar and communication.  Consider a typical downlink scenario with co-located radar and communication antennas at a base station (BS).  Despite radar relying on round-trip echoes and communication on one-way transmissions, the BS-UE (User Equipment) channel is fundamentally the same.  Radar, with its knowledge of transmitted signals, leverages matched-filtering for parameter estimation, achieving significantly higher gains than communication's channel estimation methods [4]. This suggests exploiting radar-derived Channel State Information (CSI) to enhance communication design.  Further synergy arises from the alignment between radar's parameter estimation based on delay, Doppler, and angular features and the principles of Orthogonal Time Frequency Space (OTFS) modulation [9-11].  OTFS, unlike OFDM, employs delay-Doppler (DD) domain symbol multiplexing, enabling direct interaction between information symbols and the DD channel, which can be inferred from radar estimates [4]. This synergistic relationship motivates the exploration of OTFS-based ISAC transmission.

Existing research on OTFS-based ISAC has explored various avenues.  Initial studies demonstrated the feasibility of achieving satisfactory communication performance while maintaining radar estimation accuracy [12] and extended this to MIMO systems using hybrid beamforming [13], including an efficient ML algorithm for target detection and parameter estimation.  Further work has focused on developing OTFS-based matched-filter algorithms for improved range and velocity estimation [14] and proposing ISAC-assisted OTFS systems for both uplink and downlink communication, incorporating novel DD domain channel estimation and message-passing detection algorithms [4].  While promising, these approaches often rely on sophisticated, CSIT-dependent beamforming schemes [4, 13].  However, in scenarios like co-located antennas, radar sensing doesn't directly provide communication channel fading coefficients.  Radar echo strength depends on antenna effective area and radar cross-section (RCS) [16], while communication channel fading depends on path loss and scattering [15], creating a mismatch in reflection strengths.  Consequently, beams steered towards the strongest radar echo path may not be optimal for communication.

To address this mismatch, we propose a novel ISAC framework based on spatially-spread OTFS (SS-OTFS) modulation, introducing the concept of SS-OTFS for exploiting delay-Doppler-angular (DDA) channel characteristics.  SS-OTFS incorporates spatial spreading and de-spreading modules at the transmitter and receiver, respectively, discretizing the angular domain and simplifying the input-output relationships for radar and communication.  This discretization associates each antenna (pair) with a specific angle, enabling separation of multi-path effects and facilitating system design based solely on radar-estimated delays, Dopplers, AoAs, and reflection coefficients, without prior knowledge of communication channel fading coefficients.  Our key contributions are: (1) Derivation of communication and radar models for SS-OTFS-enabled ISAC, demonstrating the near-elimination of spatial multiplexing interference and resulting in simplified effective channel matrices; (2) Development of simple beam tracking and AoA estimation algorithms exploiting the structure of the radar sensing matrix, enabling beam width control through power allocation and straightforward AoA estimation; (3) Analysis of precoding matrices and power allocation impacts on PEP for the communication model, leading to a precoding design using virtual delay and Doppler indices and demonstrating the optimality of equal power allocation; and (4) Discussion and simulation verification of radar and communication performance trade-offs with different power allocations, suggesting a bias towards radar in practical scenarios and validating the effectiveness of the proposed SS-OTFS ISAC framework.

Large language models (LLMs), the core engines of applications like Chat-GPT, are becoming increasingly pervasive.  Understanding their capabilities and limitations when processing diverse forms of language is crucial. This work focuses on slang, a ubiquitous form of informal language common in everyday conversations (Mattiello, 2005; Eble, 2012).  As Figure 1 illustrates, slang poses unique challenges for natural language processing (NLP).  For example, while "excellent" and "blazing" can describe a jacket similarly, an LLM's unfamiliarity with slang might lead to performance discrepancies. Previous work suggests pre-trained LLMs assign lower probabilities to slang than their literal equivalents (Sun et al., 2021, 2022), indicating models like BERT (Devlin et al., 2019) lack slang knowledge.

Slang knowledge in LLMs has implications beyond informal language processing.  Slang usage reflects social identity (Labov, 1972, 2006; Eble, 2012). "Blazing," for instance, means "excellent" in the US but "anger" in the UK (Green, 2010). This variability can introduce representational harm (Blodgett et al., 2020) as NLP system performance can differ significantly across demographics like age, gender, region, and ethnicity (Hovy and Søgaard, 2015; Hovy and Spruit, 2016; Blodgett and O'Connor, 2017; Tatman, 2017; Buolamwini and Gebru, 2018; Koenecke et al., 2020). Consequently, a slang-competent LLM could reveal a user's identity, potentially improving NLP performance (Volkova et al., 2013; Hovy, 2015) but also increasing the risk of personal information exposure.

Despite these implications, rigorous slang-based evaluation of LLMs is lacking, primarily due to the scarcity of publicly accessible, high-quality datasets.  Existing dictionaries (e.g., Green, 2010) often lack metadata like literal paraphrases.  Paired examples like those in Figure 1 (e.g., "blazing" and "excellent") are crucial for controlled LLM probing.  To address this, we introduce a publicly available dataset of slang usages from the OpenSubtitles corpus (Lison and Tiedemann, 2016). Using this dataset, we systematically evaluate LLM slang knowledge, focusing on widely adopted GPT models (Brown et al., 2020; OpenAI, 2023).  Our results demonstrate that while LLMs possess considerable slang knowledge, task-specific fine-tuning is essential for optimal performance.

We focus on two core tasks, illustrated in Figure 1: slang detection in natural sentences and identifying the regional-historical origins of slang via text classification. We also examine LLMs' semantic understanding of slang compared to conventional language.  Throughout our evaluation, we highlight performance discrepancies across demographics and discuss implications for fairness and privacy.

Our contributions are: 1) A publicly available dataset of annotated English slang usages from movie subtitles, providing a novel benchmark for evaluation and fine-tuning; 2) A rigorous evaluation of LLM slang knowledge, including slang detection; 3) A discussion of the implications of this knowledge for fairness and privacy in NLP.

This paper studies Probabilistic Almost-Sure Termination (PAST) for imperative programs augmented with bounded nondeterministic and probabilistic choice.  We establish a deep connection between PAST and the termination of programs with (un)bounded nondeterminism and fair termination.  Specifically, we show that deciding PAST is Π<sub>1</sub><sup>1</sup>-complete, matching the complexity of termination for programs with countable nondeterminism.

This complexity result is further underscored by our construction, for each recursive ordinal *o* < Church-Kleene ordinal (CK<sub>1</sub>), of a probabilistic program *P*(*o*) such that *o* is well-founded if and only if *P*(*o*) is PAST.  This demonstrates that transfinite ordinals up to CK<sub>1</sub> are necessary for proving PAST.  This contrasts with Almost-Sure Termination (AST) and Bounded AST (BAST) which do not require transfinite reasoning.  Typically, AST and BAST proofs employ ranking supermartingales mapping program states to reals, demonstrating a minimum expected decrease with each transition.  Our work reveals that this approach is insufficient for PAST.  We illustrate this in Section 2 with a stochastic Hydra game, a PAST program requiring ordinals up to CK<sub>1</sub> to prove termination.  Since the complexity of valid statements in standard arithmetic is Δ<sub>1</sub><sup>1</sup>, relative completeness results for PAST necessitate more powerful proof systems.

To address this, we introduce a sound and complete proof rule for a special normal form, which we call *Knievel form*,  effectively constructible for any probabilistic program.  This proof rule uses two key components: a ranking function from program states to ordinals up to CK<sub>1</sub>, where only terminal states are ranked zero, and a state-dependent certificate based on ranking supermartingales, bounding the expected time to reach a lower-ranked state independent of the scheduler.

This proof rule is complete for *all* probabilistic programs: a suitable rank and certificate can always be extracted.  Crucially, soundness is guaranteed for Knievel form programs: the existence of a ranking function and supermartingale certificate implies bounded expected running time.  However, the rule is *not* sound for general programs.  Therefore, our complete proof system involves first transforming a program into Knievel form and then applying the proof rule.

Our core results are summarized as follows:

1. Deciding PAST for probabilistic programs with bounded nondeterministic and probabilistic choice is Π<sub>1</sub><sup>1</sup>-complete.

2. For any probabilistic program *P*, there is an effectively constructible Knievel form program *P'* and non-probabilistic programs *P*<sub>1</sub> (bounded nondeterministic choice) and *P*<sub>2</sub> (unbounded choice) such that *P* is PAST iff *P'* is PAST iff *P*<sub>1</sub> is fairly terminating iff *P*<sub>2</sub> is terminating.

3. For any recursive ordinal *o*, there is a probabilistic program *P*(*o*) such that *o* is well-founded iff *P*(*o*) is PAST. Hence, proving PAST requires ordinals up to CK<sub>1</sub>.

4. There is a sound and complete proof rule for Knievel form programs using a ranking function to CK<sub>1</sub> and ranking supermartingales.  While complete for all PAST programs, the rule is sound only for programs in Knievel form.

A probabilistic program augments an imperative program with primitives for randomization, enabling direct implementation of randomized computation and probabilistic modeling. Applications include machine learning, bioinformatics, epidemiology, and information retrieval (see Katoen et al. [2015]).

"Well, did he get up? Did he fall on something? Is he okay?"

L’histoire de la Sud-Africaine qui aurait donné naissance à dix bébés est fausse, selon une enquête officielle.  Gosiame Sithole, 37 ans, n’a pas accouché de décuplés au début du mois, contrairement à ce qui avait été affirmé.  Des tests médicaux ont démontré qu'elle n’a même pas été enceinte récemment.  Mme Sithole est actuellement placée en observation en vertu de la loi sur la santé mentale et recevra un soutien.

L'histoire a initialement été rapportée par le Pretoria News, appartenant au groupe de médias Independent Online (IOL).  Le journal affirmait que Mme Sithole avait accouché le 7 juin à l’hôpital universitaire Steve Biko (SBAH) de Pretoria, accusant l'hôpital et les autorités sanitaires de négligence médicale et de tentative de dissimulation.  Le gouvernement provincial du Gauteng a fermement démenti ces accusations, les qualifiant de fausses et non fondées, et a annoncé des poursuites judiciaires contre le rédacteur en chef du Pretoria News, Piet Rampedi, et IOL.

L’origine de cette histoire remonte à décembre dernier.  Mme Sithole, mère de jumeaux de six ans, et son compagnon Teboho Tsotetsi, résidaient à Thembisa, un township de la province de Gauteng.  Ils fréquentaient la même église que Piet Rampedi, qui les a rencontrés et interviewés en mai.  Lors de cette interview, le couple aurait déclaré attendre huit bébés.  Le 8 juin, Pretoria News annonçait la naissance surprise de dix bébés, citant M. Tsotetsi, qui affirmait avoir reçu l'information par SMS de sa compagne.

Rampedi s’est appuyé sur des messages WhatsApp sans obtenir de confirmation indépendante de l’hôpital.  Le maire local a ensuite confirmé les naissances, repris par d’autres médias, dont la BBC.  Cependant, un porte-parole du gouvernement a plus tard précisé que le maire se basait uniquement sur les dires de la famille.  Des dons ont afflué pour le couple, surnommés les « 10 de Thembisa », dont un million de rands du président de IOL.

The advent of fifth-generation (5G) mobile communications in 2020 spurred global commercialization.  From 2G to 5G, communication frequency bands have increased from 100 MHz to the GHz range [1, 2], exploiting higher-frequency electromagnetic waves for greater spectral resources.  Further exploration of millimeter wave, terahertz, and optical communication is crucial for discovering new spectral resources [3–5].  While free-space optical (FSO) communication, visible light communication (VLC), and short-range near-infrared communication have been extensively studied and widely deployed, light waves are easily absorbed by opaque obstacles, limiting optical communication primarily to line-of-sight scenarios.  Moreover, higher-frequency signals like millimeter waves and terahertz waves increasingly exhibit characteristics similar to optical signals, such as narrow pulses and susceptibility to blockage [6–9], necessitating solutions to mitigate their impact on communication quality.

Reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS) offer a novel approach.  These meta-surfaces programmably modulate passing electromagnetic waves [10–13].  Current microwave-band RIS structures primarily comprise arrays of digital coding units, enabling adjustment of incident beams to control the intensity, phase, frequency, and polarity of outgoing beams.  Di and Zhang [12] proposed using RIS for microwave beamforming, effectively mimicking a large-scale base station antenna array directed towards multiple nodes in free space.  This approach reduces the burden on the base station, improves energy efficiency, and allows for the recollection and retransmission of previously unreceived microwave signals.

Analogous to microwave RIS, optical RIS structures require the following functionalities: (1) Reflecting the incident beam; (2) Preserving the original beam's information with minimal alteration; (3) Programmably controlling the intensity, phase, frequency, polarization, and other characteristics of the outgoing beam; (4) Precisely adjusting the outgoing beam's direction to track the user.

Existing technologies like spatial light modulators (SLMs) and optical micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) address these requirements [14–17].  Proposed in 1982 [16], two-dimensional magneto-optic SLMs adjust the amplitude, phase, polarization, and other parameters of transmitted light.  Combined with lens groups, SLMs reconstruct light fields with minimal power loss.  Comprising digital coding unit arrays, SLMs allow programmable adjustment of incident light amplitude and phase at modulation frequencies up to 100 Hz.  SLMs have been employed for signal modulation in low-speed VLC systems [18] and for converting single beams into multiple beams to track multiple mobile users [19]. Optical MEMS, comprising arrays of adjustable micro-lenses, offer cost-effective and readily manufacturable solutions for controlling reflected light direction, but lack the ability to freely control the phase, frequency, and polarization of the outgoing beam.

Leveraging optical RIS, we propose a controllable multi-branch wireless optical communication system with RIS in the channels, termed an optical intelligent channel communication system.  By deploying multiple optical RIS, or intelligent channel reconfigurable nodes (ICRNs), we create multiple artificial optical channels, or intelligent channels.  The system's intelligence lies in its ability to: (1) Track mobile users by coordinating the transmitter and ICRNs to direct the signal towards the user's receiver center; (2) Establish multiple controllable channels between the base station and users, with adjustable paths via ICRN selection; (3) Provide the base station with knowledge of each channel's physical path, enabling real-time channel state information (CSI) estimation; (4) Optimize power efficiency by dynamically allocating power to each channel based on CSI, ensuring communication stability.

This paper analyzes the performance of this system, assuming accurate beam alignment with the receiver center.

A woman urinating on a busy Bay of Islands beach, less than 50 meters from public toilets, has sparked outrage among residents.  The incident follows closely on the heels of a case where a French freedom camper defecated on a Dunedin street, garnering national headlines and even prompting the French government to update its travel advisory, urging tourists to respect local laws.

Waitangi resident Paitangi Ostick witnessed the woman, believed to be in her 60s, relieving herself on Tii Beach around midday on Thursday as Ms. Ostick was turning into her driveway opposite the beach.  "I saw her crouch down, I saw this white arse, and I thought 'what the?' ... I couldn't believe it," she said.  Families often picnic and children play in the area where the woman urinated.

Ms. Ostick confronted the woman, asking why she used the beach as a toilet. The woman responded indifferently, saying, "It's not the first time and it won't be the last."  The woman's husband, who said they were from Cromwell in the South Island, told Ms. Ostick to "go back where you came from, we were here long before you."  Ms. Ostick, who is Māori and has a tā moko on her chin, is clearly a long-term resident.

Later that day, Ms. Ostick posted photos of the couple and their vehicle on a Facebook page called the Paihia Noticeboard. The post quickly gained traction, attracting over 120 comments within 24 hours.

Ms. Ostick explained that she picks up rubbish from the beach most mornings and regularly confronts freedom campers for hanging clothes on, or leaving food scraps around, a tapu tree adjacent to Waitangi Marae. She noted this summer has been particularly challenging regarding visitor behavior.  The day before the beach urination incident, a man left a bag of rubbish outside her gate.  She has even stopped running the track to Haruru Falls due to the amount of toilet paper and human waste left behind by visitors.

Venus, often called the "Evening Star," presents a paradox.  While relatively close to Earth, it remains a hostile and unexplored world.  We haven't sent a spacecraft there in 30 years, and for good reason.  Its thick atmosphere, composed of 97% carbon dioxide and laced with corrosive sulfuric acid clouds, creates a hellish environment.  Surface temperatures average over 800 degrees Fahrenheit – hotter than any other planet in our solar system – and the atmospheric pressure is a crushing 90 times that of Earth. These conditions are far beyond anything humans can withstand.

Given this extreme environment, why return to Venus?  Astronomers believe that Venus may once have been Earth-like, potentially covered with oceans and capable of supporting life.  Even today, Venus exhibits familiar geological features like mountains and valleys, hinting at a more hospitable past.

This potential for discovery drives renewed interest in Venus exploration.  NASA is developing innovative solutions to overcome the challenges. One concept involves deploying a research station that would float approximately 30 miles above the surface, safe from the extreme ground conditions.  They are also investigating technologies like mechanically driven devices, inspired by World War II designs, capable of operating under high pressures and temperatures without electricity.

The allure of Venus lies in our innate human curiosity and drive to explore.  We possess boundless imaginations, and to truly progress as a civilization, we should strive to become a multi-planetary species.  Innovation and learning have propelled us from the first automobiles a century ago to where we are today.  Imagine the possibilities that await us in the next 100 years, perhaps including a deeper understanding of our enigmatic neighbor, Venus.

Neural network architectures are widely used in information retrieval, employing various strategies to represent and compare user queries with potential documents. This work focuses on enhancing document representation to improve retrieval quality and robustness.

One common approach is the Bi-encoder (Karpukhin et al., 2020), utilizing two transformer models (Vaswani et al., 2017) – which can be shared or separate – to encode queries and documents into vector representations. Similarity, often calculated using dot product or cosine similarity, is then computed between these vectors to determine relevance.

Contrastingly, Cross-encoders (Nogueira and Cho, 2019) combine query and document inputs early on, creating a joint embedding vector for relevance prediction. This deeper interaction often leads to superior performance compared to bi-encoders when nuanced understanding is crucial.

Bridging these two approaches are late-interaction models like ColBERT (Khattab and Zaharia, 2020), ColBERTv2 (Santhanam et al., 2021), and SPALDE++ (Formal et al., 2022).  These models independently encode queries and documents into token-level vectors, resembling a "bag of embeddings" approach.  The "late interaction" occurs when cosine similarity or dot product scores are calculated across these token-level vectors.

All these architectures rely on informative embeddings of both queries and documents.  While query content is beyond our control during retrieval, we can enrich document embeddings, which is the core hypothesis driving this work.

To this end, we propose LLM-augmented retrieval, a model-agnostic framework designed to enhance document embeddings with richer contextual information.  A key component is the introduction of *doc-level embedding*, which further integrates contextual information.

The main contributions of this work are:

1. The LLM-augmented retrieval framework, improving the quality and robustness of existing retrieval models.
2. The doc-level embedding approach for richer contextual representation.
3. Comprehensive evaluation across various models and datasets, demonstrating state-of-the-art performance exceeding original models.
4. Enhancements to key retrieval model training components, including negative sampling and loss functions.

The article "Driverless Cars Are Coming" presents a compelling case for autonomous vehicles as a revolutionary technology.  However, the author questions the reliability of these systems and their potential impact on safety.  Will driver-assist features function flawlessly, or will their failures lead to even greater dangers?  Sergey Brin, co-founder of Google, champions driverless cars as the future of transportation, a paradigm shift from the dream of flying cars. Brin believes this technology will fundamentally reshape the world.  Despite the excitement surrounding autonomous vehicles, the author argues against their adoption.  While acknowledging the allure of technological advancements, the author contends that the complex systems within driverless cars are inherently prone to failure, ultimately jeopardizing driver safety.

A central concern is the potential for manufacturers to downplay the risks of driverless technology. Will the public receive a balanced perspective, or will negative aspects be suppressed? The author fears that driverless cars will prove to be another technological misstep.  Quoting the original article, the author highlights the inherent limitations of autonomous systems: "They can steer, accelerate, and brake themselves, but all are designed to notify the driver when the road ahead requires human skills."  This requirement for driver vigilance is further emphasized: "This means the human driver must remain alert." The author argues this dependence on human intervention undermines the very concept of a driverless car, exposing a fundamental flaw in the technology.  Drivers, lulled into a false sense of security, may become distracted or drowsy, unprepared for the sudden need to take control. This reliance on imperfect human intervention increases the risk of accidents.  Overconfidence in the technology could lead to dangerous situations, such as intoxicated individuals relying on the car to navigate them safely home, potentially endangering themselves and others if the system fails.

Further concerns arise regarding the reliability of driver-assist functions.  The article mentions GM's development of vibrating seats to alert drivers of danger.  However, the author questions the long-term functionality of such systems and the driver's ability to respond appropriately.  Who, the author asks, actually reads instruction manuals thoroughly?  The excitement surrounding new technology may lead to drivers neglecting proper training, creating hazardous situations on the road.  Trying to learn complex systems while driving could exacerbate risks and lead to panic in emergencies.  The author predicts a rise in accident rates, counteracting efforts to improve road safety.

Liability in the event of an accident involving a driverless car is another key concern.  The author believes that the human driver, rather than the manufacturer, will likely be held responsible, even if the accident stems from technological failure.  This raises questions about fairness and accountability in the age of autonomous vehicles.

The author concludes by reiterating the potential dangers of driverless cars and urging caution.  Would you, the author asks, entrust your loved ones to a technology with such inherent risks?  Instead of improving road safety, the author argues that driverless cars will likely increase accident and fatality rates.  For these reasons, the author believes driverless cars should not be embraced as the future of transportation.

阿富汗塔利班即将重返执政，尽管承诺改变过去的高压统治，但圣战士暴行事件却频频传出。近日，一名阿富汗妇女因未穿着罩袍（Burqa）而惨遭当街击毙，家人只能无助地围在身旁，画面令人震惊。

据《纽约邮报》（New York Post）报导，塔利班接管喀布尔后，城市迅速发生变化。塔利班武装分子取代了阿富汗安全部队在城内巡逻，外出女性明显减少。在塔喀省（Takhar），一名女性因未在公共场合穿着罩袍而被击毙，倒卧在血泊中，家人只能焦急地围在她身边查看伤势，束手无策。

(引用推特略)

喀布尔市中心一家服饰店店主透露，近日罩袍销量飙升，许多男性顾客担心妻女人身安全而前来购买。27岁的居民妮兰表示，她乘车经过市区15分钟，竟然没有看到一个女人。“一切都变了。我们不知道该怎么办，也不知道还能不能保住工作，感觉生活和未来都一片茫然。”

过去20年，阿富汗女权，尤其是在城市地区，取得了巨大进步。然而，塔利班的掌权将使当地妇女和女童成为最脆弱的群体。这个基本教义派组织曾在美军入侵阿富汗前的2001年之前统治阿富汗五年，并根据伊斯兰教法严格规定女性不能受教育、不能工作、不允许在没有男性家属陪同下外出，外出时必须穿着布卡（Burqa），甚至连眼睛都必须被全身罩袍覆盖。

(图片描述略)

塔利班暴行受害者哈特拉（Khatera）讲述了她的遭遇。去年10月，她在下班回家的路上，遭到三名塔利班战士包围。他们要求她出示身份证后，便向她连开了八枪。当时她已怀孕两个月，除了枪伤外，还身中多处刀伤，眼球也被挖出。在遭受塔利班一连串残忍暴行后，她失去了意识，被丢弃在路边。更令人震惊的是，策划袭击她的人正是她身为塔利班战士的父亲。

尽管塔利班如今强调将改变过去的高压统治，尊重女性权利，但一些逃难的阿富汗妇女指控，塔利班要求当地家庭公布家中女性名单，试图强娶未成年女孩。为了应对当前动荡的局势，许多家庭被迫采取“绝望的手段”保护孩子，例如“让未成年的女儿嫁人”。

Additive manufacturing (AM), commonly known as 3-D printing, has experienced rapid growth in popularity and market share due to its ability to create complex geometries with engineering properties that often meet or exceed those of conventionally manufactured parts, while significantly reducing overhead costs [1] [2] [3].  One such AM process, Powder Bed Fusion (PBF), builds three-dimensional parts layer by layer from metal powder (Fig. 1). The PBF process involves a three-stage build cycle: 1) spreading a thin layer of powder over a base plate or previously deposited layer, 2) selectively melting the powder into the desired pattern using a high-powered laser or electron beam (e-beam), and 3) lowering the build platform to allow for the next layer of powder.

Despite its advantages, PBF presents challenges.  Parts manufactured via PBF often exhibit high levels of residual stresses [5] [6] [7], porosity [8] [9] [10], and anisotropy in material properties [2, [10] [11] [12] [13] [14]. These defects stem directly from the thermal management of the PBF process.  Currently, PBF machines operate in open-loop, with the irradiated energy, *u*, dictated by a G-Code schedule [15].  The parameters governing this schedule are determined through operator experience, heuristic design-of-experiment procedures [16], or computationally intensive predictive models [17].  Feedback control of the thermal management process could significantly improve the quality of PBF-manufactured parts.

While the need for improved thermal management in PBF is recognized, the controllability and observability of the process—fundamental criteria for modern control synthesis—remain unestablished. This paper addresses this fundamental gap.  Our analysis considers both current and emerging thermal actuation and sensing hardware capabilities, without regard for computational constraints during model construction.  The goal is to establish a controls theoretic foundation for PBF, enabling the application of modern control tools such as multivariable robust controllers, state estimators, and fault detection schemes to this important and evolving manufacturing technology. A más de tres semanas del deslave en el barrio Manzano 78 de Tiquipaya, alrededor de 20 familias que perdieron sus viviendas y pertenencias por el desborde del río Taquiña se declararon en estado de emergencia.  En un recorrido realizado a la OTB, ubicada a escasos metros del puente Chapisirca, se constató que las vías están expeditas y la gente continúa limpiando el barro de utensilios y máquinas de coser.  Varios relataron que desde el 21 de febrero no hay energía eléctrica ni agua potable en la zona.

Los damnificados exigen a la Alcaldía colaboración con maquinaria pesada para limpiar la zona. “Pedimos que se limpie todo. Si no atienden nuestra petición, tomaremos medidas drásticas. A nosotros hasta una cucharilla nos hace falta”, sostuvo David Flores, representante de la OTB.  Las familias analizan la posibilidad de retornar con carpas al espacio donde estaban ubicados sus hogares, ya que en algún momento deben abandonar el albergue en el que se encuentran refugiados. "Todos estamos de acuerdo con la reubicación, pero queremos que nos garanticen el terreno para gestionar la construcción de una vivienda social”, acotó Flores.

Comentó que extraoficialmente los vecinos conocen que la Alcaldía pretende retirar a la gente del sector al negar maquinaria y ayuda para retirar el lodo y las piedras de las viviendas destruidas.  “No puede haber discriminación a los damnificados con el pretexto de que no tienen papeles”,  reclama Flores.

Técnicos del Ejecutivo municipal negaron que incurran en discriminación y detallaron que el sector es una zona de alto riesgo, lo que dificulta el ingreso de equipo pesado.

Harsh beeping ripped me from sleep. "Warning. ICARUS malfunction, system failure. Shutting down," a voice announced. *Crap*.

My heart hammered as I scanned my surroundings. The pod was in freefall. Through the window, I could make out my destination in the distance: Cancer, The Industrial Center, one of the twelve cities orbiting the now grey and desolate Earth, a monument to our ancestors' folly.

These orbiting utopias, designed to house future generations and salvage our species, were named after the ancient zodiac signs, symbols of fortune in a bygone era. My grandparents, brilliant scientists among the first to inhabit these celestial havens, were assigned to Gemini, City of the Sciences. Every generation since had followed suit. Now, I was poised to become the first of our lineage to die outside Gemini, the first Citizen to perish beyond the Aphelion System—the collective name for our floating cities.

The faces of my family, friends, and coworkers flashed before me. A tear traced a path down my cheek as I closed my eyes, surrendering to the inevitable. My mind raced, replaying the events, searching for a reason, a way out.  Why *my* pod? What had I done to deserve this?  What if…?

A sudden warmth enveloped the cabin. My eyes snapped open to a blinding orange-white inferno outside. *This is it.* I would die on the old world, my body lost forever.  A wave of regret washed over me, quickly followed by a strange acceptance.

Then, as abruptly as it began, the fiery embrace receded. I glimpsed the landscape rushing towards me before the pod slammed into the ground, tossing me violently against my restraints.  When the rolling and tumbling finally stopped, I wrestled with the door, managing to pry it open just enough to squeeze through. *Thank God for seatbelts.*  Survival felt miraculous, improbable.

The pod’s once pristine white exterior was now a charred, blackened ruin.  Around me stood trees, a silent, verdant army.  I had crash-landed in a forest clearing. We'd been taught that Earth was virtually lifeless, yet here was undeniable proof to the contrary.  I made a mental note of the anomaly, but my immediate priority was contacting help. The emergency radio, with its independent power source, should be operational.  I scrambled back into the wreckage, pressed the large orange button, and waited.

Thirty seconds. One minute. Two. Two and a half. Silence.

No. *No, no, no, no, no.* I'd survived a crash landing only to face death by starvation.

From Luke's perspective, joining the Seagoing Cowboys was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.  One of the key roles involved caring for horses, young cows, and mules during their overseas transport, including feeding them.  Shipboard life offered ample leisure time, filled with activities like baseball, volleyball, table tennis tournaments, fencing, boxing, reading, whittling, and various games.  The experience also broadened horizons and fostered a sense of global awareness.

Luke's travels with the Seagoing Cowboys instilled in him a deep appreciation for different cultures and their needs.  He made sixteen Atlantic crossings and two Pacific voyages, aiding those affected by World War II.  Witnessing the devastation firsthand, particularly the destruction of homes, was a powerful motivator for his continued service.  His journeys took him to diverse and memorable locations, including New Orleans, Greece, various European countries, and China.  He even enjoyed a gondola ride in Venice and explored the ruins of a castle in Crete.

However, life as a Seagoing Cowboy wasn't without its hazards.  During a night watch, Luke slipped on a wet ladder, sliding down on his backside.  A small metal strip providentially stopped him from going overboard.  Though grateful to be alive, he suffered cracked ribs and was incapacitated for several days.  One of his voyages aboard the *Charles W. Wooster* to Greece involved a two-week Atlantic crossing.

Remote sensing technology plays a vital role in monitoring and understanding the dynamic interplay between human activities and the Earth's ecosystems.  By providing large-scale, long-term, and periodic observations of the Earth's surface, it enables the study of ecosystem changes and their societal impacts (Coppin et al., 2004).  Detecting land-cover changes from multi-temporal remote sensing images, acquired by spaceborne and airborne platforms, has become a central focus in the field (Tewkesbury et al., 2015; Zhu, 2017).

Numerous change detection approaches have been developed, reflecting the technology's long history.  Traditional methods, predating deep learning, can be broadly categorized into four types: image algebra, image transformation, post-classification comparison, and other advanced methods. Image algebra methods, such as change vector analysis (CVA) (Bovolo and Bruzzone, 2007; Bruzzone and Diego Fernàndez Prieto, 2000; Du et al., 2020), directly compare spectral bands of bitemporal images to measure change intensity. Image transformation methods, including multivariate alteration detection (MAD) (Nielsen et al., 1998), principal component analysis (PCA) (Celik, 2009; Deng et al., 2008), slow feature analysis (SFA) (Wu et al., 2014), and Fourier transform (Chen et al., 2023), transform raw image features into a new feature space to highlight change-relevant information. Post-classification comparison methods involve classifying images from different times and then comparing the resulting classification maps (Xian et al., 2009). Other advanced methods leverage machine learning models like support vector machines (Bovolo et al., 2008), conditional random fields (Hoberg et al., 2015), Markov random fields (Kasetkasem and Varshney, 2002), and object-based image analysis (OBIA) (Gil-Yepes et al., 2016; Hussain et al., 2013).

The advent of deep learning has revolutionized change detection, offering improved efficiency and accuracy in analyzing multi-temporal imagery (Shi et al., 2020).  These methods can be categorized as supervised or unsupervised, depending on the use of annotated data. Unsupervised deep learning methods typically focus on extracting spatial-spectral features from multi-temporal images and then calculating change intensity. Examples include using deep belief networks (DBN) (Zhang et al., 2016a), autoencoders (Bergamasco et al., 2022; Liu et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2016b), deep CVA (DCVA) (Saha et al., 2019), and various specialized neural network architectures (Liu et al., 2020, 2022; Wu et al., 2022).  Recently, graph convolutional networks (GCNs) have been employed to capture nonlocal dependencies in multi-temporal images (Chen et al., 2022c; Tang et al., 2022; Kipf and Welling, 2016). However, unsupervised methods face limitations due to the lack of training labels, potentially leading to suboptimal feature extraction and hindering the use of complex architectures.  Their practical application is often restricted to smaller study areas.

Supervised deep learning methods, on the other hand, leverage annotated data to train change detectors, resulting in higher accuracy.  Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) are dominant in this category.

En octubre de 2017, publicaciones de The New Yorker y The New York Times desataron una oleada de críticas contra Harvey Weinstein, que confluyeron en el movimiento #MeToo.  Las denuncias contra el ex productor de Hollywood dieron paso a otras acusaciones similares contra figuras del cine, los medios de comunicación y la política.  En mayo de 2018, Weinstein se entregó a las autoridades de Nueva York para enfrentar los cargos en su contra.  Un grupo de mujeres, incluyendo a la actriz Louisette Geiss, presentó una acción legal colectiva en su contra, acusándolo de dirigir una operación de tráfico sexual entre 1993 y 2011.  Según el Daily News,  diez mujeres se unieron a la demanda en 2017, alegando que Weinstein las atraía a encuentros privados con la promesa de empleo en Hollywood.

Este jueves, un juez federal del distrito sur de Nueva York, Alvin Hellerstein, permitió que la demanda por tráfico sexual contra Weinstein continúe.  Sin embargo, Hellerstein decidió que Weinstein Co., Miramax, sus ejecutivos, directores, y el hermano del productor, Robert Weinstein, quedan fuera de la demanda.  El juez argumentó que estas partes no se beneficiaron de la presunta conducta del productor.

“La corte decidió correctamente que Harvey Weinstein deberá enfrentar el cargo de tráfico sexual, que usó su poder para engañar y manipular mujeres, sabiendo que intentaba abusar sexualmente de ellas”, declaró al Daily News Elizabeth Fergan, abogada de las demandantes.  A pesar de la victoria parcial, Fergan expresó su desacuerdo con la desestimación de algunos reclamos y anunció su intención de apelar dicha decisión.  El ex productor, por su parte, ha rechazado todas las acusaciones.

A 59-year-old Nigerian woman named Maureen is suffering after allegedly being attacked by her brother, Francis Egbujie, in Enugu State over a family property.  According to the Women’s Aid Collective (WACOL), who shared Maureen's story, their late father entrusted the property to her care, making her promise not to transfer ownership to Mr. Egbujie.  Despite this, Mr. Egbujie has allegedly persistently pressured Maureen to relinquish the property.

On September 30, 2020, Maureen reported to WACOL's legal clinic that Mr. Egbujie attacked her with a stick, injuring her head.  WACOL posted a picture of her injury online with the caption, "BROTHER ATTEMPTS TO KILL ELDER SISTER OVER FAMILY PROPERTY!!!"  Maureen explained that she uses the proceeds from the property to care for their late elder brother’s children.

Although Maureen and her younger sisters reported the incident to the Trans Ekulu police station, the police allegedly detained the sisters and threatened to arrest Maureen, instead of arresting Mr. Egbujie.  Maureen is currently receiving treatment at an undisclosed medical facility.

She has sought WACOL's assistance in seeking justice and ensuring Mr. Egbujie faces legal consequences for his actions.  WACOL has petitioned the Enugu State Commissioner of Police to transfer the case from the Trans Ekulu police station to the State CID for a proper investigation.  They are also providing Maureen with palliative care and supporting her medical treatment.

Generative artificial intelligence (genAI) holds transformative potential across diverse fields, from computer science and creative arts to language processing. While its efficacy is proven in areas like medicine and healthcare, its application in engineering domains, specifically urban planning and architectural design, remains largely unexplored. This paper addresses this gap by exploring the use of genAI, particularly generative design methodologies, for intervention planning in urban environments.

Urban green space (UGS) availability is crucial for the health and well-being of urban residents. Studies show beneficial associations between green space exposure and reduced stress, improved mood, better mental health, and decreased psychological distress, particularly in adolescents [14]. However, significant disparities exist in UGS accessibility between Northern and Southern European cities, with the former enjoying above-average availability and the latter facing below-average access [7].  This underscores the need for innovative intervention planning strategies, which this paper aims to address through genAI.

Generative design, employing advanced algorithms and computational techniques, offers a systematic approach to automating the design process.  By defining parameters and constraints, generative design can produce numerous design scenarios.  This research extends its application to multi-scale intervention planning, encompassing architectural design and urban revitalization, to harness genAI's potential for transforming urban landscapes.

The primary objective is to showcase the potential of generative AI models in these applications.  We introduce a simple Graphical User Interface (GUI) Desktop application developed for generating images and implementing generative design in real-world scenarios.  Through experimentation and case studies, we demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of this technology for intervention planning, offering insights into its practical implications for shaping future urban environments.

The remainder of this paper is structured as follows: Section 2 provides a literature review; Section 3 describes the experimental setup; Section 4 presents the results; and Section 5 concludes the work.

No one can quite remember when the Last War started. Our best guess is a few years after the Great Doom, when the outside world was destroyed and our store became the only remaining sanctuary.  So much time has passed that few can even remember what the Outside is like, or even why we fight. Division and mistrust are so embedded here, there is great doubt if the store could ever run again, all the sections in harmony, operating the massive commercial outpost it was before.

In response to a milk shortage after the Doom, Dairy raised their prices astronomically, prompting Pharmacy to do the same. That was the final straw. Butter and milk are one thing, but when no one can afford antibiotics, it's just a matter of time until everything exploded. Sporting Goods and Automotive, already militaristic due to their access to dangerous weapons and equipment, aligned and struck the first blow.  They invaded and annexed Pharmacy – a pill bottle is no match for Tire Knights armed with rifles and hunting knives.  A deal with Grocery – food for medicine – quickly established the three factions as the dominant alliance.

But it didn't last. It never does. Legend says black-hat operatives from Electronics staged a false flag operation, framing Automotive for stealing weapons and trading them to Fashion for clothing, which they then resold to Sporting Goods.  This ignited the bloodiest civil war in our history, even more violent than the Familial War, when Men's, Women's, and Kid's splintered.

All this was so many years ago.  But war has never bothered me, or my fathers, or their fathers before them. For a hundred generations, we have existed alongside war, yet remained unaffected.  Our section is the lone island in this turbulent sea of conflict.

Why is that, you ask? It's simple. Our tribe is the Keeper of the Gardening section, the Watcher of the Harvest. And even the most bloodthirsty of our fellow sections know they cannot, and should not, threaten us or disrupt us. After all, no matter what else happens in the Store, the spices must flow.

The odd thing about teleporting is that it’s not instantaneous. Depending on the distance, materializing on the other side takes anywhere from 10 to 1,000 seconds. This usually leaves plenty of time to contemplate your purpose – or to simply zone out, as I tended to do.  The process involves a gradual coalescence, a slow return to wholeness, culminating in the world snapping into focus just as the attendant frantically waves you off the pad. This, much to my embarrassment, was precisely my experience upon arriving at New Hope Medical Clinic in Pennsylvania.

After my clumsy dismount, I exchanged greetings with the attendant, confirmed my appointment with the pretty, blonde receptionist, and then followed an orderly to Professor Alan Templeton's room.  Templeton, the brilliant mind behind the teleportation device I’d just used, had tragically succumbed to madness shortly after its creation. His psychosis, fixated on straight lines and sharp angles, remained a baffling enigma.

Over the years, others had developed similar symptoms, leading to the official designation of "Transporter Psychosis."  Affecting roughly one in a billion people, it was statistically safer than air travel, with only twenty-six cases recorded across Earth and the Colonies.

As we neared Templeton's room, the orderly diverted me into a smaller antechamber. “Put these on, please,” he instructed, proffering a set of oddly-shaped clothes.

“Excuse me?” I questioned, slightly offended.  My tweed jacket and slacks might be a bit dated, but surely not grounds for a forced wardrobe change.

“It’s the lines, sir,” the orderly explained with a weary sigh. “Your clothes have straight lines.”

I glanced down at my attire, then at the garments he held.  Even the stitching flowed in curves, eschewing any hint of linearity.  With a nod of understanding, I changed. The orderly, satisfied, then guided me to a rounded door at the hallway's end. “Fifteen minutes, sir.”

The room itself was a dome, every corner smoothed and rounded.  Professor Templeton, his white hair carefully combed back, sat perched on a beanbag chair, scribbling on circular paper.  His aversion to straight lines was clearly no exaggeration.

“Come in, come in,” he beckoned, gesturing towards another beanbag. “Another vulture to inquire about Transporter Psychosis, I presume?”

“Uh, yes?” I stammered, surprised by his seemingly lucid demeanor.

He fixed me with a steady gaze. “Of course I seem sane. Now sit and ask your questions.” He returned to his scribbling.

As I settled onto the beanbag, attempting to formulate my questions, Templeton abruptly thrust his hand in front of my face, holding up four fingers. “How many fingers do you see?”

“Uh, four?”

He huffed. “Bah, four. Just like the rest of them.”

“Wrong answer?” I inquired, bewildered.

He waved his hand dismissively. “You see, but you don’t *really* see. Now ask your questions.”

I discreetly activated my hidden recorder. “Professor, for the record, could you please verify your identity?”

A frown deepened on his face.  “Professor Alan Templeton, professor of Theoretical Physics, inventor of the Teleporter. Born August 31st, 2025. I have a mole on my left ass cheek known only to my mother, my wife, and four women in Barcelona.”  His unexpected candor startled me into an awkward laugh, which I quickly stifled, realizing he was entirely serious.

“Professor, your psychosis—”

“It’s not a psychosis!” he roared, leaping to his feet and pacing. “You reporters are vultures, feasting on my words, but none of you truly listen! The lines!” he shouted, pointing beyond the door. “The lines are the problem, not me!”

Emboldened, I ventured, “But what about sharp angles?

In "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," the author argues compellingly for further study of our neighboring planet despite the acknowledged difficulties presented by its hostile environment.  The author builds this argument by highlighting several key benefits of Venusian exploration.

The author begins by establishing the close relationship between Earth and Venus.  "Often referred to as Earth's 'twin,' Venus is the closest planet to Earth in terms of density and size, and occasionally the closest in distance too." This similarity, the author suggests, makes Venus an invaluable subject for comparative planetology. Understanding Venus, particularly its dramatic shift from a potentially habitable world – "Long ago, Venus was probably covered largely with oceans and could have supported various forms of life, just like Earth" –  to its current state, can offer crucial insights into Earth's own evolution and future.

Beyond scientific understanding, the author frames Venusian exploration as a necessary step in human progress.  "Our travels on Earth and beyond should not be limited by dangers and doubts but should be expanded to meet the very edges of imagination and innovation.”  The inherent challenges of studying Venus, rather than being deterrents, are presented as opportunities to push the boundaries of human ingenuity.  This pursuit of knowledge in the face of adversity is portrayed as essential for growth and advancement.

Finally, the author contends that overcoming the obstacles of Venus exploration has broader implications for space travel.

Discourse parsing aims to unveil the logical structure of a text by identifying and labeling relations between discourse units (See Fig. 1 and Fig. 2).  Several discourse schemes, such as Rhetorical Structure Theory (RST) (Carlson et al., 2001) and PDTB (Prasad et al., 2008), guide the development of various discourse corpora. However, the complex and labor-intensive nature of text-level discourse annotation results in relatively small corpora compared to other NLP tasks.  This data sparsity poses a significant challenge.

One approach to address this sparsity is multi-task learning, training on multiple corpora simultaneously.  Previous multi-task learning efforts primarily focused on classifying discourse relations between two text spans (Liu et al., 2016; Li et al., 2017) rather than considering the entire discourse structure. This limited scope stems from the principle that multi-task learning requires closely related tasks.  However, discourse structures vary significantly across corpora, ranging from shallow predicate-argument structures (e.g., Fig. 1) to deep tree structures (e.g., the CDTB tree in Fig. 2).

This work explores an alternative approach: unifying existing discourse corpora under a single framework to create a larger, more comprehensive dataset. We chose the dependency discourse structure (DDS) as our unifying framework. In DDS, elementary discourse units (EDUs) are directly linked without considering intermediate spans.  Morey et al. (2018) argue that DDS offers a general discourse representation, demonstrating its utility by evaluating the English discourse corpus RST-DT (Carlson et al., 2001) and related parsing techniques from a dependency perspective.

Our research investigates the feasibility of this unification, focusing on two key questions: (i) How can diverse discourse structures be converted into DDS? (ii) How can this unified data best improve discourse parsing techniques?

Guided by these questions, we unified three Chinese discourse corpora: HIT-CDTB (Zhang et al., 2014), SU-CDTB (Li et al., 2014b), and Sci-CDTB (Cheng and Li, 2019). HIT-CDTB employs a predicate-argument structure similar to PDTB, with connectives as predicates and text spans as arguments.  SU-CDTB, following RST, uses a hierarchical tree structure, with EDUs as leaves and connectives as intermediate nodes. Sci-CDTB, a small-scale corpus of 108 scientific abstracts, is, to our knowledge, the only existing Chinese DDS corpus.

Unifying these corpora presented several challenges, including inconsistencies in EDU granularity and relation type definitions.  Furthermore, HIT-CDTB's predicate-argument structure sometimes omits relations between adjacent spans, potentially resulting in incomplete dependency structures.  To address these issues, we redefined EDU granularity, mapped different relation sets, and developed semi-automatic conversion methods.  These methods involved automatic dependency tree transformation for each corpus followed by manual proofreading to ensure consistent EDU segmentation, supplement missing information, and correct transformed dependency trees.

Unlike Morey et al. (2018), who focused solely on RST-to-DDS conversion, we unified multiple discourse schemes into the dependency framework and explored how this unified data could improve discourse parsing.  We implemented several discourse dependency parsers and conducted experiments to assess their performance with the unified data, leading to insights on how to best leverage this resource.

Kelly turned.  The man sat across from her, legs stretched across the aisle. "Were you talking to me?" she asked, knowing it had to be her or he was talking to himself. He smiled.

"Yeah. You looked like you were dreaming of fireflies."

"How can you tell that, just by looking at me?" Kelly leaned forward, catching a scent of leather and pine from his cologne—a welcome mask against the subway's unmentionable odors.

"Can't imagine a girl like you dreaming of anything less than pure magic," he said with a lopsided grin.

"That's quite the line," Kelly said. "How often does it work?"

"I don't know. Never seen a girl worth trying it on before."

Kelly smiled. "It wasn't fireflies," she admitted. "But I *was* dreaming. I do that a lot these days."

"The kind of dream you'd share with a stranger?"

Kelly paused, considering. "Yeah, I think so.  In fact, I think it's the kind of dream I'd *only* share with a stranger."

"Dangerous, huh?"

"Maybe." Kelly turned to face him fully. Her ankle brushed against his calf, still stretched across the aisle. After an instinctual recoil, she let it rest there, amused by the brief, impersonal—yet somehow intimate—touch. "I was dreaming about leaving the city behind. Everything.  The ex-boyfriends, the crappy job, the roommate, the friends…just letting them go. Taking off and finding someplace quiet where nobody knows my name."

"Sounds lonely," he said.

"That's the point," Kelly replied. "I don't think I've ever *been* truly lonely. And somehow, that's the loneliest feeling of all. I don't even know what the voice inside my head sounds like. I hardly ever have the chance to think."

"So where would you go, if you could go anywhere?"

Kelly tilted her head back, looking at him through her lashes. "There's this little town I visited once as a kid. My parents took my brother and me on a road trip to Florida, and we stopped overnight in Georgia.  Little gingerbread farmhouses."

"And it was summertime?" he asked.

"Yeah. Sweltering."

"So I *was* right. You were dreaming of fireflies," he said.

Kelly frowned, trying to recall that hot summer night from years ago.

Smart, or driverless, cars are often touted as the future of transportation.  However, I believe they belong only in the future, and not on our current roads. While seemingly appealing to some, particularly those unable to drive due to disabilities, the current reality of these vehicles presents significant concerns.

The core functions of these "smart cars" involve steering, accelerating, and braking – tasks any competent human driver can already perform.  While features like heads-up displays offer potential benefits, their effectiveness relies entirely on driver attentiveness.  If the driver isn't engaged, these features become irrelevant, negating any perceived advantage.

The question of liability in accidents involving autonomous vehicles is complex. If a smart car is involved in a collision due to a faulty system, the responsibility should fall squarely on the manufacturer.  This raises a crucial point: if system failures can lead to accidents, these cars may introduce more danger than benefit.  Google's announcement of its first smart car accident on March 1, 2016, underscores this concern.

The intersection of neuroscience and game research has emerged as a fertile ground for innovation in the past decade, mirroring the historically fruitful relationship between artificial intelligence (AI) and games.  Just as games have served as testing grounds for AI, pushing the boundaries of algorithms while AI enhances game design and player experience, neuroscience and games are now engaged in a similar synergistic dance.  Figure 1 illustrates this burgeoning field, showing a significant increase in publications on Scopus since 2010, with 1245 articles identified using relevant keywords, indicating a rapidly growing body of research.

This synergy manifests in several key areas.  First, similar to how AI draws inspiration from the brain, game research, particularly player experience research, benefits from neuroscience tools like EEG and fMRI. These tools offer objective measurements of cognitive activity, providing insights into player engagement, challenge, and stress [3, 4, 5].  Conversely, games offer neuroscience valuable platforms for studying cognitive processes in engaging, controlled environments.  Researchers use games as simulations to explore attention, memory, and decision-making [6, 7], collecting real-time data on player actions and neural responses. Games also hold potential for neurofeedback training, allowing players to regulate their brain activity [8].

Second, as gaming's cultural impact grows, understanding its effects on the brain becomes crucial.  Research investigates the potential of games to enhance cognitive abilities like decision-making [9] and visual attention [10], while also examining potential negative consequences [11].

Finally, brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) represent a third exciting area of convergence.  Initially focused on medical applications, BCIs are now expanding into games and entertainment, promising increased accessibility and novel interaction paradigms [12, 13, 14]. BCIs allow players to control games using brain signals, offering new possibilities for both "abled" and disabled gamers [15, 16]. This technology enables non-intrusive interaction and even real-time game adaptation based on the player's cognitive state [17].  Games, in turn, provide engaging environments for BCI development and training, offering diverse scenarios and motivating user participation [18].

While challenges remain, including ethical considerations, data privacy, and robust calibration, the potential of this interdisciplinary field is vast. Personalized gaming experiences, therapeutic interventions, and inclusive design are just a few of the possibilities.  The following sections will delve deeper into these areas, exploring the state-of-the-art, addressing open challenges, and identifying future opportunities.

Il y a des moments où le temps se fige, concentrant toute une existence en une fulgurance douloureuse. Je me tiens là, droite et rigide, à l’autre bout de la France que je viens de traverser comme un automate.  Devant moi, des amis sanglotent, épaules contre épaules. J’ai la sensation d’être projetée dans une autre dimension. Pourtant, chaque détail de la scène est gravé en moi avec une acuité terrible. Je sais que ce moment s’inscrit profondément, me transformant, nourrissant – une fois encore – l’insondable gouffre de ma colère contre le monde.

Par-delà la foule aux visages sombres, je découvre le visage, la vie, de celui que je connaissais pourtant depuis plus de dix ans sans jamais avoir entendu le timbre de sa voix. Ironique, ces adieux en PowerPoint pour quelqu’un qui abhorrait ce genre d’artifice. Je sais que notre ami commun, juste à côté de ces sanglots déchirants, pense lui aussi qu’il vaut mieux préparer notre propre clé USB de notre vivant, avant que nos familles endeuillées ne compilent nos pires photos et nos moments les plus honteux.  Il faudrait penser à enregistrer nos voix, pour quand il ne restera plus que le silence.

J’ai du mal à entendre qu’il s’est *donné* la mort, comme s’il s’était offert un cadeau, alors qu’en réalité, il s’est *ôté* la vie. La colère monte en moi en apprenant qu’il travaillait dans cette entreprise où l'on encourageait cyniquement les départs « par la fenêtre ». S’il a bien été le bourreau de sa propre existence, le commanditaire, lui, est ailleurs, bien à l’abri, prospérant sur le sang et les os de milliers d’autres comme lui.

The blinding headlights cut through the dark, stormy atmosphere.  A deafening crash, the crunch of metal against bone—I felt the impact against my small body, yet pain was absent. Numbness, a perverse benefit of this afflicted state. Lying on the cold, hard, wet road, life ebbed away, breath shallowing as the distant wail of a siren faded into the encroaching darkness.

Then, abruptly, my eyes fluttered open. I could breathe again. I was sitting on something soft, comfortable, white.  Gone were my torn, dirty clothes, replaced by skinny jeans and black Converse, the uniform of my high school days.  As my vision cleared, I saw a small bed in a blue bedroom, adorned with trophies and awards. Muffled music and voices drifted from somewhere beyond.  A wave of déjà vu washed over me, unsettlingly familiar.

Across the room, in a similar bed, lay my ex-husband, looking a decade younger.  The dark circles, the scabs on his face and arms—all gone. He looked sober, healthy, a sight unseen for twelve long years.  He opened his eyes, caught my gaze, and a mischievous grin spread across his face. He rose, walked over, and stood at the edge of my bed, leaning in.  With a chuckle, he reached into his jeans pocket, pulling out a pipe and a small baggie filled with what I instantly recognized as meth.

"Try some," he said. "It won't hurt."

Mobile Ad Hoc Networks (MANETs) have been proposed in the literature (Kiess and Mauve 2007, Reina et al. 2015, Mohammed and Al-Ghrairi 2019) as a communication technology for emergencies and disasters.  Cellular-based infrastructures may become unavailable due to significant damage in such situations.  MANETs, however, can be rapidly deployed without fixed infrastructure, setup, or prior requirements. This flexibility is particularly attractive when communication between victims and rescue teams is crucial.  A key challenge in MANET implementation is demonstrating sufficient reliability compared to other approaches (Kiess and Mauve 2007).  Real-world verification and validation (V&V) under emergency conditions is virtually impossible, making simulation a vital tool in MANET research.

Simulators offer a cost-effective way to evaluate the performance and accuracy of algorithms and systems without requiring actual hardware. They also enable the assessment of network capacity under extreme conditions by virtually varying parameters and exploring different scenarios (Manpreet and Malhotra 2014).  However, despite increased development and usage, the credibility of simulator results has declined over time (Kurkowski et al. 2005, Hogie et al. 2006).  Some of the challenges encountered in MANET development (arXiv:2004.14093v1 [cs.DC] 29 Apr 2020) are inherent to simulation in general: repeatability, consistency, and model accuracy (Sargent 2001).  Simulators often focus on specific aspects of the network structure itself, neglecting the complexity and heterogeneity of the systems that rely on it, such as autonomous vehicles, unmanned aircraft systems, and communication software.

Figure 1 illustrates a real-world example of a MANET-based ecosystem in an emergency. Collaborative drones operating in a complex environment must communicate without fixed infrastructure, transmitting data to rescue teams equipped with mobile devices running real-time 3D processing software. This allows professionals to assess the situation.  The data should also be stored in an internet-connected database to enable informed decision-making by management teams.  Decision support can be further enhanced through AI-driven decision-making processes (Phillips-Wren and Jain 2006).  Ideally, verification and simulation of the entire ecosystem should consider all aspects and characteristics of the various devices and disaster scenarios. Âgé de sept mois, c'est un bébé tranquille qui fait d'elle une maman vraiment attentive et très sereine. Elle recommence tout juste à avoir envie de retourner sur les plateaux de tournage », confie-t-elle. Après de précieux mois passés à pouponner loin du tumulte de la pandémie, Laura Smet semble impatiente de retrouver son clap de réalisatrice.

De son côté, Nathalie Baye savoure pleinement son rôle de grand-mère, contrairement à Johnny Hallyday qui avait déclaré : « Déjà que j'ai eu du mal parfois à être père, alors grand-père, n'en parlons pas. » « Johnny était attaché à l'idée d'incarner une éternelle jeunesse. Moi, je suis très heureuse d'être grand-mère. Et Laura sait qu'elle peut compter sur moi », souligne Nathalie Baye.

L'actrice de *Juste la fin du monde* n'aspire désormais qu'à une chose : « Être une bonne grand-mère. »  « Les miennes étaient particulièrement merveilleuses, joyeuses, et me faisaient faire des tas de choses. J'espère surtout rassurer ma fille lorsqu'elle devra se séparer de son enfant », avait-elle confié à *Madame Figaro* en octobre 2020.  Le petit Léo, qui a forcément hérité d'un ADN artistique, pourra peut-être en témoigner d'ici quelques années…

Retrouvez l'intégralité de l'interview de Nathalie Baye dans le dernier numéro de *Gala*.
